The reference here to the subject of the poet's *teu=kros is like that in the Oedipus Coloneus (1410 n.) to his Antigone, and that in the Philoctetes (1437 ff.) to his *filokth/ths e)n *troi/a|..

The intervention of the Atreidae His scenes with the Atreidae. has already been considered in its general relation to the dominant idea of the play. Their scenes with Teucer now require consideration from a different point of view, viz., with regard to the poetical workmanship. One aim of the poet has evidently been to prolong the controversy sufficiently for a gradual tension of interest. This is especially manifest in the words of the Chorus after the exit of Menelaüs,—‘A dread strife will be brought to the trialV. 1163.’; words which mark the crescendo, and prepare the way for Agamemnon. The whole process which leads up to the climax is skilfully managed. First, there is the scene between Teucer and Menelaüs. The king of Sparta has those traits of harshness and arrogance which Athenian audiences would expect in the partIt is to Menelaüs that the Andromachè of Euripides addresses her invective against Sparta ( Andr. 445 ff.).—Welcker (Rhein. Mus. for 1829, pt. iii. pp. 258 ff.) finds allusions in this part of the play to contemporary relations between Athens and Sparta (Menelaüs), and between Athens and Argos (Agamemnon): but I cannot think that the poet intended this., and is clearly intended to be more odious than his brother. Though he is not the Captain General,—as Teucer reminds him, —yet the insubordination of Ajax is the topic on which he chooses to dwell. Ajax, he complains, would never obey him; and then he enlarges (like Creon in the Antigone) on the public danger of unruliness. After his angry dialogue with Teucer, he departs, with a hint of appeal to force. Then comes that beautiful scene which affords a pause between the two parts of the controversy; the child Eurysaces is brought in by Tecmessa, and placed as a suppliant by the corpse of Ajax. In the choral ode which follows, it may be noticed that the closing prayer—to pass beneath Sunium, and ‘greet sacred Athens’—is peculiarly suggestive at this point, when Teucer has just encountered the Spartan, and is about to withstand the Argive. The second chapter of the contest then begins with the entrance of Agamemnon. He alone can finally decide whether burial shall or shall not be granted. Whereas Menelaüs had resented the want of deference in Ajax, Agamemnon takes a more vital point, and depreciates his services. This calls forth the fine vindication of Ajax by Teucer, in which the debate culminates. The short dialogue which ensues between Agamemnon and Odysseus shows the former in a comparatively favourable light, and illustrates his superiority to Menelaüs. If he is not gracious or generous, he at least indicates a wish to see his dutySee on v. 1350, to/n toi tu/rannon eu)sebei=n ou) r(a/|dion. There is a somewhat similar utterance of Agamemnon in a fragment of the Polyxena (fr. 481 Nauck), where he is perplexed by conflicting demands upon him., and is capable of yielding to wise counsel. Thus the whole controversy concerning the burial of Ajax has variety, dramatic life, and a gradually rising interest.

To those who further realise Modern criticism on this part of the play. that the decision concerning the burial is the true climax of the drama, this part of the play will certainly not appear unworthy of its author. The disfavour which it has sometimes found with modern criticism may be ascribed partly to inadequate appreciation of its poetical art and dramatic significance, but more, perhaps, to the fact that a prolonged rhetorical debate has not the same attraction for modern readers which an ancient Athenian audience found in it. The example of Aeschylus in his Award of the Arms, where Ajax and Odysseus spoke in support of their respective claims, may have had some influence in leading Sophocles to compensate for the more restricted scope of his subject by providing a rhetorical interest of a similar kind. A fragment of AeschylusSee above, p. xx, n. 5. indicates that his heroes exchanged taunts of the same nature as those which pass between Teucer and the Atreidae. It may be granted that some parts of the scene between Teucer and Menelaüs are wholly repugnant to a modern tasteEspecially vv. 1142—1158.. The best apology for them is that Attic Tragedy was a popular entertainment, and that Athenian hearers not only tolerated but expected sharp personalities in a strenuous debate, however dignified the disputants or the occasion,—as Demosthenes is a witness. But there is no ground for any such suspicion as that of BergkGr. Lit. vol. III. p. 381. Cp. Bernhardy, Gr. Lit. pt. II. sect. ii. p. 366., that the latter part of the play is by an inferior poet (such as Iophon , the usual scape-goat),—and has been tacked on to an early play of Sophocles, which stopped, or was left unfinished, at the death of Ajax. A careful and sympathetic study will rather leave a conviction on the mind that both the dramatic treatment and the diction bear the stamp of Sophocles, though some of the details are not in his happiest vein, and though the form of the whole—a prolonged controversy—makes a somewhat exacting demand on the modern The test of performance.reader. When the Ajax is seen on the stage,—and this is the proper test,—a modern spectator finds that in the latter part of it the interest is thoroughly sustainedThe Ajax was performed at Cambridge, by members of the University, in 1882. No result of that experiment was more striking than the decisive proof which it afforded that the Ajax, as a whole, is a thoroughly effective play for the stage, and that its power of holding an audience is not diminished by the death of the hero at a comparatively early moment in the action.. The foreground is full of movement and animation, as Menelaüs, Agamemnon and Odysseus successively appear; while the pathetic group in the background—the child kneeling in supplication by his father's body, with Tecmessa near him—keeps before the mind the significance of the issue which is in suspense. It is then, far more easily than in a mere perusal of the text, that one can view the whole action of the play in a right perspective; and justice is instinctively rendered to the degree in which, here as elsewhere, Sophocles evinces his command over the highest art of the theatre.

A few words may suffice to characterise those minor Tecmessa. persons of the drama whose principal function is to bring the central figure into relief. Tecmessa, the daughter of a Phrygian prince, whom the fate of war has given to Ajax, loves him with a submissive devotion, and has won from him a constant affection. He is ‘her dread lord, of rugged might’; standing to her in the place of country, parents, everything; her only stay and hope on earth. She appreciates his great qualities in their obvious aspects. His laments, in his first despair, affright her, because they seem alien from his nature; but she has no insight into the workings of his mind. She is easily lulled into the belief that he has abandoned the purpose of self-destruction, since the only distinct idea which she had connected with it was that of the misery which it would bring upon her. When her fears are suddenly re-awakened, she bitterly cries that she has been ‘deceived.’ To her, the one question had been whether the love that he owed her would prevail on him to live; she had no clear perception of any other motives, that might urge him to die; still less could she measure their force. After his death, her simple loyalty refuses to think of him as crushed by his foes. It is no triumph for them, but a blank loss: the victory is rather his: ‘All that he yearned to win hath he made his own,—the death for which he longed.’ Death was what he desired, and the gods consented; that is all that she understands, beyond the import for herselfSee vv. 961—973..

The Salaminians The Chorus. are the staunch followers of Ajax, true to him in weal or woe, and jealous of his good name, which is their own. He turns to them in his misery, as to tried friends, charging them with his last wishes, and with his message to Teucer. But their leading characteristic is their complete dependence on Ajax, and their utter helplessness when his protection is withdrawn. They are dismayed by the anger of the Greeks, and at one moment even think of seeking safety in flight; they bewail the hardships of the camp, and pine for the delights of home. In thus portraying them, the poet probably intended to suggest the Homeric contrast between the passive common folk (laoi/) and the ‘Zeus-nurtured’ chiefs. The Salaminians contribute to illustrate the greatness of the hero who had been their ‘defence against nightly terror and the darts of the foe’; even their complainings, however unmeet for warriors, serve to recall the weary stress of those ten years at Troy during which Ajax had been the bulwark of the ungrateful Achaeans.

The sequel to the story The Teucer of Sophocles. of Ajax was treated by Sophocles in two of his lost plays, the Teucer and the Eurysaces. The subject of the former is already adumbrated in the Ajax (1008—1020): Teucer, on his return to Salamis, is upbraided and expelled by Telamon. A few verses remain from a speech in which the aged king lamented the death of his son, —verses of much beauty and pathos, which reveal some gentler traits in the gloomy and choleric Telamon:—

w(s a)/r), w)= te/knon, kenh\n e)terpo/mhn sou te/ryin eu)logoume/nou w(s zw=ntos: h( d' a)/r' e)n sko/tw| lh/qousa/ me e)/sain' *)erinu\s h(donai=s e)yeusme/non Soph. fr. 519 (Nauck), from Stobaeus Flor. 122. 10..

This work is supposed to have been the model of Pacuvius in his tragedy of the same name, from which Cicero quotes part of the passionate reproaches addressed by Telamon to Teucer Cic. De Orat. 2. 46. 193.Ribbeck, Trag. Rom. Fragmenta, pp. 116 ff. A fragment of the Teucer of Sophocles (no. 520 Nauck), belonging to the description of a storm, may be compared with a similar fragment (no. XV. Ribbeck) from the Teucer of Pacuvius..

The Eurysaces of Sophocles is known only by the citation His Eur saces. of a single word from itHesych. s. v. a)do/caston. Soph. fr. 204 (Nauck).; but a probable conjecture as to its argument has been based on fragments from the Eurysaces of Attius, taken in connection with a passage of JustinFor the fragments of the Eurysaces of Attius, see Ribbeck, pp. 179 ff. They contain the complaints of some one who is being driven forth into exile, and who upbraids the Greeks with their ingratitude. That this person was Teucer, is inferred by Welcker (Gr. Trag. p. 198) from Justin XLIV. 3, in which, with great probability, he finds an outline of the plot: Gallaeci Graecam sibi originem asserunt: siquidem post finem Troiani belli Teucrum morte Aiacis fratris invisum patri Telamoni, cum non reciperetur in regnum, Cyprum concessisse, atque ibi urbem nomine antiquae patriae Salaminam condidisse. Inde accepta opinione paternae mortis patriam repetisse. Sed cum ab Eurysace, Aiacis filio, accessu prohiberetur, Hispaniae litoribus appulsum loca, ubi nunc est Carthago nova, occupasse; inde Gallaeciam transisse, et positis sedibus genti nomen dedisse.. After his repulse by Telamon, Teucer had founded the new Salamis in Cyprus. On a report of Telamon's death reaching him there, he returned to the old Salamis; but was repelled by Eurysaces, and finally settled among the Gallaeci in the north-west of Spain.

An *ai)/as maino/menos is ascribed to Astydamas (c. 360 B.C.), The story of Ajax in later literature. the younger of two tragic poets who bore that nameNauck, Trag. Gr. Frag. p. 777.. The title suggests a play similar in general scope to that of Sophocles; but nothing is known of it. The *ai)/as of Carcinus (c. 375 B.C.?) is equally unknown Ib.p. 797.. The *ai)/as of Theodectes (c. 330 B.C.) appears to have been more on the lines of Aeschylus; i.e., it contained the *(/oplwn kri/sis, with speeches by Ajax and Odysseus Ib.p. 801. One of the points for which Aristotle refers to the *ai)/as of Theodectes taken from a speech of Odysseus ( II. Rhet. 23§ 24).. That contest appears as a theme for rhetorical prose in the harangues for the two heroes which are ascribed to Antisthenes (c. 380 B.C.), and which in any case date probably from the fourth century B.C.These pieces, entitled *ai)/as and *)odusseu/s, are printed in the Fragm. Oratorum (p. 167) edited by H. Sauppe, who, with H. FossE. , questions the ascription to Antisthenes. They are e)pidei/ceis of the same class as the speeches for and against Palamedes ascribed respectively to Gorgias and Alcidamas, and the Busiris of Isocrates. (Cp. Attic Orators, vol. II. p. 89, new ed.)
The earliest author of Latin tragedy, the Greek freedman Livius Andronicus, wrote an Aiax Mastigophorus, doubtless founded, as the title indicates, on Sophocles. These words occurred in it:—
Praestatur laus virtuti, sed multo ocius Verno gelu tabescitFrag. II. (Ribbeck, p. 2).:
an echo, probably, of the words in the Ajax (vv. 1266 f.),
feu=: tou= qano/ntos w(s taxei=a/ tis brotoi=s xa/ris diarrei=.

The metaphor of the melting frost (scarcely a happy image for evanescent praise) may have been suggested by diarrei=. Nothing is known as to the Aiax of Ennius, but one of the two verses which remain from it recalls a passage in the Ajax of SophoclesFrag. II. (Ribbeck, p. 17): Animam misso sangui tepido tullii efflantes volant. The word tullii is explained by Festus as=silani (springs), or rivi. The sense is then, ‘The warm blood flows,—the streams fly forth, spirting out the life.’ There is a marked resemblance, as Scaliger noted, to Soph. Ai. 1411 ff., e)/ti ga\r qermai\ | su/rigges a)/nw fusw=si me/lan | me/nos. The verbal parallelism of efflantes with fusw=si, and tepido with qermai/, strongly suggests imitation.. If we may suppose that Ennius, like Livius Andronicus, based his treatment of the subject wholly or mainly on Sophocles, then there is significance in the fact that the later dramatists, Pacuvius and Attius, each wrote an Armorum IudiciumRibbeck, p. 80 (Pacuvius): p. 154 (Attius).; a title which suggests that the desire to vary from their Latin predecessors sent them back to the *(/oplwn kri/sis of Aeschylus, and possibly to the play of Theodectes. A fragment from the Armorum Iudicium of Attius belongs to the speech in which Odysseus urged his claim to the arms. The verse which Attius has paraphrased from the Ajax (vv. 550 f.),

Virtuti sis par, dispar fortunis patris, suggests, however, that he may have imitated Sophocles in other details also; perhaps seeking, by such eclecticism of treatment, to distinguish his work from the earlier Armorum Iudicium of Pacuvius. The rhetorical capabilities of the subject are illustrated by Ovid, whose powers of brilliant and ingenious declamation are seen to considerable advantage in the speeches of Ajax and OdysseusMetamorph. XIII. 1—398.. His spirited and pointed verse presents a striking contrast to the tame and mechanical treatment of the same episode in the Greek epic of Quintus SmyrnaeusPosthomerica v. 181—316..
The earliest reference in modern literature to the Ajax of Sophocles is of sufficient interest to deserve a passing mention here; it occurs in the first scene of Titus Andronicus, v. 379:—
The Greeks upon advice did bury Ajax That slew himself; and wise Laertes' son Did graciously plead for his funerals.

As Steevens saw, these lines must have been written (or prompted) by some one who knew the Ajax itself; for no translation of Sophocles existed in the sixteenth century, and the mediation of Odysseus is not mentioned elsewhere. Modern criticism doubts, and with good reason, whether Shakespeare had any part in the Titus AndronicusSee Dowden, Shakspere, p. 54., though Meres, in 1598, included it among his plays: and in this passage, at all events, we seem to see the work of a playwright who had been at one of the Universities.

It is interesting to inquire how far the influence of the Illustrations from ancient Art.poets can be traced in such works of Greek art as are concerned with the tragic end of Ajax. A favourite subject was the actual contest for the arms. Some red-figured vases, of the fifth century B.C., show Ajax and Odysseus vehemently disputing the possession of the prize,—ready, indeed, to rush at each other, while their friends on either side hold them back: Agamemnon, as judge, stands between them. This type seems to have been created, or at least developed, by the vase-painter A Duris vase-painting on this subject by Duris may be seen in Baumeister, Denkmäler, p. 29, plate 30.. But an earlier form of the same subject occurs on black-figured vases of the sixth century B.C. Here there are only the three principal figures,—Ajax, Odysseus, and Agamemnon,—and the a)gw\n for the arms approaches still more nearly to the character of a fight. The competitors are advancing against each other with drawn swords, while Agamemnon tries to keep them apartC. Robert, Bild und Lied, p. 217, gives a copy of this scene from a black-figured lekythos in the Berlin Museum.. The black-figured vases prove that the original literary source was not the *(/oplwn kri/sis of Aeschylus, —as the red-figured vases would have allowed us to suppose,— but some older poem. Other works of art represent the close of the contest. A relief on a sarcophagus found at OstiaFigured in Baumeister, p. 29, pl. 31. shows Odysseus seizing the arms which have just been awarded to him, while Ajax, escorted by indignant friends, is retiring, with visible fury in his eyes,—the o)/mmata a)stra/ptonta of the IliupersisSee above, § 2.. The same moment is depicted on a vase in the British MuseumNo. 829: discussed by Robert in Bild und Lied, pp. 218 ff.: Athena herself presides over the court, indicating the artist's literal interpretation of the verse in the Odyssey (11. 547 pai=des de\ *trw/wn di/kasan kai\ *palla\s *)aqh/nh). On a stone in front of the goddess are seen the yh=foi by which the arms have just been adjudged to Odysseus,—a detail which recalls the language of Pindar and Sophocles, who both speak of the award as decided by ballot Pind. Nem. 8. 26: Soph. Ai. 449, Soph. Ai. 1135..

The painters Parrhasius and Timanthes (c. 400 B.C.) are said to have competed at Samos in an a)gw\n grafiko/s, the subject of their pictures being Ajax and Odysseus contending for the armsPliny, N. H. 35. 36 § 72: Aelian, V. H. 9. 11. Timanthes gained the prize; when Parrhasius said that he condoled with Ajax on having for a second time got the worst of it.. But the famous picture on this subject was by Timomachus of ByzantiumThe date of Timomachus is uncertain. Brunn (Gesch. d. gr. Künstler, vol. II. p. 282) would refer him to ‘the time of the Diadochi’ (i.e., circ. 320—270 B.C.), on account of the tendencies shown in his choice and treatment of subjects. At any rate Pliny is evidently wrong in saying that Timomachus painted in the time of Julius Caesar (N. H. 35. 40 § 30), as he already had the fame of an ‘old master’ in 70 B.C. ( Cic. In Verr. 2. 4. 60.), whose work was directly inspired by Sophocles. It represented Ajax, as the poet describes him, sitting among the slaughtered cattle, and brooding on selfdestruction, in that gloomy despair which followed his frenzyPhilostratus, Vit. Apoll. 2. 22 § 5: see n. below on verse 346.. An epigram in the Anthology attests the vivid impression which this picture made on the beholderJacobs, Anthol. vol. II. p. 648, no. 83: *ai)=an, *timoma/xou ple/on h)\ patro/s: h(/rpase te/xna th\n fu/sin. o( gra/yas ei)=de/ se maino/menon, kai\ sunelussh/qh xei\r a)ne/ri, kai\ ta\ kerasta\ da/krua tou\s lu/phs pa/ntas e)/mice po/nous. The style is somewhat affected and obscure. ‘Ajax, Timomachus, not Telamon, is thy sire: Art has made Nature's claim her own! The painter saw thee in thy frenzy,— his hand raged with the rage of his hero, and the mingled pigments from his brush have blended all the throes of pain.’ The last words have point; for it was in portraying a conflict of emotions that Timomachus peculiarly excelled.. It was kindred in conception to another celebrated work of the same painter, Medea meditating the murder of her children. Both pictures were at Cyzicus in the early part of the first century B.C.; they were purchased by Julius Caesar, and placed in the temple of Venus Genetrix at Rome. Ovid in exile remembered both:—
Utque sedet vultu fassus Telamonius iram,
Inque oculis facinus barbara mater habet Tristia 2. 525 f.

The Tabula Iliaca in the Capitoline Museum contains a small picture, inscribed *a*i*a*s *m*a*n*i*w*d*h*s, which probably shows the influence of Timomachus; Ajax is seated in an attitude of deep dejection, and near him lies the severed head of a ram,—a detail taken from the play of Sophocles (vv. 237 ff.)See the reproduction of the Tabula Iliaca in Baumeister's Denkmäler, p. 716, pl. 775: the small picture of Ajax is numbered 80 in the plate.. The hero's suicide is the subject of some Etruscan vase-paintings. One of these shows the sword planted in the ground, as Sophocles describes it (v. 815)Baumeister, p. 30 b..
The date of the Ajax is unknown; but internal Date of the play. evidence affords reasons for believing that, if not the earliest of the seven plays, it is the next oldest to the Antigone.

(1) The Parodos has the form of an anapaestic marching-song (vv. 134—171), followed by a lyric ode (vv. 172—200), as in the Persae, the Supplices, and the Agamemnon of Aeschylus. This simplest type of Parodos occurs in no other play of Sophocles, though that of the Antigone is akin to it.
(2) Anapaests for the Chorus are interposed in the iambic dialogue (vv. 1163—1167). The only other play of Sophocles in which this occurs is the Antigone (vv. 929—943).
These are (I think) the only clear indications of a relatively early date. Some other points, however, have been urged, and demand consideration here.

(3) It has been noted by G. WolffIn his edition of the play, p. 140 (4th ed. 1887). and others that several words and phrases in the Ajax are Aeschylean: e.g. v. 56 r(axi/zw ( Pers. 426 etc.): 412 po/roi a(li/rroqoi ( Pers. 367): 447 fre/nes dia/strofoi ( P. V. 673): 673 leuko/pwlos h(me/ra ( Pers. 386): 740 u(pespanisme/non ( Pers. 489 etc.). Again, the epic h)= r(a (172, Pers. 954) occurs also in Pers. 633, but not elsewhere in Tragedy; the Doric and epic plural toi/ (1404), used by Aeschylus ( Pers. 584 etc.), is not elsewhere used by Sophocles. The Persae, it will be seen, furnishes most of these parallelismsWe may also compare Ai. 789 f., fe/rwn...pra=cin (‘announcing his fortune’), with Pers. 248, fe/rei...pra=gos (in a like sense): and Ai. 769, e)pispa/sein kle/os, with a similar use of the active e)pe/spasen in Pers. 477.. But such coincidences merely show that the Ajax belongs to a period when Aeschylus had a strong influence on the younger poet's style; and we have no means of setting an inferior limit to that period. In so far, then, as the language of the play has an Aeschylean stamp, it seems more accurate to say that this characteristic is entirely consonant with the hypothesis of a relatively early date than to claim it as a separate indication of such a date. With regard to the epic h)= r(a and toi/, it should be remembered that the play contains several phrases which show a deliberate aim at epic colouring, such as klutw=n e)na/rwn (177), e(li/kessi bousi/, klutoi=s ai)poli/ois (374 f.), ou)li/w| (933), polu/tlas (954), koi/lhn ka/peton (1165), which the poet may have deemed appropriate to a subject taken from the Trojan cycle and concerned with a Homeric hero.

(4) Some critics have thought that only twelve choreutae were used in the Ajax, and infer that the play belonged to a time when Sophocles had not yet raised the number of the Chorus to fifteen Muff Chr., Chorische Technik d. Soph. pp. 52, 78 ff.; and O. Hense, Der Chor. des Soph. p. 5. Nauck adopts this view in the 8th ed. of Schneidewin's Ajax, p. 63, and n. on 892 ff.. The chief ground of this theory is the fact that verses 892—914 and 938—960 (taken together) contain twelve utterances of the Chorus. It is assumed that each utterance represents a single choreutes. But this is an assumption only; and it does not appear a probable one, when it is observed that verses 900—903, and 908—914, are passionate expressions of a feeling common to the whole Chorus, and would naturally, therefore, be given by the whole Chorus. In verses 866—878, again, the attempt to distinguish twelve parts, one for each of twelve choreutae, involves a highly arbitrary process. The mere fact of h(mixo/ria being there employed proves nothing; for the use of hemichoria occurs in plays written at a time when the number of the tragic chorus was certainly fifteen ( Eur. Or. 1258 ff., Eur. Alc. 93—111, Eur. Alc. 226—232).

(5) Lastly, it has been supposed that the play was written ‘not long after the introduction of a third actorIntrod. to Schneidewin's Ajax, p. 64.,’ because three actors are on the scene together only in the prologue (Athena, Odysseus, Ajax), and at the end (Agamemnon, Teucer, Odysseus); Odysseus being silent while Ajax is present (92—117), and Teucer while Agamemnon is present (1318—1373). But it appears very unsafe to assume that these facts indicate an early and tentative stage in the use of the third actor. They may be due simply to the construction of the play and to the requirements of each dramatic situation.

As between the Ajax and the Antigone, the claim to priority would rest with the Ajax, if the form of the Parodos were the test; though the Parodos of the Antigone is also of an early type (see n. on Ai. 134). But much more weight is due to the fact that the Antigone, alone of the seven plays, rigorously adheres to the practice of Aeschylus, in never admitting the division of an iambic trimeter between two or more speakers (a)ntilabh/). This was no trivial detail, but a general rule of composition which materially affected the character of dialogue. When Sophocles at last decided to relax that rule, the result was a marked gain in lightness and rapidity at moments when the dialogue became animated or excited. The fact that he had made this change before he wrote the Ajax seems clearly to indicate that the Ajax is later than the Antigone.

Aristotle's work Title. called *didaskali/ai was a chronological list of tragedies and comedies produced at Athens, the list being based on official records contemporary in each case with the production. Similar works were afterwards compiled by Callimachus (c. 260 B.C.) and others. The *didaskali/ai of Aristotle and of Callimachus are known to have been still extant in the second century A. NowD. , we learn from the Greek Argument to the Ajax that ‘in the Didascaliae’ the play was styled simply *a*i*a*sSee below, page 4, line 9: e)n de\ tai=s didaskali/ais yilw=s *a*i*a*s a)nage/graptai.. This is conclusive as to the original title; since, whether the Didascaliae meant, be Aristotle's, or one of the later works, in any case the ultimate authority for the statement dates from the time when the play was produced. In the extant manuscripts the title is *ai)/as *mastigofo/ros (alluding to the lash which Ajax carries in the first scene); as it is also in the citations by Zenobius (c. 130 A.D. ), Athenaeus, and Clement of Alexandria. On the other hand, the Greek Argument states that Dicaearchus (a pupil of Aristotle) called the play *ai)/antos *qa/natos, which he could scarcely have done if the title *ai)/as *mastigofo/ros had already obtained currency. We may infer from these facts that the epithet *mastigofo/ros was added by some Alexandrian scholar whose authority sufficed to establish it as a permanent part of the title. If the object had been merely, as the author of the Argument suggests, to distinguish the play from the *ai)/as *lokro/s of Sophocles, *telamw/nios might have seemed a fitter designation; but doubtless the intention was rather to distinguish it from later dramas on the same subject, such as those of Astydamas, Carcinus and Theodectes.

Scene:—Before the tent of Ajax, at the eastern end of the Greek camp, near Cape Rhoeteum on the northern coast of the Troad. ODYSSEUS is closely examining footprints on the sandy ground. ATHENA is seen in the air (on the qeologei=on).

According to the rule of the Greek theatre, the side of the scene on the spectator's right represents the home-region,— in this case, that of the Greek camp. To the spectator's left is the region of the open country, stretching east and south from the camp, over the plain of Troy, towards those ‘Mysian highlands’ from which Teucer returns (v. 720). Aristotle speaks of skhnografi/a as an invention distinctive of Sophocles ( Poet. 4: see Smith's Dict. of Ant., new ed., vol. II. p. 816). And the words in v. 4, e)/nqa ta/cin e)sxa/thn e)/xei, rather suggest that the Greek camp was somehow indicated here,—perhaps with a glimpse of the Hellespont, and of Cape Rhoeteum. It is not known whether the theatre of the fifth century B.C. had peri/aktoi,—those triangular prisms on pivots, with scenery painted on each of their three faces, which served as movable side-scenes. A periaktos on the spectator's right could have been used to show the camp. Or, if this resource was not then available, the purpose may have been effected by painted hangings on the back-wall, which, in the fifth century B.C., was probably a temporary structure of wood. With regard to the change of scene after v. 814, see note on 815.

div3.p: Prologue. Athena confirms the surmise of Odysseus as to the guilt of Ajax; shows her favourite his afflicted foe; and points the moral.

a)ei\ me/n, followed in 3 by kai\ nu=n: cp. Tr. 689-691 e)/xrisa me
...ka)/qhka (n.): Lucian Dialog. marin. 8 pa/lai me
 to\ th=s *)inou=s paidi/on e)pi\ to
 *)isqmo
 e)komi/sate..., kai\ nu=n su\ to
 kiqarw|do
...a)nalabw
 e)cenh/cw. The passage in Aesch. Ag. 587—598 (a)nwlo/luca me
 pa/lai...kai\ nu=n ta\ ma/ssw me
 ti/ dei= s' e)moi\ le/gein;) is scarcely a true parallel,—the interval being so long. Plato has a)ei\ me
 followed by a)ta kai\ nu=n (Prot. 335 D), a)ta ou)=n kai\ to/te (Rep. 367 E). Similarly I. Il. 107 ff. ai)ei\ toi...kai\ nu=n.

*larti/ou, as in 380: but *laerti/ou in 101, and *lae/rtou in 1393. *lae/rths is the only Homeric form ( Ph. 87 n.), but Eur. , like Soph. , uses all three. In Latin, Laertius or Lartius is usu. the adj. (Plaut. Bacch. 4. 9. 22 Ulixes Lartius), but, acc. to Priscian (7. 5, p. 303), could be also the name. The writing *la)rti/ou appears in all the editions from the Aldine to Brunck's; the coronis was first omitted by Schaefer (ed. 1810), on the ground that crasis is not marked within a word.

pei=ra/n tin' e)xqrw=n a(rpa/sai, to snatch (by vigilant and subtle craft) some means of attacking foes,—some moment when foes can be taken at a disadvantage. For the objective gen. e)xqrw=n, cp. Diod. Sic. 14. 80 kairo
 eu)/qeton ei)s th
 tw=n polemi/wn e)pi/qesin: for a(rpa/sai, Plut. Philop. 15 a(rpa/sas to
 kairo/n: Xen. An. 4. 6. 11 tou= e)rh/mou o)/rous..kle/yai ti..kai\ a(rpa/sai fqa/santas. Like the verb (peira=n th=s po/lews, Her. 6. 82), pei=ra often denotes an enterprise against an enemy (Thuc. 3. 20, etc.).—Not, ‘to forestall (or baffle) some attempt by a foe.’ qhrw/- menon with inf.: cp. Eur. Helen. 63 qhra=| gamei=n me: ib. 545 o(/s me qhra=tai labei=n.

Athena's words are illustrated by the action of Odysseus against Palamedes (Xen. Mem. 4. 2. 33),—by his capture of Helenus (Ph. 606),—his designs on Philoctetes,—his theft of the Palladium (Ov. Met. 13. 99),—and his nocturnal expedition with Diomedes (Il. 10).

skhnai=s … nautikai=s. Each chief has his quarters at the place on the shore of the bay where his own ships are drawn up. The plural here is probably poetical, denoting the tent of Ajax only, and not also those of his followers. We have the sing. of skhnh/ at 218 and 796, the plur. at 754 and 985; and in 754 u(po\ skhnai=si is precisely equivalent to skhnh=s u(/paulon in 796. So, too, the plur. of klisi/a in 192, and the sing. in 1407.
The Homeric klisi/a was a wooden hut (Il. 24. 448 ff.). By skhnh/, an Athenian in the poet's day would usually understand a tent of skins, such as was commonly used by soldiers (Xen. An. 1. 5. 10).

ta/cin e)sxa/thn. While Odysseus was stationed at the middle point of the Greek camp, the posts of danger and honour at the eastern and western ends respectively were held by Achilles and Ajax,—toi/ r() e)/sxata nh=as e)i+/sas | ei)/rusan, h)nore/h| pi/sunoi kai\ ka/rtei+ xeirw=n (Il. 11. 8 f.).

kunhgetou=nta: his keen scrutiny suggests a hunter; as his sagacity suggests a hound (8). We can speak of a dog ‘hunting,’ but a Greek would hardly have said ku/wn kunhgetei=. The transition from one image to the other is natural and easy.

metrou/menon, with the eyes. In Attic the midd. is rare, except as=‘to have measured out to one,’ [Dem.] or. 34 § 37: but it is frequent in later poetry, as Apoll. Rh. 1. 724, Mosch. 2. 157.Nauck holds that metrou/menon could denote only literal measurement (as with a foot-rule). But its figurative sense—as denoting a mental process of examination and comparison— is exactly illustrated by the use of summetrei=sqai in the sense of ‘to compute’ ( Her. 4. 158, etc.). Cp. also Lat. metiri (oculis, auribus, etc.).

neoxa/rakta, newly imprinted on the sandy soil. The tent was close to the sea (e)/falos, 192). Ajax had gone out in the past night, and come back at dawn. All the footprints are fresh; but Odysseus has to make out whether the more recent lead to or from the tent.

ei)/t' e)/ndon ei)/t' ou)k e)/ndon. Either ou) or mh/ can be used in an indirect question introduced by ei): Plat. Gorg. 462 D e)rwta=|s ei) ou) kalh/ moi dokei= ei)=nai: Theaet. 163 D boulo/menos e)re/sqai ei)..mh\ oi)=den. The same rule holds when the indirect question is alternative (‘whether...or not’), and the second part of it is introduced by ei)/te (as here), or by h)/. Plat. Crat. 425 B ei)/te kata\ tro/pon kei=tai ei)/te mh/, ou(/tw qea=sqai: Rep. 451 D skopw=men ei) h(mi=n pre/pei h)\ ou)/. When a writer uses mh/ in one such question, and then ou) in another, the motive of the change may be his wish to mark (by ou)) a negative fact (or what he conceives as such): Antiphon or. 5 § 14 ou) dei= u(ma=s e)k tw=n tou= kathgo/rou lo/gwn tou\s no/mous katamanqa/nein, ei) kalw=s u(mi=n kei=ntai h)\ mh/, a)ll' e)k tw=n no/mwn tou\s tou= kathgo/rou lo/gous, ei) o)rqw=s kai\ nomi/mws u(ma=s dida/skei to\ pra=gma h)\ ou)/.

e)kfe/rei: schol. ei)s te/los e)ca/gei: ‘brings out,’ as from a labyrinth, to the desired goal. Cp. O. C. 98 e)ch/gag' ei)s to/d' a)/lsos, (your guidance) ‘hath led me home to this grove.’ Plat. Phaedo p. 66 B kinduneu/ei toi w(/sper a)trapo/s tis e)kfe/rein h(ma=s.

kuno\s *lakai/nhs. According to Aristotle, the Laconian dogs were crossbred with foxes (e)c a)lw/pekos kai\ kuno\s oi( *lakwnikoi/, Hist. Anim. 8. 28, p. 607 a 3). He describes them as a small breed, with long nostrils and keen scent (o(/swn oi( mukth=res makroi/, oi(=on tw=n *lakwnikw=n kunidi/wn, o)sfrantika/: Gener. Anim. 5. 2, p. 781 b 9). They were the best hunting dogs, as Pindar testifies, fr. 106: a)po\ *tau+ge/toio me\n *la/kainan | e)pi\ qhrsi\ ku/na tre/fein [v.l. tre/xein] pukinw/taton e(rpeto/n. The Molossian dog is often associated with the Laconian ( Hor. Epod. 6. 5Molossus aut fulvus Laco: G. 3. 405 Velocis Spartae catulos acremque Molossum); but Aristotle tells us that the Molossian breed had no special merit for sporting purposes; its best product was the large sheep-dog. The chief points common to the Laconian and Molossian breeds were courage and pertinacity (a)ndri/a and filoponi/a, Hist. An. 9. 1, p. 608 a 31).

The use of the feminine gender by Sophocles here may be illustrated by Aristotle's remark,—ai( *la/kainai ku/nes ai( qh/leiai eu)fue/sterai tw=n a)rre/nwn ei)si/n,— i.e., ‘of a finer intelligence’ (ib. p. 608 a 27).—Cp. Shakesp. Midsummer-Night's Dream 4. 1. 124, where Theseus says, My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind | ... A cry more tuneable | Was never holla'd to, nor cheer'd with horn, | In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly.

eu)/rinos is nom., not gen. (from eu)/ris). It is true that eu)/ris occurs in Aesch. Ag. 1093, and a)/rrines in Xen. Cyn. 3. 2; while eu)/rinos (from r(i/s) occurs only in late Greek, as Babrius 43. 8 sku/lacin eu)ri/nois: Aelian N. A. 2. 15 di/khn eu)ri/nou kuno/s, etc. (In Apoll. Rh. 3. 1299 e)u+/rinoi is not from r(i/s, but from r(ino/s,—‘of good leather.’) But the form is correct in itself; such alternatives were frequent (cp. su/zugos by the side of su/zuc, etc.); and three points here recommend the nominative. (1) The order of the words w(/s tis eu)/rinos ba/sis. (2) The idiom, consonant with tragic style, by which the epithet of the hound is transferred to ba/sis: cp. Eur. H. F. 450 grai/as o)/sswn..phga/s: Phoen. 1351leukoph/xeis ktu/pous xeroi=n. (3) The fact that ba/sis, with no epithet, would be somewhat weak. Libanius (c. 350 A.D. ) took eu)/rinos as nom., vol. 4. p. 1065 eu)ri/nw| ba/sei to\ lanqa/non a)nixneu/ontes. The genitive was understood by the schol. on v. 7, and by Manuel Palaeologus or. 6. 331 (la/kainai ku/nes: eu)/rinas tau/tas ei)=pe *sofoklh=s).
tugxa/nei: sc. w)/n: cp. El. 46 n.

sta/zwn i(drw=ti. Some think that i(drw=ti refers to ka/ra only, and that sta/zwn xe/ras cifokto/nous is equivalent to sta/zwn ai(/mati xe/ras: cp. El. 1422foini/a de\ xei\r | sta/zei quhlh=s *)/areos: Aesch. Eum. 41ai(/mati | sta/zonta xei=ras. Certainly cifokto/nous suggests the blood upon his hands. But the integral phrase, sta/zwn i(drw=ti, must surely go with xe/ras no less than with ka/ra. The hands are bathed in sweat and in blood.

paptai/nein, from meaning ‘to glance timidly’ around, passes into the sense of looking about anxiously for someone or something ( Il. 17. 115paptai/nwn *ai)/anta), and so comes to denote restless search, as in Pind. O. 1. 114mhke/ti pa/ptaine po/rsion, Pind. P. 3. 22paptai/nei ta\ po/rsw. Here, the notion of moving forward in a wary quest is assisted by ei)/sw.
e)/rgon, opus est: 852: El. 1372 n.
e)nne/pein d): here de\=a)lla/: Ant. 85 n.: Ph. 94.
o(/tou xa/rin. Athena already knows his motive (36); but this touch of divine irony is dramatically useful by giving the cue for his statement.

spoudh\n e)/qou th/nd)=e)spou/dasas peri\ tou/tou. This periphrasis, more elegant than that with poiei=sqai, is much used by the poet; thus ti/qesqai pro/noian (536), e)pistrofh/n ( O. T. 134), ta/fon (ib. 1447), fo/non ( O. C. 542), mh=kos lo/gwn (ib. 1139), lhsmosu/nan ( Ant. 151), suggnwmosu/nhn ( Tr. 1265).
w)= fqe/gm' *)aqa/nas: cp. El. 1225w)= fqe/gm), a)fi/kou; (n.).

filta/ths e)moi\ qew=n: as he says in Ph. 134, *ni/kh t' *)aqa/na *polia/s, h(\ sw/|zei m' a)ei/. In Od. 20. 47 she says to him, au)ta\r e)gw\ qeo/s ei)mi, diampere\s h(/ se fula/ssw | e)n pa/ntessi po/nois.

ka)\n a)/poptos h)=|s o(/mws. The general sense of a)/poptos here is, ‘far from my sight’; the question is whether this means, (1) ‘seen only at a distance,’ ‘dimly seen’; or (2) ‘unseen.’ I formerly preferred the first view, for which we may compare Ph. 467, plou=n mh\ )c a)po/ptou ma=llon h)\ )ggu/qen skopei=n, ‘to watch the weather near our ship, rather than from afar.’ But I now feel two difficulties which it involves. (1) The emphasis on voice and thought—fqe/gma, fw/nhma, cunarpa/zw freni/—is so strong as to imply that he does not see her, even at a distance. (2) There can be no doubt that she was visible to the audience. She was probably on the qeologei=on,—a sort of platform, which projected from the wings, at the back of the proscenium, and close to its upper edge. If, then, Odysseus spoke of her as ‘seen only afar,’—a dim vision in the clouds,—the effect would be scarcely happy for the spectators, whose eyes could measure the actual distance between goddess and hero. On the other hand, there would seem nothing strange in her remaining invisible to him. In the Hippolytus, Aphroditè speaks the prologue, and was certainly visible to the spectators; but not to Hippolytus, who says, klu/wn me\n au)dh/n, o)/mma d' ou)x o(rw=n to\ so/n.

When Ajax comes forth, he, indeed, appears to see her (v. 91, w)= xai=r' *)aqa/na, k.t.l.); while to Tecmessa she is invisible (301). But this, again, would not be inconsistent with Greek belief. In Il. 22. 277Athena restores the spear to Achilles, yet is unseen by Hector. In Il. 1. 198 she appears to Achilles, but the others see her not.

For a)/poptos as=‘out of sight,’ cp. El. 1488(of Aegisthus) pro/qes | a)/popton h(mw=n: Dionys. Hal. 2. 54e)n a)po/ptw| ti/qentai to\n xa/raka (‘in a place out of sight’). It may be added that we might suppose Athena to be invisible to Odysseus now, without necessarily excluding the idea that she becomes visible to him at a later moment in the dialogue. Thus in Eur. Hipp. 1391 the presence of Artemis is known to Hippolytus only by a divine fragrance, though to the spectators she is doubtless visible; but a little later he beholds her (1440).—See Appendix.

cunarpa/zw freni/ expresses the thrill of instant recognition, as the voice falls distinctly (eu)maqe\s) on his ear; it also suggests the emotion of joy. For the verb, cp. Simylus (a poet of the Middle Comedy) ap. Stobaeus Flor. 360. 4. 14 krith\n to\ r(hqe\n duna/menon cunarpa/sai.

kw/dwnos … *turshnikh=s. The trumpet meant here was in form like the Roman,—straight, gradually increasing in diameter, and ending in a bell-shaped aperture (kw/dwn). ‘Tyrrhenian,’ a frequent epithet of the trumpet ( Aesch. Eum. 567, Eur. Phoen. 1377, Verg. Aen. 8. 526, etc.), perhaps means no more than that the instrument was first brought to Europe by Tyrrhenian pirates,—the lh|stosalpigktai/ of Menander (frag.incert. 399). The Tyrrheni, according to a tradition for which Herodotus is the earliest witness (1. 94), were of Lydian origin; and the bronze trumpet may have been a Lydian invention (see Dict. Ant. ‘Tuba’). Homer mentions the trumpet only in similes, as when the voice of Achilles is likened to it ( Il. 18. 219, etc.). But the Greeks must have had it as early at least as the time of the Dorian conquest, to judge from the legends heard by Pausanias at Argos (2. 21, § 3), where there was a shrine of *)aqhna= *sa/lpigc.—See Appendix.

As to the gender of kw/dwn, De Sens. 6 p. 446 b 22 has th=s kw/dwnos (bell). In Ar. Pax 1078 the words xh( kw/dwn a)kalanqi/s are said to mean a kind of hound. But kw/dwn (bell) is masc. with Thuc. , Strabo, Plutarch, Diodorus and Lucian.

e)pe/gnws with partic. (kuklou=nt)) of the act observed, as Xen. Cyr. 8. 1. 33e)pe/gnws d' a)\n..ou)de/na ou)/te o)rgizo/menon.. ou)/te xai/ronta. For slightly different uses of e)pigignw/skw, cp. Soph. Ant. 960, Soph. El. 1296.Remark eu)= as 2nd syll. of 3rd foot, referring to the word before it: cp. 95, Ant. 166, Ant. 723.

ba/sin kuklou=nt), moving round and round, going backwards and forwards in the attempt to make out the footprints,—like a hound questing about for the scent. Cp. Ant. 226o(doi=s kuklw=n e)mauto
 ei)s a)nastrofh/n. Eur. Or. 632poi= so
 po/d' e)pi\ sunnoi/a| kuklei=s (‘pacing to and fro in meditation’), | diplh=s meri/mnhs diptu/xous i)w
 o(dou/s;

tw=| sakesfo/rw|: Il. 7. 219*ai)/as d' e)ggu/qen h)=lqe fe/rwn sa/kos h)u+/te pu/rgon, | xa/lkeon, e(ptabo/eion,—i.e., made by stitching together seven layers of ox-hide, and then covering the outer face with plates of bronze. Cp. 576: Ovid Met. 13. 2clypei dominus septemplicis Aiax.
a)/skopon, inconceivable,—of unimaginable horror: cp. El. 864a)/skopos a( lw/ba.
e)/xei pera/nas=a perfect ( O. T. 577 n.): the double acc., as with dra=n, poiei=n, etc. (cp. 1324).
ei)/rgastai, instead of repeating e)/xei pera/nas: cp. O. T. 54w(s ei)/per a)/rceis th=sde gh=s, w(/sper kratei=s (n.).

trane/s, ‘clear,’ like the cognate toro/n (rt. ter, tra, te-trai/nw, to pierce). The adj. tranh/s is not elsewhere extant, but tranw=s is used by Aesch. ( Aesch. Ag. 1371) and Eur. ( Eur. El. 758). The form trano/s was current in later Greek; the earliest instance seems to be Halic. Dionys. (c. 25 B.C.) De Comp. Verborum c. 22 tranh\n kai\ kaqara\n du/namin.

a)lw/meqa: this fig. sense, with ref. to uncertainty (‘to be at sea,’ as we say), belongs nowhere else to this verb, but often to plana=sqai ( Her. 6. 37, etc.; Hipp. Ma. 304 C planw=mai me\n kai\ a)porw= a)ei/).

)qelonth/s. The form e)qelonth/s occurs in Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon, and the Orators, as e)qelonth/r does in Od. 2. 292.On the other hand qelonth/s is cited only from Porphyrius (c. 270 A.D. , see Lobeck, Phryn. 7) and Hierocles (c. 450 A.D. ), ap. Flor. 75. 14 (p. 449. 20). Similarly e)qelh/mwn is the form used by Plato (Crat. 406 A), while the earliest authority for qelh/mwn is Apoll. Rhod. 2. 557. In tragic iambics qe/lw was naturally preferred, on metrical grounds, to e)qe/lw, though the latter occurs in tragic anapaests (as O. T. 1303, Ph. 145). If qelonth/s were found in a passage where metre required it, the rarity of the form would not justify its rejection. But where, as here, aphaeresis was available, it is surely more probable that the poet wrote e)qelonth/s.
u(pezu/ghn, as if the task were a yoke under which he placed himself: cp. Ph. 1025kloph=| te ka)na/gkh| zugei/s (n.): Aesch. P. V. 108a)na/gkais tai=sd' u(pe/zeugmai.
kathnarisme/nas: for e)nari/zw ‘to slay’ (properly with the further notion of ‘despoiling’) cp. O. C. 1733, Tr. 94.From the cognate form katenai/romai we have kath/nares in Ant. 871.
e)k xeiro\s, by a human hand. The military sense, ‘at close quarters’ ( H. 7. 2. 14 e)ne/balon kai\ e)k xeiro\s e)ma/xonto), is less fitting here.

au)toi=s poimni/wn e)pista/tais: cp. fr. 873 au)toi=sin o(/plois. The idiom occurs in the Iliad (as 8. 24),—sometimes with su/n added (as 14. 498), a form of it found also, though not often, in later poetry ( Eur. Ion 32au)tw=| cu\n a)/ggei).

e)pista/tais, ‘overseers,’ ‘masters’ or ‘guardians’ of them; as a warrior is o(/plwn e)pista/ths ( Aesch. Pers. 379), and a rower, e)retmw=n ( Helen. 1267). Cp. Eur. fr. 188. 4 ska/ptwn, a)rw=n gh=n, poimni/ois e)pistatw=n. The herdsmen being dead, there was no one who could identify the assailant.

pa=s tis. The deed was found out at dawn. Common rumour at once pointed to Ajax. Then the o)pth/r (29) informed Odysseus, who reached the tent of Ajax very soon after the latter's return; as is shown by 296—304 compared with 91—113.

ne/mei: cp. Galen 7. 582 (Kühn) ou)k i)/shn a(/pasi ne/mei th\n ai)ti/an.—The corrupt tre/pei may have come from the gloss on e)kei/nw|..ne/mei which occurs in some of the later MSS., ei)s au)to\n tre/pei. This is one of the few instances (like Ant. 386 and 831) where a true reading, lost in L, has been preserved in other MSS. Cp. crit. notes on 44, Ant. 61.
tis placed before its noun: 1163: Ph. 519.

o)pth\r, a scout; cp. Od. 14. 261o)pth=ras de\ kata\ skopia\s w)/truna ne/esqai: Aesch. Theb. 36skopou\s de\ ka)gw\ kai\ katopth=ras stratou= | e)/pemya. In Suppl. 185, however, o)pth=res are ‘eye-witnesses,’—the usual sense of the word in Attic prose.

pedi/a is the acc. describing the ground traversed (as we can say, ‘to walk the earth’): cp. 845: Aesch. P. V. 708stei=x' a)nhro/tous gu/as: Helen. 598 pa=san planhqei\s th/nde ba/rbaron xqo/na: Callim. Hymn. Dian. 193 e)foi/ta | pai/pala/ te krhmnou/s te.

neorra/ntw| (as in 828), ‘newly sprinkled’ with blood: a compound suggested to the poet by the frequent use of r(ai/nw in that connection; as Il. 12. 430e)pa/lcies ai(/mati fwtw=n | e)rra/dat): Pind. I. 7. 50r(ai/nwn fo/nw| pedi/on.—When thus seen, Ajax was in the act of driving the animals that still lived to his tent: phdw=nta describes his wild gestures of triumph.

fra/zei te ka)dh/lwsen: the first verb refers to the announcement, ‘I have seen Ajax,’—the second, to a statement with more detail,—as to the direction in which he was going, etc. For historic pres. followed by aor., cp. Ant. 406 kai\ pw=s o(ra=tai ka)pi/lhptos h(|re/qh; (n.).
kat' i)/xnos: cp. Plat. Rep.p. 410 B kata\ tau)ta\ i)/xnh tau=ta diw/kwn. Similarly kata\ po/das tino/s, ‘at his heels’ ( Her. 9. 89, etc.).

shmai/nomai, midd., assure myself about them, identify them, by the indications observed. Cp. Xen. Cyn. 6. 22(of hounds): ai( d' e)peida\n lampra\ h)=| ta\ i)/xnh,...e)nshmaino/menai, o(/rous tiqe/menai e(autai=s gnwri/mous, taxu\ metaqeu/sontai. Appian Bell. Civ. 4. 19 shmhna/menoi to\ gigno/menon ei)=nai su/mbolon e)k qeou=. Aelian N. A. 7. 48 a)/strois au)ta\s (the cities) e)shmai/neto. Oppian Cyneg. 1. 454 mucwth=rsi ku/nes de\ pani/xnia shmh/nanto.
ta\ d' e)kpe/plhgmai: ‘as to other tracks’—viz., those of the cattle which Ajax had driven to the tent—he is bewildered.

o(/tou, as the context shows, is right: he cannot imagine who had made these tracks. o(/pou (cr. n.) would mean that, in the line of footprints made by Ajax, some were missing, which Odysseus did not know where to find.

kairo
, adv., as 1316: Helen. 479 kairo
 ga ou)de/n' h)=lqes: Ar. Ach. 23a)wri/an h(/kontes. But ei)s kairo
 in 1168.
ta/ t' ou)=n: for ou)=n in the first of two such clauses, cp. O. T. 1049ei)/t' ou)=n e)p' a)grw=n ei)/te ka)nqa/d' ei)sidw/n.
e)/bhn … ei)s o(do/n, ‘came into the path,’—placed myself on the route by which Ajax must pass.

kunagi/a|. Though we may conveniently render, ‘A watcher friendly to thy chase,’ the dat. seems really to depend on the whole idea, fu/lac pro/qumos (a zealous watcher in the interest of thy chase), rather than on the adj. only; though in H. 2. 3. 40 we have oi( pro/qumoi th=| po/lei gegenhme/noi. Cp. O.C. 355 fu/lac de/ moi (vulg. mou) | pisth\ kate/sths.—The Doric form of kunagi/a is supported by L here, as by the MSS. generally in Eur. Hipp. 109: while in Eur. Bacch. 339 the MSS. favour kunhgi/ais, and the Doric form was restored by Matthiae. Attic Tragedy used kunago/s, kunagi/a, kunhgetei=n, kunhge/ths.
h)= kai/, in eager question: cp. 44, 48: El. 314 n.
pro\s kairo\n=kairi/ws, O.T. 325 n.
w(s, ‘know that’: Ph. 117 n.— soi, ethic dat.
pro\s ti/, ‘wherefore?’ Cp. O.T. 766, 1027, 1144.

h)=|cen, trans., as Eur. Or. 1427 ff. para\ bo/struxon au)/ran.. | .. ku/klw| | pteri/nw|...a)/|sswn, ‘agitating’ the air with a fan. Eur. Itis not impossible to take h)=|cen as intrans. (‘broke forth in violence’); but it would be very harsh.

duslo/giston is an epithet proper to the violence, transferred to the hand which wrought it; ‘reasoning amiss,’ i.e. ‘irrational,’ ‘insensate.’ Cp. 229 paraplh/ktw| xeri/. An exact parallel to this active sense is afforded by Arist. Rhet. 2. 8. 4, where oi( pepaideume/noi are called eu)lo/gistoi, i.e., ‘reflecting,’ ‘prudent.’ In its passive sense, duslo/giston would mean that the deed is ‘inexplicable’: cp. Anaximenes ap. Eclog. 2. 8. 17 to\ ga\r duslo/giston tou= bi/ou toi=s a)nqrw/pois tu/xhn prosagoreu/omen, ‘we give the name of chance to that element in life which men find hard to explain.’ But here the agent's frenzy is more in point than the observer's perplexity.—Some take duslo/giston with ti/: ‘for what unintelligible reason?’ But this enfeebles the sense and mars the rhythm.
barunqei\s, incensed, vexed, as O.T. 781: cp. baru/s in 1017.
o(/plwn, causal gen.: cp. Tr. 269w(=n e)/xwn xo/lon: Ph. 327 n. For the adj. *)axillei/wn, instead of *)axille/ws, cp. O.T. 267 tw=| *labdakei/w| paidi/ (n.).
ti/ dh=ta: i.e., why, in that case, did he attack cattle, rather than the men who had awarded the arms?

e)pempi/ptei: cp. 185 e)n poi/mnais pi/tnwn, and 374 f.— th/nde … ba/sin, a cognate acc. (as if the verb were e)pembai/nei): cp. Aesch. Pers. 305ph/dhma kou=fon e)k new\s a)fh/lato. ( Soph. Tr. 339, tou= me th/nd' e)fi/stasai ba/sin, is different: see n. there.)
e)n u(mi=n: so 366 e)n a)fo/bois me qhrsi\ deino\n xe/ras: cp. 1092, 1315.
h)= kai\: cp. 38 n.
w(s e)p' *)argei/ois: w(s here marks the intention of Ajax (which was frustrated): cp. Ph. 58plei=s d' w(s pro\s oi)=kon (n.).

ka)\n e)cepra/cat): schol. mh\ le/ge bou/leuma, fhsi/n: ou) ga\r h)=n bou/leuma a)lla\ pra=gma, ei) kathme/lhsa e)gw/. Cp. Ph. 555kou) mo/non bouleu/mata, | a)ll' e)/rga drw/men). The answer is more forcible than if the poet had written ka)\n e)ce/prace/ g': see on Ph. 105, Ph. 985, El. 408.—The midd. e)kpra/ssomai is rare; in Her. 7. 158 it means ‘to avenge’ (fo/non). Cp. O.T. 287 e)praca/mhn (n.).

poi/aisi k.t.l. The datives denote manner (or attendant circumstance), and refer to to\ bou/leum)...h)=n in 44. ‘What were these daring schemes, what was this rash confidence, with which he planned the attack?’—i.e., ‘How could he possibly have conceived such a mad enterprise?’ For tai=sde combined with poi/aisi, cp. Ph. 1204poi=on e)rei=s to/d' e)/pos;
nu/ktwr k.t.l.: an answer to the last question:—he relied on darkness, and on craft; and none shared his secret.
h)= kai\: 38 n.
pare/sth, came close to us: cp. Tr. 748pou= d' e)mpela/zeis ta)ndri\ kai\ pari/stasai; El. 295boa=| parasta=s.

kai\ dh\, ‘already’: O.C. 31 n.— dissai=s … strathgi/sin pu/lais, the tentdoors of the two chiefs, Agamemnon and Menelaüs. (Cp. Paus. 4. 19. 2th
 skhnh
 th
 strathgi/da.) The phrase is equivalent, of course, to dissw=n strathgw=n pu/lais. 721 strath/gion, n. But, since there were two tents and two entrances, dissai=s is strictly the epithet of pu/lais|: i.e., the literal sense is, ‘two doors of chiefs.’ If the two chiefs had shared the same tent, so that only one entrance could be meant by pu/lais, then, indeed, dissai=s could be explained only as referring to the subst. implied in strathgi/sin,—‘the tent-door of two chiefs,’= dissostrathgi/sin pu/lais. But such a use of dissai=s seems impossible. Could dissa\ a)delfw=n a(/rmata (e.g.) mean, ‘a chariot belonging to two brothers’?

kai\ pw=s: for kai\ prefixed to interrogative words, see on O.C. 263.—Join e)pe/sxe with fo/nou. The word maimw=san is Homeric: Il. 13. 77peri\ dou/rati xei=res a)/aptoi | maimw=sin. Cp. Lycophron 1171 maimw=n kore/ssai xei=ra diyw=san fo/nou,—a reminiscence, partly of this v., and partly of one of an unknown poet (tw=n tragikw=n tis, Athen. 10. p. 433 F), frag. adesp. 96, i)/sxein keleu/w xei=ra diyw=san fo/nou.
e)gw/, an expression of divine majesty and power; cp. 69, 85.

dusfo/rous, hard to bear up against: her hand is heavy upon him. Cp. 643 du/sforon a)/tan: O.T. 87 ta\ du/sfor), i.e., the woes of Thebes: El. 144tw=n dusfo/rwn, miseries. Besides this sense, the only other in which the word occurs is, ‘hard to carry about,’ ‘moving with difficulty,’ as Plat. Tim.p. 74 E i(/na mh\ du/sfora ta\ sw/mata a)perga/zointo (‘unwieldy’). A scholiast wrongly took dusfo/rous here as=kakw=s ferome/nas, parafo/rous, i.e. ‘led astray,’ ‘misguided.’

gnw/mas, opinions, beliefs,—here, the fancies or illusions of madness. There is a certain irony in the word. Some editors strangely prefer the conjecture lh/mas,—as if the goddess had afflicted him with sore or weak eyes ( Plut. 581 *kronikai=s lh/mais...lhmw=ntes ta\s fre/nas).

Join th=s a)nhke/stou xara=s with gnw/mas: his eyes, under Athena's spell, see his human foes in the cattle whom he slays or torments; these fancies are the fancies of (or connected with) his baneful joy in his imaginary triumph. For the adj., cp. El. 888qa/lpei tw=|d' a)nhke/stw| puri/ (n.).

Others take the gen. as depending on a)pei/rgw, placing a comma after the verb, and another after balou=sa,—a punctuation which is found in the Aldine. But (1) the sense of xara=s is then attenuated to that of ‘hoped-for vengeance,’—whereas, as a)nhke/stou shows, it clearly denotes the frantic joy which Ajax actually felt; and (2) the order of words is then less natural.

pro/s te poi/mnas=pro\s poi/mnas te: for te misplaced, cp. 654: O.T. 258 n. As distinguished from herds of oxen, poi=mnai are flocks of sheep and goats; cp. 63, 297, 374. But the word poi=mnai is also used more vaguely to denote both herds and flocks (42, 300): and in 1061 we find even mh=la kai\ poi/mnas, ‘sheep and cattle.’

su/mmikta/ te … frourh/mata: confused, unshared, spoil-charges of herdsmen, i.e., ‘the confused droves, your unshared spoil, guarded by herdsmen.’ lei/as is a defining gen., denoting that in which the frourh/mata consisted; bouko/lwn is a possessive gen. Cp. El. 681*(ella/dos | pro/sxhm' a)gw=nos, the pride of Greece (possessive gen.), consisting in a festival (defining gen.): so Aesch. Ch. 183kardi/as kludw/nion | xolh=s (defining gen.). Others prefer to take lei/as as a partitive gen. (‘forming part of the spoil’),—less fitly, I think.

a)/dasta: cp. Il. 1. 125a)lla\ ta\ me\n poli/wn e)cepra/qomen, ta\ de/dastai. At v. 26 the word lei/as is used to denote the slaughtered animals generally. Sheep and oxen were alike lei/a in the large sense, as having been taken from the foe, but the oxen are more especially so-called, because they were to be shared among individual chiefs or others, while the flocks were kept for the public maintenance. With a)/dasta here, cp. 146 loiph/, and 175 panda/mous (n.).

e)/keire … fo/non. kei/rein fo/non=to cause bloodshed by hewing; as tuflou=n e(/lkos=‘to inflict a blinding wound’ ( Ant. 972 n.), trw=sai fo/non=‘to deal a deathwound’ ( Suppl. 1205).—Note the parh/xhsis in e)/keire—polu/kerwn: cp. 528, 1112: O. T. 370 n.

polu/kerwn fo/non, a slaughter of many horned creatures, like xero/plaktoi...dou=poi (631 ff.), au)/xhma eu)/ippon, a glory consisting in good horses ( O. C. 711 n.), r(imfa/rmatoi a(/millai, contests of swift chariots (ib. 1062 f. n.).— The accent of polu/kerwn (cp. 64 eu)/kerwn) is acc. to the rule that adjectives in -ws follow the Attic 2nd decl. of nouns in -ws or -wn, which can be proparoxytone if the w in the last syll. is immediately preceded by e, or separated from it only by a liquid: thus a)cio/xrews, baqu/gews, i(/lews, filo/gelws.
r(axi/zwn, here in a general sense, ‘hewing down’; properly, to cut through the spine (r(a/xis), to cleave in twain; cp. 299: Aesch. Pers. 426e)/paion, e)rra/xizon.

ka)do/kei me
 k.t.l.: properly, ka)do/kei e)/sti me
 o(/te..., e)/sti de\ o(/te: but me
 is misplaced (as in Ph. 279o(rw=nta me
 nau=s, and ib. 1136 o(rw=n me
 a)pa/tas); and e)/sti de\ is omitted. Cp. O. T. 603tou=to me/n, balanced in 605 by tou=t' a)/llo.
foitw=nt): cp. Aesch. Th. 661(boasts) flu/onta su\n foi/tw| frenw=n. For the plur. no/sois cp. 338 nosh/masi: Eur. Or. 270mania/sin lussh/masi.

w)/trunon, ei)se/ballon. Hermann supported his conjecture, *)erinu/wn w)/trunon (cr. n.), by the remark that the asyndeton in the traditional text implies an agitation of mind unsuitable to the goddess. But it rather expresses the vehemence with which the frenzy sent by her drove Ajax onward. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 288kai\ lu/ssa kai\ ma/taios e)k nuktw=n fo/bos | kinei=, tara/ssei.

ei)s e(/rkh kaka/. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 1611th=s *di/khs e)n e(/rkesin. Here it is the epithet kaka/ which marks the figurative sense of e(/rkh: as dirges are u(/mnoi a)/luroi ( Eur. Alc. 447), and the eagle of Zeus is pthno\s ku/wn ( Aesch. P. V. 1022). For the similar use of other words denoting nets or toils, see on El. 1476a)rkusta/tois.

ka)/peit' e)peidh\: this harsh combination of sounds (as we should think it) is not rare; thus Ar. Eccl. 1100ka)/peit' e)peida
 th=sd' a)pallagw=: Vesp. 1322 e)/peit' e)peidh\ )me/quen: Plut. 695 e)/peit' e)peidh\ mesto\s h)=n: [Dem. ] or. 59 § 89 e)/peit' e)peida
 peisqh=|. Similarly Eur. Or. 238e(/ws e)w=si/ s): Helen. 1292 h)
 gunh\ ge/nh|: I. T. 1339 h)=men h(/menoi.
e)lw/fhsen implies only respite or alleviation, not cure: cp. Thuc. 6. 12§ 1 a)po\ no/sou mega/lhs kai\ pole/mou braxu/ ti lelwfh/kamen. Cp. Soph. Tr. 554 n.
po/nou: the simple gen. is usual with lwfa=n: cp. Phaedr. 251 C lwfa=|..th=s o)du/nhs.
au)=, ‘in their turn’: cp. 1088: Ant. 601.
a)/ndras=a)nqrw/pous: cp. 243 dai/mwn | kou)dei\s a)ndrw=n.
eu)/kerwn, since the oxen were his most conspicuous prizes: there is a bitter irony in the epithet. For the accent, see on 55.

kai\ soi\, to thee also (as I myself have seen it): cp. Plat. Phaed. 64 C e)a\n a)/ra kai\ soi\ cundokh=| a(/per kai\ e)moi/. Seyffert writes kai/ soi (as if the sense were, ‘I will further show thee’): but this is plainly wrong.

dei/cw … perifanh=, ‘will show thee openly’ (instead of allowing it to remain hidden in the tent): cp. El. 1366ai(\ tau=ta/ soi dei/cousin, *)hle/ktra, safh=. Cp. 81 perifanw=s..i)dei=n.—We might, indeed, take perifanh= as a mere epithet, ‘this signal, notable, frenzy’; but in the actual context the other view is preferable.
qroh=|s, ‘proclaim’: cp. 785: O. C. 597pa=s tou=to/ g' *(ellh/nwn qroei=.

mhde\ sumfora
 de/xou to
 a)/ndra, lit., ‘do not receive (or take) the man as a calamity,’ i.e., ‘do not apprehend harm from his coming.’ There is a light touch of half-playful irony in the words with which the goddess reassures her favourite. Cp. Eur. Or. 138a)ll' e)moi\ | to/nd' e)cegei=rai cumfora\ genh/setai. Hdt. 6. 61tou\s gone/as sumforh
 to\ ei)=dos au)th=s poieume/nous. Similarly Il. 21. 39tw=| d' a)/r' a)nw/i+ston kako
 h)/luqe di=os *)axilleu/s: O. T. 379*kre/wn de/ soi ph=m' ou)de/n. —Whitelaw (Translation, p. 440) takes the constr. to be, mi/mne (mhde\ sumfora
 de/xou) to
 a)/ndra,—‘Bravely await, expecting no mischance, | His coming,’— dia\ me/sou construction ( Ant. 1279 f., n.). A difficulty in this view is that de/xou must then have definitely the sense of prosde/xou.

a)postro/fous, proleptic: cp. Ant. 791su\ kai\ dikai/wn a)di/kous fre/nas paraspa=|s. Here the adj. is equiv. to a)postre/yasa,— ‘I will avert, and (thereby) hinder.’— a)pei/rcw … ei)<*>idei=n, without mh/: as ei)/rgw takes the simple inf. in O. T. 129, Ph. 1407, Tr. 1257.

These three verses have been rejected (cr. n.), on the ground that, after this promise from Athena, Odysseus had no cause to feel the alarm which he shows in vv. 74 ff., or to ask the question (v. 84) which elicits a renewal of that promise (85). But the poet wished to render the preparation for the hero's entrance as impressive as possible; and chose, therefore, to represent Odysseus—a brave man—as still uneasy, until the assurance given to him had been repeated in a yet more explicit and emphatic form.
ou(=tos: cp. 89, 1047: O. C. 1627w)= ou(=tos ou(=tos *oi)di/pous, ti/ me/llomen;
se\ to\n k.t.l.: in a peremptory call of this kind, the acc. regularly stands first; cp. 1228, and see on Ant. 441se\ dh/, se\ th\n neu/ousan k.t.l.
ai)xmalwti/das, instead of ai)xmalw/twn: cp. Eur. Or. 222a)delfh=| xeiri/ (a sister's hand); I. A. 1306 eu)nai=s basili/si (the bed of a king).

a)peuqu/nonta, lit. ‘straightening out,’ here, binding behind the back: O. T. 1154ou)x w(s ta/xos tis tou=d' a)postre/yei xe/ras; Od. 22. 189su\n de\ po/das xei=ra/s te de/on qumalge/i+ desmw=| | eu)= ma/l' a)postre/yante diampere/s. So Achilles deals with his captives, Il. 21. 30dh=se d' o)pi/ssw xei=ras e)u+tmh/toisin i(ma=sin. Hom. Od. 3. 5. 22retorta tergo bracchia libero.

Cp. Eur. Andr. 719w(=d), w)= ka/kiste, th=sd' e)lumh/nw xe/ras; | bou=n h)\ le/ont' h)/lpizes e)ntei/nein bro/xois; (‘strain with cords’). Ajax fancies himself to be tying the hands of human prisoners behind them, when he fastens the fore feet of an ox or sheep to its hind feet. Cp. 299.
ti/ dra=|s..; Odysseus is brave, but reasonably reluctant to face a raging maniac who hates him (1336).
mhdamw=s sf' e)/cw ka/lei. The omission of sf) (cr. n.) seems undesirable here; though it could be defended (see Ph. 801 n.). Cp. 496.

ou) si=g' a)ne/cei mhde\ deili/an a)rei=; lit., ‘Wilt thou not be patient in silence, and forbear to win the name of coward?’ Cp. Tr. 1183ou) qa=sson oi)/seis mhd' a)pisth/seis e)moi/; ‘Give me thy hand at once —disobey me not!’ O. T. 637ou)k ei)= su/ t' oi)/kous su/ te, *kre/on, kata\ ste/gas, | kai\ mh\ to\ mhde\n a)/lgos ei)s me/g' oi)/sete; ‘Come, go thou into the house...and forbear to make much of a petty grief.’ See Appendix.
si=g' a)ne/cei: cp. fr. 618 su/ggnwte ka)na/sxesqe sigw=sai.

deili/an a)rei=, ‘win,’ ‘acquire,’ the reputation of cowardice: cp. Ant. 924th\n dusse/beian eu)sebou=s' e)kthsa/mhn (n.): I. T. 676 kai\ deili/an ga\r kai\ ka/khn kekth/somai. The fut. midd. a)rou=mai occurs in O. C. 460 swth=r' a)rei=sqe, and Pind. P. 1. 75a)re/omai.. misqo/n. The fut. act. a)rei=s has better MS. authority here; but is (I am now convinced) wrong. It could mean only, ‘raise thy cowardice,’ in the sense, ‘allow thy coward fears to rise,’—a very forced one. Further, there is no other example of a fut. act. a)rw= with a^. See note in Appendix on the Future and Aorist forms from a)ei/rw, ai)/rw, a)/rnumai.
e)/ndon a)rkei/tw me/nwn: for the personal constr. (instead of a)rkei/tw au)to\n e)/ndon me/nein), cp. 635: Ant. 547a)rke/sw qnh/|skous e)gw/: O. T. 1061a(/lis nosou=s' e)gw/.
ti/ mh\ ge/nhtai; ‘lest what happen?’ So Suppl. 543 nekrou\s de\ tarbei=t' ei) krubh/sontai xqoni/; | ti/ mh\ ge/nhtai; mh\ kataska/ywsi gh=n | tafe/ntes u(mw=n;
a)nh\r, emphatic, a man indeed; cp. 1238 ou)k a)=r' *)axaioi=s a)/ndres ei)si\ plh\n o(/de;
e)xqro/s ge. Odysseus refrains from replying that Ajax was then sane, but now is frenzied. ‘Yes,’ he answers, ‘my foeman,—as he is still.’ That enmity, he means, will now be more dangerous than ever.

ou)/koun ge/lws h(/distos..; The goddess suggests the vulgar sentiment of mankind, not as approving it, but, as it were, to test the disposition of Odysseus; who passes it by in silence, and afterwards repudiates it by his action.
e)moi\ me\n: the particle merely throws a slight stress on the pronoun: Ant. 11 n.
fronou=nta ga\r: ‘yes, for...’: the ga\r of assent, O. T. 1117 n.

e)ce/sthn with acc., as meaning ‘avoid’: Dem. or. 20 § 10 ou)de/na pw/pote ki/ndunon e)ce/sthsan (a phrase which occurs also in or. 23 § 76): Plat. Phileb.p. 43 A a)lla\ ga\r u(peksth=nai to\n lo/gon e)pifero/menon tou=ton bou/lomai (‘to elude the brunt of this argument’). Cp. Thuc. 2. 88§ 2 mhde/na o)/xlon...u(poxwrei=n (‘to face any numbers’). But e)ci/stasqai takes a dat. when it means to ‘make place for’ (672), or ‘give way to’ ( Soph. Ph. 1053).
ou)de\ nu=n refers to ou)k in 82: ‘even as it is (i.e. though he is insane) thou hast no reason to fear him, since he will not see thee.’

o)fqalmoi=s … toi=s au)toi=s, i.e., with eyesight as good as ever. Odysseus forgets, or ignores, the promise of Athena that she would avert from him the eyes of Ajax (69 f.). She now renews the assurance in a stronger form. Ajax shall, in respect to him, be blind.

dedorko/ta properly implies keen, bright vision: Suppl. 409 dedorko\s o)/mma (with Tucker's note). Chrysippus ap. Gellius 14. 4 e)/ntonon kai\ dedorko\s ble/pousa (said of Justice), which Gellius renders, luminibus oculorum acribus.
ge/noito k.t.l.: cp. Her. 5. 9ge/noito d' a)\n pa=n e)n tw=| makrw=| xro/nw|.

me/nta)\n, a crasis frequent in Attic prose ( Dem. or. 1 § 26, Plat. Rep.p. 375 D, etc.). Here me/ntoi expresses reflective assent (‘well, certainly’), as so often in Plato (e.g., Plat. Soph.p. 245 B a)lhqe/stata me/ntoi le/geis).

qeou=, not qea=s,—the generalising masc.: Aesch. Eum. 297(ref. to Athena), e)/lqoi: klu/ei de\ kai\ pro/swqen w)\i qeo/s. So Soph. Ant. 463(o(/stis), Soph. Tr. 151(au(tou=), Soph. El. 145(o(\s), Soph. El. 771(pa/sxonti), Soph. El. 1026(e)gxeirou=nta), Soph. El. 1105(to\n a)/gxiston).

me/noim' a)/n. Among its many shades of meaning, the opt. with a)/n sometimes expresses; as here, what the speaker feels that he must do; cp. Ant. 1108w(=d' w(s e)/xw stei/xoim' a)/n (n.). See below, Ant. 186.
h)/qelon d' a)\n, as Ph. 1278, and ib. 1239 a)\n..e)boulo/mhn: so h)qe/lhsa with a)/n, ib. 427, O. T. 1348, and ei(lo/mh<*> a)/n, Tr. 734.For h)/qelon without a)/n, see 1400.
e)kto\s w)\n tuxei=n, to be clear of the peril: cp. Ph. 504e)kto\s o)/nta phma/twn: ib. 1260 i)/sws a)\n e)kto\s klauma/twn e)/xois po/da: fr. 657. 3 e)kto/s ei)si tw=n kakw=n.
ou(=tos: 71.

*ai)/as. When a proper name of the 3rd declension comes from a stem ending in ant (as *ai)ant), the Attic vocative ends in a_s: so *qo/as, a)/kouson, I. T. 1436. The Homeric vocative of *ai)/as is always *ai)=an (a^) —formed on the analogy of the voc from stems in ont, as *kre/on (stem *kreont). The vocatives *pouluda/ma ( Il. 12. 231), *laoda/ma ( Od. 8. 141) are exceptions, due perhaps to a sense that here the ending -an might suggest an accusative.
th=s summa/xou: there is a terrible irony in this, since he had angered her by rejecting her aid in battle (774).
Ajax enters from the tent, carrying the heavy, blood-stained thong, with which he has been scourging the cattle (241 f.). Hence the title mastigofo/ros (see Argument to the Play).
*diogene\s te/knon: cp. Aesch. Th. 127w)= *diogene\s filo/maxon kra/tos (Athena): Eur. Cycl. 350w)= *palla/s, w)= de/spoina, *diogene\s qea/. Cp. Eur. Ion 465pai=s a( *latogenh/s.
pare/sths: cp. 117.

ste/yw, ‘crown,’ in the fig. sense of ‘honouring with gifts’: cp. El. 457o(/pws to\ loipo
 au)to
 a)fnewte/rais | xersi\ ste/fwmen h)\ tanu=n dwrou/meqa: Ant. 431xoai=si..to
 ne/kun ste/fei. (In later Greek, stefanou=n is said of any honorarium; as Plut. Timol. 16 to
..a)/nqrwpon e)stefa/nwsan.. de/ka mnai=s.) Here, the word may refer more esp. to hanging up trophies in Athena's temple (Aesch. Th. 278 la/fura da/|wn douri/phxq' a(gnoi=s do/mois | ste/yw,— where, however, the text is doubtful: cp. Agam. 577 ff.).
lafu/rois (rt. lab), spoils taken from the enemy, a poetical word, used by Xenophon. The epithet pagxru/sois suggests votive gifts (a)naqh/mata) of golden vessels.
e)kei=no marks (better than tou=to would have done) the somewhat abrupt change of subject. Athena treats Ajax as one whose thoughts can be turned at pleasure in any new direction.
e)/gxos, ‘sword’; cp. 287, 658, 907, Ant. 1236; synonymous with ci/fos (10, Ant. 231, Ant. 1034), and fa/sganon (834, Ant. 899).
eu)=: cp. 18.— pro\s *)argei/wn stratw=|, ‘on’ them,—denoting an encounter at close quarters; cp. 97.
to\ mh/, where (after the negative) to\ mh\ ou) would be normal; so O. T. 1387 f., Ant. 443, Ph. 348 f.

h)/|xmasas xe/ra; The exact sense seems to be, ‘hast thou used an armed hand upon them?’ The acc. xe/ra is analogous, though not precisely similar, to the cognate accusative in ai)xma/sai ta/de ( Tr. 355, ‘to do those deeds of arms’), and ai)xma\s ai)xma/ssousi ( Il. 4. 324), ‘they will wield spears.’ The fact that pro\s stands with dat., and not with acc., shows that the phrase cannot mean, ‘hast thou armed thy hand against them?’ —Musgrave's h(/|macas, though specious, is coarser; there is a keen edge in the reference of h)/|xmasas to the prowess of a warrior.
w(/st) (‘so that’) is far better here than w(s (‘know that..’, 39); and is the more forcible because ge is absent (cp. 45 n.).
*ai)/ant) (instead of e)me/) adds a certain majesty to the vaunt; cp. 864: as when Achilles says ( Il. 1. 240), h(= pot' *)axillh=os poqh\ i(/cetai ui(=as *)axaiw=n.
to\ so\n, ‘thy saying’; cp. 1401: but in 1313, ‘thy interest.’

qano/ntes … a)fairei/sqwn. The grim irony is like that of O. T. 1273 f. e)n sko/tw|.. | o)yoi/aq): O. C. 1377(they are to die) i(/n' a)ciw=ton tou\s futeu/santas se/bein: Ant. 310(after a like threat) i(/n' ei)do/tes to\ ke/rdos e)/nqen oi)ste/on | to\ loipo\n a(rpa/zhte: Tr. 1110(Deianeira shall perish) i(/n' e)kdidaxqh=| pa=sin a)gge/llein k.t.l.
ta)/m), emphatic: the arms which, when Achilles was dead, belonged by right to Ajax. Schol.: kalw=s ta\ e)ma\ e)/fh, ou)x a(\ dei= me labei=n, w(s i)di/wn a)pesterhme/nos.
ei)=en (‘so far so good’) marks that the speaker is about to pass to a new point; O. C. 1308, El. 534, Ph. 1308.
ti/ ga\r dh\: here ga/r (‘now’) merely prefaces the question; dh/=‘then,’ ‘in the next place.’ Cp. I. T. 576 ti/ d' h(mei=s oi(/ t e)moi\ gennh/tores; | a)=r' ei)si/n;
pou= soi tu/xhs e(/sthken; Cp. 314: O. T. 1442i(/n' e(/stamen | xrei/as: Tr. 375pou= pot' ei)mi\ pra/gmatos; ib. 1145 cumfora=s i(/n' e(/stamen.
soi, ethic dat.: O. C. 81h)= be/bhken h(mi\n o( ce/nos; (i.e., ‘Do we find ourselves alone?’) For the double question, cp. 983 f.

tou)pi/tripton, ‘accursed’; cp. the imprecation, e)pitribei/hs ( Ar. Av. 1530, Thesm. 557). Others explain it, from the sense ‘rubbed down,’ as ‘practised in trickery,’ ‘knavish’ (cp. peri/trimma, a)/lhma, etc.). Ar. Plut. 275 w(s semno\s ou(pi/triptos: Andoc. or. 1 § 99 w)= sukofa/nta kai\ e)pi/tripton ki/nados. Ar. Av. 430pukno/taton ki/nados, | so/fisma, ku/rma, tri/mma, paipa/lhm' o(/lon. Here ki/nados is acc.: cp. 118, Ph. 444 n.
e)ch/rou m' o(/pou, sc. e)sti/: a frequent ellipse after o(/pou (890, O. T. 926, Ant. 318). Cp. 33.

e)/gwg). In favour of omitting the colon after e)/gwg), it has been urged that, if it remains, the goddess seems to accept the description just given of her favourite; and that it would better become her to reply merely, ‘I mean Odysseus, thy foe.’ But she is displaying the insanity of Ajax, and has already received his fierce vaunts with the irony of seeming approval.

*)odusse/a, with synizesis: cp. Eur. Phoen. 913sfa/cai *menoike/a to/nde: [Eur. ] Rhes. 977 e)/peit' *)axille/a *qe/tidos k.t.l. But synizesis is not applied by Sophocles to *)odusse/a in Ph. 1220, to *)axille/a in Ph. 331 and 358, or to *qhse/a in O. C. 1055 and 1630. Here Nauck writes *)odussh=, a form found in Rhes. 708; cp. Eur. El. 439*)axilh=.

e)nsta/thn, ‘adversary’: a word not extant elsewhere. It comes from e)ni/stasqai as=‘to stand in the way’ of a person or thing, ‘oppose,’ ‘resist.’ For the literal sense, see Lysias or. 3 § 8 eu)qu/s me tu/ptein e)pexei/rhsen: e)peidh\ de\ au)to\n h)muna/mhn e)nsta/s (‘when I stood up to him and repelled him’), e)/balle/ me li/qois: for the fig. sense, Thuc. 8. 69§ 2 h)/n tis e)nisth=tai toi=s poioume/nois. Hence in logic, e)/nstasis, instantia, ‘objection’ (cp. Isocr. or. 5 § 39, e)nsth=nai toi=s ei)rhme/nois). In Etym. M. p. 625. 25 e)nsta/ths (quoted from this passage) is loosely explained as=a)ntista/ths.
h(/distos, most welcome; cp. El. 929kat' oi)=kon, h(du\s ou)de\ mhtri\ dusxerh/s.

ki/on' e(rkei/ou ste/ghs, lit., ‘a pillar of the domestic roof.’ As *zeu\s e(rkei=os is the god of the household ( Ant. 487 n.), e(rkei=os ste/gh is a poetical phrase for the house. In such a phrase, ste/gh could mean either (a) ‘roof,’ or (b) generally, ‘building.’ Here, it probably means ‘roof’; as is suggested by the fact that, in Homer, e(/rkos sometimes denotes the enclosure of the au)lh/, open to the sky ( Od. 22. 442, etc.): in using e(rkei=os, then, as=‘domestic,’ the poet may have felt that ste/gh, tectum, would make the sense clearer. This is also suggested by ki/on): see Eur. H. F. 1006, where the roof of the house falls in, breaking one of the ki/ones (called also la/i+noi o)rqosta/tai, ib. 979 f.) which supported it:—pro\s ki/ona | nw=ton pata/cas, o(\s pesh/masi ste/ghs | dixorragh\s e)/keito krhpi/dwn e)/pi. Cp. also Aesch. Ag. 897u(yhlh=s ste/ghs | stu=lon podh/rh (‘of a lofty roof | A strong-based pillar’; Kennedy).—I now prefer this view to that which takes e(rkei=os ste/gh as=‘the building of an enclosure’; i.e. an au)lh/, open to the sky, within the house;—the ki/wn being then one of the columns of a peristyle surrounding this court, as in the a)ndrwni=tis of an ordinary Greek dwelling.

deqei\s pro\s ki/on): the regular preparation for a flogging: cp. Aeschin. or. 1 § 59 dh/santes pro\s to
 ki/ona au)to
...e)masti/goun. Lysias fr. 52 § 4 pa/lin pro\s to
 ki/ona au)to
 mastigou=n dh/santas. Hypereides ap. Pollux 3. 80. So Plaut. Bacch. 4. 7. 24 abducite hunc intro atque astringite ad columnam fortiter.

dei=n pro\s ki/ona (properly, ‘to take and bind to a pillar’), not pro\s ki/oni, was thus the usual phrase; but Artemidorus (c. 160 A.D. ) Oneirocr. 1. 78 has prosdeqei\s ki/oni e)/labe plhga\s polla/s. Cp. 240.—ki/wn is masc. in Herodotus Attic. uses it in both genders (fem. 1. 92, masc. 4. 184). With Pindar it is always fem.; and usually so in the Odyssey, but not always; in Od. 8. 66, pro\s ki/ona makro\n e)rei/sas, the masc. has a metrical motive, but not in 19. 38, ki/ones u(yo/s' e)/xontes.

e)rga/sei. In v. 107 she continued his sentence; here, feigning keener alarm, she interrupts it.—Nauck reads e)rga/sh| (aor.), depending on pri\n a)/n: which not only is weaker, but requires dh/sas instead of deqei\s in 108.

pri
 a)
 … foinixqei\s qa/nh|. After qanei=n ga au)to
 ou)/ ti/ pw qe/lw (106), we should have had pri
 a)
 foinixqh=|. But the emphasis on ma/stigi prw=ton nw=ta foinixqei\s serves to excuse the presence of qa/nh|,—added, for the sake of greater clearness, after the long interval. So in Tr. 1130Hyllus says of Deianeira, te/qnhken, and then in 1133 Heracles, oi)/moi: pri
 w(s xrh=n sf' e)c e)mh=s qanei=n xero/s; where the stress on th=s e)mh=s similarly palliates the illogical form of the sentence.
foinixqei\s: Eur. Hec. 153foinissome/nhn ai(/mati. Ar. Ach. 320katacai/nein to\n a)/ndra tou=ton ei)s foiniki/da.
ai)ki/sh|: cp. O. T. 1153mh\ dh=ta, pro\s qew=n, to\n ge/ronta/ m' ai)ki/sh|.

xai/rein … s' e)fi/emai. It seems best to suppose that the constr. is e)fi/emai xai/rein de, ‘It is my injunction that thou have thy will in all else.’ Cp. O. T. 1054 f. o(/ntin' a)rti/ws | molei=n e)fie/mesqa: where the acc. similarly belongs to the inf. There is no example of e)fi/emai/ tina (instead of tini) poiei=n ti: though we find in Tr. 1221tosou=ton dh/ s' e)piskh/ptw, like keleu/w tina/ ti. Nor does the sense here require that se should be the object of e)fi/emai.—Remark the objection to rendering e)fi/emai here ‘I desire’: when the verb has that sense, with an inf., its subject is the same as that of the inf.: e.g. Phil. 1315w(=n de/ sou tuxei=n e)fi/emai, | a)/kouson. Further, the sense, ‘enjoin,’ ‘command,’ better suits the insane u(/bris of Ajax.
xai/rein … ta)/lla, to have her pleasure, i.e., to have her commands obeyed, in all other things: schol. e)fi/emai/ se ei)s ta\ a)/lla keleu/ein moi kai\ xai/rein w(s peiqome/nou mou.
su\ s' ou)=n: for this use of ou)=n with pron. and imperat., cp. 961: O. T. 669o( d' ou)=n i)/tw: Ar. Ach. 185oi( d' e)di/wkon ka)bo/wn. | *d*i. oi( d' ou)=n bow/ntwn.

te/ryis h(/de soi to\ dra=n: the inf. (with art. added, as oft., O. C. 47 n.) is in apposition with te/ryis h(/de: ‘since this is thy pleasure,—even to do (thus).’ Instead of te/ryis soi to\ dra=n to/de, the defining pron. has been assimilated to te/ryis: cp. Tr. 483h(/marton, ei)/ ti th/nd) (instead of to/d)) a(marti/an le/geis (n.).

xrw= xeiri/, fei/dou k.t.l.: the asyndeton adds vigour to the command: cp. 811 xwrw=men, e)gkonw=men: 844 geu/esqe, mh\ fei/desqe: 988 i)/q), e)gko/nei, su/gkamne: Eur. Hec. 1044a)/rasse, fei/dou mhde/n.
mhde\n, adv.: w(=n=tou/twn a(/: so Eur. Med. 400fei/dou mhde\n w(=n e)pi/stasai.

tou=to soi\ d' e)fi/emai. The emphasis on tou=to warrants the place of de/, which often, indeed, comes third in a sentence, or even later; cp. 169: O. T. 485o(/ ti le/cw d' a)porw=: Aesch. P. V. 399dakrusi/stakton a)p' o)/sswn r(adinw=n d' ei)bome/na r(e/os: Eur. fr. 776 deino/n ge, toi=s ploutou=si tou=to d' e)/mfuton.
o(ra=|s..th\n … i)sxu\n o(/sh: cp. 103.
th\n qew=n i)sxu\n: for the absence of a second art., cp. 664 h( brotw=n paroimi/a: Ant. 10tw=n e)xqrw=n kaka/ (n.).

ti/s a)
 hu(re/qh, ‘who could have been found?’ the potential aor. indic. with a)/n: cp. Ant. 502po/qen kle/os g' a)
 eu)klee/steron | kate/sxon...; Dem. or. 37 § 57 pw=s a)
..e)gw/ ti/ se h)di/khsa;
pronou/steros. The Homeric Ajax, though not subtle in thought or speech, has robust good sense: as Hector says ( Il. 7. 288), *ai)=an, e)pei/ toi dw=ke qeo\s me/geqo/s te bi/hn te | kai\ pinuth/n.
dra=n … ta\ kai/ria: cp. Shakesp. All's Well 1. 2. 26 He did look far | Into the service of the time, and was | Discipled of the bravest.

e)gw\ me
: me
