 merely emphasizes the pron.: cp. 455, Xen. Cyr. 1. 4. 12e)gw\ me
 ou)k oi)=da. e)/mpas, followed by kai/per and a participle; Il. 24. 523a)/lgea d' e)/mphs | e)n qumw=| katakei=sqai e)a/somen, a)xnu/menoi/ per. Cp. 563.

a)/th| sugkate/zeuktai: the more ordinary word would have been sune/zeuktai, but metre has prompted the double compound, which recurs only in later Greek. The kata/ adds the idea of a constraining force: cp. Plutarch Camill. 2 tou\s a)ga/mous lo/gois te pei/qonta kai\ zhmi/ais a)peilou=nta sugkatazeu=cai (constrain into marriage with) tai=s xhreuou/sais gunaici/. Eur. Hipp. 1389oi(/a| cumfora=| sunezu/ghs. Eur. Andr. 98sterro/n te to\n e)mo\n dai/mon' w(=| sunezu/ghn.
ou)de\n to\ tou/tou k.t.l. The swfrosu/nh of Odysseus finds similar expression at 1365 (kai\ ga\r au)to\s e)nqa/d' i(/comai).
ei)/dwl' … skia/n. As unreal as phantoms; as unsubstantial as shadows. Cp. fr. 12 a)/nqrwpo/s e)sti pneu=ma kai\ skia\ mo/non, | ei)/dwlon a)/llws.
au)to\s: as Ajax had done more than once (766—775).
o)/gkon, ‘pomp,’ Tr. 817.Cp. Shakesp. Merch. 1. 1. 124 showing a more swelling port | Than my faint means would grant continuance.

a)/rh|, ‘take upon thee,’ ‘assume’: subjunct. of 1st aor. h)ra/mhn (not of 2nd aor. h)ro/mhn, which would have a^). The sense of h)ra/mhn is usu. ‘to take up’ or ‘take upon one,’ rarely ‘to win,’ which is the regular sense of h)ro/mhn. See Appendix on 75.— a)/rh|s (from 1st aor. act. h)=ra) has inferior MS. authority, and is also less suitable in sense: it would mean, ‘lift up,’ ‘exalt.’
bri/qeis, ‘art weighty,’ i.e. ‘powerful’: cp. Pind. N. 3. 40suggenei= de/ tis eu)doci/a| me/ga bri/qei.
makrou=, extensive, ‘large’: cp. 825: Tr. 1217xa/rin braxei=an pro\s makroi=s a)/llois didou/s.

plou/tou ba/qei: cp. Tyrtaeus fr. 12. 6 ploutoi/h de\ *mi/dew kai\ *kinu/rew ba/qion (so Camerarius: ma/lion G. M. Schmidt): Pind. O. 13. 63baqu
 kla=ron (‘a rich domain’): Suppl. 555 baqu/plouton xqo/na (referring to soil): Eur. fr. 453 *ei)rh/na baqu/ploute: Callim. Cer. 114 to
 baqu
 oi)=kon (‘opulent’): Aelian V. H. 3. 18 e)n ei)rh/nh| te dia/gein kai\ plou/tw| baqei=. Indeed, baqu/s could be said (like paxu/s) of a rich man: Xen. Oec. 11. 10baqei=s te kai\ e)rrwme/nous a)/ndras, ‘men of substance and power.’—The feeble v.l. ba/rei (cr. n.) was prompted by bri/qeis.
h(me/ra: cp. 475: Pind. P. 8. 95 e)pa/meroi: ti/ de/ tis; ti/ d' ou)/ tis; skia=s o)/nar | a)/nqrwpos.
kli/nei: the image is from depressing the scale of a balance: Il. 19. 223e)ph\n kli/nh|si ta/lanta | *zeu/s.

ka)na/gei: so Ph. 866ka)na/gei ka/ra. Cp. Ant. 1158tu/xh ga\r o)rqoi= kai\ tu/xh katarre/pei | to\n eu)tuxou=nta to/n te dustuxou=nt' a)ei/. Eur. fr. 420 o(ra=|s tura/nnous dia\ makrw=n hu)chme/nous | w(s mikra\ ta\ sfa/llonta, kai\ mi/) h(me/ra | ta\ me\n kaqei=len u(yo/qen, ta\ d' h)=r' a)/nw.

kakou/s (which has needlessly been suspected, cr. n.) is interpreted by vv. 127 ff., and more immediately by the contrast with tou\s sw/fronas: it means those who, like Ajax, are led into dusse/beia by overweening self-reliance or pride.

div2.p: Parodos, in two main parts, viz., (1) 134—171, the anapaestic marching-song, or parodos proper, sung by the Chorus as they enter; (2) 172— 200, the lyric ode, sung after they have taken up their position in the orchestra.

This is the form of Parodos used by Aeschylus in the Persae, the Supplices, and the Agamemnon. Nearest to this early and simple form is that in which lyric strophes are intermingled with anapaestic systems. A parodos of the latter type is found in the Prometheus Vinctus, the Antigone, and the Philoctetes.
The anapaestic march consists here of 38 verses; in the Aeschylean Supplices, of 40. It is much longer in the Persae (64 vv.), and in the Agamemnon (63).

The Chorus of fifteen Salaminian sailors enter the orchestra from the spectator's right (as they come from their quarters in the Greek camp). They march in three files (stoi=xoi) of five men each. At the close of the anapaests (v. 171), they form themselves in three ranks (zuga/) of five each, facing the proscenium.
It can scarcely be doubted that the anapaests were chanted by the whole Chorus, and not by the coryphaeus alone (see MA. üller, Gr. Bühnenalterthümer, p. 217, n. 2).

div3.p: *telamw/nie pai=: Il. 13. 67*telamw/nion ui(o/n. The followers of Ajax call upon him to come forth from his tent, —where, for some days previously, he had remained in sullen seclusion (194 f.), —and to refute this dire rumour of his onslaught on the cattle. Surely it is a malignant slander. Or is it possible that some angry deity has driven him to such a deed? Assuredly it is abhorrent from his own nature.

*salami=nos (defining gen.)..ba/qron, the pedestal, or firm seat, consisting of Salamis. The island itself is the ba/qron: this is clear from 859 f. w)= gh=s i(ro
 oi)kei/as pe/don | *salami=nos, w)= patrw=|on e(sti/as ba/qron. Just so in Ph. 1000, e(/ws a)
 h)=| moi gh=s to/d' ai)peino
 ba/qron, ‘while I have this craggy Lemnos beneath my feet.’

th=s a)mfiru/tou *salami=nos … a)gxia/lou: for the place of the second epithet, see n. on O. T. 1199ta\n gamyw/nuxa parqe/non | xrhsmw|do/n. While th=s a)mfiru/tou would suggest to an Athenian the narrow strait, so familiar to his sight, which divides Salamis from the Attic mainland, the second epithet, a)gxia/lou, would, as it were, turn his eyes seaward, inviting him to look forth from the shore of Salamis itself towards the Saronic Gulf. Each adjective lends a touch to the picture. This is thoroughly Greek. See, for instance, I. A. 164 e)/molon a)mfi\ parakti/an ya/maqon *au)li/dos e)nali/as, the sandy sea-shore of Aulis by the waves: Helen. 400 e)p' oi)=dma po/ntion glaukh=s a(lo/s,—where the blue expanse, the surge, and the depths beneath it (po/ntion) are all suggested.

a)gxi/alos was properly said of a place on the sea-coast ( Il. 2. 640*xalki/da t' a)gxi/alon). In Aesch. Pers. 888 it is a mere general epithet for islands (Lemnos, Icaros, etc.). Here, in the Athenian poet's mind, it has its proper sense, for he is thinking of Salamis as a fringe of the Attic coast; and it is again the Athenian's point of view which interprets the true relation of a)gxia/lou to a)mfiru/tou.
e)/xwn: cp. Pind. N. 4. 48*ai)/as *salami=n' e)/xei patrw/|an.

se\ me
 eu)= pra/ssont' e)pixai/rw: for the acc., expressing the object of joy, cp. Ph. 1314h(/sqhn pate/ra to
 a)mo
 eu)logou=nta/ se: Eur. Hipp. 1339tou\s ga eu)sebei=s qeoi\ | qnh/|skontas ou) xai/rousi: Rhes. 390 xai/rw de/ s' eu)tuxou=nta.
plhgh\ *dio\s (cp. 279), suggested by his long inaction (194 f.). Cp. Il. 12. 37*dio\s ma/stigi dame/ntes.
zamenh\s, ‘vehement’; a word not found in Il.or Od., but which occurs in Hom. hymn. Merc. (307), and is frequent with Pindar; thus fr. 231 to/lma..zamenh/s.
lo/gos … kako/qrous, like Tr. 791duspa/reunon le/ktron, O. T. 518bi/ou..tou= makrai/wnos: cp. 709.
e)pibh=| with acc. is rare; but cp. O. T. 1299ti/s s), w)= tlh=mon, | prose/bh mani/a; Eur. Andr. 491e)/ti se, po/tnia, | metatropa\ tw=nd' e)/peisin e)/rgwn.
pefo/bhmai, a form found in Il. 10. 510(pefobhme/nos), and often in Attic prose; it is emphatic (=‘thoroughly scared’).
pthnh=s here suggests timorous flight; cp. Il. 5. 778trh/rwsi peleia/sin i)/qmaq' o(moi=ai.
o)/mma pelei/as, since fear or anguish is seen in the eye; cp. Tr. 527a)mfinei/khton o)/mma nu/mfas (n.). O. C. 729o(rw= tin' u(ma=s o)mma/twn ei)lhfo/tas | fo/bon newrh=.

th=s nu=n fqime/nhs nukto\s, thus placed at the beginning of the sentence, indicates the time to which the whole following statement refers. As the rumours began only at daylight, the reference is, in strictness, to the moment denoted by e)piba/nt' — o)le/sai.
e)pi\ dusklei/a|, for, tending to, our disgrace; cp. Her. 1. 68e)pi\ kakw=|, Her. 4. 164e)pi\ diafqorh=|.

to
 i(ppomanh= leimw=n), the plain ‘wild with horses,’ i.e., on which great numbers of horses (out at pasture) disport themselves. In Il. 20. 221Erichthonius, son of Dardanus, is described as keeping great droves of horses on the moist meadow-lands near the lower spurs of Ida: tou= trisxi/liai i(/ppoi e(/los ka/ta boukole/onto. Sophocles used the word karpomanh/s (fr. 591), doubtless in a sense parallel with that of u(lomanh/s, i.e. ‘abounding in fruit’: and the sense which he attached to leimw
 i(ppomanh/s was probably leimw
 o(\s mai/netai i(/ppois rather than e)n w(=| i(/ppoi mai/nontai. But the idea of wild abundance would naturally, in this case, be blended with that of the horses frisking or galloping in freedom on the plain. Hence the difference made by the verbal analysis which we prefer is not one which much affects the picture. —See Appendix.

bota\ kai\ lei/an: a hendiadys, =bota\ dori/lhpta: cp. El. 36a)spi/dwn te kai\ stratou= (=stratou= w(plisme/nou): Eur. Bacch. 919*qh/bas kai\ po/lism' e(pta/stomon. We might, indeed, understand bota\ of the sheep, and lei/an of the oxen (cp. 53 n.): but that seems less fitting here. loiph\=a)/dastos. See on 53.

ai)/qwni sidh/rw|, the Homeric phrase ( Il. 4. 485, Il. 7. 473, Il. 20. 372). This epithet, ‘flashing,’ is given also to other objects of bright metal, as a le/bhs or a tri/pous ( Il. 9. 123, Il. 24. 233).
yiqu/rous: Pind. P. 2. 75oi(=a yiqu/rwn pala/mais (the arts of slanderers) e(/pet' ai)ei\ brotw=n. (Ep. Rom. i. 30 yiqurista/s, katala/lous.)

pa=sin *)odussei/s. L has pa/ntwn o)dusseu/s, and it is possible that (as Nauck thinks) the poet wrote pa/ntwn *)oduseu/s. (Euripides has that Homeric form in anapaests, Hec. 143h(/cei d' *)oduseu\s o(/son ou)k h)/dh.) But it seems improbable, seeing that the short form occurs nowhere else in Sophocles, though he uses the name some twenty-five times. On the other hand, a transcriber might easily have written the gen. pa/ntwn after w)=ta, by mistake for the less usual dative.

eu)/peista has the best authority here, but is otherwise known only from Aristotle. In Eth. N. 7. 10 (p. 1151 b 10) eu)/peistos, o(/tan tu/xh|, e)/stai o( e)gkrath/s, it means, ‘easy to persuade,’ as opp. to du/speistos. But in another place ( Arist. peri\ a)to/mwn grammw=n, p. 969 b 22), the words eu)/peiston o(/ti a)na/gkh k.t.l. mean, ‘it is easy to show,’ etc. As we can say, pei/qw tina/ ti, it is natural that eu)/peistos should be capable of both senses. Here eu)/peista will be, ‘things of which it is easy to persuade the hearer.’ It has more point than eu)/pista, since it implies the skill of the calumniator. Cp. fr. 786 taxei=a peiqw\ tw=n kakw=n o(doiporei=.

tou= le/cantos, not, of course, Odysseus, but simply the man from whom o( klu/wn heard the story. The slander mobilitate viget, viresque acquirit eundo (Aen. 4. 175). As it spreads and gains in strength, the spiteful joy of each new hearer is greater than that of his informant.

a)/xesin kaqubri/zwn: for the dat., cp. Her. 1. 212trithmori/di tou= stratou= katubri/sas: Paus. 4. 27. 3kaqubri/santes tw=n *dioskou/rwn th=| qusi/a|. Similarly Her. 3. 37tw=| a)ga/lmati katege/lase.
tw=n … mega/lwn yuxw=n, those diotrefei=s basilei=s like Ajax, who, in the true Homeric spirit, are conceived as mega/qumoi, megalo/yuxoi above common men.
i(ei\s with gen., like other verbs of ‘aiming at’: Ant. 1034toceu/et' a)ndro\s tou=de: Eur. Cycl. 51r(i/yw pe/tron sou.
a(ma/rtois (cr. n.), the original reading in L, seems better, as being simpler and clearer, than a(ma/rtoi, though tis could, of course, be easily supplied from the next clause.
kata\ d' a)/n tis e)mou=: for the separation of kata\ from its case, cp. 969.
to\n e)/xonq), the rich or great: Suppl. 240 oi( d' ou)k e)/xontes kai\ spani/zontes bi/ou.. | e)s tou\s e)/xontas ke/ntr' a)fia=sin kaka/. So Alc. 57, etc.

o( fqo/nos. Cp. Pind. N. 8. 22(of fqo/nos) a(/ptetai d' e)slw=n a)ei/, xeiro/nessi d' ou)k e)ri/zei. Trag.incert. frag. 547. 12 (ed. Nauck) pro\s ga\r to\ lampro\n o( fqo/nos bia/zetai (lia/zetai Wecklein).

pu/rgou r(u=ma, protection, garrison, for the city walls: O. T. 56w(s ou)de/n e)stin ou)/te pu/rgos ou)/tenau=s | e)/rhmos a)ndrw=n mh\ cunoikou/ntwn e)/sw. For r(u/esqai, ‘to defend,’ said with ref. to a town, cp. Il. 6. 403e)ru/eto *)/ilion *(/ektwr: O. T. 72th/nde r(usai/mhn po/lin.—Not, ‘tower of defence.’
meta\ expresses alliance, and u(po/, service; but there is no stress on the difference of relationships.

o)rqoi=q), have a fair course, be prosperous: cp. Ant. 675tw=n d' o)rqoume/nwn | sw/|zei ta\ polla\ sw/maq' h( peiqarxi/a (n.).—Some suppose an allusion to building. The small stones, filling the interstices, keep the large stones in their places: Legg. p. 902 E ou)de\ ga\r a)/neu smikrw=n tou\s mega/lous fasi\n oi( liqolo/goi li/qous eu)= kei=sqai. ‘Great without small Make a bad wall,’ Donaldson, New Crat. § 455. The simple words do not warrant this fancy.

tou/twn gnw/mas, maxims, precepts, concerning these things. prodida/skein properly implies gradual teaching ( Plat. Gorg.p. 489 D, prao/tero/n me prodi/daske), and is fitting here because the truths are elementary.
toiou/twn, ‘so foolish,’ referring to tou\s a)noh/tous: cp. 218, 251, 562, 929.

a)pale/casqai: this form is quoted by Hesychius from the poet's lost Hipponoos ( Soph. fr. 282). In Soph. O. T. 171a)le/cetai is a fut.: which, like this aor., seems to come from a stem a)lek rather than from a)lec (whence the pres. a)le/cw): see n. there.

a)ll' o(/te ga\r dh\ … pth/ceian a)/fwnoi. The most probable account of this passage is that d) should be inserted after ai)gupio\n in 169 (cr. n.). ‘We can do nothing without thee;—no (we are helpless), for, when they have escaped thine eye, they chatter like flocking birds; but (de/) terrified by the mighty vulture, perchance they will suddenly cower,’ etc. Note these points:—

(1) a)lla\ prefaces a confirmation of the statement just made in a negative form (165 ou)de\n sqe/nomen): cp. El. 307e)n ou)=n toiou/tois ou)/te swfronei=n, fi/lai, | ou)/t' eu)sebei=n pa/restin, a)ll' e)/n toi kakoi=s | pollh/ )st' a)na/gkh ka)pithdeu/ein kaka/.

(2) a)lla\ … ga\r is elliptical; ‘No (we can do nothing), for’ etc.: cp. El. 223a)ll' e)n ga\r deinoi=s ou) sxh/sw k.t.l., ‘but (ye speak in vain), for’ etc.: Ant. 155a)ll' o(/de ga\r dh\.. | xwrei=, ‘but (let us cease), for’ etc.

(3) The reading me/gan ai)gupio\n d' u(podei/santes, which allows the words me/gan ai)gupio\n to begin the clause describing the sudden discomfiture of the foes, gives those words a signal force and spirit. They become much tamer, if, deleting u(podei/santes and the stop after a)ge/lai, we place a comma after ai)gupio/n, and govern it by a)podra=sai supplied from a)pe/dran.

(4) This reading is confirmed by the fact that since u(podei/santes refers to the foes of Ajax (and not, as the schol. took it, to the birds), there is a change from simile to metaphor: the ‘vulture’ is Ajax. This is quite in the manner of Sophoclean imagery: cp. n. on Ant. 117 ff.— For other views, see Appendix.
o(/te … dh\, epic, ‘when now,’ ‘when at length,’ Od. 2. 314nu=n d' o(/te dh\ me/gas ei)mi/.
a)pe/dran, for a)pe/drasan ( Thuc. 1. 128), like the poetical e)/ban, e)/stan, e)/tlan, etc.
ai)gupio\n, an Homeric image: Od. 22. 302oi( d), w(/s t' ai)gupioi\ gamyw/nuxes a)gkuloxei=lai | e)c o)re/wn e)lqo/ntes e)p' o)rni/qessi qo/rwsi.

ta/x' a)\n can mean only ‘perchance’: we cannot take ta/xa separately, as=‘swiftly’; e)cai/fnhs should be taken with pth/ceian, notwithstanding Alcaeus fr. 27, which the poet clearly had in mind, e)/ptazon w(/st' o)/rniqes w)=kun | ai)/eton e)capi/nas fa/nenta.
sigh=| pth/ceian a)/fwnoi: sigh=| implies motionless awe; cp. Pind. P. 4. 57e)/ptacan d' a)ki/nhtoi siwpa=|. Cp. too the Homeric a)kh\n e)ge/nonto siwph=|.
The Chorus being now drawn up in the orchestra (134 n.), the lyric part of the Parodos begins. Strophe 172—182=antistr. 183—193: epode 194 —200. For metres, see Metrical Analysis.

h)= r(a/ se..; The Homeric h)= r(a is sometimes interrogative ( Il. 7. 446), but occurs also where there is no question (12. 164 h)= r(a/ nu). h)= r(a is interrogative in Pind. P. 9. 40, Pind. I. 7. 3: but not in Pind. P. 11. 38.This h)= is not the contracted form of the disjunctive h)e/ ( Il. 6. 378 f. h)e/ ...h)=), which was not used in direct question.
The sailors ask whether Artemis or Ares can have driven Ajax to such a deed. In connection with their chief, the deities of hunting and war naturally occur to them. They do not think of Athena.

*tauropo/la=*tauropo/los: for the form, cp. Pind. O. 3. 26*latou=s i(pposo/a quga/thr: Eur. Ion 1478*gorgofo/na. There were two cults of Artemis, originally quite distinct. (1) The *tauropo/los was a goddess who rules over bulls,—one of the numerous attributes of Artemis in her relation to wild animals: cp. ai)po/los, i(ppopo/los, oi)opo/los. A Macedonian silver coin (from Amphipolis) shows her riding on a prancing bull, and carrying a torch in either hand. On another coin she appears (with the inscr. *t*a*u*r*o*p*o*l*o*s) carrying two torches, and with the horns of a bull growing out of her shoulders: these horns were meant to suggest the crescent moon. The cult of the Tauropolos was purely Greek, and had nothing fierce or cruel about it. (2) The cult of Artemis *taurikh/ (or *taurw/) had orgiastic elements; it was of Asiatic origin, and belonged to a primitive stage of natureworship. The ritual was a bloody one, and in early times involved human sacrifice. This was the Artemis whose cult was said to have been brought to Brauron in Attica, from the Tauric Chersonese, by Iphigeneia and Orestes.

It is possible that Sophocles here was thinking only of the *tauropo/los proper, and names her simply because bulls had been among the victims of Ajax. On the other hand, the savage nature of the bloody onslaught might suggest that she was associated in his thought with the *taurikh/. Such an association occurs as early as I. T. 1457 where the Brauronian Artemis (e)pw/numon gh=s *taurikh=s, 1454) is called *tauropo/los. The dithyrambic poet Timotheus of Miletus (c. 400 B.C.) addressed the Ephesian Artemis as maina/da, quia/da, foiba/da, lussa/da (Bergk fr. 1). See Appendix.
*dio\s, (daughter) of Zeus: cp. 1302 *laome/dontos. But the art. (h() is prefixed to *dio\s in 401, 450.

mega/la refers primarily to the strength and loudness of the popular rumour (198 f.); but also suggests dread or horror, as when impious words are called mega/loi lo/goi ( Ant. 1350). Cp. 226 o( me/gas mu=qos.
ma=ter ai)sxu/nas e)ma=s: as peiqarxi/a is th=s eu)praci/as mh/thr ( Aesch. Theb. 224), etc. The boldness is somewhat like that of Soph. O. T. 157, w)= xruse/as te/knon *)elpi/dos, a)/mbrote *fa/ma.
panda/mous … bou=s, because they were still common property, lei/a a)/dastos: see on 54.
h)= pou, ‘I ween’: a phrase frequent in this play; cp. 382, 622, 850, 1008: Tr. 846.

ni/kas tino\s a)ka/rpwton xa/rin, on account of some victory (given by her to Ajax) which brought her no karpo/s, no reward; h)/ r(a … yeusqei=sa e)na/rwn, either, it may be, because she was disappointed of spoils; ei)/t' a)dw/rois e)lafaboli/ais, or by reason of deer-slaying after which he made no dw=ra to her. The general cause, denoted by ni/kas.. xa/rin, is divided into two special cases; (1) a victory in war; (2) a victory in hunting. [This is simpler than to suppose that ni/kas..xa/rin refers to the withholding of a public offering,—which Ajax ought to have made on behalf of those who fought under his command; and that e)na/rwn refers to a private vow, which he had made on his own account. On this view, three different causes would be indicated; and h)= pou in 176 would be disjunctive,—‘either, I ween,’—as it is in Od. 13. 234.]

ni/kas a)ka/rpwton xa/rin=ni/kas..a)karpw/tou xa/rin ( Ant. 793 f. nei=kos a)ndrw=n cu/naimon): cp. I. T. 566 kakh=s gunaiko\s xa/rin a)/xarin a)pw/leto. Legg. p. 853 D w(=n dh\ xa/rin ou)k e)pi/xarin le/goim a)\n..no/mon. (Others take xa/rin as acc. of respect with yeusqei=sa: ‘disappointed as to the tribute,’ etc.)
h)/ r(a: the disjunctive h)\ (or h)==h)e/) is rarely thus followed by r(a. (Cp. 172 n.) For h)\ … ei)/te, cp. Eur. Alc. 114h)\ *luki/as | ei)/t' e)pi\ ta\s a)nu/drous | *)ammwni/das e(/dras.
klutw=n: cp. the Homeric kluta\ teu/xea.
yeusqei=sa with gen.: cp. 1382: Tr. 712ei)/ ti mh\ yeusqh/somai | gnw/mhs.

a)dw/rois … e)lafaboli/ais: for the causal dat., cp. Tr. 1127toi=s ge pro/sqen h(marthme/nois (n.). Those who retain the MS. reading dw/rois understand: ‘deceived either by gifts of spoils (promised, but not given), or in regard to slaying of deer.’ (Nauck, reading the genitive e)lafaboli/as, take dw/rois with that also.) But this is awkward. And, in support of a)dw/rois, it should be noted that Sophocles elsewhere also has co-ordinated a causal dat. with a partic. (or adj.) of causal force, like yeusqei=sa here. See Tr. 239*d*h. eu)ktai=a fai/nwn, h)\ )po\ mantei/as tino/s; *l*i. eu)xai=s (‘for a vow’). O. C. 333*o*i. po/tera po/qoisi; *i*s. kai\ lo/gwn g' au)ta/ggelos.
e)lafaboli/ais: Artemis the huntress (*)agrote/ra) was especially *)elafhbo/los: see on O. C. 1092 f., and cp. Tr. 213*)/artemin *)ortugi/an e)lafabo/lon.

The causes here conjectured for her wrath remind us of her anger with Oeneus, who had failed to render firstfruits at harvest-tide ( Il. 9. 534xwsame/nh, o(/ oi( ou)/ ti qalu/sia gounw=| a)lwh=s | *oi)neu\s r(e/c)). Cp. Eur. Hipp. 147 where the Chorus suggest that the Cretan Dictynna may be wroth with Phaedra, as a)ni/eros a)qu/twn pela/nwn (for having failed to make holy offerings of honey-cakes).

h)\..*mh\..; The reading of the MSS., h)\ xalkoqw/rac h)/ tin) *)enua/lios, was explained by supposing that xalkoqw/rac meant Ares, as distinguished from Enyalios (so the schol. here). How the second h)/ should be corrected, is uncertain. (1) In favour of mh/, it may be noted that the interrogative mh/ is often followed, as here, by tis, and that its tone of tentative suggestion is just in place. Cp. Od. 9. 405 f. h)= mh/ ti/s seo mh=la brotw=n a)e/kontos e)lau/nei; h)= mh/ ti/s s' au)to\n ktei/nei do/lw| h)e\ bi/hfi; O. C. 1502mh/ tis *dio\s kerauno/s, h)/ tis o)mbri/a | xa/laz) e)pirra/casa; (2) Another possibility is dh/, as=‘then’ (to make a last guess). (3) soi/ would be fitting, indeed, but would require us to suppose that the second h)/ in the MSS. is an inadvertent repetition of the first, not a corruption of some word like itself. (4) ei)/ has also been suggested. But the implied construction, momfa\n e)/xwn, ei)/ tin) (ei)=xen), would be too harsh. (5) h)= is condemned by the fact that with Sophocles this interrogative h)= regularly stands first in its clause; only a vocative sometimes precedes it: see on Ant. 1281.

*)enua/lios is in the Iliad either the War-god (2. 651), seemingly identical with Ares, or an epithet of Ares (17. 211 *)/arhs | deino\s e)nua/lios). Like *)enuw/, the word is of uncertain (possibly Thracian) origin. The mention of this deity has a two-fold fitness here; (1) on account of the reference in 178 to Artemis Agrotera; for, acc. to Pollux 8. 91, the Athenian Polemarch made annual offerings *)arte/midi) *agrote/ra| kai\ tw=| *)enuali/w|: (2) because in the island-home of Ajax there was a i(ero/n of Enyalios, founded by Solon to commemorate the victory by which Athens wrested Salamis from the Megarians ( Plut. Sol. 9). Further, Enyalios is here supposed to have helped Ajax; whereas Ares usually favoured the Trojans (cp. Il. 20. 38). As to the Attic relationship between the two deities, see Appendix.

momfa
 e)/xwn=memfo/menos: Eur. Or. 1069e(
 me
 prw=ta/ soi momfh
 e)/xw: so Aesch. P. V. 445me/myin ou)/tin' a)nqrw/pois e)/xwn.

cunou= doro\s, causal gen.: cp. 41 n., and Il. 1. 93ou)/t' a)/r' o(/ g' eu)xwlh=s e)pime/mfetai ou)/q) e(kato/mbhs. cunou= here=‘making common cause with him,’ ‘allied’; cp. Eur. Tro. 58pro\s sh\n a)fi=gmai du/namin, w(s koinh\n la/bw. (The word may have been suggested by Il. 18. 309cuno\s *)enua/lios, though there the sense is, ‘The war-god is impartial.’)

e)nnuxi/ois maxanai=s, by devices against Ajax in the night,—i.e., by impelling him to the nocturnal onslaught.—This seems to be the only instance in Tragedy (except Aesch. Theb. 132maxana=|) where the Doric form of a word from the st. mhxan has good support from our MSS. But this fact does not warrant G. Wolff's view that the form in h was alone used by the tragic dramatists.
e)tei/sato, not e)ti/sato, was the Attic spelling in the poet's age: see Meisterhans, Gramm. Att. Inschr., § 43.

freno/qen g), by the prompting of thine own mind,—if it had not been deranged by some god. Schol. oi)/koqen (=in virtue of thine own qualities), a)po\ oi)kei/as gnw/sews. The emphasis given by ge shows that this is the meaning.—Not e)p' a)ristera\ freno/qen (as=frenw=n), ‘to the leftward of thy mind’: nor, ‘went from good sense (=a)po\ frenw=n) into folly.’

e)p' a)ristera\ … e)/bas, deviating from the right course: Aesch. P. V. 883e)/cw de\ dro/mou fe/romai lu/sshs | pneu/mati ma/rgw|. Theognetus (a poet of the New Comedy), *fa/sma fr. 1. 7 e)pari/ster' e)/maqes, w)= ponhre/, gra/mmata (i.e., ‘to your misfortune’). Schneid. cp. Ennius Annales 208 Quo vobis mentes, rectae quae stare solebant | Antehac, dementes sese flexere viai?
to/sson: the only example, except Aesch. Ag. 140, of this form in Tragedy.
pi/tnwn, instead of w(/ste pi/tnein: cp. Ant. 752h)= ka)papeilw=n w(=d' e)pece/rxei qrasu/s; (‘doth thy boldness run to open threats?’)

h(/koi ga\r a)\n, ‘will’ (or ‘must’) ‘come’: cp. 88 me/noim' a)/n. The ga\r here refers to a thought implied in the last sentence:—‘You would never have done this thing of your own nature; (and if you have done it in madness, that proves nothing against your nature,) for heavensent madness cannot be helped; only, may the gods avert the evil rumour!’— i.e., ‘may it prove to be false.’
From verse 172 down to this point, the Chorus have been asking whether the rumour can be true. Now they pass to the alternative:—‘But if it is untrue, then up and refute it.’

*zeu\s … *foi=bos. Both gods are averters of evil, a)leci/kakoi, a)potro/paioi. But Zeus is invoked with especial fitness as being the source of mysterious voices and rumours ( Il. 8. 250e)/nqa panomfai/w| *zhni\ r(e/zeskon *)axaioi/).

u(poballo/menoi. The midd. u(poba/llesqai (paisi/on) was said of a woman who ‘secretly put to her breast’ the child of another, and passed it off as her own: Thesm. 564 th=s dou/lhs tekou/shs a)/rren, ei)=ta sauth=| | tou=q' u(peba/lou, to\ so\n de\ quga/trion parh=kas au)th=|. Cp. below, 481. Hence the metaphor here,—‘falsely suggesting’ stories, laying to thy charge things which thou hast not done.

kle/ptousi mu/qous, tell crafty tales: cp. 1137: Ph. 57to/d' ou)xi\ klepte/on, ‘this must not be represented falsely’: El. 37kle/yai..sfaga/s, i.e. to effect by stealth. Also ib. 56 lo/gw| kle/ptontes. The participle u(poballo/menoi closely coheres with kle/ptousi, and mu/qous depends on both.
oi( mega/loi basilh=s, the Atreidae. For the nom. in -h=s, cp. El. 690brabh=s (n.).
h)\ ta=s k.t.l.: supply basilh=s (or -eu\s) from the last clause.
a)sw/tou, profligate, worthless.

*sisufida=n. Anticleia, the mother of Odysseus, was said to have been with child by Sisyphus when she married Laertes: hence Ph. 417ou(mpolhto\s *sisu/fou *laerti/w|, the son of Sisyphus, bought (with e(/dna) by Laertes: see n. there, and on Ph. 625.

mh/, mh/ m), a)/nac. If m) be sound, it can be only the acc.: an elision of moi is impossible (see O. C. 1436, n. in Appendix). And me could be explained only as depending on the phrase kaka\n fa/tin a)/rh|, as meaning, ‘win an evil repute, to my injury’ (mh/ me diaba/lh|s, au)to\s diaballo/menos): cp. El. 123 ff. ta/keis..oi)mwga\n ..*)agame/mnona. But this is certainly forced; and, though the Chorus afterwards speak of themselves as involved in their chief's peril (252 ff.), that thought is less fitting here.

The simplest remedy is that which is proposed by Prof. v. Wilamowitz-Möllendorff (cr. n.), who, referring to the hiatus after a)/na in 193, would here omit m). The syllables mh/, mh/ m) answer metrically to momfa\n in 180, and we should thus have to suppose that mh/, mh/, a)/nac represents --u-. Such an hiatus seems a very doubtful one for tragic lyrics: otherwise the suggestion would be welcome, as mh/, mh/ is supported by O. C. 210mh/, mh/ m' a)ne/rh|. Morstadt's remedy, mh\ mhke/t), w)=nac, (instead of mh/, mh/ m), a)/nac, e)/q),) has found much favour, and is satisfactory in itself; but it does not account for the origin of the vulgate.

klisi/ais o)/mm' e)/xwn. The sense required is, ‘keeping thy face hidden in the tent’: so that klisi/ais is a locative dat. The adv. w(=d) helps to suggest the idea of ‘hidden.’ The objections to the version, ‘keeping thine eyes fixed on the tents,’ are, (1) that e)/xwn could not well stand for e)pe/xwn, and (2) that the seclusion of Ajax within his tent is not then expressed.— a)/rh| with a (=lw/ban in 181), from h)ra/mhn: cp. 129, and see Appendix on 75.
a)/na, the prep., with anastrophe, as=a)na/sthqi: the hiatus as in Il. 9. 247a)ll' a)/na, ei) me/mona/s ge.

o(/pou … pote/, ‘wheresoever,’ i.e. in whatever spot within the dwelling. The change of pote\ to poti\ (on which see Tr. 1214 n.) introduces a strange phrase, sthri/zei pro\s sxolh=|. The simple dat. (of circumstance) is clearly right.

a)gwni/w| sxola=| seems to mean, ‘battlepause,’ i.e., rest from battle. Other explanations are: (1) sxolh/ which causes an a)gw/n (discrimen); because, while Ajax rests, his foes are perilously active. Now, if the Chorus assumed that Ajax, while absent from battle, had been employed in other effort, then, indeed, they might call his rest a)gw/nios sxolh/, ‘a strenuous rest,’ like otium negotiosum. But it seems impossible that a)gw/nios sxolh/ should mean merely, his ‘perilous’ or ‘critical’ rest,—made so by the acts of others.

a)/tan ou)rani/an fle/gwn, ‘kindling a flame of ruin high as heaven,’ Whitelaw. Cp. Suppl. 808 i)/u+ze d' o)mfa\n ou)rani/an=ou)ranomh/kh: and see n. on Ant. 418.This is more forcible here than, ‘inflaming the heaven-sent plague’ (=qei/an: cp. 186).

a)ta/rbhta, neut. pl. as adverb. I keep this, the reading of the MSS., as Wecklein and Bellermann do. Dindorf strikes out w(=d) (unwarrantably), and writes a)ta/rbhtos. In an epode, the strophic test is absent, and the logaoedic metre admits of Dindorf's reading. There is, however, a point in favour of a)ta/rbhta which deserves to be noted; viz., that the adverbial neut. pl., though it has no special relation to verbs of motion, is, in fact, very often joined with such verbs; and that the phrase a)ta/rbhta o(rma=tai is therefore thoroughly consonant with poetical usage. See (e.g.) O. T. 883u(pe/ropta poreu/etai: O. C. 1695ou)/toi kata/mempt' e)/bhton: Il. 17. 75a)ki/xhta diw/kwn | i(/ppous: Pind. O. 7. 45bai/nei..a)te/kmarta: Soph. Ph. 1740a)parqe/neut' a)lwme/na: Eur. Bacch. 435ou)d' a)/kranq' w(rmh/samen. For the hiatus at the end of the verse, cp. 425 xqono\s molo/nt' a)po\ | *(ellani/dos.
eu)ane/mois, with a^ (not a_, as if Doric for eu)hne/mois): so probably in fr. 342 eu)ane/mou li/mnas. Cp. Od. 19. 432ptu/xas h)nemoe/ssas.
ba/ssais: O. C. 673xlwrai=s u(po\ ba/ssais (n.): Il. 21. 449*)/idhs e)n knhmoi=si poluptu/xou u(lhe/sshs.

kagxazo/ntwn. Dindorf writes kaxazo/ntwn, on the ground that the form kagxa/zw was not Attic. (His further change of pa/ntwn into a(pa/ntwn is merely for the sake of equalising this v. with 197 f.) The main facts are these. 1. Aristophanes uses kaxa/zwn once ( Eccl. 849), and also the noun kaxasmw=n (Nub. 1073). 2. It is true that kagxa/zw cannot be proved by metre from any verse earlier than that of Babrius (100. 8 kagxa/sas), and Paulus Silentiarius (6th cent.) in Anth. Pal. 6. 74. 3 (kagxa/zousa). 3. On the other hand the MSS. have a)neka/gxase in Plat. Rep. 337 A, and a)nakagxa/sas in Euthyd. 300 D; forms, be it noted, which carry their own commendation, since, in the compound with a)na/, the nasal (g before x) makes pronunciation easier. 4. Lastly, there is the analogy of the Homeric kagxala/w. Surely, then, there is no reason to doubt that Sophocles could have used kagxa/zw if he found it metrically convenient.

barua/lghta. I follow the MSS. in leaving the hiatus (cp. 196), which here has the special justification of a pause, making it needless to write barualgh/tws with Dindorf. That the scholiast in L, like the MSS., had the neut. pl., appears from his paraphrase, bare/a kai\ a)lgeina/. Some editors prefer to write barua/lght), which is also metrically possible. The sense is, ‘fraught with heavy pain’ to us; the a)/lgos is not the bitter indignation felt by the Greeks. The word occurs only here: and barualgh/s is post-classical.
e(/staken, ‘stands fixed’: cp. 1084.

div2.p: The first e)peiso/dion falls into two principal parts. In the first (201—332), the hero's plight is made clear by the exchange of tidings between Tecmessa and the Chorus, each learning what the other has to tell. In the second part (333—595), Ajax himself speaks with the Chorus and Tecmessa; his words foreshadow a resolve to die. The first part opens with a kommos between the Chorus and Tecmessa (201—262); the second, with a kommos between the Chorus and Ajax (348—429).

div3.p: vao\s a)rwgoi\, i.e., rendering service in it; Ajax addresses them as ge/nos nai+/as a)rwgo\n te/xnas (356). The Iliad (2. 557) assigns twelve ships to Ajax.
genea=s: for the gen., cp. Plat. Prot. 316B *)apollodw/rou ui(o/s, oi)ki/as mega/lhs.
xqoni/wn a)p' *)erexqeida=n: for a)po\ with ref. to descent, cp. Ant. 193pai/dwn tw=n a)p' *oi)di/pou.

Erechtheus, o( ghgenh/s ( Her. 8. 55), ‘whom Earth, the grain-giver, brought forth, and Athena, daughter of Zeus, fostered’ ( Il. 2. 547), is representative of the Athenian claim to be au)to/xqones. It was in his reign, acc. to Her. 8. 44, that the folk once called *kranaoi/, and then *kekropi/dai, were first named *)aqhnai=oi. For *)erexqei=dai as=*)aqhnai=oi, cp. Pind. I. 2. 19kleinai=s *)erexqeida=n xari/tessin a)rarw\s | tai=s liparai=s e)n *)aqa/nais, ‘having attained to the glorious honours given by the Erechtheidae in shining Athens.’ (In Soph. Ant. 981 f., however, the patronymic has a narrower sense, denoting merely the family of Erechtheus.) So, again, the Athenians are *qhsei=dai ( Soph. O. C. 1066), the Thebans *kadmei=oi, the Trojans or Romans Aeneadae; and an unknown poet (frag. adesp. 274) calls the Argives xqoni/ous *)inaxi/das, where Hesychius explains the adj. by au)to/xqonas kai\ ou)k e)ph/ludas,— the sense of xqoni/wn here. (Cp. O. C. 948 n.)
Salamis is in this play a kingdom independent of Athens, but the Salaminians are of Athenian stock, and revere ‘sacred Athens’ (1222) as the metropolis of their race. See Introduction, § 4.
thlo/qen instead of thlou=: cp. Tr. 315ge/nnhma tw=n e)kei=qen (n.). It goes with tou=..oi)/kou, not with khdo/menoi.

w)mokrath\s denotes the rugged, massive, untamed strength of Ajax, and is meant to suggest a contrast with his present affliction; so 548 w)moi=s..no/mois, 885 w)mo/qumos, 931 w)mo/frwn. (The word was absurdly taken by some to mean, ‘with strong shoulders,’—as the Iliad mentions his eu)re/as w)/mous, 3. 227.)

qolerw=| (qolo/s, o(, mud), ‘turbid,’ with ref. to his clouded mind: cp. Her. 4. 53(of a river) r(e/ei te kaqaro\s para\ qoleroi=si. So Aesch. P. V. 885qoleroi\ de\ lo/goi pai/oud' ei)kh=| | stugnh=s pro\s ku/masin a)/ths,—words turbid with passion.— xeimw=ni: cp. Soph. Ph. 1194a)lu/onta xeimeri/w| | lu/pa|: ib. 1460 xeimazome/nw|.
nosh/sas, ‘stricken’: this aor., in the ‘ingressive’ sense (‘fell ill’), is frequent in Attic: e.g. Thuc. 1. 138§ 4 nosh/sas teleuta=| to\n bi/on: Plat. Tim.p. 84 C o(/tan..nosh/sh|.

ti/ de\ ba/ros e)nh/llaktai nu\c h(/de th=s h(meri/as; ‘And what heaviness (heavy trouble) has the past night received in exchange for the (already grievous) fortune of the day?’ e)nh/llaktai in a midd. sense; cp. Diod. frag. 60 e)ge/neto basi/lissa i)diwtikh=s e(sti/as e)chllagme/nh h(gemoni/an. The fact that h)/llagmai has more often a passive sense in Attic is quite compatible with such an exceptional use; thus Antiphon can say, to
 plou=n pepoihme/nos (or. 5 § 21), and tetimwrhme/nos e(auto/n ( B. b. § 8). But it is more doubtful whether such a notion as moi/ras, pra/cews, or katasta/sews can here be supplied with th=s h(meri/as. The parallels adduced are such as h( e(w/|a, h( e(wqinh/, h( o)yi/a, h( prwi+/a, th
 qerei/hn (‘in summer,’ Her. 1. 189), th
 xeimerinh/n (id. 1. 202). There was indeed a tendency in Greek idiom to make substantives out of fem. adjectives; i.e. to use the fem. adj. alone, whenever the subst. (such as gh=, o(do/s, w(/ra, moi=ra, di/kh) could readily be understood. And that tendency must be considered here.

No tolerable emendation has been made. h)remi/as, ‘stillness,’ though possible, is very feeble. eu)mari/as (=eu)marei/as), which Nauck adopts, is directly contrary to the sense; for, even before the dread rumour arose, the Chorus had been disquieted by the long seclusion and inaction of Ajax (194 f.). a)mmori/as, without some further definition (such as th=s pri\n), would be too vague. And the words nu\c h(/de suggest that there was some mention of day. On the whole, the traditional reading, though difficult, is less open to objection than any remedy which has been proposed.

The schol. in L has: gr. de\ a)hmeri/as a)nti\ th=s a)hdou=s fora=s (‘unpleasant course’), kai\ e)/stai o( nou=s, poi=on ba/ros e)/laben au(/th h( nu\c a)po\ th=s prote/ras a)hdi/as; This explanation of a)hmeri/as by a)hdou=s fora=s and a)hdi/as indicates (I think) a reference, not to h(me/ra—as if a)hmeri/a could mean dushmeri/a—but to h(/meros: the original scholium may have had a)nhmeri/as (meant as ‘unkindly fortune’).

*frugi/ou *teleu/tantos. Cp. 331: 488. Similar examples confirm this reading: fr. 796 *)alfesi/boian h(\n o( gennh/sas path/r (it is improbable that Sophocles wrote *)alfhsi/boian): Aesch. Th. 488*(ippome/dontos sxh=ma: Suppl. 889 *parqenopai=os, ei)=dos e)coxw/tatos. ( Aesch. Th. 547, *parqenopai=os *)arka/s, is rejected by many critics.) Indeed, such license was not strictly confined to proper names, to judge by Aesch. Ch. 1049faioxi/twnes.
Lobeck remarks that the father of Tecmessa is called Teuthras by Malela and others, Tethras by Cedrenus, and Teuthas by Tzetzes.
le/xos, concubine, o(meune/tis (501): being douria/lwtos, she is dou/lh (489). Cp. Tr. 360kru/fion w(s e)/xoi le/xos (Iolè).

se … ste/rcas a)ne/xei: lit., ‘having conceived a love for thee, he upholds thee,’—i.e., ‘he is constant in his affection for thee’: so Eur. Hec. 123ba/kxhs a)ne/xwn le/ktr' *)agame/mnwn, ‘constant to’ her bed. (In Soph. O. C. 674, where to
 oi)nw=p' a)ne/xousa kisso
 is the common reading, we should probably read to
 oi)nwpo
 e)/xousa kisso/n.)
u(pei/pois, ‘hint,’ ‘give a clue’: they do not yet surmise, from her words in 205—207, with what terrible fulness of detail she can speak.
le/gw, subjunct.
qana/tw| … i)/son: O. C. 529qa/natos me\n ta/d' a)kou/ein. In the Creusa, fr. 332, Sophocles used i)soqa/naton as=ou) pa/nu a)nekto/n, acc. to Pollux 6. 174.
mani/a| ga\r: notice the ga/r in two successive clauses ( El. 180 n.): here it prefaces the statement ( O. T. 277 n.).— h(mi\n, ethic dat.: El. 272.

nu/kteros, adverbial: cp. 930 pa/nnuxa kai\ fae/qont' a)neste/nazes. Il. 1. 497h)eri/h d' a)ne/bh. The word is irregularly placed, as if the speaker had meant to designate Ajax by o( kleino\s only, and had then added *ai)/as: for similar irregularities, cp. El. 693 f., n.
a)pelwbh/qh, a somewhat rare pass. aor.: Ph. 330e)celwbh/qhn: Plat. Gorg. 473 C lw/bas..lwbhqei/s.
toiau=t), introducing the ground for the statement; cp. 164 n.— ai(mobafh=: cp. 95 e)/bayas e)/gxos eu)=..;

xrhsth/ria, with tragic pathos, since the word denoted holy sacrifices to the gods (properly, before consulting an oracle): Aesch. Theb. 230sfa/gia kai\ xrhsth/ria | qeoi=sin e)/rdein. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 645paia=na to/nd' *erinu/wn.
A strophe, to which vv. 245—256 form the antistrophe. For the metres, see Metrical Analysis.
a)ne/ros … a)ggeli/an: for the objective gen., cp. 998: Ant. 11mu=qos.. fi/lwn (n.).

ai)/qonos, ‘fiery’; cp. 1088: Aesch. Theb. 448ai)/qwn..lh=ma: in v. 147 the word is applied to a bright sword. This inflexion (instead of ai)/qwnos) occurs elsewhere only in Hes. Op. 361ai)/qona limo/n (Bergk's correction of the MS. ai)/qopa), a reading which is made certain by Aeschin. or. 3 § 184 limo/n t' ai)/qwna kratero/n t' e)pa/gontes *)/arha, and Callim. Hymn. Cer. 68 e)/mbale limo/n, | ai)/qwna, kratero/n: where the fig. sense of the epithet is ‘fierce.’

The v.l. ai)/qopos is impossible here, as in the verse of Hesiod; it could refer only to complexion. Cp. Eustathius p. 862. 10 fe/retai ai)/qwn bou=s kai\ si/dhros kai\ a)/nqrwpos kai\ le/wn: ai)/qoy de\ ou)dei\s au)tw=n le/goit' a)/n, a)lla\ tou)/noma oi)/nw| me/lani e)piti/qetai. The variant was doubtless due, in both passages, to the rarity, for ai)/qwn, of the inflexion with o: which is illustrated by the dat. pl. nh/fosi in Theognis 481, and by such alternative forms of the gen. as *ai)/sonos, *)aktai/onos, etc.
a)/tlaton ou)de\ feukta/n, unendurable, and yet one from which there is no escape: for ou)de/ as=a)ll' ou), cp. El. 132, El. 1034.

tw=n mega/lwn *danaw=n are clearly not the Greek chiefs (oi( mega/loi basilh=s, 189), but the Greek army at large. It is the popular fury that the Salaminians are now thinking of: in 228 peri/fantos..qanei=tai alludes to public stoning, the liqo/leuston *)/arh of v. 253.
klh|zome/nan, noised abroad by them: cp. Tr. 659klh/|zetai quth/r, he is rumoured to be sacrificing; and ib. 1268 klh|zo/menoi | pate/res.
o( me/gas mu=qos: cp. 173 w)= mega/la fa/tis (n.).
a)e/cei, au)/cei, increases by diffusing it. (Not, ‘exaggerates.’)
peri/fantos: cp. 1311 qanei=n prodh/lws.
parapla/ktw|, frantic: Eur. H. F. 935ge/lwti parapeplhgme/nw|. The adj. is more usually paraplh/c. Cp. 40 duslo/giston..xe/ra.

sugkatakta\s, slain in a confused heap, cattle and men together. (In Eur. Or. 1089sugkate/ktanon=‘helped to slay.’) For the nonthematic aor., cp. Soph. Tr. 38e)/kta (n.).— kelainoi=s here suggests both the dark, gleaming metal, and the dark stains of blood upon it. Cp. Soph. Tr. 856kelaina\ lo/gxa (n.).

ci/fesin, poet. plur.: cp. Pind. P. 4. 242 *fri/cou ma/xairai: Eur. Ion 192a(/rpais (the scimitar of Perseus). The dat. ci/fesin, following xeri/, defines the instrument used (slain by the hand with the sword): cp. 310 o)/nuci sullabw\n xeri/. Eur. Helen. 373 o)/nuxi..ge/nun | e)/deuse foini/aisi plagai=s.

i(pponw/mas, ‘guiding horses,’ refers to riding in both the other places where it occurs ( Eur. Hipp. 1399, of Hippolytus; Nub. 571, of Poseidon Hippius). Here, both=ras, closely following bota/, must mean the herdsmen who tended the sheep and oxen (=poimni/wn e)pista/tais, 27). It would be forced, then, to suppose that i(pponw/mas means ‘tending horses,’—with ref. to the horses of the Greeks on the leimw\n i(ppomanh/s (143 f.). That would be as if one said, ‘the cattle, and their herdsmen, who also tended horses.’ Herdsmen in charge of great flocks and herds, on a wide plain, and near a watchful foe, might well be mounted. It is no objection— and least of all, in an Attic tragedy— that the Homeric warrior does not ride. —The reading i(pponw/mas, instead of i(ppono/mous (‘horse-feeding’), is made certain by metre (v. 245), and is confirmed by the first hand in L (cr. n.).
a)/ra, ‘then,’ marks her new perception: cp. 927, 934, 1026: Tr. 1172, etc.
h)/luqe. This form, not used by Aesch. , occurs only here in Soph. ; Eur. has it not only in lyrics ( Eur. Or. 813, etc.), but also in dialogue ( Eur. El. 598, Eur. Tro. 374).

w(=n (neut.), instead of h(=s, since poi/mnhn is a ‘noun of multitude’; cp. O. C. 1070a)/mbasis, oi(\ k.t.l. (n.). Then th
 me
 (sc. poi/mnhn) follows w(=n, as it might have followed h(=s: cp. Thuc. 1. 2§ 3 th=s gh=s h( a)ri/sth, ib. 5 § 1 to
 plei=ston tou= bi/ou. Finally, ta\ de\ (sc. bota\) refers to w(=n.—The antithesis to th
 me
 is given by ta\ de/, not (as some have thought) by du/o d'.

e)/sw, ‘within the house,’ refers to all the incidents that followed his arrival (h)/luqe). Schneidewin wrongly joins e)/sw sfa/ze (‘stach tot’), comparing Aesch. Ag. 1343pe/plhgmai kairi/an plhgh\n e)/sw. But sfa/ze denotes ‘cutting the throat,’ not ‘stabbing’; cp. 298.
e)pi\ gai/as, where they stood upon the floor; as distinguished from those animals which he caught up and rent asunder.
pleurokopw=n, slashing at their sides with his sword: a compound like qalattokopei=n ( Ar. Eq. 830), metewrokopei=n ( Ar. Pax 92).

a)rgi/podas: for the rt. ARG, denoting ‘brightness,’ and its derivatives, cp. O. C. 670 n. As Ajax purposed to flog Odysseus (110), the ram which suffers that fate here might naturally be identified with him. The first ram, which is beheaded at once, might then represent Agamemnon; and Menelaüs would here be ignored. On this view, however, there is a discrepancy with verses 97—110, since both the Atreidae are there supposed to be dead, while Odysseus has still to suffer. Here one ram (Agamemnon) is slain, and the other (Odysseus) flogged, in rapid succession.

If the two rams are the two Atreidae, then Odysseus is ignored here. This would be consistent both with vv. 97— 110 and with 298—306. The flogging of the second ram here would correspond with the words tou\s de\ desmi/ous | h)|ki/zeq) in 299 f. Then came the colloquy of Ajax with Athena (301); after which, he slowly regained his sanity,—before he had inflicted the lash upon Odysseus. That the ‘two rams’ are here the royal brethren might be suggested by the analogy of the two eagles in Ag. 115.On the other hand, the special ferocity with which Ajax treats the second ram rather indicates that it represents Odysseus. There would be no point in so distinguishing Menelaüs from Agamemnon. On the whole, it seems most probable that the poet meant Agamemnon and Odysseus, but was careless of strict consistency with vv. 97—110.

kefalh\n kai\ glw=ssan a)/kran. He first shears off the head; then, still holding it, while the carcass drops to the ground, cuts off the end of the tongue; and next hurls both head and tongue from him. a)/kra glw=ssa can mean the extremity, the tip, of the tongue, as in Theocr. 9. 30 e)pi\ glw/ssas a)/kras: so in Ph. 748a)/kron po/da is the heel. It could not mean, ‘the tongue from the roots,’ glw=ssan prumnh/n ( Il. 5. 292).—It was customary to cut out the tongues of animals slain for sacrifice, and to offer them separately ( Od. 3. 332: Ar. Pax 1060). But I doubt whether there is any reference here to the sacrificial custom; the act of Ajax rather expresses merely fierce hatred of a slanderer.

r(iptei= has the support of the MSS., not only here, but also in Ant. 131, Tr. 780.In the latter place, it is confirmed by Athenaeus p. 65 F, for he has r(iptou=nta in his paraphrase. r(iptei=n, used only in pres. and impf., was current in Attic ( Ar. Eccl. 507r(iptei=te xlai/nas). It has good authority in Thuc. 5. 103§ 1 (a)narriptou=si), and Cyneg. 9. 20 (r(iptou=si). In Tragedy it is nowhere required by metre; and Elmsley (on Eur. Heracl. 150) supposes that the tragic poets used only r(i/ptw. No difference of sense between r(ipte/w and r(i/ptw can be clearly shown; though it has been fancied that r(ipte/w implies the frequency or vehemence of the act (iacto as compared with iacio).
o)rqo\n a)/nw … dh/sas: i.e., making the animal stand on its hind legs, with its forefeet lashed up to the pillar—as if they were the hands of a human prisoner.
ki/oni, lit., ‘at a pillar,’ a dat. of place (cp. El. 174 n.); not, ‘to a pillar’ (pro\s ki/ona, El. 108).

i(ppode/thn r(uth=ra, a leathern strap or thong, belonging to the harness of a horse,—such as the reins of a bridle ( O. C. 900speu/dein a)po\ r(uth=ros), or driving-reins ( Il. 16. 475, where see Leaf). Hesiod Scut. 308 r(uta\ xalai/nontes, ‘slackening the reins.’ Ajax makes a diplh= ma/stic, a whip with two thongs, by doubling the strap. Cp. Aeschin. or. 2 § 157 labw\n r(uth=ra mastigoi/hn ai)xma/lwton.
ligura=|, Homeric: Il. 11. 532ma/stigi ligurh=|.
kaka\ denna/zwn r(h/maq), like o)neidi/zwn o)nei/dh: see on Ant. 759denna/seis.
dai/mwn: cp. O. T. 1258lussw=nti d' au)tw=| daimo/nwn dei/knusi/ tis: | ou)dei\s ga\r a)ndrw=n oi(\ parh=men e)ggu/qen.

h)/dh toi kra=ta. The reading of the best MSS., both here and in the strophe (221 f.), can be retained, if in the strophe we make the slight change of a)ndro\s to a)ne/ros. If, on the other hand, we strike out toi here, then we must also change kra=ta to ka/ra, or else, keeping kra=ta, change e)dh/lwsas in 221 to e)/deicas or e)/fhnas. (The impf. e)dh/lous would be unsuitable.) Here toi is quite in place, as introducing the comment. h)/toi, as a correction of h)/dh toi, is doubly impro bable, since h)/dh is emphatic, and h)/toi would be somewhat weak. See Appendix.

kra=ta … kruya/menon, in token of grief and shame. Plat. Phaedop. 117 C e)gkaluya/menos a)pe/klaion e)mauto/n: Aeschin. or. 2 § 111 ta/ ge dh\ katage/lasta pantelw=s, e)f' oi(=s oi( sumpre/sbeis e)nekalu/yanto. Liv. 4. 12 Multi ex plebe spe amissa..capitibus obvolutis se in Tiberim praecipitaverunt.

podoi=n klopa\n a)re/sqai: cp. Aesch. Pers. 481ou)k eu)/kosmon ai)/rontai fugh/n: [Eur. ] Rhes. 54 (nukte/rw| pla/th|) ai)/resqai fugh/n. The verb here means, ‘to take up,’ ‘betake oneself to’; not ‘to win,’ ‘secure’: see Appendix on 75. For klopa\n, cp. Eur. Or. 1499e)ce/klepton e)k do/mwn po/da.

qoo
, properly the epithet of ei)resi/as, is transferred to zugo
 (cp. Ant. 794 n.): zugo
 e(/zomai, as Aesch. Ag. 183se/lma..h(me/nwn, Eur. Or. 956tri/poda kaqi/zwn.

nai+\ meqei=nai, ‘to let the ship go,’— h(ni/as, or the like, being understood. Cp. Eur. fr. 779 krou/sas de\ pleura\ pterofo/rwn o)xhma/twn | meqh=ken (‘he let his horses go’): ai( d' e)/ptant' e)p' ai)qe/ros ptuxa/s. The elliptical use of meqie/nai, with dat., in this sense, seems to be rare: but it is parallel with that of e)fie/nai as=indulgere (e.g. Plat. Rep. 388E o(/tan tis e)fih=|..ge/lwti).
toi/as: 164 n.

e)re/ssousin, ‘ply,’—properly, to ply the oar; then, to put anything in lively motion; Ant. 158mh=tin e)re/sswn, ‘revolving’ thoughts in the mind. Cp. the elegiac poet Dionysius ap. Athen. p. 669 A ei)resi/h| glw/sshs a)pope/myomen ei)s me/gan ai)=non (‘by our swift strains will we waft him to the haven of fame’).
dikratei=s *)atrei=dai, the two princely Atreidae: cp. 390 tou/s te dissa/rxas..basilh=s: O. C. 1055ta\s disto/lous | ...a)delfa\s, i.e., the two journeying sisters; and ib. 17 n.
pefo/bhmai: 139 n.

liqo/leuston *)/arh, a violent death by stoning; cp. Ant. 36fo/non..dhmo/leuston. Aesch. Ag. 1616dhmorrifei=s..leusi/mous a)ra/s. When, as here, *)/arhs stands for the notion of a ‘violent death,’ it always, of course, implies an onslaught; as in Soph. O. C. 1679o(/tw| mh/t' *)/arhs | mh/te po/ntos a)nte/kursen (death in battle, or by drowning): Aesch. P. V. 860qhlukto/nw| | *)/arei dame/ntwn, i.e., by the onslaught of murderous women. (In Pind. P. 11. 36xroni/w| su\n *)/arei is best taken, with Gildersleeve, as =‘by tardy help of Ares.’) The initial A is long here (answering to the penult. of sugkatakta\s in 230), as in 614, Soph. Ant. 139, Soph. El. 96.

The accus. is, in the first place, object to pefo/bhmai, but is felt also as a cognate acc. to cunalgei=n (like a)/lgos a)lgw=), and could be, further, an acc. of the inner object with tupei/s ( Il. 24. 420e(/lkea... o(/ss' e)tu/ph): it is one of those cumulative constructions which Greek idiom (esp. in poetry) favours. Note that a simple inf. after fobou=mai usu. denotes what one is afraid to do ( Aesch. Ch. 46fobou=mai d' e)/pos to/d' e)kbalei=n), but can also denote what one fears to suffer: Plat. Phaedop. 68 E fobou/menoi..h(donw=n sterhqh=nai.
ai)=s' a)/platos, a fate such that no one can approach him, or stand at his side, without being involved in his doom. The Nemean lion is a)/platon qre/mma, Tr. 1093.

The words lampra=s a)/ter steroph=s go with lh/gei, not with a)/|cas: they stand first, because they express the foremost thought,—viz., that the violence of his frenzy is past. ‘Attended by the lightning-flash no more, the storm in his soul is subsiding, after a sharp outburst (a)/|cas o)cu/s), like the wind of the south.’ A key to these much-discussed verses may be found, I think, in a passage which seems to have been overlooked. The Greeks had observed that, when the *no/tos was a stormy wind, it was accompanied by clouds; but, when gentler, by a clear sky: Problem. 26. 20 (p. 942 a 34) o( no/tos, o(/tan me\n e)la/ttwn h)=|, ai)/qrio/s e)stin, o(/tan de\ me/gas, nefw/dhs. The mood of Ajax is now once more becoming ai)/qrios, like the milder south-wind; lately it was like a fierce storm from the south, and nefw/dhs, dark with the clouds from which the steroph/ of his madness was flashing. Compare the description of the mad Ajax by Arctînus in the Iliupersis (ap. Eustath. p. 859. 47), o)/mmata/ t' a)stra/ptonta baruno/meno/n te no/hma.— For other views of this passage, and the attempts to amend it, see Appendix.
oi)kei=a pa/qh, those which one brings on himself: so El. 215oi)kei/as ei)s a)/tas | e)mpi/pteis.

parapra/cantos, having acted ‘at the side,’ i.e., ‘having had a hand in the matter,’—‘having contributed to the result.’ This sense nowhere else belongs to parapra/ssw (which in Her. 5. 45 means ‘to do something beyond’ one's proper task, and in Plut. Agis 16‘to exact unjustly’); but for the force of the prep., cp. parai/tios ( Aesch. Ch. 910, etc.), as=‘partly the cause.’— Not, ‘having done amiss’ (=paraba/ntos).
u(potei/nei: lit., ‘lays to’ (or ‘beneath’) the mind: [Dem. ] or. 13 § 19 ta\s e)lpi/das u(mi=n u(potei/nwn.

pe/pautai, sc. o( *ai)/as th=s no/sou: cp. 279. The subject to eu)tuxei=n is rather h(ma=s than au)to/n: the thought is, dokw= o(/ti eu)tuxoi=men a)/n. Cp. O. T. 87le/gw ga\r kai\ ta\ du/sfor), ei) tu/xoi | kat' o)rqo\n e)celqo/nta, pa/nt' a)\n eu)tuxei=n. In the omission of the subject to the inf., as in pe/pautai and in tou= kakou=, there is a shade of reticence which suits the recent sense of horror in the speaker's mind.

frou/dou ga\r k.t.l.: the gen. is not absol., but depends on lo/gos. Cp. fr. 346 mu/xqou ga\r ou)dei\s tou= parelqo/ntos lo/gos. Their thought is that, if he is himself again, his value to the Greeks will plead for pardon of his frenzy.
po/tera is used, instead of po/teron, to avoid an anapaest, as in 460, and O. C. 333.

The words koino\s e)n koinoi=si mean strictly, ‘a partner among partners,’ =koinwno\s e)n koinwnoi=s: cp. O. T. 239mh/t' e)n qew=n eu)xai=si mh/te qu/masin | koino\n poei=sqai. Similarly kinsfolk can be termed koinoi/, as sharers in a common lineage ( O. T. 261 n.). The iteration, koino\s e)n koinoi=s, emphasises the idea of mutual sympathy: cp. 467 mo/nos mo/nois (and 1283 mo/nos mo/nou), 620 a)/fila par' a)fi/lois, and n. on Tr. 613.
to\ … dipla/zon, intrans., ‘that which is double’ (cp. i)sa/zw, ‘to be equal’): but the verb is trans. in Andoc. or. 4 § 11 to\n fo/ron..dipla/seien, unless we should there read diplasia/seien.

Though ou) nosou=ntos (gen. abs.) is an easy and specious conjecture, yet ou) nosou=ntes is better; because (1) it gives a rhetorical antithesis to a)tw/mesqa which suits her point; and (2) it suggests the identity of their interest with that of Ajax. The figurative sense of nosei=n is often found in juxtaposition with the literal, as in O. T. 60nosei=te pa/ntes, kai\ nosou=ntes, w(s e)gw\ | ou)k e)/stin u(mw=n o(/stis e)c i)/sou nosei=.

a)tw/mesqa, i.e. we are worse off than before: the word is a forcible one (cp. 384), but occurs elsewhere also where the sense is only comparative: Ant. 17ou)/t' eu)tuxou=sa ma=llon ou)/t' a)twme/nh: cp. ib. 314.
pw=s … o(/pws. The language here, to which groundless exception has been taken (cr. n.), expresses the musing wonder of simple minds.

oi(=sin ei)/xet' e)n kakoi=s=kakoi=s e)n oi(=s ei)/xeto: cp. 1144: Her. 9. 37e)n tou/tw| tw=| kakw=| e)xo/menos. The antecedent kakoi=s is drawn into the relative clause, though here its case is not thereby affected: cp. Ant. 404qa/ptousan o(
 su\ to
 nekro
 | a)pei=pas.
fronou=ntas is far better than the v.l. ble/pontas: it hints what is meant by the vague kakoi=s.
ka)ne/pneuse: after the actual cessation (e)/lhce), a brief space is still needed to permit a)napnoh/. Cp. Il. 11. 382a)ne/pneusan kako/thtos: and n. on O. C. 1113 f.
Instead of kei=nos, we might have looked for au)to/s: but the former has been preferred, because it better marks the antithesis between Ajax and his friends.
pa=s, adverbial: Ph. 386po/lis ga/r e)sti pa=sa tw=n h(goume/nwn.

e)lh/latai: Tr. 1045(sumfora\s) oi(/ais.. e)lau/netai (n.). For the emphatic perf., cp. El. 64.Here it expresses that complete prostration has at once followed the return of sanity: cp. Plat. Phaedop. 80 D h( de\ yuxh\..a)pallattome/nh tou= sw/matos eu)qu\s diapefu/shtai kai\ a)po/lwlen.
a)=r)=a)=r' ou); O. T. 822a)=r' e)/fun kako/s; El. 614.
di\s to/s)=dipla=. Cp. Il. 1. 213tri\s to/ssa..dw=ra: Eur. El. 1092di\s to/sws (‘in double measure’).— e)c a(plw=n: Soph. Tr. 619(xa/ris) e)c a(plh=s diplh=.

de/doika mh\ … h(/kh|. Though h(/kei is tenable (‘I fear that it certainly has come’), h(/kh| seems better, since there is still a real uncertainty and anxiety in their minds. See on El. 580.(h(/koi, which was the common reading, is of course impossible here.)

pw=s ga/r, sc. a)/llws e)/xei; Normally, pw=s ga/r follows a negative statement, as in El. 911ou)d' au)= su/: pw=s ga/r; (sc. e)/drasas): while pw=s ga\r ou)/ follows an affirmative, as ib. 1307 oi)=sqa me\n ta)nqe/nde, pw=s ga\r ou)/; The use of pw=s ga/r here is thus peculiar, though the sense is clear.

ei) pepaume/nos k.t.l. The fact that despair has succeeded to frenzy argues that he is under the spell of some angry god. When the malady passed away, his mind ought to have recovered a healthy tone. They had already hinted at a qei/a no/sos as a possibility (186).
mhde/n ti: Eur. Andr. 1234mhde/n ti li/an: Eur. Alc. 522ou)de/n ti ma=llon oi)=da.

w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn k.t.l.: w(s marks the point of view to be taken: the gen. abs. presents the state of the facts as the condition under which one's opinion must be formed. Cp. Aesch. P. V. 760w(s toi/nun o)/ntwn tw=nde/ soi maqei=n pa/ra. Eur. Med. 1311w(s ou)ke/t' o)/ntwn sw=n te/knwn fro/ntize dh/. Thuc. 7. 15§ 1 w(s..tw=n stratiwtw=n..mh\ memptw=n gegenhme/nwn ou(/tw th
 gnw/mhn e)/xete. Xen. An. 1. 3. 6w(s e)mou= ou)=n i)o/ntos o(/ph| a)
 kai\ u(mei=s, ou(/tw th
 gnw/mhn e)/xete. See also below, 904, 981.
ti/s ga/r: for ga/r in question, cp. Ph. 161, Ph. 327, Ph. 651.
prose/ptato, as if winged to its aim by the god; Aesch. P. V. 644(the heaven-sent trouble) o(/qen moi sxetli/a| prose/ptato: Eur. Alc. 420kou)k a)/fnw kako\n to/de | prose/ptat).

From the Homeric e)/ptato ( Il. 13. 592, etc.) Tragedy borrows this non-thematic aor. (of which the active form would be e)/pthn): cp. 693. The aor. of pe/tomai in Attic Comedy and prose is usu. e)pto/mhn (see Veitch, Irreg. Verbs, 2nd ed., p. 530): and of this we have the inf. pte/sqai in O. T. 17,—again in accord with Homeric precedent ( Il. 4. 126e)pipte/sqai).
tu/xas depends on dh/lwson. The change to tu/xais, dependent on cunalgou=sin (cr. n.), is not only groundless, but injures the rhythm of the verse.
kei=nos ga\r: here ga\r merely prefaces the narrative ( O. T. 277 n.).

a)/kras nukto/s, as the context shows, means here, ‘at dead of night.’ The only other instance of a)/kros so used (natural though the use is) seems to be Theocr. II. 36
turo\s d' ou) lei/pei m' ou)/t' e)n qe/rei ou)/t' e)n o)pw/rh|
ou) xeimw=nos a)/krw (‘depth of winter’). Elsewhere a)/kra nu/c means either (1) the beginning of night, nightfall, as in Aratus 775 a)/krh| nukti/: or (2) the verge between night and dawn, as ib. 308 a)kro/qi nukto/s. In Theophrastus De Sign. Pluv. 1. § 2 (p. 389 ed. Wimmer) the a)kro/nuxoi a)natolai/ of stars are their risings o(/tan a(/ma duome/nw| a)nate/llh| (ta\ a)/stra), i.e. soon after sunset, at nightfall. The sense of a)kre/speros varies like that of a)/kra nu/c. In Hippocr. Epidem. 7. 653 a)kre/speros fri/kh is a chill at the approach of evening (as Galen Exeg. p. 418 explains); while in Nicander Ther. 25 a)kre/speros is explained by the schol. as=‘at the close of evening,’ ‘at nightfall.’ The latter is the sense of a)/kra| su
 e(spe/ra| in Pindar P. 11. 10. [In H. A. 9. 34, p. 619 b 21, the words a)/xris e(speri/ou have been conjecturally changed to th
 a)rxe/speron, from Athen. p. 353 B; or to th
 a)kre/speron: the sense required is ‘at nightfall.’]

lampth=res. These were braziers, raised on stands, in which pine-wood was burned, at once for light and for heat ( Od. 19. 64fo/ws e)me\n h)de\ qe/resqai). Od. 18. 307au)ti/ka lampth=ras trei=s i(/stasan e)n mega/roisin, | o)/fra faei/noien: peri\ de\ cu/la ka/gkana qh=kan, | .. kai\ dai+/das mete/misgon. As Helbig remarks (Das Hom. Epos p. 78), the smoke thus caused explains why the Homeric me/garon is sometimes called ai)qalo/en ( Il. 2. 414, Od. 22. 239).
For this mode of indicating the time, cp. Her. 7. 215peri\ lu/xnwn a(fa/s: Propert. 3. 8. 1 ad extremas..lucernas: Aul. Gellius 3. 2 post primam facem.
e)/gxos: cp. 95.
e)co/dous e(/rpein: cp. Thuc. 1. 15§ 2 e)kdh/mous stratei/as .. ou)k e)ch/|esan.
kena/s, i.e., with no apparent object; cp. El. 1054qhra=sqai kena/.

The general word, a)/klhtos, is defined by the two clauses in apposition with it, ou)/q' u(p' a)gge/lwn klhqei/s, ou)/te sa/lpiggo/s tou klu/wn. Here the double ou)/te is more emphatic than a double ou)de/: with the latter, the sense would be, ‘uncalled, and not summoned,’ etc. Cp. Tr. 391ou)k e)mw=n u(p' a)gge/lwn | a)ll' au)to/klhtos. Aesch. Cho. 838h(/kw me\n ou)k a)/klhtos, a)ll' u(pa/ggelos.
a)forma=|s, intrans., as in Thuc. 4. 78§ 5 e)k th=s *meliti/as a)fw/rmhsen (‘he started’): pei=ran is cogn. acc.; cp. Plat. Parm.p. 135 D h( o(rmh\ h(\n o(rma=|s.
sa/lpiggos: a non-Homeric trait; see on 17. Cp. fr. 357 a)sa/lpigkton w(/ran = me/shn nu/kta.
pa=s eu(/dei strato/s. Cp. the phrases peri\ prw=ton u(/pnon ( Thuc. 2. 2§ 1), nocte concubia ( Liv. 25. 9§ 8).

u(mnou/mena, decantata. Schol. a)ei\ qrulou/mena u(po\ pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn kai\ koina/. Plat. Rep.p. 549 D kai\ a)/lla dh\ o(/sa kai\ oi(=a filou=sin ai( gunai=kes peri\ tw=n toiou/twn u(mnei=n. Phorm. 3. 2. 10 cantilenam eandem canis.

gunaici\ k.t.l.: cp. Eur. Heracl. 476gunaiki\ ga\r sigh/ te kai\ to\ swfronei=n | ka/lliston. In Ar. Lys. 514 f. the Attic wife describes a like incident: ti/ de/ soi tau=t' ; h)= d' o(\s a)\n a(nh/r: | ou) sigh/sei; ka)gw\ )si/gwn.
ko/smon: cp. fr. 61. 4 ai(=s ko/smos h( sigh/ te kai\ ta\ pau=r' e)/ph.
maqou=s), literally, ‘having perceived’ hismood.
e)ssu/qh=e)su/qh, an epic license allowed in narrative. Cp. Theog. 183 a)pe/ssuqen (3rd pl.). suqei/s occurs in O. C. 119, and suqw=men ib. 1724: e)su/qh in Helen. 1302 (lyr.).
ta\s e)kei= … pa/qas: briefly described by Athena, 55—60. The Chorus knew no details (230 f.). tu/xas (cr. n.) is a weaker v.l. The fem. pa/qh occurs also in Ant. 979 and O. C. 7.
ku/nas both=ras: schol. tou\s poimenikou\s ku/nas: ou) ga\r a)nairei= kata\ th\n skhnh\n a)/nqrwpon.

eu)/eron is a certain emendation of eu/kerwn, which was doubtless due to a reminiscence of v. 64. (Bellermann, who retains eu)/kerwn, refers it to the horns of the rams; while Prof. Campbell, who also keeps it, says, ‘The word describes all the cattle, small and great, excepting the bulls, which have been mentioned separately.’) The form eu)/eros (Attic for eu)/eiros). from ei)=ros, ‘wool,’ occurs in Tr. 675(oi)o\s eu)e/rou) and is proved by metre in Ar. Av. 121.The mention of the shepherd's dogs is naturally followed by that of the sheep.

hu)xe/nize (a word not elsewhere found in classical Greek) means here, ‘beheaded,’ by a blow on the au)xh/n (cervix), or hinder part of the neck. (Cp. Pind. P. 2. 93e)pauxe/nion .. zugo/n.) The Homeric deiroromei=n ( Il. 21. 89, etc.) may have suggested au)xeni/zein.

a)/nw tre/pwn, turning the heads of the victims upwards, so as to expose the throats to the sword. Cp. Il. 1. 459au)e/rusan me\n prw=ta kai\ e)/sfacan kai\ e)/deiran: where au)e/rusan is now explained as = a)v-ve/rusan, by assimilation for a)n-ver, ‘they lifted up’ the heads of the victims (not au) e)/rusan, ‘drew back,’ as it was formerly taken): see Leaf ad loc.
e)/sfaze (235), cut the sfagh/, iugulum. The whole neck is tra/xhlos, collum.
ka)rra/xize: see on 56.
desmi/ous: cp. 239 ff.
w(/ste=w(s, an epic use frequent with Aesch. and Soph. : Soph. O. C. 343, etc.
fw=tas, here opposed, as a)/ndras is in 64, to qh=ras: sometimes fw/s is opp. to qeo/s ( Il. 17. 98 etc.).

u(pa/|cas is not a certain reading here; but (despite the fact that the first hand in L wrote a)pa=cas) it has, on the whole, at least as good authority as a)pa/|cas. The latter makes good sense enough, ‘rushing away from me’; but u(pa/|cas, expressing the sudden rush forward, as if towards something which had suddenly caught his attention, adds a picturesque touch which is absent from the other reading. For this sense of u(po/ in comp., cp. u(pa/gw, etc. The third possibility, e)pa/|cas, would properly denote a rush onwards in a direction which had already been taken; and is thus less fitting here.
skia=| tini\: Tecmessa, of course, followed Ajax to the door, but Athena was invisible to her: see on 15. Ajax seemed to speak with some phantom,—some creature of his brain.

lo/gous a)ne/spa; the phrase denotes the abrupt, spasmodic manner in which his words were jerked forth. They were wild and incoherent (21—116). Cp. Plat. Theaet.p. 180 A w(/sper e)k fare/tras r(hmati/skia ai)nigmatw/dh a)naspw=ntes a)potoceu/ousi. Menander *(papizome/nhs fr. 7 po/qen tou/tous a)nespa/kasin ou(=toi tou\s lo/gous; Ar. Ran. 903to\n d) (Aeschylus) a)naspw=nt' au)topre/mnois (-ous?) | toi=s lo/goisin k.t.l., (where the idea is that of tearing up trees by the roots; but the use of a)naspa=n in ref. to a bold style is suggestive). Eustathius p. 679. 61 ou) mo/non e)pi\ futw=n to\ a)naspa=n le/getai, a)lla\ kai\ e)pi\ a)lazonei/as, w(s dhloi= to\ para\ *sofoklei= lo/gous a)ne/spa.
*)atreidw=n ka/ta: for kata/ placed after its case, cp. 969.
a)mf' *)odussei=: for a)mfi/ with dat. in this sense, cp. 340, 684: El. 1180a)mf' e)moi\ ste/neis.

suntiqei\s ge/lwn polu/n, ‘combining,’ ‘mingling,’ much laughter with the vaunts: cp. Suppl. 65 cunti/qhsi de\ paido\s mo/ron, blends that theme with her lament.—Not, ‘fabricating,’ with reference to the unreality of the triumph.

ge/lwn, as in Ant. 647: but ge/lwt) below, Ant. 382, Ant. 958. Eur. too uses ge/lwn where it is metrically convenient ( Eur. Ion 1172). The form implies an Attic declension, like that of new/s. In Hom. Od. 18. 350 and 20. 346 ge/lon should prob. be read; in the former place the MSS. give also ge/lw and ge/lwn. Stems in t are post-Homeric, as Monro observes (Hom. Gr. § 107 n.).

u(/brin is plainly that which he inflicts, not that which he punishes; though the latter would be suggested by the usual sense of e)kti/nesqai, as in Eur. H. F. 547mh/ pote *kre/ontos qa/naton e)kteisai/ato (‘avenge’). Here the verb means, ‘inflict in vengeance.’

e)ktei/saito (for the spelling, see on 180 f.), not e)ktei/soito: the latter would be tenable only if au)tou= could replace au)tw=n. When he spoke with Athena, he fancied that he had already slain the Atreidae (100); and Odysseus, though reserved for further chastisement, was already desmw/ths (105).
i)w/n (=o(/te h)/|ei) adds animation; see on Ant. 768dra/tw, fronei/tw mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/ndr' i)w/n.

e)pa/|cas is better here than a)pa/|cas. The regular sense of e)pa/|ssein is ‘to rush at,’ or ‘against’; here it denotes that he rushes in again as if to renew the attack. a)pa/|cas, on the other hand, would be somewhat awkward, since he was coming towards the speaker; and certainly cannot be defended by Tr. 693ei)/sw d' a)postei/xousa, where Deianeira means, ‘as I was going away from you into the house.’ It is quite needless to write e)sa/|cas.
au)=qis … pa/lin: O. C. 1418 n.

mo/lis pws, by some slow and painful process, which she cannot analyse. Plat. Prot.p. 328 D mo/gis pws e)mauto\n w(sperei\ ounagei/ras. So mo/lis pote/ Helen. 896. For pws thus used, cp. also Il. 14. 104ma/la pw/s me kaqi/keo qumo\n e)niph=|, ‘thou hast strangely moved me.’
a)/ths, the havoc made by him; cp. Ant. 1260(alluding to the corpse of Haemon), ou)k a)llotri/an | a)/thn, ‘the work of no stranger's madness.’
)qw/u+cen. In O. C. 1624 this word begins a trimeter, the augment being omitted, as often in r(h/seis (see O. T. 1249 n.): here, however, it is better to suppose aphaeresis. Cp. 1337 )kra/thsa.

e)reipi/ois is defined by nekrw=n, wrecks consisting of corpses; and this phrase, again, by a)rnei/ou fo/nou, corpsewrecks of slain sheep. Thus both the genitives here serve to define; while in lei/as..bouko/lwn frourh/mata (54), the first gen. defines, and the second is possessive. Cp. 465, 616 f. The phrase nekrw=n e)rei/pia occurs also in Eur. fr. 266. 2; and xlanidi/wn e)reipi/ois (which seems to verge on bathos) in frag. incert. 7 (ed. Nauck).

e)reifqei\s: the pres. pass. e)rei/petai (‘crashes down’) occurs in O. C. 1462; this aor., in Arrian Anab. 1. 21. 4(of a tower) ou)de\..xalepw=s a)\n h)rei/fqh. Ol. 2. 47 has e)ripe/nti. The old v.l. e)reisqei\s would mean, ‘supported on,’ but is wretchedly weak. The very fact that e)reifqei\s follows e)reipi/ois—that the slayer is prostrate among the slain—gives the word a singular force and pathos.

a)pri\c … sullabw\n, tightly clutching: Plat. Theaet. 155 E ou(= a)\n du/nwntai a)pri\c toi=n xeroi=n labe/sqai. Cp. fr. 328. 3 tou= ge kerdai/nein o(/mws | a)pri\c e)/xontai. The word is from the rt. of pri/w, as=‘to grip’ (1030 n.), with euphonic a: Aesch. uses a)/prigda ( Aesch. Pers. 1057). Cp. the Latin phrase mordicus tenere.
o)/nuci … xeri/, with the hand, by the nails; both datives are instrumental, but one (o)/nuci) more closely defines the other; see on 230 f. (xeri\..ci/fesin).

kai\ to
 me
 h(=sto plei=ston k.t.l. The bold order of words is explained by e)/peita in 312: i.e., the thought is; ‘for one part of the time—the longest —he sat mute; then,’ etc. By separating to
 from plei=ston, the writer obtains the same effect as if he had said, kai\ prw=ton me
 kai\ to
 plei=ston xro/non k.t.l.

ta\ dei/n' … e)/ph, ‘those dread threats’ (which still haunt my memory): cp. 650, 1226: Soph. Ph. 180pou= d), o(\s ta\ deina\ th=|d' e)fubri/zei po/lei | *kapaneu/s; ‘those dread vaunts’ (of which we have heard). See Soph. Tr. 476, and Appendix there, p. 192.

fanoi/hn. The optat. of the fut. fane/w is formed with the modal suffix ih, like the pres. optat. of contracted verbs, dra-o-ih-n, drw/|hn. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 3. 1. 14e)roi/h (opt. of fut. e)re/w): Platonic Epist. 7. p. 339 D diabaloi/hn.
e)n tw=| pra/gmatos: cp. Ant. 1229e)n tw=| sumfora=s diefqa/rhs; Ph. 174 e)pi\ panti/ tw| xrei/as.
The words ka)gw/, fi/loi, dei/sasa are apologetic; she would gladly have spared him the details which his threats constrained her to relate.

pro\s ga\r kakou= te: for the prep., cp. 581, 1071. He always set forth, laid down as a rule, toiou/sde go/ous e)/xein pro\s a)ndro\s kakou=, pertain to him, are characteristic of him. The words, pro\s a)ndro\s kakou= k.t.l., are equiv. to an adverb with the intrans. e)/xein: i.e., as we can say, go/oi a)na/ndrws e)/xousi, so go/oi e)/xousi pro\s kakou= a)ndro/s. This intrans. use of e)/xein with phrases of an adverbial kind is frequent with Herodotus; e.g. 2. 91 a)gw=na gumniko\n <*>ia\ pa/shs a)gwni/hs e)/xonta, ‘consisting in every sort of contest’: see other examples on O. T. 709.—The alternative explanation is, ‘he taught that it (was) the part of a craven e)/xein go/ous toiou/sde, to indulge in such laments.’ e)/xein would then be used as in Od. 24. 515dh=rin e)/xousi. But this implies an impossible ellipse of e)=nai after e)chgei=to.

baruyu/xou, ‘heavy-hearted,’ lacking the buoyant spirit which quickly rallies itself from despondency. Ajax was emphatically a soldier. (The schol.'s paraphrase, mikroyu/xou, conveys a different idea.) The word occurs nowhere else, baruqumos being the usual term; but cp. baru/frwn, and the post-classical baruka/rdios. Plutarch illustrates the poet's meaning when he speaks ( Mor.p. 477 E) of men e)n o)durmoi=s ta\ polla\ kai\ baruqumi/ais kai\ meri/mnais..diatri/bontas. So Heracles says, Tr. 1074, a)ll' a)ste/naktos ai)e\n ei(po/mhn kakoi=s.
e)chgei=t): the word implies authoritative exposition (as of the sacred law by the e)chghtai/), and suggests the submissive reverence with which Tecmessa listened to her lord.
a)yo/fhtos … kwkuma/twn: cp. O. C. 677a)nh/nemon..xeimw/nwn (n.).— u(peste/naze, groaned low; cp. El. 79u(postenou/shs.
o)ce/wn: Ant. 423pikra=s | o)/rniqos o)cu\n fqo/ggon.

tau=ros w(\s bruxw/menos: Theog. 832 tau=ros e)ribru/xhs. The word expresses deep, sullen tones, such as might come from a bull in pain: it usually implies a sound of anger or anguish, whereas muka=sqai can denote the mere lowing of oxen; hence Nonnus 29. 311 bruxhdo\n e)mukh/santo. The unhappy conjecture brimw/menos (‘snorting’) was prompted by a supposed inconsistency between bruxw/menos and u(peste/naze: but there is no reason why deep tones should not be also muffled.
nu=n d) contrasts his present behaviour with that described in 317. The contrast is not with u(peste/naze (322), as though he were now wholly silent.
a)/sitos. Od. 4. 788(Penelope in her anxiety for Telemachus) kei=t' a)/r' a)/sitos a)/pastos e)dhtu/os h)de\ poth=tos.

sidhrokmh=sin: as the dead are oi( kamo/ntes, oi( kekmhko/tes, so sidhrokmh/s is one who has died by the sword: cp. Aesch. Cho. 365dourikmh=ti law=|: ib. 889 a)ndrokmh=ta pe/lekun (an axe by which men die).
w(/s ti drasei/wn, instead of drasei/wn ti simply: cp. O. C. 630 w(s telw=n e)fai/neto: Xen. An. 1. 5. 9dh=los h)=n *ku=ros w(s speu/dwn: Lys. or. 12 § 90 dh=loi e)/sesqe w(s o)rgizo/menoi.
drasei/wn: cp. Ph. 1001e)rgasei/eis (n.). Vesp. 168 a)/nqrwpos ou(=tos me/ga ti drasei/ei kako/n.
toiau=ta is qualified by pws: something in his utterances, which she cannot define, suggests this. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 3. 3. 7e)/lecen w(=de/ pws ei)s to\ me/son.

kai\ le/gei kw)du/retai. The word h(/suxos in 325 does not imply silence; it contrasts the quietness of his present demeanour with his former frenzy, and with the first vehemence (317) of his grief. His occasional words, or laments (such as i)w/ moi/ moi, 333), are in a tone which foreshadows the worst.

The verse is rejected by Nauck and others as though it were inconsistent with v. 325, and had been patched up from v. 383. There is no ground for this view. On the other hand, after h(/suxos in 325, the fear expressed in 326 would be unintelligible, if no reason were subjoined. Bergk, who joins in condemning the verse, allows that Sophocles is usually careful of logical coherence in drama (‘pflegt .. sorgfältig zu motiviren’); but suggests that here the neglect of it might be ‘a mark of the archaic style’ (Jahr. f. Class. Phil. 97. 378).
e)sta/lhn, her (self-imposed) errand; cp. El. 404oi(=per e)sta/lhn o(dou=: O. C. 20prou)sta/lhs.
ei)selqo/ntes. Dramatic effect required that, instead of the Chorus literally complying with this request, the interior of the tent should be disclosed to them (346).
lo/gois. The fi/loi of the MSS. was doubtless in its origin a mere oversight, but may have been helped to keep its place in the text by the construction in 1353, kratei=s toi tw=n fi/lwn nikw/menos.
*teleu/tantos: 210 n.

h(mi=n could be joined with le/geis: for we sometimes find a word devoid of emphasis standing first in a trimeter, though a slight pause follows; e.g. 847 i)/dh|s: Aesch. Ag. 1130ou) kompa/saim' a)
 qesfa/twn gnw/mwn a)/kros | ei)=nai, kakw=| de/ tw| proseika/zw ta/de: Aesch. P. V. 673dia/strofoi | h)=san, kerasti\s d' k.t.l. But on the whole it seems better to have a comma after le/geis, and to take h(mi=n as ethic dat. (‘to our sorrow’): though this, too, is slightly harsh; for such an ethic dat. ought not to stand first, but to follow some significant word, as in 216 mani/a| ga a(lou\s h(mi
 o( kleino/s: El. 272to
 au)toe/nthn h(mi/n.

diapefoiba/sqai: the compound occurs only here. foiba/zw, from *foi=bos, meant ‘to inspire,’ as Apollo inspires the divine frenzy of ma/ntis or of poet; Anthol. 9. 525. 22 *foi=bon, foiba/zonta, filoste/fanon, filoghqh=: Longinus 8 § 4 pa/qos foiba/zon tou\s lo/gous. (The word could mean also ‘to utter prophetically,’ as in Lycophron 6 dafnhfa/gwn foi/bazen e)k laimw=n o)/pa.) Tecmessa has just described both the recent frenzy of Ajax—which she had already pictured in vv. 233 ff.—and his present despair. By diapefoiba/sqai the Chorus mean that a malign power has taken permanent possession of his mind. The mental trouble outlasts the frenzy (279 f.). Both dia/, and the perfect tense, serve to mark this. By kakoi=s they mean his troubles in regard to the arms of Achilles.
i)w/ moi/ moi. Cp. El. 77, where a similar cry (behind the scenes) is a prelude to the heroine's entrance.
ma=llon: we understand nosh/sei, or the like.
h)\ ou)k: the same crasis as in O. T. 555, O. T. 993, O. T. 1140.
*ai)/antos, oi(/an k.t.l.: cp. 785 o(/ra..to/nd' o(poi=) e)/ph qroei=. As in 308 )qw/u+cen marked the first pangs of his despair, qwu+/ssei here denotes a fresh access.

toi=s pa/lai nosh/masi cunou=si =toi=s pa/lai cunou=si n.: for the irregular order, cp. Ph. 1316ta\s..e)k qew=n | tu/xas doqei/sas (n.). The sense is toi=s n. a(\ pa/lai cunh=n. If the order of words were normal, cunou=si would be predicate; ‘vexed by his former maladies, as they haunt him,’ o(/te cu/nestin. But then (1) the alternative to h)\ nosei=n is less clearly marked, since the old nosh/mata are, in a sense, still with him; and (2) cunou=si, as referring merely to a memory of them, is somewhat forced.

parw/n, being, as he is, in the presence of his own handiwork. The implied antithesis is with what he might feel if told of things which he had done elsewhere, but which he could not see. Cp. 1131, 1156.

i)w\ pai= pai=. One of the signs that he is resolved to die is the way in which his thoughts dwell upon his son; he cannot rest till he sees him (530—544). The child is the heir of his fame, and may live to clear it of the stain (556 f.). As Eurysaces is not at once brought to him, he next cries (342), *teu=kron kalw=: Teucer is his second thought, for to Teucer he will commit the care of his son (562).
Prof. Campbell understands i)w\ pai= pai= as meaning Teucer, whom an elder brother might so address. Tecmessa, at least, did not so take the words.
w)/moi ta/lain): the nom. as in 800, El. 788, and oft.

*eu)ru/sakes, so named from the shield of Ajax (19): cp. 574 n. The first syll. of a dactyl in the third foot is usually either the last syllable of a word, or else a monosyllable; but proper names are exempt from the rule.
a)mfi\ soi\: for the prep., cp. 303: in 562 the sense is different.
pou= pot' ei)=; She had sent the child out of the tent, in charge of servants (531—539), and now fears that he has not been removed to a sufficient distance.
*teu=kron: the son of Telamon by Hesionè (1302), and half-brother of Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569).

to
 ei)saei\ … xro/non: the phrase to
 a)ei\ xro/non is frequent. The separation of to
 ei)saei\ from xro/non deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility that to
 a)ei\ may sometimes have been used (without xro/non) as=‘for ever’: a usage which, however, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— lehlath/sei: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), ‘in pursuit of foes’ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. 1. 11§ 1 (the Greeks at Troy) fai/nontai...pro\s gewrgi/an th=s *xersonh/sou trapo/menoi kai\ lh|stei/an th=s trofh=s a)pori/a|.
