The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. 1. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brother's suicide.

a)noi/gete: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular person, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877a)ll' a)noi/cate: Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had pro/spoloi, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.
ai)dw= … la/boi: cp. Ph. 1078fro/nhsin.. la/boi: Tr. 669 f. proqumi/an | ... labei=n.

ka)p' e)moi\: for this modest kai/, cp. Ph. 192ei)/per ka)gw/ ti fronw=, and n. on Ant. 719.ble/yas should naturally go with ka)p' e)moi/, though ble/pein e)pi/ tini seems to occur nowhere else, and e)pible/pein tini/ only in Lucian Astr. 20kai\ sfi/si ginome/noisi tw=| me\n h( *)afrodi/th tw=| de\ o( *zeu\s...e)pe/bleyan (‘looked with favour’). The alternative is to take e)p' e)moi/ as= ‘in my case,’ and ble/yas as epexegetic; but this is certainly harsh.
dioi/gw: cp. O. T. 1287dioi/gein klh=|qra, and ib. 1295.
pra/gh, deeds: cp. 21.

The e)kku/klhma is now pushed on through the central door. It was a small stage, but large enough to allow of Ajax being shown surrounded by some of the slaughtered animals. The word pra/gh in 347, and the language of vv. 351 ff., show that the carnage was represented. The other plays in which Soph <*>es has used the eccyclema are the Antigone (1294, where see n.), and the Electra (1464 f., n.).

Ajax, sitting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus (Vit. Apoll. 2. 22 § 5) thus describes it: to
 *ai)/anta to
 *timoma/xou..a)pektono/ta ta)n th=| *troi/a| bouko/lia kaqh=sqai a)peirhko/ta [cp. v. 325 h(/suxos qakei=], boulh
 poiou/menon kai\ e(auto
 diafqei=rai. The picture was at Cyzicus in 70 B.C. ( Cic. In Verr. 2. 4. 60), but was afterwards bought by Julius Caesar for the Temple of Venus Genetrix in Rome ( N. H. 7. 38 § 126). See Introduction § 20.

This kommos serves, like the last (201—262), as a lyric expression of tragic pathos; after which the situation is further developed, as in the former case, by iambic dialogue. But in one respect this kommos differs from its predecessor. In order to bring the mind of Ajax into fuller relief, the lyrics are given to him alone, while the Chorus and Tecmessa speak only trimeters.
The structure is as follows:—1st strophe 348—355=1st antistr. 356—363: 2nd str. 364—378=2nd ant. 379—393: 3rd str. 394—411=3rd ant. 412—429. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
i)w\ fi/loi nauba/tai: his first words mark the affection which was so deep in the rugged nature.
e)mme/nontes: Cp. O. T. 351(tw=| khru/gmati) e)mme/nein.
o)rqw=| no/mw|, the right, sound rule of loyalty to friendship—which the Greek chiefs have forsaken.
i)/desqe/ m): for this midd. aor., cp. Ph. 351 n. The constr. is as in Aesch. P. V. 92i)/desqe/ m' oi(=a pro\s qew=n pa/sxw qeo/s.

ku=ma is the bloodshed; za/lhs, the storm of frenzy by which it was caused: cp. Pind. O. 12. 11oi( d' a)niarai=s | a)ntiku/rsantes za/lais e)slo\n baqu\ ph/matos e)n mikrw=| peda/meiyan xro/nw|. The epithet foini/as, denoting the effect of the za/lh (i.e., really belonging, in sense, to ku=ma), has a more vivid fitness than in Soph. O. T. 24, where by buqw=n..foini/ou sa/lou is meant the pestilence.

a)mfi/dromon, ‘running around’ me.— kuklei=tai: this rare midd. is read in Her. 8. 16, mhnoeide\s poih/santes tw=n new=n e)kukleu=nto w(s perila/boien au)tou/s. But in fr. 787. 2 kuklei=tai is pass.; and so Ellendt would take it here (‘is rolled around me’),—needlessly, I think. kuklou=tai would be the more usual midd. form ( Her. 3. 157, and oft.).

oi)/m): this elision occurs in 587; Ant. 320, Ant. 1270; Ar. Ach. 590.Though it breaks the rule of Tragedy against eliding diphthongs, it was doubtless too familiar to offend the ear. The oi)\ e)me\ deilh/n in Anth. 9. 408 does not warrant us in supposing that oi)/m)=oi)/ me.

a)fronti/stws e)/xei. Cp. Tr. 366pe/mpwn ou)k a)fronti/stws: Xen. Cyr. 1. 6. 42mhde/pot' ou)=n a)fronti/stws e)/xe, ‘never be heedless.’ For the pass. form of the word, cp. duslo/giston (40 n.). It is not easy to decide whether the subject to e)/xei is Ajax, or tou)/rgon: but the usage of the adverb rather favours the view that it is Ajax. The phrase is designedly euphemistic and reticent.
nai+/as a)rwgo\n te/xnas, helpful of the seaman's art, i.e., its ministers: the gen., as in Aesch. Eum. 486a)rwga\ th=s di/khs o(rkw/mata. Cp. 201.

a(/lion o(\s e)pe/bas is the best correction of a(li/an o(\s e)pe/bas. The two short syllables o(\s e)p- then correspond with a long syllable (the first of e)mme/nontes) in v. 350; as the dochmiac metre allows. Hermann's later emendation, o(\s a(li/an e)/bas, avoids, indeed, resolving the long syllable, but unwarrantably alters e)pe/bas: nor is there much force in his reason for preferring it, viz., that the gloss e)pe/bas tw=n new=n points to a(lia=n.. plata=n, and this to a(li/an (rather than a(/lion) pla/tan. Cp. Eur. Heracl. 82a(li/w| pla/ta|.
o(\s follows ge/nos, as in 760 o(/stis refers to sw/mata in 758, and in Ant. 707 ff. o(/stis is resumed by ou(=toi.

e)pe/bas, absol., ‘embarked’ (as in Thuc. 7. 62§ 2 e)pibh/sontai),—recalling the moment when they set forth from Salamis together; a point which is lost if e)pe/bas be taken as =‘thou hast come hither.’
e)li/sswn: cp. Eur. Or. 171po/da so\n ei(li/ceis, i.e., ‘move swiftly.’

phmona\n e)parke/sont): cp. Il. 2. 873ou)de/ ti/ oi( to/ g' e)ph/rkese lugro\n o)/leqron: Od. 17. 568ou)/te ti *thle/maxos to/ g' e)ph/rkesen ou)/te tis a)/llos. Thus, though e)parkei=n could not mean literally ‘to ward off,’ epic precedent warranted its use in an equivalent sense, which was strictly that of bringing one help against a danger. In lyrics, at least, where epic associations have a large scope, it seems needless to write a)parke/sont).

The traditional reading poime/nwn is explained by the schol. in L, tw=n e)me\ poimaino/ntwn kai\ qalpo/ntwn: i.e., the sense was taken to be, ‘I see that thou, alone of my shepherds (=of those who care for me), canst help.’ But poime/nwn, in such a context, would suggest rather the idea of chieftainship (cp. poime/na law=n, naw=n poime/nes in Suppl. 767): and there can be little doubt that phmona\n is right.

a)lla/, appealing: cp. O. T. 14, etc.: Pind. O. 6. 22w)= *fi/ntis, a)lla\ zeu=con h)/dh moi sqe/nos h(mio/nwn (‘come, yoke’).— For the enclitic me before its verb, cp. El. 1359a)lla/ me | lo/gois a)pw/llus.
sunda/i+con: a(/ma toi=s botoi=s.

eu)/fhma fw/nei: cp. 591.— kako
 kakw=| didou\s a)/kos: so fr. 74 e)ntau=qa me/ntoi pa/nta ta)nqrw=pwn nosei=, | kakoi=s o(/tan qe/lwsin i)a=sqai kaka/. Her. 3. 53mh\ tw=| kakw=| to\ kako
 i)w=: Thuc. 5. 65§ 2 dianoei=tai kako
 kakw=| i)a=sqai: Plat. Prot.p. 340 E i)w/menos mei=zon to\ no/shma poiw=.— to\ ph=ma th=s a)/ths: cp. Soph. Ph. 765to\ ph=ma.. th=s no/sou: Hom. Od. 3. 152e)pi\ ga *zeu\s h)/rtue ph/ma kakoi=o.—Not, ‘make the present woe worse than the (original) plague’: th=s a)/ths would then need further definition.

qrasu/n, bold, enterprising; eu)ka/rdion, stout-hearted in facing danger; a)/treston, intrepid in the critical stress of fight. The good sense of qrasu/s is frequent in poetry from Homer onwards, though in Attic prose the bad sense predominates.

a)fo/bois, fearing no harm from man;—a pathetic epithet, which is marred by taking it as=‘not formidable’ to man. a)fo/bois..qhrsi\ is not an oxymoron (as if it meant, ‘wild creatures which are not wild,’ ‘tame beasts’): qhrsi/ is a generic term; he attacked beasts instead of men: cp. fr. 855. 12 e)n qhrsi/n, e)n brotoi=sin, e)n qeoi=s a)/nw.
deino\n xe/ras: cp. Il. 7. 457a)fauro/teros xei=ra/s te me/nos te.
oi)/moi ge/lwtos: for the gen., cp. 908 w)/moi e)ma=s a)/tas: O. C. 1399oi)/moi keleu/qou k.t.l.
de/spot), as in 485: she is a dou/lh (489).

ou)k e)kto/s; ou)k a)/yorron k.t.l. It seems more probable that in v. 384 the MSS. have lost a syllable (as mh/n) than that here we should omit the second ou)k. Cp. O. T. 430 f.: ou)k ei)s o)/leqron; ou)xi\ qa=sson; ou) pa/lin | a)/yorros oi)/kwn tw=nd' a)postrafei\s a)/pei; If here we read, ou)k e)kto\s a)/yorron e)knemei= po/da; the verse becomes much tamer; while e)kto\s, taken with a)/yorron e)knemei=, is positively weak. It may be added that the first syllable of a)/yorron here, and of kai/per in 384, must then be treated as having the time-value of -u: whereas all the other trimeters in this kommos are normal.
For e)kto\s cp. O. T. 676ou)/koun m' e)a/seis ka)kto\s ei)=;
a)/yorron is probably the adv., as in Tr. 902o(/pws a)/yorron a)ntw/|h patri/, El. 53a)/yorron h(/comen.

e)knemei= here gives the notion, ‘take forth into other pastures.’ This rare compound occurs in Theophr. Hist. Plant. 9. 16 § 1 o)li/gos o( to/pos o( fe/rwn, kai\ tou=ton ai( ai)=ges e)kne/montai, depascunt, ‘the region which bears (the plant dictamnum) is small, and is stripped of it by the browsing goats.’ The analogy of Pind. N. 6. 15, i)/xnesin e)n *pracida/mantos e(o\n po/da ne/mwn, would certainly point to e)knemei=s, but we must allow for the poetical use of the middle voice, so frequent with Sophocles. Of the midd. fut., Thuc. 4. 64§ 5 has nemou/meqa, Dem. or. 21 § 203 nemei=sqai.

w)= pro\s qew=n k.t.l. The MSS. seem right in giving this verse to the Chorus. Just after so violent a rebuke, the timid Tecmessa would scarcely venture on praying her ‘master’ to be ‘sane’; while the intercession of the Chorus is natural enough.
w)\ du/smoros: cp. Ant. 1319w)\ me/leos, where w)\ is exclamatory, and stronger than the mere sign of the vocative (w)=).
o(\s, with causal force; El. 160 n.

xeri\ me
 meqh=ka, instead of xeri\ meqh=ka me
: for the irregular place of me/n, cp. Ph. 279o(rw=nta me
 nau=s.. | ..bebw/sas, a)/ndra d' ou)de/n' e)/ntopon (instead of o(rw=nta nau=s me
). xeri\ belongs in sense to e)/deusa no less than to meqh=ka.

tou\s a)la/storas: in O. C. 788 and Tr. 1235 the word denotes ‘avenging spirits’; here, ‘accursed wretches,’ as the polluted Orestes calls himself a)la/stora ( Aesch. Eum. 236): cp. Dem. or. 18 § 296 a)/nqrwpoi miaroi\ kai\ ko/lakes kai\ a)la/stores, h)krwthriasme/noi ta\s e(autw=n e(/kastoi patri/das (‘who have crippled their respective cities’),—a passage which suggests that a)la/stwr, as said of a man, meant rather one who is a ‘curse’ or ‘plague’ to his neighbours, than one who is driven by an avenging spirit; indeed, such a passive sense is not easily conceived.
klutoi=s: from the Homeric kluta\ mh=la ( Od. 9. 308).
ai)poli/ois: Il. 11. 679ai)po/lia plate/) ai)gw=n. This is the only express mention of goats among his victims; but there is no reason to think that ai)po/lion could be used as merely =poi/mnion.
e)remno\n: suggested doubtless by Aesch. Ag. 1390e)remnh=| yaka/di foini/as dro/sou.
ai(=m' e)/deusa: cp. Tr. 848te/ggei dakru/wn a)/xnan (n.).

e)p' e)ceirgasme/nois: e)pi\ denotes the condition: Aesch. Ag. 1379e(/sthka d' e)/nq' e)/pais' e)p) e)ceirgasme/nois. (The phrase occurs also in Aesch. Pers. 525.) Cp. Soph. Ant. 556e)p' a)rrh/tois..toi=s e)moi=s lo/gois (n.).

ou) ga ge/noit' a)
 k.t.l. Two modes of expression are here mixed: (1) ou)k a)
 ge/noito tou=to ou)x w(=d' e)/xein, it could not come to pass that this should not be thus. (2) ou)k a)
 ge/noito o(/pws tou=to ou)x w(=d' e(/cei,—with the same meaning: cp. O. T. 1058f. ou)k a)
 ge/noito tou=q), o(/pws e)gw\ … | … ou) fanw= tou)mo
 ge/nos. In other words, the constr. would be plain if o(/pws were struck out. The irregular presence of o(/pws is due to its association with statements of impossibility in the formula ou)k e)/stin o(/pws ou) ( O. C. 97, El. 1479): its place is explained by the analogy of such a sentence as O. T. 1058ou)k a)
 ge/noito tou=q), o(/pws k.t.l., where tou=to is subject to ge/noito. The declension of ou)dei\s-o(/stisou), as an integral equivalent for pa=s tis, similarly illustrates the manner in which the associations of idiom could sometimes generate anomalies in grammar.

For the sentiment, cp. Tr. 742to\ ga | fanqe
 ti/s a)
 du/nait' a)
 a)ge/nhton poei=n; (n.).

pa/nq' o(rw=n: as Philoctetes says to Odysseus, Ph. 1013a)ll' h( kakh\ sh\ dia\ muxw=n ble/pous' a)ei\ | yuxh/ k.t.l., ‘thy base soul, ever peering from some ambush.’ The conjecture pa/nta drw=n is not only weak, but incorrect, since the sense would require pa=n drw=n.

a(pa/ntwn t). It is needless to change t) to d): though de/ often occurs thus in ‘epanaphora,’ as Ant. 806ta\n nea/tan o(do\n | stei/xousan, ne/aton de\ fe/ggos leu/ssousan (n.). Here the case for d) would be stronger if a(/panq) (and not pa/nq)) had preceded.
kakw=n o)/rganon: cp. Ph. 407(of Odysseus) e)/coida ga/r nin panto\s a)\n lo/gou kakou= | glw/ssh| qigo/nta kai\ panourgi/as.

a)/lhma, ‘fine meal’ (a)le/w), hence, ‘a subtle knave,’—a word found only here and in 389. paipa/lh (reduplicated from pa/lh) had the same senses, literal and figurative; and paipa/lhma was a current term ( Ar. Av. 430, Aeschin. or. 2 § 40). In fr. 827 Odysseus is called pa/nsofon kro/thma, as in Ph. 927panourgi/as | deinh=s te/xnhm' e)/xqiston.—For the early repetition of a)/lhma, in 389, cp. that of kei/somai in Ant. 76(n.).
h)= pou: cp. 176.

a)/geis. The phrase a)/gein ge/lwta denotes frequent or continued derision, as a)/gein ktu/pon=‘to keep up a noise’: Eur. Or. 182ktu/pon h)ga/get): ou)xi\ si=ga k.t.l. So nei=kos a)/gein, to sustain a conflict ( Pind. P. 9. 33): sxolh\n a)/gein, etc.

cu
 tw=| qew=|. Those who write cu/n toi qew=| here do so on the ground that su
 qew=|, not su
 tw=| qew=|, is the regular phrase when the sense is general, ‘with the divine aid’; whereas in O. T. 146su
 tw=| qew=| refers to a particular god (Apollo). But there is an arbitrary rigour in this doctrine. o( qeo/s often means ‘the divine power’ generally: e.g. frag. adesp. 471 o( ga qeo\s me/gistos a)nqrw/pois no/mos: and 496. 2 po/rrw ga e(stw\s o( qeo\s e)ggu/qen ble/pei. And this very phrase, su
 tw=| qew=|, occurs once, at least, in a passage where the context plainly indicates that the sense is general, viz. Eur. fr. 490 su
 tw=| qew=| xrh\ tou\s sofou\s a)nastre/fein | bouleu/mat' a)ei/. There, indeed, as here, Nauck changes tw=| to toi, but without any warrant.

i(/doimi k.t.l. The question whether the MSS. have lost a syllable here depends on the view taken of 369. I have given reasons for thinking that the second ou)k in that verse is genuine; from which it would follow that there is a defect here. Bellermann, indeed, is content to hold that Sophocles neglected an exact correspondence; but this seems very unlikely. L. Dindorf's remedy i)/doimi <mh/n> nin, has this advantage over the others (cr. n.), that it gives a light adversative force, and so fitly responds to v. 383, cu\n tw=| qew=| k.t.l. ‘Triumph, like defeat, is the gift of heaven.’—‘Yet would that I could see him,’ etc. The next best conjecture is perhaps that of Apitz, i)/doimi/ nu/n nin.
mhde\n: me/g' ei)/ph|s: cp. El. 830mhde\n me/g' a)u+/sh|s (n.).

propa/twr, a word used by Pindar, Eur. , and Herodotus. The reading pa/ter (requiring xeroi=n instead of xeri\ me
 in 372) had an obvious and prosaic motive; viz., that Aeacus, the grandfather of Ajax, was the son of Zeus ( Il. 21. 189), so that Zeus could not properly be called an ‘ancestor’ of the hero's ‘ancestors.’ But when the poet wrote progo/nwn propa/twr, it was enough for him that it expressed the thought, ‘author of my line’; he did not trouble himself with this subtlety.—It was the nymph Aegina who bore Aeacus to Zeus ( Plat. Gorg.p. 526 E: to
 dikasth

 th=s *ai)gi/nhs ui(o/n).

pw=s a)
 … qa/noimi: cp. Ph. 531 f. pw=s a)
 u(mi
 e)mfanh\s | e)/rgw| genoi/mhn (n.).
dissa/rxas (found only here): see on 251 dikratei=s.

o)le/ssas: cp. Ph. 1163pe/lasson. (Below, in 927, some edd. read e)canu/ssein: see n. there.) This epic licence in tragic lyrics is illustrated by their toleration of such forms as to/sson (185), me/ssos, zw/ein ( El. 157, O. C. 1213), pnei/ein ( Ant. 1146), etc.

basilh=s is the form which the grammarians Draco and Herodian read here (cr. n.). But, so far as Attic inscrr. are available, they indicate that the acc. plur. from eu stems ended in -e/a_s, always uncontracted; while the contraction in -ei=s (not -h=s) was the rule from the Macedonian age onwards. (The earliest example of tou\s basilei=s quoted by Meisterhans, Gramm. Att. Inschr. § 39, belongs to 318—311 B.C.) We must regard the acc. basilh=s here, then, not as an old Attic, but as a poetical form. On the other hand, basilh=s was the form of the nom. plur. in the older Attic (cp. 189). Herodian (l. c., cr. n.) cites nomh=s from Xenophon, as if it were an acc. pl. like basilh=s here: but in the place to which he apparently refers ( I. Cyr. 1§ 2) it is nom., and the best recent edd. give nomei=s.
qa/noimi kau)to/s: cp. Aesch. Cho. 438e)/peit' e)gw\ nosfi/sas o)loi/man.

sko/tos, the darkness of death, as the gates of Hades are sko/tou pu/lai ( Eur. Hec. 1): e)/rebos, as in Soph. O. C. 1389to\ *tarta/rou | stugno\n...e)/rebos. So, too, in Il. 8. 368 it is merely a term for ‘the nether gloom’ (e)c e)re/beus a)/conta), not a definitely named region, Erebos.
w(s e)moi/: for this limiting force of w(s, cp. O. C. 20makra\n...w(s ge/ronti: Plat. Soph.p. 226 C taxei=an, w(s e)moi/, ske/yin.

e(/lesq' e(/lesqe/ m): the most probable reading; see on 414. Here the midd. means, ‘take to yourselves’ (and not, as normally, ‘choose’): it is thus more expressive than e(/lete: cp. O. T. 887kaka/ nin e(/loito moi=ra. Conversely we find eu(rei=n where eu(re/sqai would be normal ( El. 1061).
ge/nos, as well as o)/nasin, is governed by ei)s: cp. O. T. 734*delfw=n ka)po\ *dauli/as: ib. 1205 ti/s a)/tais a)gri/ais, ti/s e)n po/nois: El. 780ou)/te nukto\s..ou)/t' e)c h(me/ras.
a)/cios. For the ellipse of ei)mi/, cp. 813 n.
ble/pein, to look for help; cp. El. 958e)s ti/n' e)lpi/dwn | ble/yas' e)/t' o)rqh/n;
a( *dio\s … qeo\s: cp. 450: O. C. 623xw( *dio\s *foi=bos.

o)le/qrion should answer metrically to eu)/frones in 420. If it be sound, the first syllable must represent the anacrusis, which is omitted before eu)/frones: and the e is long, as it is in 799 (o)leqri/an), O. T. 1341(o)le/qrion), and O. C. 1683(o)leqri/a): though we find e^ in Tr. 845(o)leqri/aisi), and ib. 878 (o)leqri/a). The neatest emendation is ou)/lion (cr. n.).
fu/gh| … menw=. For the delib. subjunct. combined with fut. indic., cp. Tr. 973ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai;
ei) ta\ me\n fqi/nei k.t.l. The conjectures of various critics are recorded and classified in the Appendix. Here I will briefly state what seem the main points of the problem.

(1) The antistrophic verses, 423—427 (e)cerw=...pro/keimai), appear sound. The changes which have been proposed in them have all been designed to suit some emendation in 405 ff., and would have no probability if verses 423 ff. were considered simply on their own merits.

(2) There is only one real discrepancy of metre between the traditional text here and that of the antistrophe; viz., that toi=sd) in 406 answers to the tina of ou)/tina in 424, where the a, being the last syllable of a verse, could be either long or short, and is here long. (Some, indeed, read ou)/tin' a(: cr. n.) That is, instead of toi=sd), we require u-. As to e)cere/w in 423, answering to ei) ta\ me\n in 405, we should write e)cerw=. With regard to the diction of 405 ff., the most suspicious point is the redundancy o(mou= pe/las, suggesting that one of the words was a gloss upon the other.

(3) If, then, we assume that the antistrophe is sound, we may conclude that the fault in the strophe lies within the words ei) ta\ me\n fqi/nei, fi/loi, toi=sd' o(mou= pe/las. A very slight change will restore the metre, viz. toioi=sd) for toi=sd): cp. the words of Ajax in 453 w(/st' e)n toioi=sde xei=ras ai(ma/cai botoi=s. There he points to the slain cattle around him; and so he probably does here also. We could then understand the sense to be: ‘If those things (ta\ me\n, his glories in the past) perish, my friends, o(mou= toioi=sde, along with (i.e., by the slaughter of) such creatures, pe/las, near me there.’ But pe/las may have been a marginal gloss (on o(mou=), which has displaced some other word: e.g., the poet may have written toioi=sd' o(mou= botoi=s (cp. v. 453).

(4) Whatever may have been the original form of the words ei) ta\ me\n fqi/nei, fi/loi, toi=sd' o(mou= pe/las, it is at least highly probable that their general sense was, ‘If my old renown is perishing.’ This is suggested by the other passages where we find the same sequence of ideas,—i.e., the thought of his past glory closely followed by that of his present disgrace; see (1) 421—427: (2) 437—456: (3) 612—621.

(5) Those who believe that the antistrophic verses 423—427 are corrupt have a freer hand for emendation here; and, as will be seen in the Appendix, some of the proposed restorations have been very bold. But such remedies pass into the region of pure guess-work.

proskei/meqa, ‘addicted’ to them. Her. 3. 34filoini/h|...proske/esqai. The word can also denote, in a good sense, that to which the attention is given, as Thuc. (1. 93 § 7) says of Themistocles, tai=s ga\r nausi\ ma/lista prose/keito.

mw/rais. L has mwrai=s (as it has mwra\n in El. 890), that being the later accent, according to the general rule that adjectives in -ros are oxytone. But the grammarians attest that the Attic accent was mw=ros. See, e.g., Eustath. p. 245. 17 mw=ros par' *)attikoi=s, o( para\ toi=s u(/steron mwro/s: and Chandler, Greek Accentuation, § 404 (2nd ed.).

di/paltos, in active sense (cp. a)/yaustos e)/gxous, O. T. 969 n.), wielding their swords with both hands, i.e., with their utmost force. I. T. 323 w(s d' ei)/domen di/palta polemi/wn ci/fh. That the word had passed into a figurative sense (in which di- was merely equiv. to ‘fiercely’), is indicated by tripa/ltwn phma/twn in Aesch. Th. 985, woes hurled on one with crushing force. di/paltos should not be explained with ref. to the two spears of the Homeric warrior ( Il. 5. 495pa/llwn d' o)ce/a dou=re).

fwnei=n, exclamatory: Aesch. Eum. 837e)me\ paqei=n ta/de. It was common in colloquial Attic; see e.g. Vesp. 835 ba/ll' e)s ko/rakas: toioutoni\ tre/fein ku/na. For this inf. with the article added, see Ph. 234feu= to\ kai\ labei=n (n.).
e)/tlh, of what one brings oneself to do; here, ‘deigned.’ Cp. 528, Tr. 158.

po/roi a(li/rroqoi: probably ‘paths or straits of the sounding sea,’ as in Aesch. Pers. 367e)/kplous fula/ssein kai\ po/rous a(lirro/qous: meaning here the waters of the Hellespont. His thought passes from those waters to the pa/rala a)/ntra beside them, and thence to the neighbouring woodlands. For the form of the phrase, cp. Soph. O. C. 1062r(imfarma/tois...a(mi/llais.—The other version, ‘paths by the sounding sea,’ is possible, but less probable.
ne/mos, properly pasture simply; but associated with trees in Il. 11. 480e)n ne/mei+ skierw=| (a phrase repeated in Anth. 7. 55). In the Lat. nemus the notion of ‘woodland’ is seen dominant.

As I have noted in writing on the Troad elsewhere, ‘nearly all the plains and hills are more or less well-wooded. Besides the valonia oak, the elm, willow, cypress and tamarisk shrub abound. Lotus, galingale, and reeds are still plentiful, as in Homeric days, about the streams in the Trojan plain.’ (Encyc. Brit., art. ‘Troad,’ vol. XXIII. p. 578.)
polu\n polu/n me k.t.l. This order of words has the best authority, and is confirmed by the metre. Cp. 396.
dh\ merely emphasises daro/n.

a)mpnoa\s e)/xonta=e)/mpnoun o)/nta. The proper sense of a)napnoh/ is (1) ‘recovery of breath’; or (2) =ei)spnoh/ as opp. to e)kpnoh/, the drawing in of breath. Here, however, it means merely pnoh/, as=‘the breath of life.’ Cp. Eur. Or. 421mhtro\s oi)/xontai pnoai/.

*skama/ndrioi … r(oai/: cp. Il. 2. 467e)n leimw=ni *skamandri/w| a)nqemo/enti. The Scamander, still called the Mendere, is the most important river of the Troad. Rising in Ida, it flows through the central plain which now bears the name of the town Bairamitch, and thence passes northward into the plain of Troy. On the confines between the two plains, where the river winds in large curves through deep gorges in limestone rocks, its scenery is striking. From the south border of the Trojan plain to the Hellespont, the Mendere has a course of between seven and eight miles.

eu)/frones *)argei/ois: as supplying them with water. So in 863 the potamoi/ of the plain are called trofh=s.— Not: ‘friendly to my Greek foes, but hostile to me.’ Nor should the words be taken adverbially with ou)ke/t' a)/ndra mh\ to/nd' i)/dht), as meaning, ‘No longer, allies of the Greeks, will ye see me,’— i.e., ‘You will no longer see me victorious beside your favouring stream.’
ou)ke/t' a)/ndra mh\ to/nd' i)/dht): ou) mh\ with subjunct. gives a strong emphasis; cp. 83, 560.

e)cerw= gives an exact correspondence with ei) ta\ me\n in 405. The e)cere/w of the MSS. might, indeed, be compared with El. 178u(pera/xqeo, O. C. 227u(pe/sxeo, ib. 1244 klone/ousin. (In Tr. 639kale/ontai should be kle/ontai.) But e)cere/w was so familiar as the Homeric form that it could easily have displaced e)cerw= here. It is not likely that the poet would have written e)cere/w if he had meant the word to be scanned -u- by synizesis.
Join ou)/tina with stratou=: cp. 1175 kei)/ tina stratou=.
xqono\s molo/nt' a)po\ | *(ellani/dos: for the place of a)po/, and for the hiatus, cp. Tr. 510*bakxi/as a)po\ | h)=lqe...*qh/bas.

This vaunt of Ajax (modified only by the half-apologetic e)/pos e)cerw= me/ga) is epic in tone; thus Achilles says of himself (Il. 18. 105), toi=os e)w\n oi(=os ou)/tis *axaiw=n xalkoxitw/nwn: Odysseus, (Od. 9. 19,)
o(\s pa=si do/loisin
a)nqrw/poisi me/lw, kai/ meu kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei. Such a tone is better suited, indeed, to epos (in which speech is sometimes little more than audible thought) than to drama. But here, at least, as in the case of Heracles ( Tr. 1101 f.), it has the excuse of being prompted by the anguish of a sudden overthrow. (Cp. n. on O. T. 8, where Oedipus speaks of himself as o( pa=si kleino/s.)

pro/keimai: lie prostrate (323 ff.): cp. 1059.—The v.l. pro/keitai was caused by a)/ndra … to/nde: but cp. O. C. 1329, where tw=|d' a)ndri\ (=e)moi\) is immediately followed by tou)mou=, as in O. T. 534tou=de ta)ndro\s by th=s e)mh=s. See also below, O. T. 865.

ou)/toi … ou)d). There can be little doubt that the ou)/q) of the MSS. should be ou)d) here. In El. 1197 and 1412 L has ou)/q), where ou)d) is right; as in O. C. 496mh/q) instead of mhd). As to the conditions under which ou) … ou)/te was admitted in Attic poetry, see on Tr. 1058 f.

o(/pws e)w= (subjunct.), the indirect form of the ‘deliberative’ pw=s e)w=; (‘how am I to allow..?’) Cp. O. T. 1367ou)k oi)=d' o(/pws se fw= bebouleu=sqai kalw=s: Dem. or. 9 § 54 ou)k e)/xw ti/ le/gw.
a)\n … w)/|eq), ‘could have thought’; cp. 119 ti/s a)\n..hu(re/qh;

e)pw/numon here goes closely with cunoi/sein, ‘would agree so significantly’ with my woes. Hence in 914 he is called dusw/numos. For the verb, cp. Ar. Eq. 1232kai\ mh/n s' e)le/gcai bou/lomai tekmhri/w|, | ei)/ ti cunoi/seis tou= qeou= toi=s qesfa/tois, i.e., ‘agree’ with the description of the person mentioned in them. For the adj., cp. Hom. Od. 7. 54*)arh/th d' o)/nom' e)sti\n e)pw/numon: ib. 19. 409 tw=| d' *)oduseu\s o)/nom' e)/stw e)pw/numon: where in each case e)pw/numon means that the name is significant (the queen was the ‘desired one’; the child was to be ‘a man of wrath’). This usage of e)pw/numos, with ref. to the aptness of a name (or surname), is different from that in which a person or thing is said to be e)pw/numo/s tinos, either as (1) being named from it, or (2) giving a name to it. Cp. 574.

Pindar adopts the derivation of *ai)/as from ai)eto/s: I. 5. 53 kai/ nin o)/rnixos fane/ntos ke/klet' e)pw/numon eu)rubi/an *ai)/anta. This was the popular etymology (schol. Apoll. Rh. 1. 1289; schol. Theocr. 13. 37: Apollod. 3. 12 § 7). But the association of *ai)/as with ai)= ai)= appears in the legend that a hyacinth (on whose petals the letters AI were supposed to be legible, Moschus 3. 6) sprang from the blood of Ajax, as it had sprung from that of Hyacinthus: Ov. Met. 13. 397: Littera communis mediis pueroque viroque | Inscripta est foliis; haec nominis (Ajax), illa querelae (the wail of Hyacinthus).

So Odysseus was associated with o)du/ssomai ( Od. 1. 62ti/ nu/ oi( to/son w)du/sao, *zeu=; imitated by Soph. , fr. 880): Pentheus, with pe/nqos ( Eur. Bacch. 507): Polyneices, with nei=kos ( Aesch. Th. 577, etc., Soph. Ant. 110 f.): Meleager, with mele/a a)/gra ( Eur. fr. 517): Sidêro with si/dhros ( Soph. fr. 597): and Helen is e)le/naus, etc. ( Aesch. Ag. 689).

Such play on names did not seem to the Greeks unworthy of grave poetry, because to them the omens conveyed by words (o)mfai/, klhdo/nes) were so serious. In modern poetry, too, it has sometimes been used with tragic pathos. Thus Dante Purg. XIII. 109 Savia non fui, avvegna che Sapía Fossi chiamata: and Shakesp. Rich. II. act 2 sc. 1. 73 (Gaunt) O how that name befits my composition! | Old Gaunt indeed; and gaunt in being old etc. The king asks, Can sick men play so nicely with their names? No, is the reply, misery makes sport to mock itself.

The real etymology of *ai)/as is uncertain. Vase-inscriptions show that the original form was *ai)/vas, and Sonne (in Kuhn's Zeitschr. 10 p. 126) compares Indog. aiva, Skr. eva (‘course’)—a derivation which Brugmann approves (Stud. z. griech. u. lat. Gramm. 4. 180). The sense, ‘swift runner,’ would suit *oi)lh=os taxu\s *ai)/as better than the son of Telamon: and it is not improbable (as Fleischer suggests in Roscher's Lex.p. 139) that the names of the two heroes, though identical in form, were of distinct origin.
kai\ di\s … kai\ tri/s: cp. Ph. 1238di\s tau)ta\ bou/lei kai\ tri\s a)napolei=n m' e)/ph;
toiou/tois ga\r: for ga/r in two successive sentences, cp. 186.
path\r: Telamon, whom Heracles brought with him to the war at Troy, as Pindar relates ( Isthm. 5. 27 ff.), and rewarded with the hand of Hesionè (1300 ff.).

ta\ prw=ta kallistei=) a)risteu/sas, a free poetical mode of saying, ‘having won by prowess the first meed of honour.’ The word kallistei=a (properly ‘prize for beauty’) may have been chosen because the prize was Hesionè. Cp. 1300 stratou= ta\ prw=t' a)risteu/sas.

to/pon *troi/as, i.e. *troi/an: a periphrasis like to\n *kiqairw=nos to/pon ( O. T. 1134). Here *troi/a is used in the Homeric manner, to denote not only the city but the country; h( *trw|a/s, as=‘the Troad,’ occurs first in Herodotus (5. 122).
e)pelqw\n, after Telamon; cp. e)pigi/gnomai.

a)rke/sas has here (though not elsewhere) a sense which e)parkei=n with acc. often bears, viz., ‘to furnish at need’: Aesch. Ag. 1170a)/kos d' ou)de\n e)ph/rkesan. The strict meaning is then, ‘having rendered no less service by the deeds of my hand.’
tosou=to/n g' e)cepi/stasqai: cp. O. T. 1455kai/toi tosou=to/n g' oi)=da (and El. 332). Her. 7. 152e)pi/stamai de\ tosou=to, o(/ti k.t.l. Here the omission of o(/ti adds vigour to ei) zw=n k.t.l.

ei) … kri/nein e)/melle, ‘if he had been going to award,’ ‘if it had devolved upon him to award.’ The imperfect (here referring to an unreal condition in past, not in present, time) is rightly used, because it expresses the constraint of a supposed situation. But in the apodosis, the aor., ou)k a)/n tis e)/maryen, is used, because the taking of the prize is an act done at a given moment.

o(/plwn tw=n w(=n pe/ri, i.e. in a case where they were the prize. Sophocles has o(/s, suus, (epic e(o/s,) in O. T. 1248(oi(=sin), O. C. 1639 and Tr. 266(w(=n), ib. 525 (o(/n). Here it is emphatic: ‘his own arms,’—of which he could dispose with the best right.
kri/nein … kra/tos a)ristei/as, to award the first place for prowess; cp. Pind. I. 7. 5a)e/qlwn..kra/tos, victory in them. For the pres. inf. kri/nein with e)/melle, cp. Soph. O. C. 1774 n.
e)/maryen, praeripuisset; the prize due to Ajax was snatched from him.
a)nt' e)mou=: so Aesch. P. V. 467ou)/tis a)/llos a)nt' e)mou=.
nu=n d), with ref. to a past moment (‘but as it was’); so in 450, Tr. 88, El. 1334.
pantourgw=| occurs only here as=panou/rgw|: cp. panto/tolmos as=pa/ntolmos. Cp. Aesch. Th. 671fwti\ panto/lmw| fre/nas.

e)/pracan. Though pra/ssein oft. denotes intrigue ( O. T. 125), the phrase pra/ssein ti/ tini (‘to procure a thing for one by intrigue’) is peculiar. Cp. Plut. Pomp. 51pra/ttein me\n e(autoi=s e)parxiw=n kai\ stratope/dwn h(gemoni/as.
a)pw/santes, ‘having thrust out of account,’=a)tima/santes. The midd. is usual as=‘to reject’ ( Tr. 216); but the act. here is not a mere equivalent for it.
kra/th: cp. El. 689ou)k oi)=da toiou=d' a)ndro\s e)/rga kai\ kra/th.

to/d' o)/mma: some force and pathos are lost by reading to/ t' o)/mma (with xai(). Cp. Athena's words (51) dusfo/rous e)p' o)/mmasi | gnw/mas balou=sa.— dia/strofoi: Aesch. P. V. 673(Io speaking of herself) eu)qu\s de\ morfh\ kai\ fre/nes dia/strofoi | h)=san.
th=s e)mh=s is emphatic: my true purpose: so 100 ta)/m): 442 tw=n w(=n.

ou)k a)/n pote … e)yh/fisan: i.e., they would have died before they could repeat such a villainy. See on v. 100, qano/ntes ..a)fairei/sqwn. The midd. yhfi/zomai di/khn means ‘to decide a cause by one's vote’; Isae. or. 3 § 7 toi=s peri\ au)tou= tou/tou th
 di/khn me/llousi yhfiei=sqai. And for kat' a)/llou fwto\s cp. Plat. Gorg.p. 515 E ou)demi/an ai)sxra
 di/khn kateyhfi/santo au)tou=. The act. yhfi/zw usu.=‘to count’ (as Polyb. 5. 26 kata\ th
 tou= yhfi/zontos bou/lhsin, ‘at the reckoner's will’). Here, di/khn e)yh/fisan has the general sense of di/khn e)yhfi/santo: but it is not directly modelled on that prose idiom: rather it is a new poetical phrase, meaning strictly, ‘get a cause decided by yh=foi.’ It implies that the votes against Ajax were secured by the intrigues of the chiefs: cp. Pind. N. 8. 26 f. krufi/aisi ga e)n ya/fois *)odussh= *danaoi\ qera/peusan: | xruse/wn d' *ai)/as sterhqei\s o(/plwn fo/nw| pa/laisen. [e)yh/fisan certainly has not the technical sense of e)peyh/fisan, as if the Atreidae were the h(gemo/nes dikasthri/ou, who put the issue to the vote. Even if the simple yhfi/zw could be so used, this would be too technical and prosaic.]
h( *dio\s … qea\: cp. 401.

gorgw=pis, as in fr. 760. 2 the poet calls her th\n *dio\s gorgw=pin *)erga/nhn. Cp. Il. 1. 199, where Athena appears to Achilles: au)ti/ka d' e)/gnw | *palla/d' *)aqhnai/hn: deinw\ de/ oi( o)/sse fa/anqen.
a)da/matos is the form required by metre in O. T. 205, O. T. 1315, and O. C. 1572; though in all three passages L gives the epic form a)da/mastos.

e)pentu/non<*> ‘making ready’: schol. eu)trepi/zonta. Il. 8. 374a)lla\ su\ me\n nu=n nw=in e)pe/ntue mw/nuxas i(/ppous. Oppian Hal. 5. 562h)/dh ga\r delfi=sin e)pentu/nousin *)/arha.—The reading e)peuqu/nont) seems less fitting in reference to the purpose which the goddess foiled. It rather pictures him as already in the act of stretching forth his hand against his foes. But Athena had not suffered him to arrive in their presence; he had only reached their doors (49). If, however, e)peuqu/nont) is to mean merely, ‘preparing for use against them,’ then it is decidedly less vivid than e)pentu/nont). The chief recommendation of e)peuqu/nont) is the fact that it was first written by the scribe of L, though corrected either by him or by an early hand. But (since eu)qu/nw was so familiar) it may easily have been a mere slip for the rarer and more exquisite word e)pentu/nont).
lussw/dh no/son: cp. 59: fr. 855. 4 lu/ssa maina/s. In Il. 13. 53Hector is lussw/dhs, flogi\ ei)/kelos.
e)peggelw=sin. A compound used in Attic prose, but otherwise peculiar to this play; it recurs in vv. 969, 989.
e)mou= me\n: the particle merely emphasises the pron.: cp. 121 n.
bla/ptoi: cp. El. 696o(/tan de/ tis qew=n | bla/pth|, du/nait' a)\n ou)d' a)\n i)sxu/wn fugei=n (n.).
o(/stis, causal. It is needless to read dra=n m). See on O. C. 263ka)/moige pou= tau=t' e)sti/n; oi(/tines k.t.l. (i.e. e)pei\ u(mei=s).

misei= de/ m): the relative clause passes into an independent sentence; see appendix on O. C. 424.— pedi/a: for the tribrach in the 5th foot, consisting of a single word, cp. O. T. 719a)/baton o)/ros (n.), ib. 1496 pate/ra path/r.
po/tera: cp. 265 n.
naulo/xous … e(/dras. Cp. Eur. Hec. 1015*)axaiw=n nau/loxoi periptuxai/ (the Greek camp at the ships, with its tei=xos).

mo/nous t' *)atrei/das (lipw/n), i.e., leaving them bereft of my aid. Eur. Med. 52pw=s sou= mo/nh *mh/deia lei/pesqai qe/lei; Cp. Il. 9. 437, where Phoenix imagines himself remaining with the army at Troy after Achilles has gone home,—pw=s a)\n e)/peit' a)po\ sei=o, fi/lon te/kos, au)=qi lipoi/mhn | oi)=os;
kai\ poi=on..; for kai/ in questions, cp. O. C. 263(n.), El. 236.
o)/mma: so O. T. 1371e)gw\ ga\r ou)k oi)=d' o)/mmasin poi/ois ble/pwn | pate/ra pot' a)\n prosei=don: Ph. 110pw=s ou)=n ble/pwn tis tau=ta tolmh/sei lakei=n;
gumno\n is defined by tw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter: cp. Ph. 31kenh\n oi)/khsin a)nqrw/pwn di/xa: O. T. 57e)/rhmos a)ndrw=n mh\ cunoikou/ntwn e)/sw: Ant. 445e)/cw barei/as ai)ti/as e)leu/qeron.

w(=n … eu)klei/as ste/fanon (‘a glory-crown of which’..): both genitives define the quality of the ste/fanos, but eu)klei/as goes more closely with it: cp. 308 f. e)reipi/ois | nekrw=n...a)rnei/ou fo/nou.
a)lla\ dh=t), introducing another alternative, as in El. 537(n.).
e)/ruma, their city-wall; cp. Her. 7. 223to\ e)/ruma tou= tei/xeos.

mo/nos mo/nois: for the doubled adj., see on 267. The point of mo/nois is that the Trojans will not have their attention distracted by any other Greek foe. The phrase is thus an expression of the warrior's proud self-reliance (cp. 423 f.): it is marred by reading polloi=s mo/nos (cr. n.).

drw=n ti xrhsto/n: for the order of words, cp. Ar. Ach. 128a)ll' e)rga/somai/ ti deino\n e)/rgon kai\ me/ga. The sense of dra=n ti alone is often similar: El. 305n. The pres. part., not dra/sas, because he would die in the act.—There was a legend, which the poet glances at here, that Ajax, in his madness, attacked the Trojans with success; manu restituit praelium insaniens ( Cic. Tusc. 4. 23); and that his death was caused by an arrow from the bow of Paris: see n. on the Argument to the play, line 33.
*)atrei/das … eu)fra/naimi/ pou. Verg. Aen. 2. 104 Hoc Ithacus velit et magno mercentur Atreidae.
ou)k e)/sti tau=ta, as in Tr. 449: but ou)k e)/sti simply, ib. 709, Ant. 289, El. 448.
dhlw/sw … gegw/s: cp. Thuc. 1. 21§ 2 dhlw/sei...mei/zwn gegenhme/nos: Andoc. or. 4 § 14 e)dh/lwse tw=n no/mwn katafronw=n.

mh/ toi fu/sin g): for mh/ toi...ge, see on El. 518.toi (‘at any rate,’ Lat. sane) limits, while ge emphasises the word which it follows. Note that ou)/ toi could be used here, if the result were viewed simply as a fact; O. C. 1353(a)kou/sas) toiau=q' a(\ to\n tou=d' ou)/ pot' eu)franei= bi/on. But mh/ toi is used, because the result is viewed as an aim; i.e., the relative clause is virtually a final clause: cp. Isocr. or. 11 § 49 toiau=ta zhth/seis le/gein, e)c w(=n mh/t' au)to\s xei/rwn ei)=nai do/ceis mh/te tou\s mimoume/nous lumanei= mh/te th\n peri\ tou\s lo/gous pai/deusin diabalei=s.
a)/splagxnos, only here in this sense; but cp. kako/splagxnos ( Aesch. Th. 237), qrasu/splagxnos: and eu)splagxni/a [Eur. ] Rhes. 192.
tou= makrou= … bi/ou, i.e., the normal span of life; cp. O. T. 518ou)/toi bi/ou moi tou= makrai/wnos po/qos.

kakoi=sin … mhde
 e)calla/ssetai, finds no variation in respect to his woes; for the dat. cp. O. T. 25fqi/nousa me
 ka/lucin: Xen. Cyr. 4. 1. 8diefqa/rqai..tai=s gnw/mais. The generic negative mhde
 is used, because o(/stis refers to a class or type. (Cp. Soph. Ant. 178 f. o(/stis..mh\..a(/ptetai.) For the sentiment, cp. Soph. Ant. 463o(/stis ga e)n polloi=sin, w(s e)gw/, kakoi=s | zh=|, pw=s o(/d' ou)xi\ katqanw
 ke/rdos fe/rei; fr. 866 o(/stis ga e)n kakoi=sin i(mei/rei bi/ou, | h)\ deilo/s e)stin h)\ dusa/lghtos fre/nas.

par' h)=mar h(me/ra, ‘the successive’ (not, ‘alternate’) ‘days’: the series formed by placing each new day at the side of its predecessors, as a)nh par' a)/ndra could be said of forming men in rank. The sense is: ‘When a man's miseries are unbroken, ti/ te/rpein e)/xei h(me/ra par' h)=mar, what power to please him has each successive day, prosqei=sa (au)to
) tw=| katqanei=n, when it has brought him close up to death, ka)naqei=sa tou= katqanei=n, and then again moved him back from death?’ Death is the boundary-line (grammh/) on the field of life: Eur. El. 955pri
 a)
 pe/las | grammh=s i(/khtai kai\ te/los ka/myh| bi/ou (mors ultima linea rerum). The man who is captive to evil fortune is like a pesso/s on the draughtboard, at one moment moved close up to the line, and then again withdrawn from it a little; but it is death, after all,—death and nothing else,—that awaits him (tou= ge katqanei=n). This is not the platitude, ‘all men must die’, but a thought sug gested by the case of the man ‘whose woes are unvarying.’ Life has nothing in store for him; the question is merely whether he is to die at once, or to have a short and wretched reprieve. This is brought out by v. 479: kalw=s zh=n is denied to him; and that being so, the next best thing is to die honourably and quickly—kalw=s teqnhke/nai.

prosqei=sa: cp. I. A. 540 pri
 *(/aidh| pai=d' e)mh
 prosqw= labw/n: Hec. 368*(/aidh| prostiqei=s' e)mo
 de/mas. The dat. tw=| katqanei=n is easily supplied from the genitive, which is adapted to the nearer participle.
ka)naqei=sa. Cp. a)nati/qesqai, to ‘take back’ a move, to ‘retract’ an opinion ( Xen. Mem. 1. 2§ 44, etc.).
priai/mhn: cp. Eur. fr. 934 fi/lon pri/asqai xrhma/twn pollw=n safh=.
lo/gou here=‘estimate,’ ‘rate of value’: cp. O. C. 1225mh\ fu=nai to\n a(/panta nika=| lo/gon (n.).
teqnhke/nai: for the perf., cp. 275 n.: for the sentiment, El. 1320, h)\ ga\r a)\n kalw=s | e)/sws' e)mauth/n, h)\ kalw=s a)pwlo/mhn.
pa/nt' a)kh/koas lo/gon: cp. Tr. 876pa/nt' a)kh/koas: Ph. 241oi)=sqa dh\ to\ pa=n: Aesch. Ag. 582pa/nt' e)/xeis lo/gon.
u(po/blhton: see on 188 u(poballo/menoi. Eustath. p. 106. 7 *sofoklh=s u(pobolimai/ous ei)=pe lo/gous tou\s mh\ gnhsi/ous. (In O. C. 794, u(po/blhton sto/ma, the sense is, ‘suborned.’)
ge me/ntoi: O. T. 442 n.— krath=sai, aor., as the sense is, ‘to gain a victory.’ Cp. 1353.

th=s a)nagkai/as tu/xhs. The phrase means simply, ‘a fortune imposed by a)na/gkh,’—by necessity, fate; but it has different shades of meaning according to the context. Here, it is the fortune by which a)na/gkh has doomed her to be a slave; but there is no direct reference to slavery in the words. Cp. 803. In El. 48a)nagkai/as tu/xhs is the ‘fatal chance’ by which Orestes was killed. In Il. 16. 836h)=mar a)nagkai=on is ‘the day of doom’ hanging over Troy.
ei)/per tino\s sqe/nontos,=sqe/nontos, ei)/ tis e)/sqene: cp. O.C. 733 pro\s po/lin d' e)pi/stamai | sqe/nousan h(/kwn, ei)/ tin' *(ella/dos, me/ga (n.).
e)n plou/tw|, lit., amid wealth; i.e., the phrase = ‘strong and rich,’ rather than, ‘strong in riches.’ Cp. Aesch. Eum. 996xai/ret' e)n ai)simi/aisi plou/tou.
qeoi=s: for the synizesis, cp. 1129: El. 1264 n.
ma/lista: i.e., as the immediate and visible agent of the gods.
toigarou=n, ‘So then’—marking that she turns away from the mournful past.
to\ so\n le/xos cunh=lqon: le/xos is acc., as after a verb of motion: Eur. Phoen. 817h( de\ cu/naimon le/xos h)=lqen. (In Soph. Tr. 28le/xos is rather nom., ‘as bride.’)
ta\ sa/, acc. of respect, instead of soi.

e)festi/ou *dio\s, the god of the domestic e(sti/a. In Her. 1. 44 the *)epi/stios *zeu/s is the god who punishes a wrong done to the hearth by an abuse of hospitality. Cp. Eustath. p. 1930. 28 e)n th=| kat' oi)=kon e(sti/a| *di+/ e)gi/nonto qusi/ai, o(\n oi( me\n a)/lloi e)fe/stion, *(hro/dotos de\ *)iwnikw=s le/gei e)pi/stion.
sunhlla/xqhs: cp. Eur. Andr. 1245*(ele/nw| sunallaxqei=san eu)nai/ois ga/mois,—where, as here, the bride became such by the fortune of war.
ba/cin labei=n … u(p' e)xqrw=n: cp. Her. 9. 78e)/painon e(/ceis..u(po\ pa/ntwn: Eur. Phoen. 576kle/os | toio/nde..u(f' *(ellh/nwn labei=n.
xeiri/an=u(poxei/rion: Eur. Cycl. 177e)la/bete *troi/an th\n *(ele/nhn te xeiri/an.
e)fei\s, having yielded up: Thuc. 1. 95§ 6 oi(=s ou)ke/ti e)fi/esan oi( cu/mmaxoi th\n h(gemoni/an.

h(=| ga\r qa/nh|s su\ k.t.l. The reason for preferring Bothe's h(=| to ei) is that it brings out her thought with greater force: the last day of his life will be the first of her misery. There is no objection to ei) with the subjunctive, even in trimeters; cp. O. C. 1443ei)/ sou sterhqw=, and see O.T. 198 n. Either ei) or h(=| would have been written EI by Sophocles.

a)fh=|s, sc. me: but it is needless to write m' a)fh=|s with Brunck. For the omission of the pron. in acc., cp. Ph. 801e)/mprhson (‘burn me’): ib. 769 e(/khlon eu(/dein (sc. au)to/n): ib. 1368 pe/myon (sc. me): O.T. 461 ka)\n la/bh|s e)yeusme/non.—For the sense of a)fh=|s, cp. Ant. 887a)/fete mo/nhn, e)/rhmon: Her. 8. 70a)pe/ntes th\n e(wutw=n a)fu/lakton.

cunarpasqei=san. Ajax being now viewed as a public enemy (1132), his property, including the dou/lh and her son, would be seized by the Greek chiefs.— douli/an: the comparative rarity of the fem. form led to dou/lin displacing it in some MSS. (cr. n.); but cp. Aesch. Ag. 1084douli/a|..freni/: Her. 3. 14e)sqh=ti douli/h| (or doulhi/h|). The Attic prose word would be doulikh/n.
trofh/, mode of life; El. 1183dusmo/rou..trofh=s: O.C. 1687 du/soiston e(/comen trofa/n.

kai/ tis k.t.l. A reminiscence of Il. 6. 459 ff. (where Hector forebodes the fate of Andromachè) kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin, i)dw\n kata\ da/kru xe/ousan: | ‘*(/ektoros h(/de gunh/, o(\s a)risteu/eske ma/xesqai | *trw/wn i(ppoda/mwn, o(/te *)/ilion a)mfema/xonto.’

pikro\n pro/sfqegma … e)rei= describes what will be said, not to her, but of her; cp. Polit. p. 287 E a)ggei=on o(\ dh\ mia=| klh/sei prosfqeggo/meqa (call by that name). Cp. El. 1213ou)/ soi prosh/kei th/nde prosfwnei=n fa/tin (sc. au)to/n), i.e., to speak of him as dead. The reference of pikro\n is not only to the scornful word o(meune/tin, but also to oi(/as latrei/as k.t.l.

lo/gois i)a/ptwn, lit. ‘shooting with words,’—launching taunts like missiles. The instrum. dat. lo/gois marks the figurative sense of i)a/ptwn, just as to/cois defines its literal sense in Aesch. Ag. 510(to/cois i)a/ptwn mhke/t' ei)s h(ma=s be/lh): the object answering to the literal be/lh (such as o)nei/dh) is left to be understood. Cp. Rhianus (3rd cent. B.C.) ap. Stobaeus Flor. 4. 34. 9 maka/ressin e)pi\ yo/gon ai)no\n i)a/ptei (by tmesis for e)pia/ptei). This seems truer than to suppose that the constr. is lo/gois i)a/ptwn (me), ‘assailing me with taunts,’ though the latter view might be supported by the rare use of i)a/llw in Od. 13. 142presbu/taton kai\ a)/riston a)ti- mi/h|sin i)a/llein. As to the root of i)a/ptw, Curtius holds that i)a-p is expanded from i)a (=Skt. jA, ‘go’), in a causative sense, by the determinative p, just as the Lat. <*>a-c is by k. (Greek Verb, p. 167 Eng. ed.) Cp. 700.

i(/sxuse would usu. be an ‘ingressive’ aor. (‘became powerful’), like e)no/shse etc. Here, however, it refers to the past period of his pre-eminence; as the reign of a king is summed up in retrospect by h)=rce, e)basi/leuse. Cp. the aor. in El. 1144(trofh=s) th\n e)gw\ qa/m' a)mfi\ soi\ | po/nw| glukei= pare/sxon: where Electra looks back on a closed chapter of her life.
oi(/as … o(/sou: for this double relative in contrasts, cp. 923, El. 751, Tr. 1045, etc.; Thuc. 5. 7§ 2, Thuc. 7. 75§ 6.
zh/lou, enviable happiness; cp. Dem. or. 23 § 64 a(\ kai\ zh=lo/n tina kai\ timh\n fe/rei th=| po/lei.
tre/fei, only a stronger e)/xei,—has around her in her daily life. Cp. 503: Tr. 817o)/gkon..o)no/matos..tre/fein: Ph. 795tre/foite..no/son.

ka)me\ me\n k.t.l. The chief emphasis is on the clause soi\ d' ai)sxra\ k.t.l.: she merely glances at the results to herself; ‘while I shall suffer, thou and thine will be disgraced.’ e)la=|, vexabit, as in 756; cp. also 275.

ai)sxra\: Ajax had said that it was ai)sxro/n, in such a case as his, to go on living (473). Tecmessa wishes him to feel that it would be ai)sxro/n to die. But Ajax believes that Teucer's care will avert the evils which she fears (562).

ai)/desai … prolei/pwn. The participle, when used with ai)sxu/nomai or ai)dou=mai, implies that the person is doing, or has done, the act which causes shame. The infinitive implies that he has not yet done it. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 5. 1§ 21 kai\ tou=to me
 ou)k ai)sxu/nomai le/gwn: to\ d' ‘e)a
 me/nhte par' e)moi/, a)podw/sw,’.. ai)sxunoi/mhn a)
 ei)pei=n: (‘I am not ashamed of saying this; but I should be ashamed to say that.’) Here, prolei/pwn is more forcible than an infinitive. Since his words pointed to a fixed resolve (479 f.), she speaks as if he were already engaged in the deed.

klhrou=xon is not elsewhere thus used, but the fact that a word had a technical (and prosaic) sense was no bar to its figurative use in Attic poetry; cp. pra/ktwr and eu)/qunos ( El. 953 n.). Isocr. or. 5 § 136 has the phrase eu)noi/as..klhrono/mous (‘heirs’).
a)ra=tai, in a good sense, as in O. C. 1445, where see n.

oi)/ktire..ei) k.t.l. A clause with ei) and fut. indic. often denotes an object of pity or indignation ( El. 1210, Ph. 988). Cp. Lys. or. 13 § 15 ou)k e)leou=ntes..ta\ tei/xh, ei) pesei=tai, ou)de\ khdo/menoi tw=n new=n, ei)..paradoqh/sontai.— ne/as trofh=s, the nurture suitable to the young: O. C. 345e)c o(/tou ne/as | trofh=s e)/lhce (n.).

dioi/setai, sc. bi/on, ‘pass his life’: schol. dia/cei, biw/setai. The midd. has this absolute sense in Hippocr. De artic. p. 823 u(gihroi\ ta)/lla..diafe/rontai (‘they pass through life’): Xen. Mem. 2. 1. 24skopou/menos dioi/sei (a correction of die/sh|). We find also diafe/rein bi/on or ai)w=na ( Her. 3. 40, Helen. 10), or diafe/rein only ([Eur. ] Rhes. 982).—Others explain dioi/setai as pass., diripietur, ‘(if) he shall be plundered.’ In this sense the usual word is diaforei=n, though Eur. Bacch. 754 has die/feron in a kindred sense, and Arist. Poet. 8§ 4 the pass. diafe/resqai: but such a meaning, which would fix attention on the boy's property, is utterly out of place here. [Lobeck, and Blaydes after him, cite Dion or. 41 p. 506 C u(p' o)rfanistw=n diaspasqh/setai: but the correct reference is or. 43 p. 506 C, and the words, u(po\ tw=n suggenw=n kai\ e)pitro/pwn diaspasqh=nai.]— sou= … mo/nos: cp. Soph. O. C. 1250a)ndrw=n ge mou=nos: Eur. Med. 52sou= mo/nh.

u(p' o)rfanistw=n (dioi/setai), if he shall have his life controlled by them: cp. u(po/ with the midd. poreu/etai in 1253 f.: O. C. 681qa(llei d)..u(p' a)/xnas. The sense is not merely, ‘live under them,’ as if u(po/ with the genitive here took the sense of u(po/ with the dative (subditus illorum imperio, Ellendt).

The word o)rfanisth/s (found only here) =e)pi/tropos, ‘guardian.’ Eustathius (p. 533. 30), on Il. 5. 158xhrwstai\ de\ dia\ kth=sin date/onto, explains xhrwstai/ as those who administered the property of persons who left no direct heirs (tou\s xhreu/ontas diado/xwn); adding, oi(/tines kata\ lo/gon a)/llon kai\ o)rfanistai\ e)kalou=nto, w(s o)rfanw=n u(perista/menoi, kaqa\ kai\ *sofoklh=s dhloi=. Apparently, then, he knew the word only from this verse. (The verb o)rfani/zw usu.=to make o)rfano/s.)
mh\ fi/lwn (the generic mh/), of no friendly kind; for the order, cp. Aesch. Eum. 903o(poi=a ni/khs mh\ kakh=s e)pi/skopa. [The mh\ could also be explained by ei) in 510: but this is less simple.]

Compare Andromachè's description, in her lament over Hector, of the lot in store for her child, h)=mar d' o)rfaniko\n panafh/lika pai=da ti/qhsin, ‘the day of orphanhood makes a child companionless,’ etc.: Il. 22. 490—498.
ble/pw, pres. subjunct.: this is the indirect form of ei)s ti/ ble/pw; Cp. 428 e)w= (n.).

h)/|stwsas. There is no other certain instance of a)|sto/w for a)i+sto/w. (In fr. 493, ko/ron a)i+stw/sas puri/, Kuster's conjecture khro\n, if right, would point to a)|stw/sas.) The ordinary form occurs in Tr. 881au(th\n dihi+/stwse.
dori/. As to this form versus do/rei, see on O.C. 1304.

a)/llh moi=ra. Destiny, working through Ajax, ravaged her country. Destiny in some other form brought her father and mother to the grave. The poet did not wish to represent Tecmessa as living with the man who had slain her parents; and so followed, or invented, a legend which ascribed their deaths to a different agency. Throughout this speech, the Homeric scene between Hector and Andromachè is present to the mind of Sophocles. Andromachè's father had been slain by Achilles; her mother, by the visitation of Artemis ( Il. 6. 414—428).

kaqei=len … oi)kh/toras (proleptic), brought them low, so that they should be dwellers, etc. After *(/aidou, qanasi/mous is redundant; but cp. Tr. 1161a)ll' o(/stis *(/aidou fqi/menos oi)kh/twr pe/loi: though ib. 282 we have simply, *(/aidou pa/ntes ei)/s' oi)kh/tores. For qana/simos said of the dead, cp. O.T. 959, Ph. 819.
patri/s: Cp. Xen. An. 1. 3§ 6 nomi/zw ga\r u(ma=s e)moi\ ei)=nai kai\ patri/da kai\ fi/lous kai\ summa/xous.
e)n soi\ … sw/|zomai: cp. O. T. 314e)n soi\ ga\r e)sme/n (n.). The prep. expresses that her safety is in his power,—depends on him. pa=s), adverbial: cp. 275.
ka)mou=: as well as of his parents and his son.
prosei=nai, of a quality or attribute; cp. 1079, Ant. 720.

terpno\n ei)/ ti/ pou pa/qoi: cp. Dido's words to Aeneas ( Aen. 4. 316 ff.) Per conubia nostra, per inceptos hymenaeos, | Si bene quid de te merui, fuit aut tibi quicquam | Dulce meum, miserere. For the optat., marking the generality of the statement, cp. 1344: Ant. 666a)ll' d\n po/lis sth/seie, tou=de xrh\ klu/ein (n.).
xa/ris xa/rin ga/r: Helen. 1234 xa/ris ga\r a)nti\ xa/ritos e)lqe/tw. For the place of ga/r, cp. Aesch. P. V. 29qeo\s qew=n ga/r k.t.l.: for that of the art., Soph. O. T. 139e)kei=non o( ktanw/n.
ti/ktous): cp. the proverb in Zenobius 3. 328 di/kh di/khn e)/tikte kai\ bla/bh bla/bhn.
a)porrei=: cp. 1267: El. 1000 n.
ge/noit), cannot ‘become’ such, in the sense, ‘cannot finally be ranked as such.’ Whatever his other merits may be, their sum will not amount to true nobleness.
e)/xein s' a)\n … qe/loim' a)/n: the first a)/n, as well as the second, belongs to qe/loimi: cp. 537: O.T. 339 n.

w(s ka)gw\, sc. e)/xw. Cp. Il. 6. 476do/te dh\ kai\ to/nde gene/sqai | pai=d' e)mo/n, w(s kai\ e)gw/ per, a)riprepe/a *trw/essin: this also illustrates the use of kai/, on which see O.C. 53 o(/s' oi)=da ka)gw/ (n.).

kai\ ka/rt). Here kai\=‘and.’ But where kai\ ka/rta replies to a question (O.C. 65 and 301), the verb being understood, kai\ merely emphasises (‘Yea, surely’), and kai\ ka/rta is then equiv. to h)= ka/rta ( El. 312). Similarly in kai\ ma/la, kai\ sometimes=‘and,’ but sometimes merely strengthens the adv. (vel maxime): El. 1178 n.

to\ taxqe
=o(\ a)
 taxqh=|: he has not yet given his command. Cp. Tr. 1187h)= mh
 e)moi\ to\ lexqe
 e)/rgon e)ktelei=n, i.e. o(\ a)
 lexqh=|.
tolma=|, bring herself to do it: cp. 411: Ph. 481to/lmhson, ‘make the effort.’ Instead of agreeing to take her advice (e)/ph), Ajax replies that he will be ready to praise her obedience.
For the alliteration (parh/xhsis) cp. 1112: O.T. 371 tuflo\s ta/ t' w)=ta to/n te nou=n ta/ t' o)/mmat' ei)= (n.).
a)ll), in assent; cp. Ph. 48 n.
w(s i)/dw: cp. 538. The words express his impatient yearning.

kai\ mh\n fo/boisi/ g). The formula kai\ mh/n (lit. ‘and verily’) introduces a new fact or thought; as in Tragedy it often announces a new comer (1168). When this new fact or thought raises a difficulty in the way of something proposed by the last speaker, then kai\ mh/n acquires an adversative force. Thus here, its literal sense, ‘and verily,’ ‘indeed,’ is tinged by the context with the sense, ‘oh, but,’ or ‘nay, but.’ The effect of ge is to place a slight stress on fo/boisi. The combination kai\ mh/n … ge is very frequent with Sophocles: cp. 539: O. T. 290, O. T. 345, O. T. 836, O. T. 987, O. T. 1004, O. T. 1066: O. C. 396: Ant. 221: Ph. 660: El. 1045, El. 1188.In all these passages the effect of ge is the same; i.e., it does not modify the sense of kai\ mh/n, but emphasises the word or phrase with which it is immediately connected.
fo/boisi, causal dat.: the plur. as in O. T. 585cu\n fo/boisi. Her fears were indicated at v. 340.

e)celusa/mhn, lit. ‘released’: i.e., allowed him to leave the tent. The midd. e)klu/omai means to ‘release,’ ‘set free,’ in O.T. 1003, Ant. 1112, Tr. 21: H. 7. 1. 25 e)celu/santo tou\s *)argei/ous. The choice of the word seems to be prompted by a wish not to say more than is implied in fo/boisi, or to imply that she had rescued the child from a danger. She speaks merely as if (in her undefined ‘fears’) she had left the care of the child to others. Then the blunt and impatient question of Ajax—e)n toi=sde toi=s kakoi=sin k.t.l.—startles her into speaking plainly,—mh\ soi/ ge/ pou du/sthnos k.t.l.

The conjecture e)cerrusa/mhn (cr. n.), ‘rescued,’ would efface this trait of reticence. It is inferred from the scholiast's phrase, tw=n fo/bwn xa/rin r(u/sasqai qe/lousa e)ch/gagon. But e)ch/gagon is there the important word, while the words r(u/sasqai qe/lousa are merely the scholiast's expansion of the motive implied in fo/boisi.
kakoi=sin: a half-euphemistic phrase, as in 272, 431, 433.
mh\ soi/ ge k.t.l. Here ge replies to his question (‘Yes, lest..’), and qualifies the whole sentence (cp. Ant. 648 n.): but it also adds to the emphasis on soi/.
pre/pon ge/ ta)\n h)=n. For ge/ toi cp. Ph. 823 n.

dai/monos, fortune: El. 1306tw=| paro/nti dai/moni. A gen. after pre/pwn is very rare, but analogous to the gen. after a)/cios: Plat. Menex.p. 239 C prepo/ntws tw=n praca/ntwn. [In Plat. Rep.p. 400 B u(/brews h)\ mani/as kai\ a)/llhs kaki/as pre/pousai ba/seis, the gen. seems to depend on pre/pousai: but might be possessive.]
a)ll' ou)=n (‘well, at any rate’), followed by ge (emphasising the word before it), occurs also in Ant. 84, Ph. 1305, El. 233, El. 1035, etc.
)fu/laca: cp. 308 )qw/u+cen.

a)rke/sai, infin. of purpose: cp. O. T. 198 n. For the sense, defendere, cp. Il. 20. 289h)\ ko/ruq' h)e\ sa/kos, to/ oi( h)/rkese lugro\n o)/leqron: Eur. El. 1300(pw=s) ou)k h)rke/saton kh=ras mela/qrois;
e)ph/|nes): for the aor., cp. El. 668 n.
e)/qou: cp. 13 n.

w(s e)k tw=nd): i.e., seeing that the child has been sent away, and that Ajax approves of her precaution (536). She wishes to divert him from the desire of seeing his son. But he instantly recurs to it.—For e)ktw=nde, ‘under these conditions,’ cp. Tr. 1109(n.). w(s gives a limiting force (as in w(s e)moi/, Tr. 395): Eur. Andr. 1184ou(=to/s t' a)\n w(s e)k tw=nd' e)tima=t' a)/n, ge/ron, | qanw/n. Thuc. 4. 17§ 1 w(s e)k tw=n paro/ntwn. There is a verbal likeness to Soph. Ant. 552ti/ dh=t' a)\n a)lla\ nu=n s' e)/t' w)feloi=m) e)gw/;
kai\ mh\n here announces a fact which favours the last speaker's wish, and not, as in 531, a fact opposed to it; here, therefore, it becomes an expression of assent.
ge emphasises pe/las.
prospo/lois, dat. of agent; rare, except with the perf. pass.; but cp. Ant. 1218qeoi=si kle/ptomai, and ib. 504 f. (n.).
mh\ ou), since ti/ me/llei is equiv. to mh\ melle/tw: cp. Aesch. P. V. 627ti/ dh=ta me/lleis mh\ ou) gegwni/skein to\ pa=n;
parousi/an e)/xein=parei=nai: a periphrasis like qh/ran e)/xwn (564), e)/xei sti/bon ( Ph. 157).
eu)qu/nwn: cp. Eur. Heracl. 728eu)qu/nwn po/da.
e(/rponti fwnei=s...; the partic. expresses the leading idea; cp. O. C. 1038xwrw=n a)pei/lei nu=n (n.).

leleimme/nw|lo/gwn, unable to catch the sound of thy words; schol. in L, ou)k a)kou/onti. Cp. Eur. Or. 1085h)= polu\ le/leiyai tw=n e)mw=n bouleuma/twn (‘laggest far behind them,’—failest to comprehend them): Helen. 1246 le/leimmai tw=n e)n *(/ellhsin no/mwn (‘am not versed in them’).
kai\ dh\, ‘already’: O. C. 31 n.

ai)=re deu=ro. The child is led in by an attendant: Ajax means, ‘lift him’ (from the ground) ‘to my arms.’ Some take ai)=re as=‘bring,’ comparing Il. 6. 264mh/ moi oi)=non a)/eire, Ar. Pax 1ai)=r' ai)=re ma=zan w(s ta/xista kanqa/rw|: but this is less simple, and less fitting.

tarbh/sei ga\r ou)\: for ou) placed after the verb, see on Ant. 96.This passage recalls Il. 6. 466—470, where Hector is about to take his little son from the nurse's arms, but the child shrinks back, frightened by the helmet,— tarbh/sas xalko/n te i)de\ lo/fon i(ppioxai/thn.

neosfagh= … fo/non, the adj. compounded with a word akin in sense to the subst.; cp. Ant. 1283neoto/moisi plh/gmasin.—There is no reason to doubt the genuineness of pou, which gives a touch of grim irony. L's reading, tou=, certainly points to tou=to/n ge: but this is very in ferior to the vulgate. Wecklein, reading tou, thinks that Ajax wishes to avoid saying mou.
dikai/ws, in a full and true sense: cp. O. T. 852ou)/toi pot), w)=nac, to/n ge *lai+/ou fo/non | fanei= dikai/ws o)rqo/n, i.e. ‘properly fulfilled.’
ta\ patro/qen is re dundant, but not pointless; the qualities derived from the father will prevail over any weaker qualities derived mhtro/qen.

w)moi=s … e)n no/mois, the rugged usages of a warrior inured to the sight of bloodshed. For the adj., cp. 205 w)mokrath/s, n. In saying no/mois rather than tro/pois, he speaks with a certain heroic grandeur (megalofronw=n, as the schol. remarks). Cp. C. 2. 15. 11 non ita Romuli | Praescriptum et intonsi Catonis | Auspiciis veterumque norma.

pwlodamnei=n, to break him in like a colt. The word was familiar in Attic ( Xen. Oec. 3. 10, etc.). Cp. Plut. Mor. 13E ou(/tw skirtw=sa neo/ths pwlodamnei=tai. Lucian Amor. 45 th\n neo/thta pwlodamnh/sas. For the metaphor implicit in the compound verb, cp. Ant. 994e)nauklh/reis po/lin.

ka)comoiou=sqai is passive, and au)to/n (the object of pwlodamnei=n) is its subject, fu/sin being acc. of respect. For the infinitives, linked by kai/, yet having different subjects, cp. Plat. Rep.p. 359 E (le/gousin) au)to\n a)fanh= gene/sqai toi=s parakaqhme/nois, kai\ diale/gesqai [sc. au)tou\s] w(s peri\ oi)xome/nou.

w)= pai= k.t.l. Paraphrased by Attius, Armorum Iudicium fr. 10, Virtuti sis par, dispar fortunis patris: and imitated by Verg. Aen. 12. 435(Aeneas to Ascanius), Disce, puer, virtutem ex me verumque laborem, | Fortunam ex aliis.

ta\ d' a)/ll' o(/moios: so Hector prays for Astyanax that he may be like his father, —w(=de bi/hn t' a)gaqo\n kai\ *)ili/ou i)=fi a)na/ssein: but adds the nobler prayer that men may say, patro/s g' o(/de pollo\n a)mei/nwn. ( Il. 6. 476 ff.)
kai/toi … kai\ nu=n: nay, even now—while that prayer still awaits fulfilment—the child is happier than his father, in unconsciousness of evil.
se is better here than se\ (which L has), though the emphasis could be defended (‘I, the man, might envy thee, the child’).

tou=to/ ge: this acc. of respect (instead of the ordinary genitive) with zhlou=n is unusual; but the same constr. sometimes occurs with words of a like sense, e.g. Vesp. 588 touti\ ga/r toi/ se mo/non..makari/zw.
ou)de\n is best taken as acc. governed by e)paisqa/nei: cp. 996: O. T. 424a)/llwn de\ plh=qos ou)k e)paisqa/nei kakw=n. It might, however, be adv. (cp. Ant. 1183tw=n lo/gwn e)ph|sqo/mhn).
e)n tw=| fronei=n mhde\n: i.e., before there is any intelligent consciousness of joy or sorrow (555).

554 b [to\ mh\ fronei=n ga\r k.t.l.] Such an unconsciousness is an ‘evil,’ as excluding to\ xai/rein, but ‘painless,’ as exempt from to\ lupei=sqai. This verse was probably written in the margin, as a parallel passage to v. 554, and then crept into the text. It may come (as Valckenär thought) from some other play of Sophocles; its tone seems less suggestive of Euripides. That it was a familiar quotation, may be seen from the way in which it is brought in by the novelist Eustathius (or Eumathius), in to\ kaq' *(usmi/nhn kai\ *(usmini/an sra=ma (c. 1100 A.D. ?), ch. 2 § 7 (Erot. Scriptores vol. II. p. 174 ed. Hercher), tou= e)/pous e)mnh/sqhn w(s to\ mh\ fronei=n ka/rt' a)nw/dunon kako/n. It is translated, along with v. 553, in the sentences of Publilius Syrus (c. 45 B.C.), 876 f., Suavissima haec est vita, si sapias nihil: | Nam sapere nil doloris expers est malum. But those two verses are doubtless later interpolations in the text of Publilius: they are wanting in the best MS. (Monac. lat. 6292).
e(/ws, without a)/n: so Ph. 764, Tr. 148.
i(/kh| pro\s tou=to, i.e. pro\s to\ maqei=n. Cp. 1365.

dei= s' o(/pws … dei/ceis: see on Ph. 54 f. th\n *filokth/tou se dei= | yuxh\n o(/pws lo/goisin e)kkle/yeis le/gwn.— )tra/fhs suggests the inbred qualities of the race; cp. Ph. 3krati/stou patro\s *(ellh/nwn trafei/s. For the prodelision of the augment in the 6th foot of the v., cp. Ant. 457)fa/nh: Helen. 263 (ei)/qe) ai)/sxion ei)=dos a)nti\ tou= kalou= )labon.

te/ws, ‘meanwhile,’ referring to the limit of time marked by v. 556. So in Od. 15. 127, th=os de\ fi/lh| para\ mhtri\ | kei/sqw, the ref. is to the limit marked by e)s ga/mou w(/rhn just before. And ib. 230 ei)s e)niauto
 | ei)=xe bi/h|: o( de\ th=os...de/deto. Other usages of te/ws are: (1) when it answers to e(/ws: Ar. Pax 32te/ws e(/ws la/qois sauto
 diarragei/s: and (2) when it means, ‘for a time’ (or, ‘hitherto’), and is followed by a clause with de/ or a)lla/: Her. 1. 82te/ws me
 dh\..te/los de/ k.t.l.

kou/fois pneu/masin, light airs, gentle breezes, such as nourish young plants. Lobeck quotes Dion Chrysostomus or. 12 p. 202 B trefo/menoi th=| dihnekei= tou= pneu/matos e)pirroh=| a)e/ra u(gro\n e(/lkontes w(/sper nh/pioi pai=des. Pliny H. N. 18. 34 Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere. Lucian Bix accus. § 1 tou\s a)ne/mous futourgou=ntas. We might add Catull. 62. 39 ut flos.. | Quem mulcent aurae, firmat sol, educat imber.

ne/an yuxh\n a)ta/llwn. Cp. Tr. 144to\ ga\r nea/zon e)n toioi=sde bo/sketai | xw/roisin au(tou= etc. (n.). The word a)ta/llw (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 nh/pion ai)doi/hs e)pi\ gou/nasi mhtro\s a)ta/llwn, and Pind. fr. 214 glukei=a/ oi( kardi/an a)ta/lloisa... | e)lpi/s. The Homeric form in this sense is a)tita/llw, Hom. Od. 18. 323pai=da de\ w(\s a)ti/talle.
The word a)ta/llw may have been suggested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: Il. 6. 400pai=d' e)pi\ ko/lpw| e)/xous' a)tala/frona, nh/pion au)/tws.

xarmonh/n might be acc. in appos. with yuxh\n only; but is better taken as acc. in appos. with the whole sentence (see on El. 130h(/ket' e)mw=n kama/twn paramu/qion).—The conjecture xarmonh/ is no gain.
560 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic oi)=da, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El.|354.
ou)/toi … mh/: cp. 83, 421.
pulwro\n, warder, guardian; Eur. Tro. 956(pu/rgwn), I. T. 1227 (naw=n).
trofh=s a)/oknon: any adj. compounded with a privativum can take a genitive; and here the gen. is the more natural since a(/oknos suggests the notion of a)feidh/s.

e)/mpa: this form occurs in Pind. N. 4. 36, and Callim. Epigr. 13 (kai/ sfin a)nihro\n me\n e)rei=s e)/pos, e)/mpa de\ le/con). A Doric form e)/mpa_n is used by Pind. P. 5. 51.In 122 and 1338, as in Soph. Ant. 845, we have e)/mpas. (The form e)/mpak), once read here, was a mere blunder: see cr. n.)— kei) stands here (as in 692 and 962) where ei) kai/ would be normal, since the reference is to an actual fact: cp. Soph. O. T.appendix on v. 305, p. 224.
thlwpo\s, properly ‘of distant aspect’ (w)/y), here merely ‘distant,’ as in Ph. 216boa=| thlwpo\n i)wa/n.
oi)xnei=: cp. El. 165 n.
qh/ran e)/xwn: for the periphrasis, cp. 540: Ph. 839qh/ran | th/nd' a(li/ws e)/xomen. He had gone on a foray (343) in the highlands of Mysia (720).
a)spisth=res. The Salaminian followers of Ajax are at once seamen and warriors; as Thuc. (1. 10 § 4) says of the Greeks who went against Troy, au)tere/tai.. h)=san kai\ ma/ximoi pa/ntes.
xa/rin, this act of kindness; viz., care for the child.
o(/pws … dei/cei is the object clause to a)ggei/lat' e)ntolh/n. A final clause, o(/pws..dei/ch|, would be less fitting here.

*)eriboi/a| le/gw. The dat. is more forcible than the acc. would be, as it keeps the command, o(/pws dei/cei mhtri/, before the mind; cp. Aesch. fr. 175 th=s *)antiklei/as a)=sson h)=lqe *si/sufos, | th=s sh=s le/gw tsi mhtro/s. Dem. or. 19 § 152 peri\ ..meizo/nwn, le/gw de\ *fwke/wn kai\ *pulw=n. Ajax adds these words to show that he does not mean Teucer's mother, Hesionè (1300). Eriboea was the daughter of Alcathoüs, king of Megara: Pindar mentions her as the mother of Ajax (I. 5. 45). She is called Periboea by Apollodorus (3. 12 § 7) and Pausanias (1. 42. 1).

me/xris ou(=. This verse is doubtless due to an interpolator who wished to limit ei)saei/. It has three marks of spuriousness. (1) me/xri, not me/xris, is the Attic form. (2) The anapaest in the first foot is a needless harshness, when either e(/ws or e)/st' a)
 was available. (3) The division of an anapaest (in the first foot) between two words has no Sophoclean parallel except in Phil. 795 to
 i)/son xro/non tre/foite th/nde th
 no/son: and the Philoctetes was one of the latest plays (409 B.C.).—It might be added that muxou\s ki/xwsi is a somewhat strange phrase; though we may compare Il. 21. 128a)/stu kixei/omen. The use of ki/xw in 657 is slightly different.
mh/t' … qh/sous): depending on o(/pws in 567. Cp. Od. 11. 546(referring to the contest from the arms), e)/qhke de\ po/tnia mh/thr (Thetis), ‘offered them as a prize.’

a)gwna/rxai (a word found only here)=a)gwnoqe/tai, the presidents of the games, such as the Amphictyons were at the Pythian festival. The presidents appointed the e)pimelhtai/ who actually supervised the contests, such as the *(ellanodi/kai at Olympia. (Cp. El. 690 n.)

mh/q' o( lumew
 e)mo/s. Only two parallels for the place of e)mo/s are brought from classical Greek literature. (1) Eur. Hipp. 683*zeu/s s' o( gennh/twr e)mo/s: where G. Wolff would omit o(. (2) Theocr. 27. 58 tw)mpe/xonon poi/hsas e)mo
 r(a/kos: where Schaefer's remedy, e)moi\, is quite admissible; Hermann wrote a)mpexo/nan..e)ma/n. The nearest analogy to such a license as o( lumew
 e)mo/s is afforded by such instances as to
 e)mo
 pate/r' a)/qlion ( Eur. El. 133 n.), where a)/qlion is a mere epithet, but ought, by position, to be a predicate. Remembering the originally pronominal sense of the art., we may hesitate to affirm that an Attic poet could not have ventured to write o( lumew
 e)mo/s, meaning, ‘that destroyer of mine.’

No correction is very probable. We cannot read mh/q' o( lumew\n e)mou=, since, though mou can represent the possessive pron., such a use of e)mou= would be unexampled. (See Krüger, Gr. Sprachlehre, § 47. 9. 13.) The dat. e)moi/ is also untenable. It is possible that the poet wrote mh/te lumew\n e)mo/s: but the article, if not indispensable, is at least very desirable here.
au)to/, that,—with an emphasis due to the place of the word.
e)pw/numon, ‘that gives thee thy name’; as at Athens the e)pw/numoi were the heroes who gave names to the Attic tribes. Cp. 430 n.

polurra/fou … po/rpakos. This must be interpreted by the usage of the poet's day, not by Homeric practice. The po/rpac may be seen on shields depicted in Greek vase-paintings; an example is reproduced in Smith's Dict. of Antiquities (3rd ed., vol. I. p. 459, art. clipeus). It was a leathern thong, running round the inner edge of the shield, and fixed at intervals of six inches or so by pins or nails, so as to form a succession of loops. The name, po/rpac, was derived from these pins (po/rpai), which could be taken out, when it was wished to remove the po/rpac and so to unfit the shield for immediate use. (It is made a charge against Cleon in Ar. Eq. 849 that he had dedicated the shields taken at Pylos au)toi=si toi=s po/rpacin.)

But a loop at the edge of the shield, such as the po/rpac offered to the warrior's hand ( Helen. 1376 e)mbalw\n po/rpaki gennai/an xe/ra), would not suffice to give him control. Hence, in the vasepainting noticed above, we see the po/rpac combined with another contrivance, viz., a band (of metal, or wood), placed vertically across the inside of the shield, and furnished at the middle with an arrangement of small bars, forming a support for the arm just below the elbow. This band was the o)/xanon or o)xa/nh.—See Appendix.

polurra/fou (‘much, or well, stitched’) is a general epithet for elaborate leatherwork, and is again illustrated by the vase-painting cited above, where ornamental tassels hang from the pins which divide the loops of the po/rpac. In Theocr. 25. 265, polu/rrapto/n te fare/trhn, the epithet probably refers to braiding; quivers were often made of hide or leather.

e(pta/boion=epic e(ptabo/eion: see n. on 19. The second part of the compound is not bou=s, but boei/a, ox-hide ( Il. 12. 296). The shield was the work of *tuxi/os, skutoto/mwn o)/x' a)/ristos,—so essentially was the currier's art that which it chiefly demanded ( Il. 7. 220). Tychios dwelt at *(/ulh,—probably the Boeotian ( Il. 2. 500). The number of seven layers of hide was probably exceptional; in Il. 15. 479Teucer has a sa/kos tetraqe/lumnon, i.e., with four such layers.

teqa/yetai. Here, as at 1141, the fut. perf. gives a peremptory tone. Athena uses it in I. T. 1464: ou(= kai\ teqa/yei. (Cp. Nub. 1436 teqnh/ceis.) The ordinary fut. pass. was tafh/somai. The practice of burying a warrior's arms with him was a primitive Aryan custom; witness the swords found in the graves at Mycenae. Sophocles in this play follows the legend that the body of Ajax was interred, and not, as was the ordinary practice in the heroic age, burned (cp. 1166 n.). The reference to the burial of the arms is thus perfectly fitting. There was less meaning in the practice, noticed by Homer, of burning a warrior's armour with him; Il. 6. 418a)ll' a)/ra min kate/khe su\n e)/ntesi daidale/oisin: Od. 11. 74a)lla/ me kakkh=ai su\n teu/xesin. It may have come down from the earlier days when interment was the rule. No arms are burned on the pyre of Patroclus ( Il. 23. 165 ff.), Hector (24. 785 ff.), or Achilles ( Od. 24. 65 ff.).
koi/n) e)moi\: koina\ is here adv.: cp. Ant. 546mh/ moi qa/nh|s su\ koina/.

pa/ktou. pakto/w (pakto/s= phkto/s) is used by Her. 2. 96(in the compound e)m-), and by Vesp. 128, of ‘stopping up’ holes, ‘caulking,’ and this may have been its special sense. But the general sense, ‘to make fast,’ occurs in Ar. Lys. 264 moxloi=s te kai\ klh/qroisi ta\ propu/laia paktou=n. Eustathius, who explains it by a)sfali/zesqai (p. 742. 43), seems to regard the use of the word with ref. to closing doors as peculiarly Attic (p. 1937. 62 to\ sugklei=sai, paktw=sai par' *)attikoi=s). According to Pollux 10. 27, however, Archilochus had used paktw=sai as=klei=sai.
e)piskh/nous=e)pi\ th=| skhnh=|, at the tent, i.e., in front of it. Cp. Ant. 1247e)s po/lin go/ous | ou)k a)ciw/sein, a)ll' u(po\ ste/ghs e)/sw, k.t.l.

filoi/ktiston: schol. on Il. 22. 88fi/loikton xrh=ma h( gunh/. Eur. H. F. 536to\ qh=lu ga/r pws ma=llon oi)ktro\n a)rse/nwn. For the neut., cp. Eur. El. 1035mw=ron me\n ou)=n gunai=kes: O. C. 592 n. The adj. is formed from the midd. oi)kti/zomai as= ‘to lament’ ( I. T. 486, etc.).

pu/kaze: the vague word (‘to close,’ ‘cover up’) is explained by the preceding dw=ma pa/ktou. Cp. Hes. Op. 622nh=a d' e)p' h)pei/rou e)ru/sai, puka/sai te li/qoisi | pa/ntoqen (‘protect’ it): perh. the nearest approach to the use of the word here, in ref. to shutting the door of a dwelling.
ou) pro\s i)atrou=: for the prep., cp. 319.

qrhnei=n e)pw|da\s: as to the medical use of e)pw|dai/, see on O. C. 1194fi/lwn e)pw|dai=s e)cepa/|dontai fu/sin. The transition from gentle incantations to drastic surgery is similarly implied in Tr. 1000ti/s ga\r a)oido/s, ti/s o( xeirote/xnhs | i)atori/as, o(\s th/nd' a)/thn | xwri\s *zhno\s katakhlh/sei; (n.)

tomw=nti means here, not e)piqumou=nti te/mnein, but deome/nw| tomh=s: cp. Lucian Lexiphanes 4 ta\ o)/mmata/ moi farmaka=|,= dei=tai farma/kwn. Ov. Met. 1. 190 Cuncta prius tentata; sed immedicabile vulnus | Ense recidendum est, ne pars sincera trahatur.
proqumi/an, the eagerness expressed by pu/kaze qa=sson.

a)re/skei with acc., as often in Attic: Eur. Hipp. 185ou)de/ s' a)re/skei to\ paro/n (and ib. 106 ou)dei/s m' a)re/skei): Vesp. 776 touti/ m' a)re/skei: Th. 406, Ran. 103, Pl. 353.Cp. El. 147e)me/ g)...a)/raren (n.).
teqhgme/nh: cp. Aesch. P. V. 311traxei=s kai\ teqhgme/nous lo/gous.
drasei/eis: cp. 326.
freni/ is not weak, because his wish for seclusion was not in itself disquieting.
kri=ne=a)na/krine: Ant. 399kai\ kri=ne ka)ce/legxe.
mh\ prodou\s ge/nh|: Ph. 773(mh\) ktei/nas ge/nh| (n.).
a)/gan ge lupei=s: cp. 951: Ant. 573a)/gan ge lupei=s kai\ su\ kai\ to\ so\n le/xos.
a)rkei=n, to render service (439 n.).

o)feile/ths: the gods hate him (457); he has no hope from them,—they are doing their worst (399—403): he owes them no duty. When Hermes reproaches Prometheus with not wishing to conciliate Zeus, the sufferer ironically answers, kai\ mh\n o)fei/lwn g' a)\n ti/noim' au)tw=| xa/rin ( Aesch. P. V. 985).
eu)/fhma fw/nei, as in 362.

toi=s a)kou/ousin le/ge: cp. Theocr. 15. 90 peisome/nois e)pi/tasse. Euripides has what seems an echo of this verse in the Hercules Furens (a play referable to 421— 416 B.C., and so later than the Ajax), 1184 *q*h. eu)/fhma fw/nei. *a*m*f. boulome/noisin e)pagge/llei.
The division of the verse between two speakers (a)ntilabh/) is here used for the first time in the play, to mark the tension of feeling.

cune/rceq),=sugklei/sete, fut. of cunei/rgw: but in Ph. 1407 we find ei)/rcw, a form which the poet may have preferred there, because in the verse before he had used e)/rceis as fut. of e)/rdw. (In Tr. 83cune/rcwn is fut. of cune/rdw.) The command is given to the pro/spoloi (544).
a)/rti: i.e. this new hope (if such she has) is one of which long experience might have taught her the vanity.

Ajax is now withdrawn into the tent on the eccyclema (ei)skuklei=tai), and the entrance is closed. Tecmessa and her child retire by another door into the part of the dwelling which is supposed to represent the gunaikw/n. They re-enter after the Choral ode, and are present while Ajax speaks (see 684 ff.). Some, indeed, suppose that they remain on the scene during the ode; but the command of Ajax to Tecmessa in 579 f., mhd' e)piskh/nous go/ous | da/krue, is against this.

Welcker thinks that not only Tecmessa (with the child), but Ajax also, remain present during the ode. (Rhein. Mus. for 1829, part 3, p. 87.) It is clear, however, from v. 593 that Ajax withdraws into the tent.

div2.p: First stasimon. 1st strophe, 596—608=1st antistr., 609— 621: 2nd str. 622—634=2nd ant. 635— 645. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: nai/eis: cp. Il. 2. 626nh/swn, ai(\ nai/ousi pe/rhn a(lo/s.

a(li/plaktos (plh/ssw), not a(li/plagktos (pla/zw), is right here; the latter has the better MS. authority, but could mean only, ‘wandering on the sea,’ as in 695 *pa\n a(li/plagkte. Cp. Pind. P. 4. 14ta=sd' e)c a(lipla/ktou..ga=s (the island of Thera). Aesch. Pers. 307qalasso/plhkton nh=son *ai)/antos.
pa=sin peri/fantos a)ei/ does not allude to the victory at Salamis, but, for Athenian ears, would necessarily be tinged with the thought of it.
palaio\s a)f' ou(= xro/nos: cp. Ph. 493o(\n dh\ palaio\n e)c o(/tou de/doik' e)gw\ | mh/ moi bebh/kh| (n.).
*)idai=a k.t.l. If this passage cannot be restored with certainty, at least the doubt lies within narrow limits. Three points should be noted.

1. The metre (logaoedic) is clear: no suspicion rests on the antistrophic verses, 613—615 kratou=nt' ... hu(/rhtai. Metre proves, then, that (a) instead of L's i)dai/a, we require --u, which is given by *)idai=a. (b) Instead of leimwni/a| poi/a| we require --uu-u, which is satisfied by leimw/ni) e)/paula. (c) Instead of eu)no/ma|, we require ---.
