2. eu)nw=mai, as a correction of eu)no/ma|, may be regarded as certain. Sophocles would have written *e*g*n*o*m*a*i. It is confirmed by the fact that our best MS., L, has mi/mnwn, not mi/mnw.
3. mhnw=n, as a correction of mh/lwn, is (to my mind) not less certain. For mhnw=n a)nh/riqmos, cp. Tr. 247(xro/non) h(merw=n a)nh/riqmon. In no other way can a)nh/riqmos be justified.

What remains doubtful, then, is only how we should correct the words, i)dai=a... leimwni/a| poi/a|. Now, in favour of *)idai=a.. leimw/ni) e)/paula, let it be noted that, if e)/paula was the genuine word, then the corruption of mhnw=n into mh/lwn is at once explained; for e)/paula meant properly a fold for cattle, as in O. T. 1138, where it is synonymous with staqma/. Here, however, it would have the general sense which it bears in O. C. 669, i(/kou ta\ kra/tista ga=s e)/paula, ‘dwellings,’—a sense in which staqma/ too was poetically used. No other conjecture accounts for the origin of mh/lwn.

The construction then is, eu)nw=mai *)idai=a leimw/nia e)/paula, ‘I am encamped in quarters on the fields of Ida,’ mhnw=n a)nh/riqmos, ‘through countless months.’ For the acc. with eu)nw=mai, cp. such phrases as zugo\n e(/zomai (249 n.), kei=mai to/pon ( Ph. 144 f.). For eu)nw=mai with ref. to camping, cp. Il. 10. 408*trw/wn fulakai/ te kai\ eu)nai/: Aesch. Ag. 559eu)nai\ ga\r h)=san dai+/wn pro\s tei/xesin: | e)c ou)ranou= de\ ka)po\ gh=s leimw/niai | dro/soi kateya/kazon—a passage which Sophocles may have had in mind.
For other views of the passage, and other emendations, see Appendix.

xro/nw|, notwithstanding xro/nos in 600. Tennyson's poem, The LotosEaters, begins thus:—‘“Courage!” he said, and pointed toward the land, | “This mounting wave will roll us shoreward soon.” | In the afternoon they came unto a land | In which it seemed always afternoon.’ The repetition of the word ‘land’ there was deliberate, being designed to suggest languor. Sophocles doubtless had no such conscious aim here; he was simply indifferent, as so often, to the recurrence ( O. C. 554 n.); but something of a like effect is actually produced. The conjecture po/nw| for xro/nw| is not probable.
e)lpi/d), the neutral ‘expectation,’ is here colured by kaka/n: below, in 1382, it stands alone as=a foreboding of evil: cp. 799 e)lpi/zei.
e)/ti: i.e., before the campaign is over.

me, though the pron. refers to the subject of the inf.: Tr. 706 n.— a)nu/sein … *(/aidan, as Suppl. 1142 potanoi\ d' h)/nusan to\n *(/aidan. Cp. O. C. 1562e)canu/sai ta\n pagkeuqh= ka/tw | nekrw=n pla/ka. But in Tr. 657pro\s po/lin a)nu/seie.

to
 a)po/tropon, the god from whom mortals shrink in horror, o(
 a)potre/pontai: cp. O. T. 1313i)w\ sko/tou | ne/fos e)mo
 a)po/tropon (n.).

a)i+/dhlon *(/aidan: the etymology of Hades was so far forgotten in the per sonification that the tautology of this phrase would not be felt. Cp. Il. 2. 758*pro/qoos qoo\s h(gemo/neuen. The Homeric sense of a)i+/dhlos is active, ‘destroying’ (a)fani/zwn): but Hes. Op. 754 has a)i+/dhla as=a)fanh=.

e)/fedros was said of an athlete who ‘sat by’ at a match between two other men, prepared to engage the winner (cp. suppositicius in Mart. 5. 24. 8). Thus in Aristoph. Ran. 792Sophocles proposes e)/fedros kaqedei=sqai, while the two other poets contend, and to encounter Euripides if the latter should vanquish Aeschylus. To the Chorus (xro/nw| truxo/menos), Ajax is an e)/fedros, as being a fresh trouble in reserve. Schol.: pro\s toi=s prw/tois kakoi=s w(/sper deu/tero/n e)sti/ moi kako\n to\ tou= *ai)/antos cunesthko/s: where the last word is happily chosen to mark that e)/fedros implies a trouble with which they have to grapple: see on Soph. O. C. 514a)lghdo/nos, a(=| cune/stas. For the fig. sense, cp. Philo vol. 2 p. 527 meta\ pa/sas ta\s ai)ki/as..au)toi=s h( teleutai/a kai\ e)/fedros timwri/a stauro\s h)=n, ‘after all their torments, the final doom reserved for them was the cross.’ The technical sense of the word was so familiar (cp. Pind. N. 4. 96, Aesch. Cho. 866) that it would be understood here without direct help from the context.

Prof. Campbell pronounces this interpretation ‘untenable,’ and renders e)/fedros ‘fixed at my side,’ because ‘Ajax had remained sitting throughout the previous scene,’ and had now apparently relapsed into sullen inaction within his tent.
qei/a|, as in 186 qei/a no/sos.— cu/naulos (au)lh/), dwelling with: cp. O. T. 1205 f. a)/tais.. | cu/noikos.
e)cepe/myw … qouri/w|: a reminiscence of Aesch. Pers. 137(e(ka/sta, each Persian wife) to\n ai)xma/enta qou=ron eu)nath=ra propemyame/na: where, as here, the midd.=‘from herself.’
pri\n dh/ pote, ‘in some bygone day.’
*)/arei with a_, as in 254 (n.).

freno\s oi)obw/tas, ‘a lonely pasturer of his thoughts,’—i.e., one who nurses lonely thoughts. They allude to the gloomy and ominous despair which has replaced his frenzy. The ending -bw/ths could mean either bosko/menos, as in Ph. 1148ou)resibw/tas (qh=ras), or bo/skwn. The latter seems best here; his frh/n represents the flock; he is the shepherd. Cp. Suppl. 304 poi=on pano/pthn oi)obouko/lon le/geis; (Argus,— Io being his sole charge.) Simonides fr. 133 *)/ossa, *kiqairw=no/s t' oi)ono/moi skopiai/. Other compounds in which oi)=os has a like force are oi)o/frwn (pe/tra, Suppl. 795), oi)o/zwnos ( O. T. 846).
hu(/rhtai. hu(/rhmai is usually pass.; but sometimes midd., as in Dem. or. 19 § 17, or. 55 § 31, Aeschin. or. 3 § 162. Here the pass. sense is more forcible: Ajax is himself the pe/nqos.
e)/rga xeroi=n … a)reta=s, handdeeds of valour: both genitives define e)/rga, but xeroi=n belongs to it more closely: cp. 308 f. e)reipi/ois | nekrw=n..fo/nou.

a)/fila par' a)fi/lois: for the doubled adj., cp. 267 n. para/ with dat. =‘in their estimation’: Tr. 589dokei=s par' h(mi=n ou) bebouleu=sqai kakw=s: Dem. or. 2 § 3 qaumasto/teros para\ pa=si nomi/zetai.
a)/fila … e)/pese, have fallen, have turned out, so as to win no kindness. The adj. is proleptic: e)/pese is a metaphor from dice: cp. Pind. O. 12. 10polla\ d' a)nqrw/pois para\ gnw/man e)/pesen.

e)/pes' e)/pese: for the iteration, cp. 1205: fr. 686 baru\s baru\s cu/noikos, w)= ce/noi, baru/s. Elsewhere Sophocles usu. iterates a word only after a slight break, as in Ph. 1462lei/pomen u(ma=s, lei/pomen h)/dh (cp. El. 211).

su/ntrofos is strongly recommended by metrical reasons, for the short me/n (=the 1st syll. of keu/qwn in 635) is very difficult to defend. Sophocles has, indeed, used the other compound in O. C. 1362mo/xqw|..e)/ntrofon. Here, however, the en of me\n might have led to e)/ntrofos. Similarly in Ant. 837e)/gklhra is probably a corruption of su/gklhra. For su/ntrofos, cp. 611 cu/naulos, n.
palaia=| … a(me/ra|, the day of old age; cp. Eur. Ion 720ne/an d' a(me/ran a)polipw\n qa/noi. Ar. Ran. 347xroni/ous t' e)tw=n palaiw=n e)niautou/s.

leukw=|, the general epithet of gh=ras, seems slightly more poetical here than leuka\, though the latter may be supported by Eur. H. F. 909w)= leuka\ gh/ra| sw/mat). Cp. Eur. Bacch. 258gh=ras polio/n. The use of me
 and de\ here is the same as in ‘epanaphora,’ where the ideas represented by the formally opposed clauses are often closely akin; e.g. Theog. 656 i)/dmen o(/ toi pe/ri me
 prapi/des pe/ri d' e)sti\ no/hma, Her. 7. 9tw=n e)pista/meqa me
 th
 ma/xhn e)pista/meqa de\ th
 du/namin.

nosou=nta frenomo/rws, suffering from a calamity (mo/ros) to the mind. The adv. (a somewhat strange compound) may have been suggested by the Aeschylean frenw/lhs ( Theb. 757), frenomanh/s ( Ag. 1140). It recalls also the paraphrase of mani/a in Eur. H. F. 1024 by lussa/di..moi/ra|.

ai)/linon, a loud, wild cry of grief, which for the Greeks had barbaric associations; cp. Eur. Or. 1395ai)/linon ai)/linon a)rxa\n qana/tou | ba/rbaroi le/gousin, ai)ai=, | *)asia/di fwna=| k.t.l. The mother's passionate grief will break forth in a cry of shrill anguish,—not in more subdued and plaintive accents, like those of the nightingale's lament. The contrast meant here is plain enough; though in some other places, where the bitter grief of the nightingale is the fore<*>st thought, the bird's note is sometimes described as ‘piercing’; e.g. Soph. Tr. 963prou)/klaion, o)cu/fwnos w(s a)hdw/n (cp. Soph. El. 107 ff.).

a)hdou=s in apposition with o)/rniqos: cp. Eur. H. F. 465stolh/n te qhro\s a)mfe/balle sw=| ka/ra| | le/ontos. For the form, cp. voc. a)hdoi= ( Ar. Av. 679), xelidoi= ( Ar. Av. 1411 etc.), ei)kw/ acc. ( Eur. Med. 1162 etc.), ei)kou/s acc. pl. ( Eur. Tro. 1178). No nom. a)hdw/, xelidw/, or ei)kw/ occurs. Conversely gorgw/ is the regular nom., but the genit. either gorgou=s ( Il. 8. 349) or gorgo/nos, and the pl. always gorgo/nes. Schol. in L: h( a)hdw\ de\ kata\ *mitulhnai/ous.
o)cuto/nous: El. 243o)cuto/nwn go/wn: Ant. 1316o)cukw/kuton pa/qos.
xero/plaktoi … dou=poi, the sound of beating hands: cp. 55 polu/kerwn fo/non (n.): O. C. 1464ktu/pos.. dio/bolos.

a)/mugma, here ‘rending,’ would ordinarily mean ‘a scratch’; cp. Aesch. Ch. 24pre/pei parhi+\s foini/ois a)mugmoi=s. The more natural word here would have been spa/ragma: cp. Eur. Andr. 826spa/ragma ko/mas o)nu/xwn te da/i+) a)mu/gmata qh/somai: ib. 1209 ou) spara/comai ko/man.

krei/sswn … keu/qwn, the personal constr., instead of krei=sso/n e)sti keu/qein au)to/n: cp. O. T. 1368krei/sswn ga\r h)=sqa mhke/t' w)\n h)\ zw=n tuflo/s: Lys. or. 26 § 4 krei/ttwn h)=n o( path\r au)tou= mh\ leitourgh/sas: Dem. or. 3 § 34 oi)/koi me/nwn belti/wn: Soph. Ant. 6. 9krei/ttwn ga\r a)\n... ge/noito o( toiou=tos poli/ths a)poqanw/n.

Elmsley's emendation, par) *)/aida|, instead of ga\r *(/aida| (the reading of the MSS.), is specious; for Sophocles has that phrase in O. T. 972 and in O. C. 1572; but here he may have been thinking of Il. 23. 244ei)s o(/ ken au)to\s e)gw\n *)/ai+di keu/qwmai. The personal sense of Hades easily passes into the local; thus we have not only ei)s *(/aidou ( Tr. 4), but ei)s *)ai+/dan ( El. 833). For the simple dat., cp. El. 174ou)ranw=| (n.).
keu/qwn, as in O. T. 968keu/qei ka/tw dh\ gh=s. Ant. 911e)n *(/aidou..kekeuqo/toin.

o( nosw=n ma/tan: here the adv. = ‘foolishly,’ i.e., insanely. Cp. Ar. Pax 95ti/ pe/tei; ti/ ma/thn ou)x u(giai/neis; Aesch. Cho. 288kai\ lu/ssa kai\ ma/taios e)k nuktw=n fo/bos. For the order of words, instead of o( ma/tan nosw=n, cp. El. 792tou= qano/ntos a)rti/ws (n.).

e)k patrw/|as h(/kwn genea=s a)/ristos … *)axaiw=n, lit., ‘noblest of the Achaeans by his descent (h(/kwn) from the line of his fathers’: i.e., having a prouder lineage than any other Achaean can claim. h(/kwn here, going with a)/ristos, has nearly the same force as (e.g.) in O. T. 1519qeoi=s e)/xqistos h(/kw, ‘I have become most hateful to them’: i.e., it denotes the outcome of an illustrious ancestry. Though a)/ristos (see cr. n.) cannot be regarded as certain, and may be a mere conjecture, it is at least far better than anything else that has been suggested.

The ingenious conjecture of Burges, o(\s eu)= patrw/|as h(/kwn genea=s a)/nwqen, would mean, ‘fortunate (eu)= h(/kwn) in his descent (a)/nwqen) with regard to paternal lineage’ (the gen. genea=s as in xrhma/twn eu)= h(/kontes, Her. 5. 62, etc.). But this is tame; and eu)= h(/kwn is also prosaic: nor does it account for the gen. *)axaiw=n. Wecklein, reading eu)= patrw/|as h(/kwn genea=s, a)/rista..*)axaiw=n, understands, ‘fortunate in his lineage, — most so, indeed, of the Achaeans’: so that a)/rista defines eu)=.
polupo/nwn refers to warlike toils: cp. Aesch. Pers. 320polu/ponon do/ru. Her. 9. 27e)n toi=si *trwikoi=si po/noisi.

suntro/fois o)rgai=s, the dispositions that have grown with his growth, his natural tro/poi: for the subst., cp. Ant. 355a)stuno/mous o)rga/s (n.): for the adj., Ph. 203(ktu/pos) fwto\s su/ntrofos w(s teirome/nou tou. With e)/mpedos supply e)sti/: he is not stable, constant, in respect to them (=ou)k e)mme/nei au)tai=s).

e)kto\s o(milei=, is conversant (with thoughts) outside of the cu/ntrofoi o)rgai/. The only peculiarity is that from cuntro/fois o)rgai=s we are left to supply a)/llais o)rgai=s (suggested by e)kto\s) with o(milei=. (We cannot, surely, understand e)kto\s o(milei= cuntro/fois o)rgai=s, as if it were an oxymoron, =ou)x o(milei=.) The expression is of the same stamp as that in Eur. Bacch. 331oi)/kei meq' h(mw=n, mh\ qu/raze tw=n no/mwn, (‘dwell with us, forsaking not the pale of our customs,’ etc.): ib. 853 e)/cw d' e)lau/nwn tou= fronei=n. For o(milei=, cp. Nub. 1399 w(s h(du\ kainoi=s pra/gmasin kai\ decioi=s o(milei=n.

tla=mon. Sophocles has this voc. in Tr. 1112(w)= tlh=mon *(ella/s), and in O. C. 978.In the latter place, as here, L has the nom., which may perh. be due to the fact that the nom. tlh/mwn so often occurs in exclamations; e.g. 893: O.C. 185 w)= tla/mwn: Ant. 229: Ph. 1102: Tr. 986.
du/sforon: cp. 51.
e)/qreyen: cp. 503, n. on tre/fei.

ai)w
 (if sound) means ‘life,’ not merely as=‘living man,’ but in the sense of ‘life-destiny’: cp. Tr. 34toiou=tos ai)w
 ei)s do/mous te ka)k do/mwn | a)ei\ to
 a)/ndr' e)/pempe. The strict meaning would be then, ‘no life-destiny which the line of Aeacus has known.’ There is a certain pathos in this which may plead for it as against Reiske's very plausible emendation di/wn (*d for A), which may be right, though, as compared with ai)w/n, it is perhaps a little weak. Cp. Il. 5. 451di=oi *)axaioi/.

div2.p: Second e)peiso/dion. Ajax comes forth from the tent, and addresses his faithful friends. The speech translates his unshaken purpose into the terms of his altered mood; yet so as to veil his meaning from the hearers, and to make them think that not only the mood, but the purpose, is changed. (See Introduction, § 12.) Tecmessa who left the scene at 595, now returns, entering on the right of the spectators, and leading her child. Their presence adds effect to v. 653; and Ajax addresses her at v. 684.

div3.p: o( makro\s … xro/nos: see Her. 5. 9, quoted in n. on 86.

fu/ei t' k.t.l.: the emphasis is on the power of time to enfeeble and destroy, rather than to produce; but the first clause serves to bring the second into relief, and is co-ordinated with it, as in Ant. 1112au)to/s t' e)/dhsa kai\ parw\n e)klu/somai.—The rash change of fu/ei to fai/nei overlooks the poet's tendency to vary his phrase in such cases; e.g. O. C. 1501safh\s me\n a)stw=n e)mfanh\s de\ tou= ce/nou: O. T. 54a)/rceis..kratei=s.

kru/ptetai, properly, ‘hides in its own bosom’ (midd.): cp. Aesch. Cho. 127gai=an..h(\ ta\ pa/nta ti/ktetai, ‘produces from herself.’ The midd. of the simple kru/ptw is rare: but cp. 246, and Tr. 474kru/yomai (n.).
a)/elpton: Archil. fr. 76 xrhma/twn a)/elpton ou)de/n e)stin ou)d' a)pw/moton. Cp. Soph. Ant. 388.
a(li/sketai, absol., ‘is captured,’ ‘is proved weak’: cp. 1267.— deino\s: cp. Tr. 476o( deino\s i(/meros: El. 770deino\n to\ ti/ktein e)sti/n.
periskelei=s: Ant. 475si/dhron o)pto\n e)k puro\s periskelh= (n.). Thus the associations of the word lead naturally to his next thought.
ta\ dei/n), adv., ‘so wondrously’: cp. 312 n. to/te, olim: cp. 1240: 1377: Ant. 391: El. 278.

bafh=| si/dhros w(/s, sc. kartero\s gi/gnetai, supplied from e)karte/roun. The bafh/ is the cold bath (lacus) into which the hot iron is plunged, and from which it receives the temper of steel. Cp. Od. 9. 391
w(s d' o(/t' a)nh xalkeu/s pe/lekun me/gan h)e\ ske/parnon
ei)n u(/dati yuxrw=| ba/pth| mega/la i)a/xonta
farma/sswn: to\ ga au)=te sidh/rou ge kra/tos e)sti/n: where Eustathius says, stomou=tai si/dhros toiau/th| bafh=| kai\ kra/tos e)/xei, o(/ e)sti kratero\s gi/netai puknou/menos ei)s ple/on. So Galen compares the tonic effect of a cold bath on the human body with the effect of the bafh/ upon iron (Meth. Med. x. 10, vol. x. 717 Kuhn), kai\ ga yuxo/meqa kai\ tonou/meqa, kaqa/per e)kei=nos (iron) e)peida
 dia/puros geno/menos e)mba/pthtai tw=| yuxrw=|. Lucr. 6. 968umor aquae ferrum porro condurat ab igni (i.e., ‘after fire’). Hence bafh/=the ‘temper’ of steel, and is often used figuratively. Arist. Pol. 4.(7.) 14 § 22 th
 ga bafh
 a)fia=sin, w(/sper o( si/dhros, ei)rh/nhn a)/gontes: Plut. Mor.p. 988 D th=s me
 a)ndrei/as oi)=on bafh/ tis o( qumo/s e)sti kai\ sto/mwma (‘wrath gives, as it were, a temper and an edge to courage’).— This passage has been discussed by R. Paehler, in an essay on ancient steel (1885), and by Prof. H. Blümner in his work on Greek and Roman technology (1887): see Appendix.

e)qhlu/nqhn sto/ma. The aor. is like e)ph/|nesa in 536 (n.): i.e., it refers, like oi)kti/rw, to the present, not to the time at which Tecmessa spoke. (Verses 594 f. suffice to prove this.) sto/ma, standing so close to bafh=| si/dhros w(/s, necessarily suggests the sense of a sharp, hard edge. At the same time, it refers, in its literal sense, to the glw=ssa teqhgme/nh (584) by which his purpose was announced. Just so the father in Aristophanes (Nub. 1107), who wishes his son to be made both acute and fluent, says, me/mnhs' o(/pws | eu)= moi stomw/seis au)to/n. Hence sto/ma cannot be completely translated; and it is the literal sense which should here be sacrificed to the other. For the verb, cp. Anth. 5. 251. 6 ou)/pw e)qhlu/nqhs (‘softened’), ou)de\ marainome/nh.

oi)kti/rw … lipei=n naturally suggests the meaning, ‘pity forbids me to leave her’; cp. Od. 20. 202ou)k e)leai/reis a)/ndras.. | misge/menai kako/thti. But the words could also mean, ‘I feel pity at the thought of leaving her,’ implying that he does intend to leave her, though with pain; which would usually be oi)kti/rw ei) lei/yw.
pro/s te loutra\=pro\s loutra/ te: 53 n.

lu/maq' a(gni/sas refers ostensibly to his washing off (with sea water) the stains of the slaughter. Such an act might be symbolical of purging oneself from a sin; as it is in Il. 1. 313laou\s d' *)atrei/dhs a)polumai/nesqai a)/nwgen: | oi( d' a)pelumai/nonto kai\ ei)s a(/la lu/mat' e)/ballon: where the meaning is that, by washing in the sea, they cast off their stains upon it ( I. T. 1193 qa/lassa klu/zei pa/nta ta)nqrw/pwn kaka/). So here the thought in the mind of Ajax is that he will purge himself of his stains by death.
e)calu/cwmai: on the question between this form and e)caleu/swmai, see note in Appendix.
molw/n … e)/nq) = molw\n e)kei=se e)/nqa, as often: cp. O. T. 796, Ph. 1466, El. 1495.
ki/xw, ‘find,’ as in O. T. 1257: not merely ‘reach,’ as in the spurious v., O. T. 571.The pres. kigxa/nei occurs in O. C. 1450.
kru/yw: cp. 899 kei=tai krufai/w| fasga/nw| periptuxh/s.
gai/as, partitive gen. with e(/nqa.
e)/nqa mh/ tis o)/yetai: cp. O. T. 1412e)kri/yat), e)/nqa mh/pot' ei)so/yesq' e)/ti: Tr. 800: El. 380, El. 436.

a)ll' au)to\ k.t.l. So Clytaemnestra's gifts to Agamemnon's tomb are to be laid up for her with the gods below: keimh/li) au)th=| tau=ta sw|ze/sqw ka/tw ( El. 438). An ingenious critic, GeelJ. , writing on vv. 646—692 in Mnemosyne (II. pp. 200—208, 1853), wishes to omit this verse, because it implies the only direct falsehood in the speech; Ajax was not going to bury his sword under ground. But why should not Ajax think of the sword as destined to be buried in his grave? The shield alone was excepted from the direction which he gave in 577: ta\ d' a)/lla teu/xh koi/n' e)moi\ teqa/yetai.

xeiri\ adds a certain emphasis, as if he said, ‘from the day that this sword came into my hand.’ Cp. Eur. Hec. 527plh=res d' e)n xeroi=n labw\n de/pas | pa/gxruson ai)/rei xeiri\ pai=s *)axille/ws | xoa\s qano/nti patri/.

The exchange of gifts between the two heroes is told in Il. 7. 303 ff.: Hector gave ‘his silver-studded sword (ci/fos a)rguro/hlon), with scabbard and well-cut baldrick; and Ajax gave his girdle bright with purple.’
e)/sxon in its normal sense, ‘obtained.’
h( brotw=n paroimi/a: for the absence of a second art., cp. 118.

e)xqrw=n a)/dwra dw=ra: cp. Menander Sent. 166 e)xqrou= par' a)ndro\s ou)de/n e)sti xrh/simon. Verg. Aen. 2. 49timeo Danaos et dona ferentes. The gnw/mh with which Medea rejects Jason's offers is different: kakou= ga\r a)ndro\s dw=r' o)/nhsin ou)k e)/xei ( Med. 618).
toiga\r prefaces the announcement of a purpose, as in Tr. 1249toiga\r poh/sw: El. 29toiga\r ta\ me\n do/canta dhlw/sw.

to\ loipo
, ‘henceforth.’ The hearers would infer that he had renounced his purpose of suicide. But in his own thought the phrase refers merely to the brief space before his death.— ei)so/mesqa, by the experience itself; maqhso/mesqa, by the self-discipline which such an experience recommends. But the principal antithesis is between qeoi=s and *)atrei/das, rather than between the verbs. We sometimes find, in good writers of this age, even synonymous verbs placed in apparent contrast, though the real antithesis lies elsewhere: e.g. Lys. or. 25 § 22 h(gou/menoi dia\ th
 tw=n tr<*>a/konta ponhri/an polu\ ma=llon swqh/sesqai h)\ dia\ th
 tw=n feugo/ntwn du/namin katie/nai.

ti/ mh/n; quid vero? ‘what then?’ i.e., ‘of course we must yield.’ Cp. Aesch. Ag. 672le/gousin h(ma=s w(s o)lwlo/tas: ti/ mh/n; (i.e., it is only natural that they should do so.) So in Suppl. 999, Eum. 203.With Plato ti/ mh/n is frequent in assenting replies, as Phaedr. p. 229 A, *f*a*i. o(ra=|s ou)=n e)kei/nhn th\n..pla/tanon; *s*w. ti/ mh/n; Cp. Phileb.p. 17 B and 44 B, Polit. 258 B, etc. The reason for preferring ti/ mh/n to ti/ mh/ here is that the former is well attested, whereas there seems to be no certain example of ti/ mh/ in the Attic of this period. With ti/ mh/ (quidni?) we should supply u(pei/kwmen; cp. Plat. Theaet.p. 161 E pw=s mh\ fw=men; Dem. or. 21 § 35 o( toiou=tos po/tera mh\ dw=| dia\ tou=to di/khn;

ta\ deina\, the dread elemental forces of nature. The word deino/s might be called the key-note of the earlier part of this speech (cp. 648 f., 674): it comes readily to the mind of the strong man, full of the thought how strength can become weakness.

timai=s, ‘dignities,’ ‘prerogatives,’ here, the provinces assigned to these elemental forces in the order of nature. Plat. Apol.p. 35 B e)/n te tai=s a)rxai=s kai\ tai=s a)/llais timai=s. Cp. Troilus and Cressida 1. 3. 83 (Ulysses tracing the ill-success of the siege to the bad discipline of the Greeks):—Degree being vizarded, | The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask. | The heavens themselves, the planets and this centre | Observe degree, priority and place, | Insisture, course, proportion, season, form, | Office and custom, in all line of order.
tou=to me\n, followed by de/ (instead of tou=to de/), as in O. C. 440 f. (n.).

nifostibei=s xeimw=nes, probably ‘winters with snowy paths,’ ‘snow-strewn.’ sti/bos, ‘path,’ is the notion present in other like compounds; O. T. 301ou)ra/nia/ te kai\ xqonostibh= (‘walking the earth’): Suppl. 1000 kai\ knw/dala pterou=nta kai\ pedostibh=: P. V. 791pro\s a)ntola\s flogw=pas h(liostibei=s, ‘where are the paths of the Sun.’—Some understand, ‘storms that range over snow’: but such a personification of the xeimw=nes seems harsh. A third version is, ‘storms dense (or piled) with snow,’ from stei/bw in the sense of ‘pressing down,’ ‘packing.’

e)ci/statai k.t.l.: cp. Soph. Ph. 543nukto/s t' a)fegge\s ble/faron h(li/ou te fw=s | i)/son badi/zei to
 e)niau/sion ku/klon, | kou)de/teron au)tw=n fqo/non e)/xei nikw/menon. Plut. Mor.p. 604 A kai/toi tw=n planh/twn e(/kastos e)n mia=| sfai/ra|, kaqa/per e)n nh/sw|, peripolw=n diafula/ttei th
 ta/cin: *(/hlios ga ou)x u(perbh/setai me/tra, fhsi
 o( *(hra/kleitos: ei) de\ mh/, *)erinu/es min di/khs e)pi/kouroi e)ceurh/sousi. (Frag. XXIX of Heracleitus, ed. Bywater.)

ai)anh\s has L's support here, as in El. 506, where see n. The prevalence of ai)anh=s in the texts of this passage may be partly explained by a desire of symmetry, since in v. 673 an epithet is given to h(me/ra|. Both ai)anh/s and ai)ano/s were probably classical. Reading ai)anh\s here, we may best take ku/klos with ref. to the course or ‘round’ of night; cp. El. 1365pollai\ kuklou=ntai nu/ktes.

th=| leukopw/lw|: Aesch. Pers. 386leuko/pwlos h(me/ra | pa=san kate/sxe gai=an eu)feggh\s i)dei=n, where the last two words suggested fe/ggos … fle/gein here,—epexegetic of e)ci/statai (‘makes room for her, so that she may kindle,’ etc.). As to the ascription of white horses to deities or heroes, see on El. 706.

e)koi/mise, gnomic aor., followed by the pres. lu/ei: cp. El. 26qumo
 ou)k a)pw/lesen, | a)ll' o)rqo
 ou)=s i(/sthsin. The a)/hma pneuma/twn is personified as an elemental power (like ta\ deina\ etc. in 669). That power can either vex the sea, or give it rest; as Aeolus, the tami/hs a)ne/mwn, has the prerogative, h)me
 paue/menai h)d' o)rnu/men, o(/n k' e)qe/lh|si ( Od. 10. 22). So in 706 *)/arhs is a giver of peace. Cp. C. 1. 3. 15 (Notus), quo non arbiter Hadriae | Maior, tollere seu ponere vult freta. Vergil may have had Sophocles in mind when he wrote placataque venti | Dant maria ( Aen. 3. 69): but when he says, placidi straverunt aequora venti ( Aen. 5. 763), the epithet makes all the difference (=a)/nemoi lh/cantes).

Lobeck, though he refrains from changing deinw=n to lei/wn, thinks that the vulgate can be defended only by supposing that the foregoing verbs, u(pei/kei, e)kxwrou=sin, e)ci/statai, tinge e)koi/mise with the sense, ‘cease from troubling the sea’: otherwise some addition to a)/hma, such as lh=can, would be needed; cp. Pind. I. 7. 12dei=ma..paroixo/menon | kartera\n e)/pause me/rimnan. But this difficulty vanishes if a)/hma is a personified agency.
e)n d), ‘and among them’; i.e., like the other powers of nature (669). e)n de/ is similarly used in O. T. 27, O. T. 181, Tr. 206.
gnwso/mesqa, ‘come to know,’ ‘learn,’ with inf., as in Ant. 1089kai\ gnw=| tre/fein th\n glw=ssan h(suxwte/ran. In Ant. 779gnw/setai=‘she will learn’ (by bitter experience).
e)/gwg): sc. gnw/somai: ‘I, at least, will so learn.’ For this elliptical e)/gwg), cp. 1347, 1365, Tr. 1248.

The vulgate e)gw\ d) may have come from h(mei=s de\ in 677. It requires us to suppose that the poet was going to write e)gw\ d), e)pi/stamai ga\r a)rti/ws (tou=to), to/n t' e)xqro\n e)xqarw=, k.t.l.,—and then changed the constr. This is awkward. On the other hand, with e)gw\ d), we could not supply gnw/somai.

o(/ t' e)xqro\s h(mi=n k.t.l. The maxim is two-edged. filei=n w(s mish/sonta is the side of it which is really in the mind of Ajax:—he dies hating the Greeks whom he had served so nobly (839—844). But the other side—misei=n w(s filh/sonta—is that which he wishes his hearers to conceive as foremost in his thoughts.

Arist. Rhet. 2. 13§ 4 (old men) kata\ th\n *bi/antos u(poqh/khn kai\ filou=sin w(s mish/sontes kai\ misou=sin w(s filh/sontes. Bias , of Prienè in Ionia, one of the e(pta\ sofoi/, is said to have flourished about 550 B.C. For other references to this famous maxim, see Appendix.

e)/s te to\n fi/lon: these words do not go closely with u(pourgw=n, but rather indicate generally the line of conduct in this case:—‘while, in relation to a friend,’ etc. Cp. Tr. 411e)s th/nde mh\ di/kaios w)/n: El. 24e)sqlo\s ei)s h(ma=s gegw/s.
boulh/somai, as in O. T. 1077(n.), O. C. 1289: cp. below, O. C. 825, ai)th/somai: O. T. 1446prostre/yomai.

toi=s polloi=si ga\r k.t.l. This is a ground for to\ filei=n w(s mish/sonta, but not (directly, at least) for the converse; and bewrays what is really uppermost in his mind. Bias , acc. to Diogenes Laertius (1. 5 § 87), gave a similar reason,—tou\s ga\r plei/stous ei)=nai kakou/s.

e(tairei/as has better authority here than e(tairi/as. Some have supposed that e(tairei/a was the form used in the sense of factio, or party ‘association,’ and e(tairi/a in that of amicitia; but there is really no good evidence for this. In Thuc. 3. 82§ 5, where the word has its political sense, the best MSS. give e(tairi/as dialuth/s.

a)mfi\ … tou/toisin: cp. 302.— dia\ te/lous..telei=sqai, fulfilled in all fulness. For the ordinary meaning of dia\ te/lous in Attic prose, see Antiphon or. 5 § 42, where it occurs twice: parw\n dia\ te/lous (‘present all through,’ from first to last): dia\ te/lous ga/r me a)pe/lue (‘he acquitted me throughout,’—in all his statements). So Aesch. P. V. 273a)kou/saq' w(s ma/qhte dia\ te/lous to\ pa=n (i.e. from beginning to end), etc. Here the stress on the notion of end, given by dia\ te/lous telei=sqai, suits the inmost thought of Ajax. The v.l. dia\ ta/xous is much feebler.
tau)ta\ th=|de=ta\ au)ta\ a(\ h(/de tima=|: cp. O. T. 839le/gwn | soi\ tau)/t).— moi ethic dat. ( O. C. 1475 n.), ‘I pray you.’

ta/de tima=te, respect these wishes. The use of tima=n is not exactly like that in Ant. 514pw=s dh=t' e)kei/nw| dussebh= tima=|s xa/rin (where see n.), but more like that in Eur. Tro. 1210no/mous | timw=sin.
me/lein, probably personal (=e)pimelei=sqai), as in El. 342kei/nou lelh=sqai th=s de\ tiktou/shs me/lein (n.).

e)kei=s). At first sight we might desire kei=s) (810), as giving a better rhythm; but the slower movement of the verse may here be designed.—Cp. O. T. 1458a)ll' h( me\n h(mw=n moi=r), o(/poiper ei)=s), O. T. i)/tw.

ta/x' a)/n … i)/sws: a formula used by Thucydides to express a strong probability (6. 10 § 4, 34 § 2, 78 § 3).— seswsme/non: contrasted in El. 1229 with qano/nta: cp. ib. 59 o(/tan lo/gw| qanw\n | e)/rgoisi swqw=. The word was thus wellchosen for his aim here.

div2.p: A joyous dance-song, u(po/rxhma, which holds the place of the second stasimon. Strophe 693—705= antistr. 706—718. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
The effect is to prepare for the catastrophe by a contrast. A joyous ode is introduced with a similar purpose in O. T. 1086—1109; Ant. 1115—1154; and Tr. 633—662.

div3.p: e)/fric): for the aor., cp. 536: Ar. Eq. 696h(/sqhn a)peilai=s, e)ge/lasa yolokompi/ais. Aesch. fr. 387 e)/fric' e)/rws de\ (e)/rwti Brunck) tou=de mustikou= te/lous. Here e)/rwti seems to mean a transport of joy; it cannot be explained of their yearning for the bright future of which they are dreaming. I do not know any exactly similar use of e)/rws. Cp. Statius Theb. 1. 493laetusque per artus | Horror iit.
a)nepta/man: for the form, see on 282 prose/ptato. Cp. Ant. 1307a)ne/ptan fo/bw|: Helen. 632 ge/ghqa, krati\ d' o)rqi/ous e)qei/ras | a)nepte/rwka.

694 ff. Pan was a domestic deity to Salaminians, since one of his reputed haunts was the islet of Psyttaleia, lying between *kuno/soura, a tongue of land on the E. side of Salamis, and the Peiraeus. Aesch. mentions it ( Aesch. Pers. 448 f.): baia/, du/sormos nausi/n, h(\n o( filo/xoros | *pa\n e)mbateu/ei, ponti/as a)kth=s e)/pi.

a(li/plagkte, though separated from fa/nhq), is perhaps best taken with it, since, as merely a general epithet of the god, it would here be less fitting; but then there must be no comma after it. Cp. Ph. 760du/sthne..fanei/s: ib. 828 eu)ae\s h(mi=n e)/lqois (n.): Theocr. 17. 66 o)/lbie kw=re ge/noio. Nonnus 43. 214 describes Pan as a)ba/toisin e)n u(/dasi kou=fos o(di/ths.

*kullani/as … deira/dos. Mount Cyllenè, in the N. E. of Arcadia, a great isolated peak, was sacred (as his birth-place) to Hermes, the father of Pan,—whose own birth was associated by legend with Cyllenè. But, of the Arcadian hills, the well-wooded Maenalus, in the interior, was more especially beloved of Pan ( Geo. 1. 17 tua si tibi Maenala curae).
xionoktu/pou (only here): cp. Nub. 270 *)olu/mpou korufai=s..xionoblh/toisi: Soph. Ph. 206u(po\ deira/si nifobo/lois | *parnasou=. Cyllenè attains a height of about 8000 feet.

qew=n xoropoi/) a)/nac: the gen. qew=n seems to be possessive rather than partitive; i.e. the precise sense seems to be, ‘divine dance-maker of the gods,’ rather than, ‘among the gods, that god who makes dances.’ For such a partitive gen., we may, indeed, compare O. C. 868qew=n | o( pa/nta leu/sswn *(/hlios (unless qeo\s should be read there). But here the meaning seems to be that Pan represents the gods in this function. Pan was to rustic xoroi/, those of nymphs and satyrs, what Apollo *mousage/ths was to the Olympians; and the province denoted by xoropoio/s here is thus limited by the context. So Pindar fr. 75 calls Pan xoreuta\n telew/taton qew=n: and an Attic skolio/n greets him as o)rxhsta/, bromi/ais o)pade\ nu/mfais.
*nu/sia: such dances as the worshippers of Dionysus—with whom Pan is closely associated through the satyrs—hold in his honour at Nysa. As to the various places so called, see on Ant. 1131.

*knw/sia: such dances as the Cretan Corybantes hold at Cnosus in honour of Zeus and Apollo. Both the epithets *nu/sia and *knw/sia denote a character of wild enthusiasm.—Cnosus, the chief city of Crete, was situated in the north of the island, in one of the plains at the foot of Ida. The form *knwso/s has older and better authority than *knwsso/s. It was there that Daedalus was said to have made the xoro/s (dancing-place) for Ariadnè ( Il. 18. 590 ff.). Crete was the part of Hellas in which an art of o)rxhstikh/ was first elaborately cultivated. The hyporcheme itself was originally Cretan (schol. on Pind. P. 2. 127).

au)todah= is best explained, with the schol. in L, au)tomaqh=, a(\ su\ sauto\n e)di/dacas. Pan is the inspired and inspiring xoropoio/s. The dances will be joyous as those of Nysa or Cnosus, but due to his prompting alone. So the minstrel Phemius says, au)todi/daktos d' ei)mi/, qeo\s de/ moi e)n fresi\n oi)/mas | pantoi/as e)ne/fusen, Od. 22. 347.

i)a/yh|s (cp. 501) here denotes properly the act of putting forth the feet or the arms in lively movement; so that i)a/ptein o)rxh/mata means strictly, ‘to dance with lively gestures.’ The musician Aristoxenus (c. 300 B.C.) mentioned the *krhtikai\ o)rxh/seis among those which he admired dia\ th\n tw=n xeirw=n ki/nhsin (Athen. I. p. 22 B). How i)a/ptw could be associated with swift motion, appears from the intrans. use in Suppl. 547 i)a/ptei d' *)asi/dos di) ai)/as (‘rushes’).—Pan might possibly be said i)a/ptein o)rxh/mata as ‘impelling’ the dance, i.e., ‘setting it in movement’; but this seems less probable.
xoreu=sai, aor., because a particular occasion (or act) of dancing is in view: but in O. T. 896ti/ dei= me xoreu/ein; because the sense is, ‘why should sacred dances continue?’

*)ikari/wn … pelage/wn: the island of Icaria, W. of Samos and E. of Myconos, gave its name to the ‘Icarian sea’: Il. 2. 145po/ntou *)ikari/oio. C. 3. 7. 21 scopulis surdior Icari. Ov. Met. 8. 229(describing how Icarus, son of Daedalus, was drowned) Oraque caerulea, patrium clamantia nomen, | Excipiuntur aqua, quae nomen traxit ab illo.
pelage/wn: the plur. as in Od. 5. 335a(lo\s e)n pela/gessin. For the synizesis, cp. 718 neike/wn: Ph. 697e(lke/wn.—For u(pe\r with gen., cp. Ant. 105*dirkai/wn u(pe\r r(ee/qrwn molou=sa.

*)apo/llwn was, like Pan, a lord of the dance; cp. Pind. fr. 148 o)rxh/st' a)glai+/as a)na/sswn, eu)rufa/retr' *)apo/llwn: fr. 116 o( *moisage/tas me kalei= xoreu=sai. Here, however, the words nu=n ga\r e)moi\ me/lei xoreu=sai seem to close the reference to dancing. Apollo, who in 187 was invoked as a)potro/paios, is here invited more especially as the healer,—to crown, by his bright presence, their joy at the recovery of Ajax.
*da/lios: cp. O. T. 154*da/lie *paia/n (n.).

eu)/gnwstos, ‘easily recognised,’ i.e., in a visible shape, e)nargh/s: cp. Tr. 11 n.: Od. 3. 420(Athena) h(/ moi e)nargh\s h)=lqe. On gnwto/s and gnwsto/s, see O. T., appendix on 361, p. 225. Some editors read eu)/gnwtos, though the form with s is here the better attested.
dia\ panto\s, with ref. to time (the regular sense of the phrase in Thuc. ; see Classen on 1. 38 § 1).

e)/lusen … *)/arhs. Ares, the god of bloodshed and violent death (253 n.), is said to have ‘cleared away’ the cloud of dread trouble which darkened their eyes, because Ajax has renounced his purpose of suicide. Cp. Tr. 654(*)/arhs) e)ce/lus' e)pi/ponon a(me/ran, ‘has cleared away the day of trouble’ (n.).
ai)no\n a)/xos: Il. 17. 83*(/ektora d' ai)no\n a)/xos pu/kase fre/nas.
a)p' o)mma/twn: Aesch. Theb. 228(qeo\s) ka)k xalepa=s du/as u(/perq' o)mma/twn | krhmnamena=n nefela=n o)rqoi=.
pa/ra=pa/resti:
leuko\n … fa/os, acc., subject to pela/sai. Cp. Aesch. Pers. 301kai\ leuko\n h)=mar nukto\s e)k melagxi/mou. For eu)a/meron fa/os cp. 138 lo/gos kako/qrous (n.).
pela/sai with gen., as Ph. 1327pelasqei\s fu/lakos: Tr. 17koi/ths e)mpelasqh=nai.

qoa=n describes the ship as a thing of life (velox navis), w)kua/lwn rather as a swift vehicle over the sea (celeris): cp. Od. 7. 34nhusi\ qoh=|si pepoiqo/tes w)kei/h|si. For the double epithet, cp. also Ph. 516eu)sto/lou taxei/as new/s.
laqi/ponos (sc. e)sti/),=lanqa/netai po/nwn: the word occurs only here and in Tr. 1021(laqi/ponon d' o)duna=n).

pa/nquta qe/smi) e)ch/nus). As Ajax had announced his purpose of ‘purging his stains’ (655) and ‘submitting to the gods’ (666 f.), the Chorus assume that he has now duly performed all the rites of kaqarmo/s and i(lasmo/s. By qew=n pa/nquta qe/smia is meant, ‘the ordinances of the gods, with all the qusi/ai which they enjoin’; since the ablutions of Ajax would be followed (as the Chorus conceive) by sacrifices to the deities whom he had offended, esp. to Athena and Artemis. There is thus a tragic irony in pa/nquta, since a qusi/a is indeed about to be offered.
eu)nomi/a|, ‘loyalty’ to these qe/smia.

marai/nei. Soph. Ant. 2. 3o( pa/nta marai/nwn ta\ kala\ xro/nos. The reading of the MSS., marai/nei te kai\ fle/gei, clearly bewrays an interpolation. The schol. in L has, ta\ u(po\ *ai)/antos dia\ pollw=n ei)rhme/na dia\ braxe/wn diech=lqen: vague words which obviously do not require us to suppose that the fane/nta kru/ptetai of v. 647, as well as the fu/ei t' a)/dhla, found an echo here. But it is possible that this very scholium may have led a prosaic reader to surmise a loss, and to supply it. (Another possibility is that marai/nei was corrupted to marai/netai, and this to marai/nei te, when a defect would be inferred.) Compare the undoubted interpolations in Soph. O. T. 896 and Soph. Ph. 1407.

a)nau/daton is not here ‘unutterably dreadful’ (as in Eur. Ion 782), but ‘not to be spoken of,’ in the sense, ‘not to be affirmed as possible’: cp. Soph. Ant. 388brotoi=sin ou)de/n e)st' a)pw/moton. Thus a)ne/lpiston (schol.) gives the meaning correctly.
e)c a)e/lptwn: Suppl. 357 e)c a)e/lptwn ka)promhqh/twn.

metanegnw/sqh is prob. passive; ‘has been converted from his anger.’ I cannot find an example of e)gnw/sqhn (simple or compound) in any but a pass. sense. a)negnw/sqhn is regularly pass. in Herod. ; e.g. 4. 154 a)nagnwsqei\s u(po\ th=s gunaiko/s (cp. 6. 50; 7. 7, etc.). The schol. in L took the word to be pass.; he explains it by metepei/sqh (as Hesychius does), and meteblh/qh. The other view —that metanegnw/sqh is midd. in sense— appears in the glosses mete/gnw and metabebou/leutai: but no proof is brought. If it be passive, however, it does not mean that the Chorus suppose Ajax to have been converted by themselves or Tecmessa: the cause is left indefinite.—The form metanegnw/qh is preferred by Wecklein: Hesychius is, however, our only witness for it.

qumou= t). qumw=n (cr. n.) is indeed nearer to the qumo\n of the MSS., since Sophocles would write it *q*u*m*o*n: but, though the plur. qumoi/ is common enough in prose (as=‘fits of passion’), it never occurs in Tragedy. The gen. depends on metanegnw/sqh as a verb of ‘desisting’ or ‘withdrawing’ from (cp. metasth=nai/ tinos). The dat. *)atrei/dais depends on metanegnw/sqh qumou= as implying kathlla/xqh or cune/gnw. Cp. 774: I. Il. 283*)axillh=i meqe/men xo/lon: Od. 21. 377me/qien xalepoi=o xo/loio | *thlema/xw|.— neike/wn: for the synizesis, cp. 702 pelage/wn.

div2.p: The third e)peiso/dion consists of two scenes. (1) 719—814. The messenger from Teucer excites the fears of the Chorus and Tecmessa. (2) 815— 865. The soliloquy of Ajax, and his death.

div3.p: to\ prw=ton, adv., in the first place. The omission of o(/ti after a)ggei=lai marks the speaker's eager haste: cp. O.T. 1234 f. o( me\n ta/xistos tw=n lo/gwn ei)pei=n te kai\ | maqei=n, te/qnhke qei=on *)ioka/sths ka/ra. For to\ prw=ton, compare also Ant. 238, Tr. 232: Ar. Eq. 642lo/gous a)gaqou\s fe/rwn | eu)aggeli/sasqai prw=ton u(mi=n bou/lomai.

*musi/wn … krhmnw=n. The eastern boundary of the ancient Mysia, dividing it from Bithynia and Phrygia, is formed by the range of Olympus, which attains a height of about 8500 ft. The krhmnoi/ meant here are the lower spurs of Olympus, in the region of Ida. Teucer had gone on a foray (343 n.) to some of the upland towns or villages of the enemy.

strath/gion, the klisi/a of Agamemnon. So in Il. 7. 382 an agora is held nhi\ pa/ra prumnh=| *)agame/mnonos. He was stationed near Odysseus, whose post, at the middle point of the naval camp ( Il. 11. 6), is mentioned as being near the place of assembly, judgment, and sacrifice; i(/na sf' a)gorh/ te qe/mis te | h)/hn, th=| dh\ kai/ sfi qew=n e)teteu/xato bwmoi/ ( Il. 11. 807 f.). Hence me/son here. The chiefs of the army had now met in front of these headquarters to hold a boulh/ on the deed of Ajax; while the laoi/ were gathered in a)gora/ around them. In Attic prose strath/gion means the council-chamber of the ten strathgoi/ (Aeschin. or. 2 § 85: or. 3. § 146).

kuda/zetai. The word from which this verb comes is written ku=dos by the schol. in L here (a)rsenikw=s de\ o( ku=dos e)pi\ th=s u(/brews), and by the schol. on Apoll. Rhod. 1. 1337 ku=dos a)rsenikw=s h( loidori/a para\ *surakousi/ois. The schol. in L illustrates the verb by two quotations: (1) from the *)/amukos of Epicharmus: *)/amuke mh\ ku/daze/ moi to\n presbu/teron a)delfo/n: (2) from the Iphigeneia of Aeschylus: ou)/ toi gunaici\ kuda/zesqai: ti/ ga/r;—where Elmsley inserts dei=, and Blomfield xrh/, after gunaici/. The verb having u^, the noun must have been o( ku/dos (u^).—For the dat. of the agency, *)argei/ois, cp. 539.

stei/xonta k.t.l. They saw him coming while he was still far off; when he drew nearer, they gathered round him in a threatening crowd; and now, having arrived at the strath/gion, he is being reviled by them. Notwithstanding the position of e)n ku/klw|, the poet may have meant pro/swqen to go with maqo/ntes, which certainly suits the sense better than to take it with stei/xonta. The order of words, though somewhat awkward, is not bolder than that in Ant. 944 f. e)/tla kai\ *dana/as ou)ra/nion fw=s | a)lla/cai de/mas e)n xalkode/tois au)lai=s. Cp. also El. 1349 f., Ph. 598, Ph. 1163.
h)/rasson, as in Ph. 374xolwqei\s eu)qu\s h)/rasson kakoi=s | toi=s pa=sin. Cp. 1244: Aesch. Theb. 382qei/nei d' o)nei/dei ma/ntin. Nub. 1373 eu)qu\s e)cara/ttw | polloi=s kakoi=s ka)|sxroi=si.
e)/nqen ka)/nqen: cp. Verg. Aen. 4. 447adsiduis hinc atque hinc vocibus heros | Tunditur.
ou)/tis e)/sq' o(\s ou)/: cp. O.T. 372 a(\ soi\ | ou)dei\s o(\s ou)xi\ tw=nd' o)neidiei= ta/xa.

to
 tou= mane/ntos k.t.l.: the art. to
 marks a quotation of the phrase which they used: ‘calling him “that kinsman of the maniac,”’ etc. Cp. Xen. Anab. 6. 6. 7e)pixeirou=si ba/llein to
 *de/cippon, a)nakalou=ntes to
 prodo/thn.

ka)pibouleutou= stratou=. The MSS. agree in stratou=, which is correct; as one could say a)ntagwnisth/s tinos. The dat. stratw=| would also be tenable (cp. Tr. 668tw=n sw=n *(hraklei= dwrhma/twn n.), and is strongly recommended by euphony. But euphony is not a sure guide in such cases (cp. Ph. 1354 n.).

a)pokalou=ntes, in a bad sense, as usu.: Dem. or. 19 § 305 a)la/stora to\n *fi/lippon a)pokalw=n. The good sense is rare in Attic of this age; De re equestri 10. 17 to\n i(/ppon toiou=ton a)pokalou=sin e)leuqe/rion: but may have been less rare later (cp. Eth. N. 2. 9: Plut. Mor. 776E).

w(s ou)k a)rke/soi to\ mh\ ou) … qanei=n: that he should not avail to save himself from dying: schol. w(s ou)k a)rke/soi e(autw=| to\ mh\ liqo/leustos gene/sqai. Cp. Aesch. P. V. 918ou)de\n ga\r au)tw=| tau=t' e)parke/sei to\ mh\ ou) | pesei=n a)ti/mws. For the fut. optat., cp. 313.

katacanqei\s, carded (like wool), torn to shreds; Eur. imitates this (Suppl. 503) pe/trois katacanqe/ntes o)ste/wn r(afa/s. Cp. Ar. Ach. 319ti/ feido/mesqa tw=n li/qwn, w)= dhmo/tai, | mh\ ou) katacai/nein to\n a)/ndra tou=ton ei)s foiniki/da;

w(/st) (‘and so’) has been suspected on account of the second w(/ste: but the latter, going with tosou=ton, does not offend the ear, since its sense is different and subordinate; cp. Ant. 735o(ra=|s to/d' w(s ei)/rhkas w(s a)/gan ne/os; Tr. 1241ta/x), w(s e)/oikas, w(s nosei=s fra/seis. So in Xen. Anab. 2. 2. 17kraugh\n.. e)poi/oun,..w(/ste kai\ tou\s polemi/ous a)kou/ein: w(/ste oi( me\n e)gguta/tw..e)/fugon: where the first w(/ste=‘so that,’ while the second =‘and so.’

kolew=n … ci/fh. The swords dieperaiw/qh kolew=n, were drawn through (and out of) the scabbards, e)rusta/, by a sharp, quick pull,—i.e. with angry haste.—Not, ‘swords plucked from the sheaths were crossed’: as if Teucer actually crossed swords with one or more of his assailants. The whole scene has been suggested by that in the first book of the Iliad, as the schol. in L saw:—e)k th=s *)axille/ws de\ pro\s *)agame/mnona a)rxh=s (read o)rgh=s) parage/graptai. There, Achilles was drawing his sword—e(/lketo d' e)k koleoi=o me/ga ci/fos—when Athena came to him ( I. Il. 194): a)/y d' e)s kouleo
 w)=se me/ga ci/fos (ib. 220).—Some of the later MSS. here have koulew=n, which was a current form in late Greek (Eustathius p. 1604. 58 to\ koleo
 koino/teron kouleo
 le/getai).
dramou=sa tou= proswta/tw: for the partitive gen., cp. Xen. Anab. 1. 3. 1ou)k e)/fasan i)e/nai tou= pro/sw: Ar. Ran. 174u(pa/geq' u(mei=s th=s o(dou=.

e)n cunallagh=| lo/gou … gero/ntwn, by means of the conciliatory words of elders: for the double gen., cp. 308 f.: for e)n, denoting the instrument, Ph. 60e)n litai=s stei/lantes, ib. 1393 e)n lo/gois | pei/sein.
h(mi\n, ethic dat.: O. C. 81h)= be/bhken h(mi\n o( ce/nos;

toi=s kuri/ois, i.e., Ajax himself, who is the ku/rios or ‘principal person’ in this matter, as being most nearly concerned in it. For the poet. plur., cp. Aesch. Ch. 688(Orestes to Clytaemnestra) ei) de\ tugxa/nw | toi=s kuri/oisi kai\ prosh/kousin le/gwn | ou)k oi)=da.

ne/as boula\s, his new ‘counsels,’ in respect of his supposed resolve to propitiate gods and men; ne/oisin … tro/pois, the new ‘dispositions,’ the character of greater gentleness and docility, which the resolve implies. e)gkatazeu/cas: he has ‘harnessed’ the new resolve, as it were, to the new character,—brought it under the yoke of his chastened will. The word conveys more than the idea of ‘adapting’ (Pindar's e(/rgmasin nikafo/rois e)gkw/mion zeu=cai me/los, N. 1. 7). It further implies self-conquest.
i)ou\ i)ou/, a cry of despair. In O. T. 1071, O. T. 1182, Tr. 1143, and Ph. 38, i)ou\ i)ou/ stands within the trimeter.

bradei=an, predicate. ‘Either Teucer was too late in sending me, or I have been too long upon the road,’—though he had come, of course, with all speed. h(ma=s … pe/mpwn o(do/n: for the cogn. acc., cp. El. 1163pemfqei\s keleu/qous. With pe/mpw, the second acc. usu. denotes the place to which ( O. T. 761a)grou/s sfe pe/myai).— )fa/nhn: cp. 308 )qw/u+cen: 557 )tra/fhs.
xrei/as th=sd), ‘this urgent matter’ (as they infer it to be from the speaker's distress). So xrei/a sometimes=‘a request’: O. T. 1435kai\ tou= me xrei/as w)=de liparei=s tuxei=n;

u(pespanisme/non, ‘scanted,’ i.e., ‘imperfectly done.’ With Aesch. this partic. means ‘scanted of’ a thing, ‘insufficiently provided’ with it: e.g. bora=s ( Aesch. Pers. 490), fo/nou ( Aesch. Ch. 577). Cp. Shakesp. Othello 1. 3. 267 You think | I will your serious and great business scant (i.e. ‘neglect’).

a)phu/da: cp. O. T. 236a)paudw=.. | mh/t' ei)sde/xesqai k.t.l.: Xen. Cyr. 1. 4. 14a)phgo/reue mhde/na ba/llein.— parh/kein. When verbs of motion compounded with para/ mean to ‘go forward,’ that sense comes through the notion of going into the presence of others (para/ tina): so oi( pario/ntes are those who come forward to address the ecclesia. Teucer was anxious that Ajax should not go forth into public (e)/cw parh/kein). In Soph. O. T. 1241, Soph. Tr. 900, and Soph. El. 1337, as often elsewhere, parelqei=n is said of entering a house.

tu/xh| represents the ‘vivid construction,’ by which the subjunct. of the ‘direct discourse’ can be retained, though the principal verb is in a secondary tense: Thuc. 1. 45§ 3 proei=pon..mh\ naumaxei=n..h)\n mh\..ple/wsi (instead of ei) mh\ ple/oien). For pri/n and subjunct., without a)/n, cp. 965. tu/xoi would mark more clearly that he is merely repeating what Teucer said: but the weight of MS. authority is on the side of tu/xh|.
oi)/xetai, an unconsciously ominous word.

to\ ke/rdiston, i.e. the most advantageous course which he could possibly take. Cp. Ant. 1113de/doika ga\r mh\ tou\s kaqestw=tas no/mous | a)/riston h)=| sw/|zonta to\n bi/on telei=n. There is no more reason for desiring to\ ke/rdion here than a)/meinon there. For to\ ke/rdiston.. gnw/mhs, cp. Thuc. 1. 90§ 2 to\..boulo/menon kai\ u(/popton th=s gnw/mhs.
qeoi=sin … xo/lou: cp. 717 f.
eu)= fronw=n, ‘with intelligence’ (cp. 1252): not ‘with good will,’ as in Il. 1. 73(Calchas) e)u+\ frone/wn a)gorh/sato.

pa/rei, as a correction of pe/ri, is irresistibly commended by the answer, tosou=ton oi)=da. Moreover, the question, ‘what does Calchas know of this matter?’ is strange in reference to the inspired seer, o(\s h)/|dh ta/ t' e)o/nta ta/ t' e)sso/mena pro/ t' e)o/nta ( Il. 1. 70).

tosou=ton. Schol. a)nti\ me/xri tou/tou: meaning that the word goes not only with oi)=da, but also adverbially with parw
: ‘thus much I know, and thus far was I an eye-witness.’ Rather the clause kai\ parw
 e)tu/gxanon is independent of tosou=ton oi)=da, as an independent sentence is often subjoined to a relative clause: see on O. C. 424h(=s nu=n e)/xontai ka)panai/rontai do/ru. It is equiv. to a participial phrase giving the ground for oi)=da, such as au)to\s i)dw/n: cp. Ant. 1192parw
 e)rw=.

sune/drou kai\ tur. ku/klou,= ku/klou tw=n sunedreuo/ntwn basile/wn: cp. Il. 18. 503oi( de\ ge/rontes | ei(/at' e)pi\ cestoi=si li/qois i(erw=| e)ni\ ku/klw| (of judges). The Homeric boulh/ consists, not of all the chiefs, but of a select number, specially summoned: cp. Il. 10. 195*)argei/wn basilh=es, o(/soi keklh/ato boulh/n. In Il. 10. 108 ff. the number indicated is about nine.

750 Calchas is present at this council, as he is at that in the first book of the Iliad ( Il. 1. 69). He knew by inspiration that, if Ajax could be kept in his tent for that one day, all would be well. Leaving the circle of the chiefs, he went to Teucer, who was awaiting the result in the neighbourhood. They sat down apart (cp. 780). The messenger was near them, and heard what Calchas said to Teucer.
oi)=os *)atreidw=n di/xa: cp. 464 n.
filofro/nws: for the o_ before fr, cp. Ant. 1104tou\s kako/fronas: ib. 336 peribruxi/oisin (n.).
pantoi/a| te/xnh|: Her. 1. 112e)xrh/ize mhdemih=| te/xnh| e)kqei=nai/ min. Xen. Anab. 4. 5. 16e)dei=to au)tw=n pa/sh| te/xnh| kai\ mhxanh=| mh\ a)polei/pesqai.

ei)=rcai. The primitive sense of the root (verg) was to ‘press’: whence come both the meanings of this verb, ‘to shut out,’ and ‘to shut in.’ Acc. to Eustathius (p. 1387. 3) the Attic form was ei)/rgw as=kwlu/w (‘shut out’ or ‘hinder’), but ei(/rgw as=e)gklei/w. Curtius (Etym. § 142) thinks that this distinction was of comparatively late origin. Our MSS. consistently give ei(rkth/, ei(rgmo/s, ‘a prison.’ Andoc. or. 4 § 27 has ei(rgnu/wn (‘imprisoning’): Plat. Tim.p. 45 E kaqei/rgnusi (indeed, the forms from eirgnu are always aspirated). But in regard to the other forms the evidence of MSS. is often conflicting, and the practice of editors has varied. In Thuc. , Bekker always writers ei(/rgw: Classen and Stahl, always ei)/rgw, even (e.g.) in 8. 74 § 3 ei)/rcein and 4. 47 § 3 katei=rcan, where the ref. is to imprisonment; though in the latter place the MSS. seem to agree on kaqei=rcan. On the other hand in Eur. Bacch. 443 the best editions give ei)=rcai. Eur. Itmay be noted that Lobeck could find no instance of a)fei/rgein earlier than Aelian (Hist. An. 12. 21 a)feirgme/nh): as to a)/ferktos in Aesch. Ch. 446, he justifies it as meaning, ‘shut in (apart),’ not ‘shut off.’ Recent editors are generally agreed in writing ei)=rcai here, and ei)/rgein in 795. This is justifiable in any case, the sense being ‘to restrain,’ rather than definitely ‘to shut in.’
h)=mar tou)mfane\s to\ nu=n to/de: the cumulative phrase marks the seer's anxiety to impress the fact upon his hearer; it is like the precise fulness of 741 f., e)/ndoqen ste/ghs | mh\ )cw parh/kein.
u(po\ skhnai=si=skhnh=s u(/paulon (796).
mhd' a)fe/nt' e)a=n: not to release him (a)fe/nta), and leave him to himself.

e)kei=non, where we might have looked for the less emphatic au)to/n, since *ai)/anta has so lately preceded; an Attic idiom: cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 60 e)le/gcai *dioklei/dhn yeusa/menon, kai\ timwrh/sasqai e)kei=non.
pote/ has been suspected, but needlessly; it refers to mhd' a)fe/nt' e)a=n: if Ajax were let out, Teucer would nevermore see him alive.

th=|de qh(me/ra|. The fact that Aristophanes uses this crasis ( Av. 1071, Thesm. 76) proves that it was familiar to Athenian ears. There is no good reason for excluding it from Tragedy, when oi)/m) is allowed in tragic verse on the ground that Comedy proves it to have been common.

w(s e)/fh le/gwn, lit., as he said in the course of his statement, i.e., ‘as he went on to say.’ So Her. 3. 156(Zopyrus) ‘nu=n te,’ e)/fh le/gwn, ‘e)gw\ u(mi=n..h(/kw me/giston a)gaqo/n’ (‘he went on to say’— in continuation of his story. So too in Her. 5. 36.Cp. Dem. or. 18 § 51 kai\ nu=n ei)=pe/ pou le/gwn, ‘o( th\n *)aleca/ndrou ceni/an o)neidi/zwn e)moi/)’ (‘he has said in some discourse or other’).

ta\ ga\r perissa\ k.t.l. To judge the text aright here, we must remember that these are the words of the ma/ntis, who speaks as the prophet of the gods. perissa\ kano/nhta s<*>mata are mortals whose over-great strength and success have made them wax too proud, so that they no longer serve the gods with due piety. Such mortals are a)no/nhtoi,—their lives can yield no worthy fruit. Compare the words of warning addressed to Xerxes ( Her. 7. 10): o(ra=|s ta\ u(pere/xonta zw=|a w(s keraunoi= o( qeo\s ou)de\ e)a=| fanta/zesqai..file/ei ga\r o( qeo\s ta\ u(pere/xonta pa/nta kolou/ein. See also v. 1077, ka)/n tis sw=ma gennh/sh| me/ga k.t.l.: and Athena's phrase in 129, mhd' o)/gkon a)/rh| mhde/n).

It is not without reason, then, that the reading ka)no/nhta is supported by the general consensus of ancient testimony. ka)no/hta is adopted by several recent editors, because the folly of Ajax is elsewhere recognised (763 a)/nous, 766 a)fro/nws), whereas he could not, they think, be called a)no/nhtos. But that depends on the point of view. In the sight of the gods, the greatest warrior would be a)no/nhtos, if he ceased kat' a)/nqrwpon fronei=n. Observe, too, that the word sw/mata confirms a)no/nhta: the idea is that of greatness which, swollen beyond the human limit, has ceased to fulfil the proper function of mankind. Such sw/mata are a)no/nhta because perissa/.
o(/stis, referring to sw/mata: cp. El. 1505toi=s pa=sin di/khn, | o(/stis k.t.l. (n.).
fu/sin blastw\n: Tr. 1062qh=lus kou)k a)ndro\s fu/sin.

fronh=| has the authority of the first hand in L, though here there is little to choose between indic. and subjunct.: cp. O. T. 1231ai(\ fanw=s): O. C. 395o(\s ne/os pe/sh|: Eur. Ion 855dou=los o(/stis e)sqlo\s h)=|.
kei=nos d). All this, down to v. 779, is still what Calchas said, as v. 780 shows.
kalw=s le/gontos: gen. absol.

au)to
 e)nne/pei: Il. 12. 210dh\ to/te *pouluda/mas qrasu
 *(/ektora ei)=pe parasta/s: O. C. 991e(
 ga/r m' a)/meiyai mou=non: Ph. 1065mh/ m' a)ntifw/nei mhde/n.
su\n qew=|, with the help of the gods (generally): cp. 383 (n.).
o( mhde\n w)\n: he who is as nought,—a mere nonentity. Cp. 1231.

kai\ di/xa kei/nwn. In Il. 17. 629 ff. Ajax says that Zeus is manifestly on the side of the Trojans; and adds, a)ll' a)/get), au)toi/ per frazw/meqa mh=tin a)ri/sthn,—i.e., without his aid. But in these words there is no impiety—a trait foreign to the Ajax of the Iliad: see Introduction § 1.

e)pispa/sein kle/os. Hesych. 2, p. 168 e)pispa/sei: e)piteu/cetai. *sofoklh=s *)atrei= h)\ *mukh/nais (=*mukhnai/as: fr. 137). ‘Draw to,’ or ‘on,’ oneself: so here, ‘achieve.’ Cp. Aesch. Pers. 477toso/nde plh=qos phma/twn e)pe/spasen, which recalls Hom. Od. 18. 73e)pi/spaston kako
 e(/cei. Neophron fr. 3. 2 (Nauck, Trag. Gr. Fragm. p. 731) broxwto
 a)gxo/nhn e)pispa/sas de/rh| (where de/rh| should prob. begin the verse). The middle voice would seem fitter in all these places: cp. Apollod. 2. 1e)pispa=sqai th
 a)po\ tw=n qew=n o)rgh/n. This seems an instance in which metrical necessity accounts for the use of the active voice; as, conversely, a metrical motive so often induced the use of middle forms.

di/as *)aqa/nas. The genitive, if sound, is best taken as depending on a)ntifwnei= in the sense of a)nti/on le/gei, ‘says to her face.’ In Ph. 1065, however, this verb takes an acc. of the person, mh/ m' a)ntifw/nei mhde/n: and no verb of ‘accosting’ affords a parallel to such a constr. as a)ntifwnei=n tinos. Such phrases as those in Aesch. Pers. 694 f. a)nti/a le/cai | se/qen (‘in thy presence’), Hom. Od. 15. 377a)nti/a despoi/nhs fa/sqai, are not relevant. (In Hom. Il. 1. 230, o(/stis se/qen a)nti/on ei)/ph|, the sense is, ‘against thee.’)

Other explanations are the following. (1) The poet meant to add something to the effect of h)ti/mase th\n parai/nesin, but changed the form of the sentence. (2) *)aqa/nas, h(ni/ka..hu)da=to stands for a gen. absol., *)aqa/nas au)dwme/nhs. (3) The gen. depends on e)/pos in 773, ‘a saying about her,’ like mu=qos..fi/lwn ( Ant. 11).

The most attractive remedy is Mehlhorn's, di/an *)aqa/nan, so that the verb shall have the same constr. as in Ph. 1065.But, if this be right, how did the genitive arise? Possibly some annotator, who thought that after hu)da=t) in 772 the subject of a)ntifwnei= might be obscure, wrote *a*i*a*s in the margin, and this, mistaken for *d*i*a*s, led to *d*i*a*s *a*q*a*n*a*s supplanting *d*i*a*n *a*q*a*n*a*n in the text. The occurrence of the same words in 757 may have helped. [The Homeric fem. is di=a, di=an. But di/a_ occurs in Rhes. 226 *)/apollon, w)= di/a kefala/.]
If, on the other hand, di/as *)aqa/nas be genuine, then corruption may lurk in deu/teron: e.g. the poet may have written ei)=ta d' a)nti/on.

toi=s a)/lloisin *)argei/wn: a somewhat unusual phrase, instead of toi=s a)/llois *)argei/ois, or toi=s a)/llois tw=n *)argei/wn. The dat. with pe/las is rare, but cp. Pind. O. 7. 18*)asi/as..na=son pe/las | e)mbo/lw| nai/ontas: Suppl. 208 qe/loim' a)\n h)/dh soi\ pe/las qro/nous e)/xein. Aesch. fr. 102 a)mfwti/des toi toi=s e)nwti/ois pe/las.

kaq' h(ma=s, ‘over against’ the place in the line of battle where Ajax is stationed. Xen. Cyr. 7. 1§ 16 (with ref. to an army arrayed for battle) ta\ me\n kaq' h(ma=s e)/moige dokei=..kalw=s e)/xein: a)lla\ ta\ pla/gia (the flanks) lupei= me.

ou)/pot' e)krh/cei ma/xh. The only natural sense of these words is, ‘battle will never break forth.’ This may mean, ‘the enemy will never be able to break forth (like a torrent bursting through a barrier), and carry confusion into our ranks.’ Ajax will suffice to stem the <*>de.—The words could not mean, ‘the battle (on our side) will never break up.’ For the verb, cp. Meteor. 2. 8 (p. 366 b 32) e)krh/cas ei)s to\n u(pe\r gh=s to/pon fanerw=s w(/sper e)knefi/as e)ch=lqen o( kinh/sas a)/nemos.

toioi=sde/ toi: cp. El. 984toiau=ta/ toi nw\ pa=s tis e)cerei= brotw=n: fr. 25 toiau=ta/ toi/ soi..le/gw: Aesch. Ag. 903toioi=sde/ toi/ nin a)ciw= prosfqe/gmasin. With the toi=s of the MSS., toioi=sde would be predicative (‘such were the words by which..’). But toi suits the final comment.

a)stergh=, pass., ‘not to be desired,’ as in O. T. 228pei/setai ga\r a)/llo me\n | a)sterge\s ou)de/n (the only other place where it occurs). The mildness of the word gives it a peculiar force: cp. Tr. 745a)/zhlon..e)/rgon.
e)kth/sat' o)rgh/n: cp. El. 1003kaka\ | kthsw/meq): Tr. 793katakth/saito lumanth\n bi/ou: fr. 101. 3 eu)/kleian a)\n kth/saito ma=llon h)\ yo/gon.
ou) kat' a)/nqrwpon fronw=n: Ant. 768fronei/tw mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/ndr' i)w/n.
e)/sti=zh=|: cp. 783, Ph. 422.— au)tou= … swth/rioi: the dat. of the person is usual with swth/rios: but cp. Aesch. Ag. 1156ga/moi..o)le/qrioi fi/lwn: Her. 2. 74a)nqrw/pwn..dhlh/mones.

su
 qew=|, qualifying the augury: cp. Eur. Med. 915pollh
 e)/qhke su
 qeoi=s promhqi/an: Ar. Pl. 114cu
 qew=| d' ei)rh/setai. Soph. O. T. 145eu)tuxei=s | su
 tw=| qew=| fanou/meq) (=su
 *)apo/llwni).
o( d' … *teu=kros: cp. Ph. 371o( d' ei)=p' *)odusseu/s (n.).

eu)qu\s e)c e(/dras, immediately on rising from his seat beside Calchas (750 n.). No sooner had Calchas finished, than Teucer rose, and sent the messenger, who was close by,—sitting among the laoi/. (Cp. Il. 2. 96law=n i(zo/ntwn,—in the agora.) Some take eu)qu\s e)c e(/dras as= ‘immediately, from his seat,’—i.e., without rising (so that he would beckon or call the man to him): cp. Il. 19. 77au)to/qen e)c e(/drhs, ou)d' e)n me/ssoisin a)nasta/s: Od. 13. 56(e)/speisan) au)to/qen e)c e(dre/wn, ‘even there as they sat.’ But in those phrases au)to/qen helps to fix the sense: whereas e)k following eu)qu\s regularly denotes the point from which the further action sets out (eu)qu\s e)c a)rxh=s, eu)qu\s e)k ne/ou, etc.). Hence eu)qu\s e)c e(/dras ought to mean, ‘immediately after sitting.’— Other explanations of e)c e(/dras are: (1) ‘from where I (the messenger) sat.’ (2) ‘After the sitting of the council.’ But Teucer would not wait for that. (3) ‘Leaving the council’ (or strictly, its neighbourhood, since Calchas had come apart from it, Od. 750). This would imply that Teucer had been included in the cu/nedros ku/klos: but the tone used towards him by Menelaüs (1120 o( toco/ths) and Agamemnon (1235 dou/lwn) makes this very unlikely.

Teucer sends a messenger, instead of going himself, probably because he hopes that his mediation with the chiefs may do some good. What he dreads is simply that Ajax should leave the tent; and a message could prevent that. He has no cause to suspect that Ajax meditates suicide.
e)pistola\s: Tr. 493 n.

fula/ssein, (these mandates) for you to observe; cp. Suppl. 179 ai)nw= fula/cai ta)/m' e)/ph deltoume/nas: and for the epexegetic inf., O. C. 231po/non.. a)ntidi/dwsin e)/xein.—fula/ssein should not be taken as governing *ai)/anta understood.

a)pesterh/meqa: ‘deprived’ (of the power to obey the command); hence, ‘frustrated.’ Cp. O. T. 769 ff., where Iocasta says, a)ci/a de/ pou maqei=n | ka)gw\ k.t.l., and Oed. replies, kou) mh\ sterhqh=|s (sc. tou= maqei=n). Eur. Andr. 913ka)/kteinas, h)/ tis sumfora/ s' a)fei/leto; (i.e., to\ ktei=nai,— ‘prevented’ or ‘baffled’ thee).—Wakefield's a)fusterh/meqa is a perf. pass. which nowhere occurs: a better conjecture is Badham's ei) d' a)/r' u(sterh/samen: but the text appears sound.

dai+/a, pass., ‘afflicted’ (dai/w, to burn), as in Aesch. Pers. 280, etc. For the act. sense, ‘hostile,’ which is more frequent, see above, Aesch. Pers. 365.The epic form dh/i+os (which never means ‘wretched’) is foreign to Tragedy, which, however, admits a)dh|os ( Soph. O. C. 1533) and dh|ou=n (ib. 1319).
ge/nos, ‘being,’ ‘creature,’ an epic use: Il. 9. 538(Artemis) h( de\ xolwsa- me/nh di=on ge/nos i)oxe/aira: ib. 6. 180 (the Chimaera) h( d' a)/r' e)/hn qei=on ge/nos ou)d' a)nqrw/pwn.
qroei=: 67 n.

curei= … e)n xrw=|. The metaphor from close shaving ( Her. 4. 175kei/rontes e)n xroi+/) means that the moment is critical: paroimi/a e)pi\ tw=n e)pikindu/nwn pragma/twn. The razor grazes the surface of the flesh. Itwould convey a different notion if we said, ‘the knife cuts to the quick.’ (The Lat. tondere ad vivam cutem is used of ‘fleecing’ a person in Plaut. Bacch. 2. 3. 8.) Thus the different image in Ant. 996, e)pi\ curou= tu/xhs, is yet kindred in purport. For e)n xrw=|, cp. Lucian Adv. Indoct. 3 th=s e)n xrw=| pro\s ta\ bibli/a sunousi/as.—The dat. xrw=| occurs only in this phrase. Sophocles has xrwti/ in Ant. 246, Tr. 767, and the Ion. xroi+/ in Tr. 605.Cp. ge/lw| ( Od. 18. 100), e)/rw| (ib. 212), i(drw=| ( Il. 17. 385), fw=| (‘light,’ Eur. fr. 534).
mh\ xai/rein tina/: inf. of result, without w(/ste: 822: Ant. 63a)rxo/mesq' e)k kreisso/nwn, | kai\ tau=t' a)kou/ein k.t.l. (n.).
787 f. Tecmessa, who, at the desire of Ajax (684), had withdrawn into the tent (692), now re-enters, with Eurysaces (cp. 809).
a)tru/twn: Pind. P. 4. 178a)/truton po/non: Moschus 4. 69 a)tru/t <*>tin | a)/lgesi moxqi/zousan.

pra=cin, ‘fortune,’ ‘plight,’ the usual sense of the sing. in Sophocles ( O. C. 560 n.). The word is somewhat strange, since the message announces nothing new which has befallen Ajax, but merely points to an imminent crisis in his fate. This is the true recommendation of the conjecture ba/cin,—not the fact that pra=cin recurs in 792. But fe/rwn … pra=cin may be a reminiscence of Pers. 248(a play of which there are several echoes in the Ajax): kai\ fe/rei (‘announces’) safe/s ti pra=gos e)sqlo\n h)\ kako\n klu/ein.— h)/lghs): for the aor. cp. 693 n.

a)/nqrwpe: cp. 1154. These seem to be the only examples of this voc. in Tragedy, as Elmsley observed. If we add w)=, w)/nqrwpe is the correct form (by the rule that, in crasis, the accent of the second word is kept: cp. w)gaqe/). But the absence of w)= makes the voc. a little less familiar and colloquial. In 1154, on the other hand, w)/nqrwpe is suitable.— o)lw/lamen: like Deianeira's sesw/smeqa ( Tr. 83).

*ai)/antos is governed by pe/ri; but, coming immediately after pra=cin, it would necessarily strike the ear as if opposed to th\n sh/n: ‘I do not know thy plight, but (I do know) that of Ajax,— viz., that, if he is abroad, I fear for him.’ It would not be well, however, to omit the comma after pra=cin, and so bind it strictly to *ai)/antos. That slight pause helps to prepare the ear for the coming construction with pe/ri.
kai\ mh\n in assent: cp. El. 556kai\ mh\n e)fi/hm). The conjectural insertion of g) after qurai=os is plausible (cp. 531 n.), but needless.
w)di/nein ti/ fh/s: Eur. Heracl. 644pa/lai ga\r w)di/nousa tw=n a)figme/nwn | yuxh\n e)th/kou no/stos ei) genh/setai.
ei)/rgein: 753 n.
e)cefi/etai: the only instance of this compound, except I. T. 1468, where e)cefi/emai has a like sense. But e)cafie/nai ( Tr. 72) was current in prose. Cp. the unique e)capei/domen in O. C. 1648.
skhnh=s u(/paulon: El. 1386dwma/twn u(po/stegoi (n.).

ka)pi\ tw=|: ‘by reason of what?’ Here e)pi/ with dat. denotes cause or occasion (rather than aim, ‘with a view to what?’). Cp. El. 333a)lgw= )pi\ toi=s parou=sin (and ib. 1230): Ph. 174<*>lu/ei d) e)pi\ panti/ tw| | xrei/as i(stame/nw|.

th/nde d' e)/codon … fe/rein. There is strong reason to think that fe/rein is genuine, and has the sense of ‘tending towards.’ For (1) Sophocles has thus used fe/rw in O. T. 517ei)s bla/bhn fe/ron: ib. 519 f. ou) ga\r ei)s a(plou=n | h( zhmi/a moi tou= lo/gou tou/tou fe/rei: ib. 991 e)s fo/bon fe/ron. Cp. Her. 1. 10e)s ai)sxu/nhn fe/rei. (2) This sense precisely suits the context here, where the apprehension is vague; Calchas had not said how the e)/codos was to be fatal, but merely that it was to be prevented, on pain of never again seeing Ajax alive. But o)leqri/an..fe/rein could not mean, ‘is of fatal tendency.’ Such a fusion of o)leqri/an ei)=nai with fe/rein ei)s o)/leqron is impossible.

Nor can we render: ‘He (Teucer) forebodes that this going-forth, which he announces, will be fatal to Ajax.’ fe/rein could be said only of the messenger— not of the man who sends him. Paley's conjecture, e)lpi/zw fe/rein, meets the point as to fe/rein, but the change to the first person is too harsh. Bothe's e)lpi/zein fe/rei (‘Teucer announces that he forebodes,’ etc.) strains both verbs. Enger's e)lpi/zei kurei=n is somewhat tame, and does not seem very probable.

Could o)leqri/an *ai)/antos have come from *ai)/antos ei)s o)/leqron? Easily, doubtless, if ei)s had been lost after -os. I incline to this solution. *ai)/antos ei)s o)/leqron is not only intrinsically better, but also slightly more probable, than o)/leqron ei)s *ai)/antos (the reading of Blaydes in his text), since then ei)s follows -on, and its unusual position would also tend to prevent its being overlooked. But the place of ei)s after its case is no objection, since *ai)/antos is an attributive gen. : see O. T. 178 n.

tou= *qestorei/ou ma/ntews: Il. 1. 69*ka/lxas *qestori/dhs, oi)wnopo/lwn o)/x) a)/ristos. Cp. above, Il. 134, *telamw/nie pai=: and n. on O. T. 267.According to one legend, Thestor was the son of Idmon (i)/dmwn), the seer who accompanied the Argonauts, and whose father was Apollo (schol. Apoll. Rhod. 1. 139). The name *qe/s-twr is from the root qes, ‘desire,’ ‘pray,’ whence qessa/menos (=ai)thsa/menos, Archil. fr. 11, etc.), polu/qestos ‘much besought’ (Curt. Etym. vol. II. p. 137): meaning, ‘one who prays to the gods.’ *ka/lxas is prob. from kalxai/nw, one who ‘darkly broods’ on futurity ( Ant. 20 n.).

o(/t' au)tw=| … fe/rei. The traditional o(/t) (o(/te) seems right. Tecmessa has already heard that the e)/codos is perilous. The new fact which she is now to learn is that ‘this day’ must decide the fate of Ajax. If, however, o(/t) be changed to o(\s, then this new fact will not be told, unless the words kaq' h(me/ran th\n nu=n be taken with what follows (o(\s..fe/rei). But they go more naturally with what precedes them (tou=..ma/ntews, sc. maqw/n).

If fe/rei be sound, the subject to it is h( e)/codos (798). There is nothing harsh in this, since the e)/codos is the matter uppermost in the minds of the speakers. fe/rei … qa/naton h)\ bi/on then means, ‘is fraught with death or life’: cp. Ph. 109ei) to\ swqh=nai/ ge to\ yeu=dos fe/rei: El. 84tau=ta ga\r fe/rei | ni/khn: ib. 1042 xh( di/kh bla/bhn fe/rei. The subject to fe/rei is certainly not h(me/ra h( nu=n. If Calchas were subject to fe/rei, the verb would mean a)gge/llei: but, for this sense, the subject must be the a)/ggelos himself, not the sender. There is no parallel for fe/rei as=merely ‘portends.’

It is possible that *f*e*r*e*i came, under the influence of *f*e*r*e*i*n in 799, from *q*r*o*e*i (the subject being Calchas): but we should not be warranted in altering the text. Wecklein and Blaydes, reading qroei=, compare O. C. 1425(ta\ tou=de) manteu/maq), o(\s sfw=|n qa/naton e)c a)mfoi=n qroei=.
oi)\ )gw/: rare in Tragedy: in El. 674, El. 1115ta/laina is added: but cp. Soph. Ph. 1274oi)\ )gw/, ti/ le/ceis;

pro/stht), place yourselves (as it were) in front of it, i.e., ‘interpose between it and me,’ ‘defend me from it.’ Cp. Her. 9. 107oi( dorufo/roi oi( *masiste/w proe/sthsan (sc. au)tou=). For the usage of prosth=nai, see on El. 980.

a)nagkai/as tu/xhs, the fortune impending over Tecmessa from that a)na/gkh, or destiny, which Calchas has expounded. Cp. 485.—Not, ‘avert the fatal chance’ which threatens Ajax (as if they were to place themselves between him and the tu/xh).
oi( me\n, the messenger, and the pro/spoloi of Ajax, who are to hasten to the camp: oi( de\ … oi( de/, the two divisions of the Chorus, who are to search the coast.
*teu=kron molei=n, depending on speu/sate: cp. Her. 1. 74e)/speusan... ei)rh/nhn e(wutoi=si gene/sqai.

e(spe/rous … a)nthli/ous. So in Eur. Or. 1258 ff. the Chorus is divided into two h(mixo/ria, which, by Electra's direction, guard respectively the east and the west side of the palace at Mycenae:—*h*m. xwrei=t), e)peigw/mesq): e)gw\ me
 ou)=n tri/bon | to/nd' e)kfula/cw, to
 pro\s h(li/ou bola/s. | *h*m. kai\ me
 e)gw\ to/nd), o(\s pro\s e(spe/ran fe/rei. There, the ‘eastward path’ is the pa/rodos on the spectator's left; the ‘westward,’ that on his right. In the Orestes, however, the hemichoria do not leave the orchestra. The Ionic form a)nth/lios was used in Tragedy: so a)phliw/ths, even in Attic prose. a)nqh/lios occurs first in the comic poet Theopompus (circ. 390 B.C.).

a)gkw=nas, the bends or bays of the coast, as in Her. 2. 99a)gkw/n is a bend of the Nile. The acc. depends on i)o/ntes ( O. T. 637ou)k ei)= su/ t' oi)/kous).— zhtei=t), a new finite verb, instead of an inf. zhtei=n, parallel with molei=n. This is a tendency of Greek idiom: cp. Ph. 216(boa=|), O. C. 351(h(gei=tai), Tr. 267(fwnei=), ib. 677 (fqi/nei).

fwto\s h)pathme/nh, deceived by him: schol. katafronh/sas h)pa/thse/ me. Cp. Eur. Or. 497plhgei\s qugatro/s. Others understand, ‘deceived concerning (or in) him’: but the genitive will hardly yield that sense.—She refers esp. to his words in 684—692.
xa/ritos: cp. 212 (ste/rcas a)ne/xei), and her words in 520 ff.— e)kbeblhme/nh: for the assonance (after h)pathme/nh) with the end of the last v., cp. 1085 f.: Ph. 121 f.: Tr. 1265 f.
ti/ dra/sw, te/knon; She shrinks from leaving the child, but decides that she must, and leaves him at the tent (cp. 985), where she rejoins him after v. 973.

o(/poiper a)\n sqe/nw. These words, implying that she has no strenght to go far, are significant, because she is to find the body of Ajax near the tent (891), while the Chorus have been vainly seeking him further off.
e)gkonw=men: cp. 988: Tr. 1255(n.).

ou)x e(/dras a)kmh\: cp. El. 22e)/rgwn a)kmh/: Ph. 12a)kmh\ ga\r ou) makrw=n h(mi=n lo/gwn. Verse 812 seems genuine. The fear which had haunted Tecmessa from the moment when Ajax regained his sanity (326), and which his words had lulled, has been revived by the message of Calchas. The definite expression of that fear, by speu/dh| qanei=n, is a fitting close to this scene, and prepares for the next.

As to the diction of the verse, three points claim notice. (1) The ge after a)/ndra emphasises, not that word, but the whole clause, a)/ndra o(\s speu/dh| qanei=n. Cp. Ant. 213 f., Ant. 648 f.: El. 1506: O. C. 1278.It contrasts e(/dras with his spoudh/. (2) speu/dh| is the original reading to which L's points (cr. n.). It generalises the statement. (3) qe/lontas, which was written by the first hand in L, is in its turn supported by speu/dh| as against qe/lontes: for, if the sentiment is general, it will depend on ou)x e(/dras a)kmh/ more fitly than on xwrw=men. In this case, the acc. qe/lontas depends on ou)x e(/dras a)kmh/ as=ou)x i(drute/on, a constr. quite possible for poetry: cp. El. 479 f. u(/pesti/ moi qra/sos..klu/ousan (n.).
e(/toimos, without the verb ei)mi/, as in O. T. 92: Eur. El. 796: Dem. or. 9 § 4: Polit. 277 E, and often.— e)/rgou, the usual antithesis to lo/gw|, is defined by podw=n.

Tecmessa now leaves the scene by the entrance on the spectator's left, leading to the open country. The Messenger, with the servants of Ajax, goes out on the spectator's right, as being bound for the Greek camp.

The Chorus leave the orchestra in two h(mixo/ria, one by the pa/rodos on the right, the other by that on the left. The withdrawal of the Chorus from the orchestra during the course of a play was called meta/stasis: their return, e)pipa/rodos. The other extant examples are:—(1) Aesch. Eum.: meta/stasis at v. 231: e)pipa/rodos at v. 299. (2) Eur. Alc.: m., Eur. Alc. 746: e)., Eur. Alc. 872.(3) Helen.: m., 385: e)., 515. (4) Ar. Eccl.: m., Ar. Eccl. 310: e)., Ar. Eccl. 478.

A change of scene is now supposed to take place, from the ground in front of the tent of Ajax to a lonely spot on the sea-shore, with trees or bushes (na/pos, 892). We do not know how this change was managed. (1) It may have been indicated merely by removing the hangings on the back-wall which represented the skhnh/ of Ajax. This is MA. üller's view (Gr. Bühnenalterthümer, p. 162). (2) Wecklein supposes that a back-wall, representing the skhnh/, was drawn back on right and left, disclosing the new scene.—We cannot assume the use of peri/aktoi in the poet's time (cp. note at the beginning of the play). Had they been in use, the peri/aktos on the spectator's left could have turned, so as to represent a new locality (to/pos). The right-hand peri/aktos, indicating the region in which the whole action takes place (xw/ra), would not have been changed.

The only other Greek play in which a change of scene is certain is the Eumenides, where the action begins at the temple of the Delphian Apollo, and passes at v. 235 to that of Athena Polias at Athens. This may have been marked merely by substituting a statue of Athena for one of Apollo.

815 Ajax is standing at the side of the scene on the spectator's right, near the underwood which screens him when he falls—so that his body is not at first visible to the Chorus when they return to the orchestra, but could be seen by Tecmessa, when she comes on the scene from the left. The point of the sword could probably be seen by the audience. Hesychius quotes Polemon, the sophist in Hadrian's age, as saying that the suspasto\n was used e)n *ai)/antos u(pokri/sei. It was a short stage-sword, of which the blade ran back; otherwise called a)ndro/mhton (Hesych., which some refer to a)nadramei=n), or a)ndromhro/n. Cp. Achilles Tatius 3. 20 o( si/dhros ei)/sw katadu/etai, tou/tw| d)...e)n toi=s qea/trois e)xrh=to pro\s ta\s kibdh/lous sfaga/s.

The antithesis to o( me
 sfageu\s k.t.l. is delayed: it is given by e)k de\ tw=nde in 823. Meanwhile, the reasons why the weapon should prove deadly have been developed in three clauses (dw=ron me
— pe/phge d)—e)/phca d)). Hence o( me
 sfageu\s k.t.l. is resumed in 823 by ou(/tw me
 eu)skeuou=men.
sfageu\s here is simply ‘the slayer.’ In Eur. Andr. 1134sfagh=s are sacrificial knives.
tomw/tatos: Plat. Tim.p. 61 E sfodro\n o)\n kai\ tomo/n.

ei)/ tw| kai\ logi/zesqai sxolh/: lit., ‘if one has leisure e)en to reason about it,’—when it is e)/rgou a)kmh/. He is not, indeed, hurried now: he has secured solitude. But in a man like Ajax, who has a deed to do, any words that delay it move a kind of scorn, which gleams through his phrase here: cp. 852 f.
dw=ron me\n k.t.l. The sword should do its work well, because (1) it is the gift of a foe, (2) it is fixed in hostile soil, and (3) Ajax has planted it with care.
a)ndro\s: cp. El. 45a)ndro\s *fanote/ws (n.).

ce/nwn, because the sword itself had been a ce/nion (661 n.). He means: ‘No one ever had such cause to rue the relationship of ceni/a as I in the case of Hector—a foe whom I had hated; for his gift has been my bane.’ See his words in 661—663. The point is missed if ce/nwn is taken as merely=barba/rwn.
polemi/a|: cp. 459: the soil itself is his enemy.
sidhrobrw=ti: the word occurs only here.
qhga/nh|=a)ko/nh|, Aeschylean ( Ag. 1536).
nehkonh/s, not neakonh/s, is now read here by all edd.: cp. nehkh/s (Hom. ), nehlifh/s (Arist. ).
peristei/las denotes merely the careful handling which he gave to it when fixing it in the ground.
qanei=n, ‘so that I should die’: its eu)/noia will appear in his speedy death. For the inf. of result, without w(/ste, cp. 786 n.
eu/sxeuou=men: ‘I am well equipped’: the preparations are complete. The verb occurs nowhere else; nor is eu)/skeuos found.
e)k de\ tw=nde, in the next place: cp. 537 n.
*zeu=. He invokes (1) Zeus, to apprise Teucer: (2) Hermes, to be his guide to the shades: (3) the Erinyes, to avenge him: (4) Helios, to give tidings at Salamis: (5) Thanatos, to bring the end.
kai\ ga\r ei)ko/s: since Zeus is the ancestor of the Aeacidae (387).

ai)th/somai: for the fut., cp. 681 n. The verb takes a double acc., and laxei=n (sc. au)to/) is epexegetic inf.: cp. O. T. 1255foita=| ga\r h(ma=s e)/gxos e)caitw=n porei=n (‘that we should give it’): Ant. 1098eu)bouli/as dei=..labei=n.
makro\n=me/ga (130 n.).
h(mi=n, ethic dat. (‘I pray thee’), with imperat. ( O. C. 1475).— a)/ggelon: the fulfilment of this prayer is related in vv. 998 f.
basta/sh|, take in the hands, ‘lift’ (920). Cp. Eur. Alc. 724basta/zwn nekro/n=e)kfe/rwn. Cp. Soph. Ant. 43nekro\n..koufiei=s.

peptw=ta peri\ ci/fei: cp. 899, 907: II. Od. 424a)poqnh/|skwn peri\ fasga/nw|: Il. 13. 570peri\ douri\ | h)/spair): ib. 8. 86 kulindo/menos peri\ xalkw=| (said of a wounded horse, ‘writhing about’ the barb of an arrow): ib. 23. 30 (bo/es) a)mfi\ sidh/rw| | sfazo/menoi. See on 899.
