pro/blhtos goes closely with the datives: Her. 9. 112tou\s mazou\s kusi\ proe/bale. Cp. Hor. Epod. 6. 10proiectum odoraris cibum.

e(/lwr, an epic word, once used (in the plur.) by Aesch. , Suppl. 800 kusi\n d' e)/peiq' e(/lwra ka)pixwri/ois | o)/rnisi dei=pnon ou)k a)nai/nomai\ pe/lein. Cp. Il. 1. 4au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin | oi)wnoi=si/ te pa=si.

Ajax forebodes that, as a public enemy, he will suffer the doom which Achilles assigns to Hector ( Il. 22. 354), Creon to Polyneices ( Ant. 205), and Electra to Aegisthus ( El. 1487). The Atreidae, in fact, so intended (1064 f.).

tosau=ta/ se … prostre/pw: the constr. is the same in O. C. 50(mh/ m' a)tima/sh|s) w(=n se prostre/pw fra/sai, where w(=n=tou/twn a(/, and the inf. is epexegetic. The midd. prostre/pomai is ordinarily used for this sense, as in fr. 760. 3: but the act. occurs also in Suppl. 1195, kakw=s o)le/sqai pro/strep' *)argei/wn xqo/na (‘pray that..’).
kalw= d) seems better than kalw= q), in turning to a new invocation.

832 The sense of pompai=on (=yuxopompo/n) is defined by xqo/nion, just as in O. C. 1548 the context defines a like epithet,—*(ermh=s o( pompo\s h(/ te nerte/ra qeo/s. See n. there, and on Ph. 133(*(ermh=s o( pe/mpwn).

a)sfada/stw|, ‘without convulsion.’ sfada/zw is from rt. sfad, denoting sudden, violent movement: whence sfedano/s, sfodro/s, sfendo/nh (a sling): Curt. Etym. § 296. The verb was often used with ref. to a convulsive death- struggle; Eur. fr. 1020 o( d' e)sfa/dazen, ou)k e)/xwn a)pallaga/s: Anton. 76 sfada/zontos (cp. dusqanatw=n ib.). Aesch. Ag. 1292e)peu/xomai de\ kairi/as plhgh=s tuxei=n, | w(s a)sfa/dastos, ai(ma/twn eu)qnhsi/mwn | a)porrue/ntwn, o)/mma sumba/lw to/de.

The precept to write sfada/|zw (and therefore, as Nauck does, a)sfa/da|stos) dates from Herodian (c. 160 A.D. ), but is not confirmed by any such independent evidence as exists in the case of mata/|zw ( Soph. O. T. 891). Ellendt writes sfada/|zw, yet a)sfa/dastos.

phdh/mati, the act of throwing himself upon the sword; Helen. 96 (of Ajax) oi)kei=on au)to\n w)/les' a(/lm' epi\ci/fos. This swift act, followed by no sfadasmo/s, is to be the means (cu\n) by which Hermes is to lay him to rest.

pleura\n diarrh/canta. Acc. to the legend followed by Aeschylus in his *qrh=|ssai (fr. 83), Ajax was invulnerable, except in one spot; when he sought to fall on his sword, it bent ‘like a bow,’— until a dai/mwn showed him the fatal place. See Introduction, § 4. The schol. here fancies that Sophocles used pleura\n with a purposed vagueness,—wishing neither to imitate nor to contradict his predecessor. Rather Sophocles, like the Iliad, ignores altogether the legend which Aeschylus used.

ta\s a)ei/ te parqe/nous: ‘the maidens who live for ever, and who ever behold,’ etc.: ta\s a)ei\=ta\s a)ei\ ou)/sas. For o( a)ei\ as=<*> a)ei\ w)/n, cp. O. C. 1700to\n a)ei\- kata\ | ga=s sko/ton ei(me/nos. For parqe/nous, O. C. 127ta=nd' a)maimaketa=n kora=n: Aesch. Eum. 791ko/rai dustuxei=s | *nukto/s: ib. 69 grai=ai, palaiai\ pai=des ai(=s ou) mi/gnutai | qew=n tis, ou)d' a)/nqrwpos, ou)de\ qh/r pote.—By his conjecture ta\s a)ei/ t' e)parge/mous, Meineke meant, ‘ever shrouded in the nether gloom.’

a)ei/ q' o(rw/sas. Here te is clearly better than de/ (the reading of L), as in El. 1098 f. o)rqa/ t' ei)shkou/samen, | o)rqw=s q' o(doiporou=men. For instances in which te can fitly be followed by de/, see Ant. 1096(n.), Tr. 143(n.).
o(rw/sas: O. C. 42ta\s pa/nq' o(rw/sas *eu)meni/das.
semna\s, an especially Athenian epithet of these goddesses: Eum. 1040i(/laoi de\ kai\ eu)qu/frones ga=| | deu=r' i)/te, *semnai/: cp. O. C. 89qew=n | semnw=n e(/dran.

tanu/podas: so elsewhere the Erinys is xalko/pous ( El. 491), kamyi/pous (‘fleet,’ Aesch. Theb. 791): cp. Soph. O. T. 418deino/pous a)ra/. Aesch. Eum. 371sfalera\ kai\ tanudro/mois | kw=la, du/sforon a)/tan.
ka/kista kai\ panwle/qrous: Aesch. Th. 552panw/leis pagka/kws t' o)loi/ato.
The last two of these four verses are certainly spurious, as three things show.

(1) The poet would not have made the dying Ajax pray that the Atreidae may die ‘at the hands of their offspring,’ unless there had been some legend that they so died. But, according to the current mythology, Agamemnon was slain by his wife and her paramour, while Menelaüs and Helen passed, without dying, to Elysium ( Od. 4. 561). It is only in later times that we meet with the story of Menelaüs and Helen having been sacrificed by Iphigeneia in the land of the Tauri (Ptolemy Heph. 4, cp. Roscher, Lex. p. 1951): a myth which the author of these verses may have had in view. Odysseus, indeed, was slain by Telegonus; but he does not come into account here, unless we make the improbable change of *)atreidw=n to *)axaiw=n in 838. [As to the double sense of au)tosfagh/s, with ref. to one who is slain (1) by himself, (2) by a kinsman, see on Ant. 56au)toktonou=nte.]
(2) These two verses confuse the construction, since w(/sper ei)sorw=s' e)me/ (sc. cunarpasqe/nta) refers to what precedes: while tw\s in 841 refers to w(/sper.
(3) The form fi/listos occurs nowhere else, except as a proper name.

tw/s is not elsewhere found in Soph. or Eur. : it is, however, used by Aesch. , not only in lyrics ( Aesch. Th. 484, Suppl. 69, 670, 691), but once, at least, in a trimeter, Th. 637h)\ zw=nt' a)timasth=ra tw\s a)ndrhla/thn. We should not, then, insist on tw/s as a mark of spuriousness: and o)loi/ato is, of course, free from objection ( O. T. 1274gnwsoi/ato n.). But the case against 841 f. seems conclusive without them.

A more difficult question is whether vv. 839, 840 are also spurious. The schol. in L on v. 841 is as follows:—tw\s au)tosfagei=s: tau=ta noqeu/esqai/ fasin u(poblhqe/nta pro\s safh/neian tw=n legome/nwn. As the lemma, tw\s au)tosfagei=s, clearly indicates, tau=ta refers only to the two verses 841 f., and not (as Dindorf and others have assumed) to all the four verses 839—842. The surmise was, says the scholiast, that vv. 841 f. were added ‘to make the meaning clearer’; i.e., to explain the elliptical phrase, w(/sper ei)sorw=s' e)me/. Such a surmise itself shows that vv. 839, 840 were believed to be older than 841 f. It is indeed plain that all four verses are not by the same author. The incoherent construction noticed above, under (2), was possible for an interpolator whose attention was fixed on w(/sper ei)sorw=s' e)me/, but hardly for one who was forging vv. 839—842 as a whole. If, then, all four verses are condemned, we must assume two independent interpolations.

I incline to think that the two verses 839 and 840 are genuine; because, otherwise, the imprecation on the pa/ndhmos strato/s (844) would follow too abruptly on v. 838. The prayer for the destruction of his chief foes, uttered in 839 f., leads up to the more sweeping denunciation of the Greek army.
i)/t), in urgent entreaty: O. C. 106(n.).
geu/esqe: Il. 20. 258geuso/meq' a)llh/lwn xalkh/resin e)gxei/h|sin.
pandh/mou stratou=: cp. Ant. 7pandh/mw| po/lei (n.). As to this curse, see Introduction, § 13.
ai)pu\n, lit. ‘steep,’ as the sun is said to ‘climb’ the sky towards the meridian.
ou)rano\n difrhlatw=n: Eur. Andr. 1011(Poseidon) i(/ppois difreu/wn a(/lion pe/lagos.
i)/dh|s: for the non-emphatic word thus placed, and followed by a pause, cp. 332 h(mi=n, n.

xruso/nwton h(ni/an. Cp. O. C. 693xrusa/nios *)afrodi/ta (n.). ‘Golden’ is similarly an Homeric epithet, not only of reins, but of shoes ( Il. 24. 340pe/dila..xru/seia), a belt ( Od. 11. 610xru/seos..telamw/n), and a girdle ( Od. 5. 231). Helbig (Das hom. Epos, p. 86) supposes that overlaying with gold-leaf is denoted in all these cases. Achilles Tatius (1. 14) refers to fala/rois a)rguroi=s, xrusai=s h(ni/ais, as parts of a luxurious equipment. The epithet in Anth. Pal. 7. 219, ou)ke/ti xrusoxa/linon o(ra=| dro/mon h)eli/oio, refers to the bit or bridle, not to the reins.
trofw=|=mhtri/, as one's ‘mothercountry’ is called simply th\n qre/yasan by In Leocr. § 47.
h(/sei … kwkuto\n: cp. 627 ai)/linon.. | h(/sei. Tr. 866h)xei= tis.. | kwkuto/n. Soph. Ph. 1350a)na/get' a)na/gete kwkuto/n.

e)n pa/sh| po/lei. This is Homeric: Sophocles is thinking of the lamentation for Hector, begun by Cassandra: Il. 24. 703kw/kuse/n t' a)/r' e)/peita ge/gwne/ te pa=n kata\ a)/stu: cp. ib. 776 (after Helen's lament) w(s e)/fato klai/ous): e)pi\ d' e)/stene dh=mos a)pei/rwn. There is more of Athenian feeling in the surmise concerning Eurydicè ( Ant. 1247), e)s po/lin go/ous | ou)k a)ciw/sein.
e)/rgon: 12 n.
a)ll' … a)ll). The second a)lla\ here merely opposes its own clause to that which the first a)lla\ introduces, as in El. 881a)ll' ou)x u(/brei | le/gw ta/d), a)ll' e)kei=non w(s paro/nta nw=|n.
*qa/nate. Ph. 797w)= *qa/nate *qa/nate, pw=s a)ei\ kalou/menos | ou(/tw kat' h)=mar ou) du/na| molei=n pote/; Aesch. fr. 255 w)= *qa/nate paia/n, mh/ m' a)tima/sh|s molei=n.

ka)kei==kai\ e)n *(/aidou ( Ant. 76, El. 356). In Hesiod Theog. 758 ff. Thanatos and Hypnos are the sons of Night, and dwell near Hades and Persephonè. A relief from Ephesus shows Thanatos, winged, and girt with his sword, in the nether world, at the moment when Hermes is about to bring Alcestis back to the sunlight. See Baumeister, Denkmäler p. 281 (pl. 281), and ib. 1730, where C. Robert's interpretation of the subject is given.
The absence of caesura gives a more deliberate weight to se\ me\n ka)kei=: cp. 994: Ph. 1369e)/a kakw=s au)tou\s a)po/llusqai kakou/s, and ib. 101: Ant. 44.
to\ nu=n se/las, i.e., ‘which I see now, but soon shall see no more.’ Cp. 753 kat' h)=mar tou)mfane\s to\ nu=n to/de.
difreuth\n (845): cp. Ant. 1065tro/xous a(millhth=ras h(li/ou, ‘courses of the sun's swift chariot.’ For kai\ to\n..*(/hlion (instead of kai\ se/, w)= *(/hlie), cp. 862 n.
panu/staton dh\: cp. 992 a(pa/ntwn dh/.
kou)/pot' … u(/steron: Ant. 808ne/aton..fe/ggos leu/ssousan a)eli/ou, | kou)/pot' au)=qis.

i(ero\n: an epithet given to cities in respect of their polissou=xoi or e)gxw/rioi qeoi/: cp. 1221. Ajax refers esp. to Zeus and the Aeacidae. Among the shrines of Salamis in the poet's day were those of Athena *skira/s ( Her. 8. 94), Enyalios (v. 179 n.), Artemis ( Paus. 1. 36. 1), and Ajax (ib. 35. 3).
patrw=|on instead of patrw/|as, since e(sti/as ba/qron is a single notion: see on kuno\s..eu)/rinos ba/sis (8). ba/qron: 135 n.

kleinai/: Pind. fr. 76 w)= tai\ liparai\ kai\ i)oste/fanoi kai\ a)oi/dimoi, | *(ella/dos e)/reisma, kleinai\ *)aqa=nai, daimo/nion ptoli/eqron. Soph. O. C. 108pasw=n *)aqh=nai timiwta/th po/lis: ib. 282 ta\s eu)dai/monas: Soph. El. 707tw=n qeodmh/twn.

kai\ to\ su/ntrofon ge/nos, following the voc., as in Ph. 986w)= *lhmni/a xqw\n kai\ to\ pagkrate\s se/las. With su/ntrofon we may understand h(mi=n rather than *)aqh/nais: the Athenians are kinsmen and associates of the Salaminians,—as the latter are genea=s xqoni/wn a)p' *)erexqeida=n (202). Cp. Ph. 171cu/ntrofon o)/mma, a companion's face. It seems improbable that su/ntrofon ge/nos alludes specially to the Attic fulh\ *ai)anti/s: that would unduly narrow the reference.

krh=nai/ te potamoi/ q' oi(/de: the Scamander (417), the Simois, the springs and fountains polupi/dakos *)/idhs. So Philoctetes, on leaving Lemnos ( Ph. 1461): nu=n d), w)= krh=nai *lu/kio/n te poto/n, | lei/pomen u(ma=s.

kai\ ta\ *tr. pedi/a prosaudw=: this clause follows the series of vocatives, and precedes their verb, as in the similar passage, Aesch. P. V. 88—92 w)= di=os ai)qh\r k.t.l... | kai\ to\n pano/pthn ku/klon *(hli/ou kalw=: | i)/desqe/ m' k.t.l.

trofh=s (cp. 189 basilh=s): the soil and the streams have sustained his life. Ar. Th. 299th=| *kourotro/fw| (i.e. th=| *gh=|), Aesch. Th. 477trofei=a plhrw/sei xqoni/. There was a custom that youths on coming of age should offer a ‘nurture-lock’ to rivers ( Aesch. Ch. 6plo/kamon *)ina/xw| qrepth/rion).
*ai)/as … qroei=, followed by muqh/somai: as to\n planh/thn *oi)di/poun ( O. C.e) is followed by e)moi/ (ib. 6). Cp. 427 pro/keimai after a)/ndra to/nde (n.).
Ajax falls upon his sword. (See n. on 815.)—The actor Timotheus of Zacynthus (says the scholiast) was celebrated in this scene: h)=ge tou\s qeata\s kai\ e)yuxagw/gei, w(s *sfage/a au)to\n klhqh=nai.

div2.p: e)pipa/rodos (see n. on 813 f.). The h(mixo/rion which has been searching ‘the westward bays’ now reenters the orchestra by the parodos on the spectator's right, and a moment or two later the other h(mixo/rion comes in at the opposite side.

The extant examples of hemichoria in Tragedy are not many. In Aesch. Theb. 1066 ff., after the collective lament of the Chorus for the house of Laïus, one semichorus expresses sympathy with Antigone, while the other elects to obey Creon. In Eur. Or. 1258 ff. the two hemichoria are supposed to guard the E. and W. sides of the palace. In E. Alc. 93—111, E. Alc. 226—232 the Chorus which bewails Alcestis is divided into two parts merely for the sake of the antiphonal dirge. Sophocles adopts a like arrangement in Soph. Tr. 863—870, where, as here, no actor is present.

div3.p: po/nos po/nw| po/non: cp. 1197, and n. on O. T. 175. Aesch. Pers. 1041do/sin kaka\n kakw=n kakoi=s. The dialogue in 866—878 is conducted by the two leaders of hemichoria. When Sophocles raised the number of the tragic Chorus from twelve to fifteen, his object was to provide a coryphaeus (distinct from the ordinary choreutae), and two subordinate leaders. The technical name for these leaders of hemichoria was parasta/tai, because they stood one on each side of the coryphaeus when the Chorus was drawn up in ranks (kata\ zuga/).

kou)dei\s … to/pos. The reading of the MSS. can mean only: ‘and no place is conscious that I have learned along with it,’ i.e., ‘have learned what it knows,’ ‘share its secret.’ The constr. e)pi/statai/ me summaqei=n (instead of summaqo/nta) is warranted by Ant. 1092 ff. e)pista/mesqa..au)to\n..lakei=n): see also ib. 293, El. 616.summaqei=n, as=‘to learn with one,’ may be defended by Plat. Symp. 3. 20e)me\ me\n paraka/lei, o(/tan me/llh|s manqa/nein.., i(/na soi..summanqa/nw. But, though this sense is possible for summaqei=n, the language of the verse, as it stands, is too elliptical and obscure. Clearly there has been some corruption. I suspect that it began under the influence of pa=| ga\r ou)k e)/ban e)gw/, with the change of an original sfe into me. *s*u*m*m*a*q*e*i*n may have been corrupted, to suit me, from *s*u*n*n*a*i*e*i*n. I would read, kou)dei\s e)pi/statai/ sfe sunnai/ein to/pos, ‘and no place is conscious of his presence.’ nai/ein can be said of temporary presence in a place: see Soph. O. C. 117, where the men of Colonus are searching for Oedipus:—o(/ra: ti/s a)/r' h)=n; pou= nai/ei; And so in Soph. Tr. 99po/qi moi.. | nai/ei refers to the wandering Heracles. See Appendix.
i)dou/, with ref. to sound: O. C. 1477, El. 1410.
h(mw=n..nao\s … o(mili/an=h(ma=s tou\s sunnau/tas: for the double gen., cp. 308 f.: for the periphrasis, El. 417ei)sidei=n patro\s | ...o(mili/an: Eur. Hipp. 1179o)pisqo/pous | fi/lwn..o(mh/guris.
koino/ploun: cp. El. 1104h(mw=n poqeinh\n koino/poun parousi/an.

ti/ ou)=n dh/; The hiatus is clearly genuine here (for the insertion of d) would be unfitting in this eager question); as also in Aesch. Theb. 704ti/ ou)=n e)/t' a)\n sai/noimen o)le/qrion mo/ron; See Appendix to , Soph. Ph. v. 100, p. 233.

e)sti/bhtai. stibe/w is not found elsewhere. The conjecture e)sti/beutai rests on the fact that stibeu/w occurs in later, though not in classical, Greek. But as Lycophron (121) used a)sti/bhtos, he either knew stibe/w, or thought it a possible form.

e)/xeis ou)=n; Euripides has a similar phrase in Suppl. 818 (Adrastus) e)/xeis e)/xeis (sc. ta\ te/kna)—*x*o. phma/twn g' a(/lis ba/ros. Cp. also Cycl. 683*x*o... e)/xeis; (‘hast thou caught them?’) *k*u. kako/n ge pro\s kakw=|. For a like coincidence, see 591 n.
kou)de\n ei)s o)/yin ple/on, lit., ‘and nothing more in respect to seeing,’ —i.e., to descrying the object of our search. For this sense of ei)s, cp. O. T. 706 n.
a)ll' ou)de\ me\n dh\, in rejecting an alternative: Tr. 1128, El. 913.

th
 a)f' h(li/ou bolw=n: so Eur. Or. 1258e)gw\ me
 ou)=n tri/bon | to/nd' e)kfula/cw, to
 pro\s h(li/ou bola/s. bolai/, like ictus ( C. 2. 15. 10),=a)kti=nes: cp. Eur. Bacch. 14h(lioblh/tous pla/kas.

dhloi==dh=lo/s e)sti: cp. 471 n. ‘He is not found to have appeared anywhere along the path from the east.’ The acc. ke/leuqon denotes the ground which the searchers have traversed: the phrase is a terse equivalent for ou)damou= dhloi= fanei\s toi=s th
..ke/leuqon e)lqou=sin. There is no real resemblance to El. 1273filta/tan | o(do
 e)paciw/sas w(=de/ moi fanh=nai, where o(do
 is cognate acc. to fanh=nai as implying e)lqei=n (cp. ib. 1318 e)ch/keis o(do/n).

div2.p: A kommo/s, in which the Chorus has both lyrics and trimeters; Tecmessa, trimeters only (except i)w/ moi/ moi, etc.). Verses 879—914 form a strophe,=antistr. 925—960. The lyric parts of strophe and antistrophe correspond thus: (1) 879—890=925—936: (2) 900—903=946—949: (3) 909—914= 954—960. The intervals between the lyrics are filled by dialogue between the Chorus and Tecmessa, mainly in trimeters: thus (1) 891—899=937—945: (2) 904—907=950—953.

At the close of the strophe, Tecmessa has ten trimeters (915—924); at the close of the antistrophe, thirteen (961—973): in the latter speech, however, some critics reject vv. 966—968, and so make it equal with the other. On this view, 879—924 =925—973.
For the lyric metres see Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: ti/s a)\n with the optat. (a)pu/oi, 887) expresses a wish, cp. El. 1103 n.— a(liada=n, sons of a(/lioi (sea-faring men, fishermen); poetical for a(lie/wn, like pai=des *(ellh/nwn ( Aesch. Pers. 402). The use of the patronymic in Greek poetry was a free one; thus Pindar can say a)fqi/tou *)ennosi/da (Poseidon, P. 4. 33), forming the word from e)/nosis. We might compare tektoni/dhs, which occurs as a proper name in Od. 8. 114.
e)/xwn … a)/gras: cp. 564 qh/ran e)/xwn (n.).

a)u+/pnous: the u is long here, as in O. C. 685(where a)/u+pnoi=a)hdw/n in 672), though short in Ph. 848: as in Ph. 827 the first *upne has u_, and the second u^. Hermann unnecessarily inserted a)mf) before a)u+/pnous (taking the u as short). The metre is dochmiac: cp. 926 n.

h)\ ti/s *)olumpia/dwn qea=n k.t.l. ‘Can any Oread of the Mysian Olympus, or any Naiad of the streams that flow into the Hellespont, tell us where he is?’ qea=n is understood again with potamw=n (*)olumpia/des qeai/, h)\ qeai\ potamw=n): for the adj. co-ordinated with a gen., cp. Pind. N. 8. 2parqenhi+/ois pai/dwn t' e)fi/zoisa glefa/rois: Eur. Med. 404toi=s *sisufei/ois toi=s t' *)ia/sonos ga/mois. As to the Mysian Olympus, see on 720.
r(utw=n, a general epithet of sea or river: Aesch. Ag. 1408r(uta=s e)c a(lo/s: Eur. Hipp. 123r(uta\n paga/n.

*bospori/wn, of the Hellespont; cp. Aesch. Pers. 723, kai\ to/d' e)ce/pracen, w(/ste *bo/sporon klh=|sai me/gan; with ref. to the bridges of boats made by order of Xerxes, h( ceu=cis tou= *(ellhspo/ntou ( Her. 7. 35).—The word i)/dris, added in L and most MSS. after potamw=n, was an early interpolation, caused by the elliptical construction. The schol. (on 879) read it, and explains potamw=n i)/dris by *nai+/s. But the antistr., Her. v. 930, pa/nnuxa kai\ fae/qont' a)neste/nazes, is clearly sound; though Elmsley suggested that a)/nac may have dropped out before a)neste/nazes.

ei)/ poqi … leu/sswn=leu/sswn, ei)/ poqi (=pou) leu/ssei: Ph. 1204ci/fos, ei)/ poqen, | h)\ ge/nun, h)\ bele/wn ti, prope/myate, i.e., ei)/ poqen prope/myai e)/xete (n.).—a)pu/oi, -u-: Ar. Eq. 1023e)gw\ me/n ei)m' o( ku/wn: pro\ sou= ga\r a)pu/w. (Moschus 2. 124 has h)pu/ontes with u_: elsewhere the pres. has u^: the fut. and aor. have u_.)
sxe/tlia, instead of sxe/tlion: so 1126 di/kaia: Ph. 524ai)sxra/: Eur. Or. 413deina/: Thuc. 5. 14§ 4 a)du/nata.

to\n makrw=n a)la/tan po/nwn. The similar phrase in Aesch. P. V. 900, a)latei/ais po/nwn, implies the constr. a)la=sqai po/nous (as cogn. acc.); and Sophocles may have had that in mind. But the gen. could also be explained as equiv. to an adj. polu/ponon: cp. Soph. Ant. 114leukh=s xio/nos pte/rugi (n.).— ou)ri/w| mh\ pela/sai dro/mw|, ‘cannot come near him (sc. tw=| *ai)/anti), with prospered course.’ Others take dro/mw| with pela/sai, ‘attain to, obtain, a prosperous course.’ (Cp. Pind. O. 1. 78kra/tei..pe/lason, ‘bring me to victory.’) Those who read ou)ri/wn..dro/mwn (cr. n.) explain it in the same way. But this is surely forced.

a)menhno\n, enfeebled in mind by the no/sos, distempered. Cp. Il. 5. 887h)/ ke zw\s a)menhno\s e)/a xalkoi=o tuph=|sin (‘feeble’),—the only instance of the word in the Iliad. In the phrases a)menhna\ ka/rhna ( Od. 10. 521, etc.), a)menhnw=n.. o)nei/rwn (ib. 19. 562), the notion is ‘unsubstantial.’ a)menhno/s is probably formed from me/nos. (Wecklein suggests that Sophocles here meant by it ‘unstable,’ ‘restless,’ as if it came from me/nw.)— o(/pou: sc. e)sti/: cp. 33.

i)w/ moi/ moi. Tecmessa,—who is not seen till v. 894,—is approaching the entrance on the spectator's left, when she descries the body of Ajax lying at the other side of the scene. The underwood amidst which he has fallen screens the sight from the Chorus, until they draw nearer. (Cp. 815 n.)

ti/nos boh\ k.t.l.: ‘whose cry came from the wood, in the covert near us?’ pa/raulos, having an au)lh/ near at hand; screened from view in the neighbouring covert: ti/nos pa/raulos boh/=ti/nos parau/lou boh/. Cp. O. C. 785a)ll' w(s pa/raulon oi)ki/sh|s (me), n.
i)w\ tlh/mwn, sc. e)gw/, not *ai)/as. Ph. 1102w)= tla/mwn tla/mwn a)/r' e)gw/.
douri/lhpton: for the Ionic form, cp. dou/reios ( Eur. Tro. 14), gou/nata ( Soph. O. C. 1607), mou=nos, cei=nos, etc.
oi)/ktw| … sugkekrame/nhn, steeped in the anguish which the lament expresses; Ant. 1311deilai/a| de\ sugke/kramai du/a| (n.).

w)/|xwka is now read in Aesch. Pers. 13, Soph. fr. 220: and in Il. 10. 252Leaf gives parw/|xwken (the reading of Aristarchus, acc. to Didymus), instead of parw/|xhken, as there is no good authority for w)/|xhka or oi)/xhka before Polybius. oi)/xwka, the traditional form here, is Ionic ( Her. 1. 189, etc.).
diapepo/rqhmai: cp. 1198 e)/persen: Tr. 1104e)kpepo/rqhmai.
ti/ d' e)/stin; O. T. 319 n.
h(mi=n, ethic: 216.
a)rti/ws neosfagh\s: the same phrase occurs in Tr. 1130.Cp. Ant. 1283(te/qnhke..) a)/rti neoto/moisi plh/gmasin.
krufai/w|: cp. 658 kru/yw.

fas- ga/nw| periptuxh/s, wrapped, as it were, round the sword; cp. Pind. N. 8. 23(fqo/nos) *telamw=nos da/yen ui(o/n, fasga/nw| a)mfikuli/sas. Verg. Aen. 10. 681An sese mucrone ob tantum dedecus amens | Induat.

w)/moi with gen.: 908, 980: Tr. 971.If the first thought of the Salaminians is, in Homeric phrase, w)/leto me/n moi no/stos ( Il. 9. 413), this is an indirect tribute to the chief on whom their welfare depended.

w)/moi, kate/pefnes, a)/nac … ta/las. The text is not certain here; but it seems most probable that v. 901 is sound, and that in the antistr., 947 f., a)/naud' | e)/rg) should replace a)/naudon | e)/rgon. The i)w\ or w)= which the MSS. place before ta/las in 902 may well have been an error.—Cp. Ant. 871qanw\n e)/t' ou)=san kath/nare/s me: and El. 808.

w)= talai/frwn gu/nai. We should expect either w)= talai=fron gu/nai, or w)\ talai/frwn gunh/, exclamatory, like El. 150i)w\ pantla/mwn *nio/ba. But the reading given above has the best MS. authority, and is tacitly accepted in several recent editions. I retain it, because the words, though addressed to Tecmessa, are in fact rather a comment upon her fate. Hence it is conceivable that the nom. of the adjective, usual in exclamations, should here be combined with a vocative of the person.
w(s w(=de tou=d' e)/xontos: cp. 281 n.: 981: Ant. 1179w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn ta)/lla bouleu/ein pa/ra.
ai)a/zein, with allusion to his name (430 f.): cp. 914 dusw/numos.

ti/nos pot' a)=r' e)/prace k.t.l. The antistrophic verse is 951, a)/gan u(perbriqe\s a)/xqos h)/nusan. I believe that the text is sound here, and that ga\r has dropped out before a)/xqos in 951. The case is parallel with that of vv. 369 and 384, in the latter of which a syllable was lost. The only tolerable emendation of e)/prace is e)/rce: and e)/prace is the fitter word, since, with its possible sense of ‘contrived,’ it suits the hypothesis that he may have procured death from another's hand; while e)/rce would, in that case, be somewhat forced. It may be added that the aorist of e)/rdw is never used by Sophocles in the indicative (though he has e)/rceien Tr. 935, e)/rcon ib. 1201, e)/rcas Ph. 117 etc.); and by Aeschylus only once, Th. 924e)rca/thn (lyr.): for in Ag. 1529h)=rcen is right, and e)/rcen only a conjecture. As to v. 951, the insertion of ga\r is not only admissible, but desirable.
au)to\s pro\s au(tou=. Cp. Ant. 1176*x*o. po/tera patrw/|as h)\ pro\s oi)kei/as xero/s; *a*g. au)to\s pro\s au(tou=.

e)n ga/r oi( xqoni/: the order of words is Ionic in style; cp. Her. 6. 69e)n ga/r se th=| nukti\ tau/th| a)naire/omai: id. 1. 108 e)k ga/r oi( th=s o)/yios..e)sh/mainon: Ph. 468pro/s nu/n se patro/s. Join oi( … phkto\n (dat. of agent: 539).
kathgorei=: Aesch. Ag. 271eu)= ga\r fronou=ntos o)/mma sou= kathgorei=.

peripete\s, in passive sense, ‘on which he has fallen’: a bold use, as Eustathius felt (p. 644. 47): *sofoklh=s e)/gxos peripete\s ei)pei=n e)to/lmhsen, w(=| peripe/ptwken *ai)/as. Lobeck quotes some phrases which, though not precisely similar, are analogous; as Aelian Hist. An. 15. 10 ta\ a)/gkistra..peripage/nta toi=s i)xqu/si, i.e., ‘on which the fish are caught,’ (peripare/nta Schneider): Chrysost. Opp. vol. III. p. 85 A e(autw=| to\ ci/fos perie/peire, made the sword a spit for his body, i.e. transfixed himself with his sword.
oi)=os, the reading of the MSS., is far better here than oi(=os.

a)/fraktos. Dindorf writes a)/farktos, as the older Attic form. Attic inscriptions attest fa/rcai (420 B.C.) and diafa/rcanti (409 B.C.): though diafra/cai occurs as early as 347 B.C.; Meisterhans, Gramm. Att. Inschr. § 43. No instance of a)/farktos is quoted from an Attic inscr., but a)/fraktos occurs c. 290 B.C., and often later. For the gen. fi/lwn, cp. 321: El. 36a)/skeuon..stratou=.
kwfo/s, in the general sense of ‘dull-witted’: schol. a)nai/sqhtos. pa/nta, adv., as O. C. 1458to\n pa/nt' a)/riston.

dustra/pelos, ‘intractable,’ not amenable to a guiding hand; cp. 609 dusqera/peutos: and see n. on 595. In Eth. Eud. 3. 7. 6 (p. 1234 a 5) the dustra/pelos is the ‘morose’ man, the opposite extreme to bwmolo/xos, while the eu)tra/pelos is the happy mean.
dusw/numos: cp. 430 f. The epithets show a natural sequence of thought; ‘intractable, and doomed to such a fate as his name foreshadowed.’

periptuxei= fa/rei, a cloak or mantle wrapped round him: for the adj., cp. 899. The fa/ros, we may suppose, has been brought by a pro/spolos from the tent hard by. The shrouded corpse, which remains partly visible (cp. 1172), is an effigy, like that of Haemon in the Antigone (1258, cp. p. xvii. n.), and of Clytaemnestra in the Electra (1466). The actor who played Ajax has now to play Teucer.
pamph/dhn is a poet. equiv. (used by Theognis and Aeschylus) for pa/mpan, formed from it with the adverbial suffix -dhn: pamph/-dhn, instead of pampa/n-dhn, by compensatory lengthening of a.

o(/stis kai\ fi/los, one at least who is a friend. kai\ emphasises fi/los: cp. Eur. H. F. 58(h( duspraci/a), h(=s mh/poq), o(/stis kai\ me/sws eu)/nous e)moi/, | tu/xoi. Eur. Ion 232pa/nta qea=sq), o(/ ti kai\ qe/mis, o)/mmasi.

fusw=nt' a)/nw pro\s r(i=nas: a reminiscence perh. of Od. 22. 18(Antinoüs dying of a wound in the throat), au)ti/ka d' au)lo\s a)na\ r(i=nas paxu\s h)=lqen | ai(/matos a)ndrome/oio: a thick jet of blood came up through his nostrils. The blood is forced up to the nostrils, and then issues from them. Cp. 1411.

melanqe\n, ‘darkened,’ can hardly be a simple equiv. for me/lan: Sophocles may possibly have thought—wrongly—that blood takes a darker colour from the action of air.— oi)kei/as sfagh=s: cp. 260 oi)kei=a pa/qh: Ant. 1176(ai(ma/ssetai) pro\s oi)kei/as xero/s.
basta/sei: see on 827. The deliber. subjunct. basta/sh|, which the schol. prefers, would be unsuitable here.

a)kmai=) a)\n … mo/loi seems the best correction of a)kmai=os … mo/loi. The phrase a)kmai=a molei=n is quite permissible in poetry: see the examples quoted on 196 f., and add Soph. Ph. 310mo/lis fanei\s | a)/elpta ka)do/khta matro\s w)le/nais.
a)kmai=os, ei) bai/h, mo/loi is impossible: mo/loi could not stand here for mo/loi a)/n: see on Ant. 605(kata/sxoi).

sugkaqarmo/sai: schol. peristei=lai. The double compound occurs only here, but Eur. has kaqarmo/zein in a similar context, Eur. El. 1227ka/lupte me/lea mate/ros | pe/plois, kaqa/rmoson sfaga/s (‘compose,’ ‘close,’ the wounds). Here the sense is, ‘compose,’ with ref. to the laying out of the dead; cp. Soph. Ant. 900qano/ntas au)to/xeir u(ma=s e)gw\ | e)/lousa ka)ko/smhsa: Soph. O. C. 1602 f. (n.): Ovid Met. 9. 502peream precor ante toroque | Mortua componar. The inf. sugkaqarmo/sai stands after a)kmai=) a)\n mo/loi as an inf. follows words of ‘fitness’ ( Plat. Symp. 173B o(do\s e)pithdei/a kai\ le/gein kai\ a)kou=sai).

oi(/ws e)/xeis. The adv. oi(/ws has been suspected, but there is no good reason for doubting that it was in use, though less frequent than oi(=on or oi(=a: it appears sound in Ar. Vesp. 1363, and in Apoll. Rh. 4. 786; though in Ph. 1007 we should read oi(=) au)= m' u(ph=lqes.—For oi(=os..oi(/ws, cp. 557.

w(s … a)/cios is best taken as a heightening of oi(/ws e)/xeis: ‘how worthy art thou,’ etc. This is easier than to supply w)/n with a)/cios (‘as being worthy’). The sense cannot be, ‘so as to be worthy,’ etc.; such an ellipse of ei)=nai is impossible.
par' e)xqroi=s, in their judgment; 620 n.
tuxei=n: El. 1469ka)p' e)mou= qrh/nwn tu/xh|.

e)/melles: cp. 1027: Ph. 1083w(/s s' ou)k e)/mellon a)/r), w)= ta/las, | lei/yein.— xro/nw|: because, for several days, he had been brooding over his wrongs (930 f.): cp. 193 makrai/wni | ...sxola=|. The words of Odysseus in 1336 f. also imply such an interval between the award of the arms and the death of Ajax.
stereo/frwn: as in Polit. p. 309 B to\ stereo\n h)=qos is said of ta\s e)pi\ th\n a)ndri/an ma=llon cunteinou/sas (fu/seis).

Erfurdt's insertion of w(=d) before e)canu/sein has been widely accepted: then e)c- (corresponding with the a^ of a)u+/pnous in 881) takes the place of a short syllable; a license possible in dochmiacs. But L's reading, stereo/frwn a)/r' e)canu/ssein kaka/n, gives an exact metrical correspondence, without any conjectural addition. No one could hesitate to prefer it, but for a doubt as to whether Tragic lyrics could admit the form e)canu/ssein. The doubled s occurs in Od. 16. 373a)nu/ssesqai (fut. midd.): Theog. 954 a)nu/ssas: Pind. P. 12. 11a)/nussen. Sophocles has o)le/ssas (390), and pe/lasson ( Soph. Ph. 1163). Hartung, G. Wolff, and Wecklein read e)canu/ssein: rightly, I believe. Observe that the close kinship of lyric with epic diction here is significantly marked by ou)li/w| in 933,—an epic and Pindaric word which is free from just suspicion, yet occurs nowhere else in Tragedy.
toi=a: 164 n.

pa/nnuxa kai\ fae/qont): schol. kata\ nu/kta kai\ h(me/ran. Cp. 217 nu/kteros (n.). The bold use of fae/qonta for h(merina/ or panhme/ria is interpreted and softened by the preceding pa/nnuxa. Doubt would be warrantable if fae/qont' a)neste/nazes stood alone.
w)mo/frwn, fierce: cp. 885 to\n w)mo/qumon.
e)xqodo/p), poet. for e)xqra/: Ph. 1137fw=t' e)xqodopo/n.

ou)li/w| su\n pa/qei, with deadly resentment. ou)li/w| refers primarily to his deadly hatred of the Atreidae, but suggests also the fatal result of his mood. For pa/qos with ref. to an affection of the mind, cp. Ph. 899a)ll' e)nqa/d' h)/dh tou=de tou= pa/qous kurw= (sc. th=s a)pori/as). With the exception of these two passages, there is perhaps no clear example of pa/qos so used before Plato. ( Thuc. 3. 84, where dia\ pa/qous e)piqumou=ntes occurs in § 1, is an interpolated chapter.)

It is indeed possible to render ou)li/w| su\n pa/qei, as Prof. Campbell does, ‘under thy calamitous wrong’ (the disappointment as to the arms). But ou)li/w| is clearly suggestive of a direct reference to w)mo/frwn e)xqodo/p' *)atrei/dais. Further, the prep. su\n more naturally denotes an accompaniment of the bitter utterance than the cause which had provoked it.

me/gas..h)=n … a)/rxwn, lit., was potent in beginning,=sfodrw=s h)=rxe: the use of me/gas being analogous to that of polu/s in such phrases as pollo\s h)=n lisso/menos ( Her. 9. 91). For a)/rxwn, cp. Tr. 871w(s a)/r' h(mi\n ou) smikrw=n kakw=n | h)=rcen to\ dw=ron: Thuc. 2. 12§ 3 h(/de h( h(me/ra toi=s *(/ellhsi mega/lwn kakw=n a)/rcei.
h)=mos, used even in trimeters, O. T. 1134, etc.
a)risto/xeir a)gw\n, like w)ku/pous a)gw/n ( El. 699), r(imfa/rmatoi a(/millai ( O. C. 1062).

o(/plwn. The defect of -uu- before this word is proved by the metre of the strophe, 890, a)ll' a)menhno\n a)/ndra mh\ leu/ssein o(/pou. Musgrave proposed xrusode/twn: cp. Il. 20. 268, referring to the arms of Achilles, xruso\s ga\r e)ru/kake, dw=ra qeoi=o. The last syll. of a)risto/xeir might facilitate the loss of a word beginning with xr. For other suggestions, see cr. n.
e)/keit). kei=mai is the classical pf. pass. of ti/qhmi (te/qeimai being used in a middle sense). Cp. 572 f. teu/xh.. | qh/sous' *)axaioi=s (n.).
h(=par: cp. Aesch. Eum. 135a)/lghson h(=par e)ndi/kois o)nei/desin.

gennai/a, true-hearted, loyal, like gennai=on e)/pos ( Ph. 1402), gennai=oi po/noi ( Eur. H. F. 357). The schol., wrongly, h( i)sxura/: a version at which he arrived perh. rather through the use of gennai=os as=‘fine,’ ‘good of its kind,’ than through the idea of ‘genuine,’ gnhsi/a.

kai\ di\s: cp. 432 kai\ di\s ai)a/zein. The aor. oi)mw=cai (referring to each act of utterance), as in El. 788oi)/moi ta/laina: nu=n ga\r oi)mw=cai pa/ra: and ib. 285 klau=sai. Cp. 982 stena/zein, of continued lament.

a)poblafqei=san … fi/lou: bereft of him: properly, arrested by a hand which separates her from him ( El. 696o(/tan de/ tis qew=n | bla/pth|, du/nait' a)
 ou)d' a)
 i)sxu/wn fugei=n). For the gen. (not found elsewhere with a)pobla/ptw), cp. Aesch. Ag. 120blabe/nta loisqi/wn dro/mwn: Tyrtaeus fr. 12. 39 ou)de/ tis au)to
 | bla/ptein ou)/t' ai)dou=s ou)/te di/khs e)qe/lei.

a)rti/ws. The schol. read a)rti/ou, which he explains by gnhsi/ou: and this reading was approved by Bergk in Rhein. Mus. (1847) p. 150, though in his text (1858) he kept a)rti/ws. Hartung gives a)rti/ou, explaining it of close, congenial friendship ( Ant. 570ou)x w(/s g' e)kei/nw| th=|de/ t' h)=n h(rmosme/na). But a)rti/ws, though somewhat tame, is clearly genuine.

dokei=n, to conjecture; fronei=n, to understand, to feel, by one's own experience: cp. O. C. 1741fronw=, ‘I know it well.’ As the Chorus had recognised Tecmessa's unique place in the affections of Ajax (211 f.), so by dokei=n she implies that they can at least form some estimate of her loss.
doulei/as zuga/: her old fear; 499.
oi(=oi might be a second exclamation; but seems better taken as causal (=e)pei\ toiou=toi). Cp. O. T. 701*kre/ontos, oi(=a/ moi bebouleukw\s e)/xei.

skopoi/, the despo/tai (500) who will be the overseers of her servile tasks (503, latrei/as). Cp. Suppl. 381 to\n u(yo/qen skopo\n e)pisko/pei, | fu/laka polupo/nwn | brotw=n: the watchful god, who punishes guilt.

w)/moi, a)nalgh/twn k.t.l.: ‘in this sorrow (tw=|d' a)/xei, lit., ‘by’ it, by the mention of it), thou hast named deeds of the Atreidae that are unutterable,—that make them ruthless’: i.e., if they should indeed enslave thee, their act would be infamous. a)nalgh/twn, as its emphatic place shows, has a predicative force. For a)/naud' | e)/rg', as a correction of a)/naudon | e)/rgon, see on 901.
a)/xei does not literally mean ‘lament,’ though it might be so rendered here, as in O. C. 1722lh/gete tou=d' a)/xous (where the literal sense is, ‘cease from this sorrowing’).

ou)k a)\n ta/d' e)/sth k.t.l. The last words of the Chorus, a)ll' a)pei/rgoi qeo/s, imply that the Atreidae may, after all, be capable of such cruelty, if the gods do not hinder them. Tecmessa replies that things could not have come to the present pass without the help of the gods; so that it is vain to rest hopes on them.
ta/d' … th=|de: Aesch. P. V. 511ou) tau=ta tau/th| *moi=ra/ pw telesfo/ros | kra=nai pe/prwtai.
e)/sth, have been brought to this state: cp. Ant. 1156ou)k e)/sq' o(poi=on sta/nt' a)\n a)nqrw/pou bi/on | ou)/t' ai)ne/saim) a)\n ou)/te memyai/mhn pote/ (n.).
mh\ qew=n me/ta, sc. sta/nta,=ei) mh\ meta\ qew=n th=|de e)/sth: cp. O. T. 1456ou) ga\r a)/n pote | qnh/|skwn e)sw/qhn, mh\ )pi/ tw| deinw=| kakw=|, sc. swqei/s.

a)/gan u(perbriqe\s k.t.l. The defect of a syllable in the MSS. here (see 905 n.) is best supplied by ga\r, which expresses assent: cp. Ph. 755*n*e. deino/n ge tou)pi/sagma tou= nosh/matos. | *f*i. deino\n ga\r ou)de\ r(hto/n. The addition of g) after a)/gan in some MSS. seems to have been prompted by a sense that some such link with the preceding verse was required.— a)/xqos, of sorrow, as Ph. 1168muri/on a)/xqos o(\ cunoikei=. — h)/nusan, effected, brought about, as Ph. 1145koina\n h)/nusen e)s fi/lous a)rwga/n. Not, ‘have made too heavy,’ like O. T. 166h)nu/sat' e)ktopi/an flo/ga ph/matos.

me/ntoi, ‘yet,’—crushing though the sorrow is: cp. O. C. 780 f. a)=r' a)\n matai/ou th=sd' a)\n h(donh=s tu/xois; | toiau=ta me/ntoi kai\ su\ prosfe/reis e)moi/. (It is not a mere expression of assent, ‘yes,’ as Paley takes it.)

*zhno\s h( deinh\ qeo\s: for the simple gen. of parentage, cp. 172 *dio\s, 1302 *laome/dontos: Ant. 824ta\n *frugi/an ce/nan | *tanta/lou. In 401 and 450 the art. (h() is prefixed to *dio/s.— futeu/ei: cp. O. T. 347cumfuteu=sai tou)/rgon.

e)fubri/zei here denotes, not deeds or words of insult, but secret exultation; hence it is joined with kelainw/pan qumo\n as an acc. ‘of the inner object,’ like that which is often added to verbs of feeling (ge/ghqe/ te fre/na, Il. 8. 559: tara/ssomai fre/nas, Ant. 1095). kelainw/pan (kelaino/s, w)/y) is not simply an equiv. for kelaino/n: the second part of the compound suggests the dark soul which watches from its place of concealment with malevolent joy; as Philoctetes says to Odysseus, a)ll' h( kakh\ sh\ dia\ muxw=n ble/pous' a)ei\ | yuxh/ etc.—The epithet ‘dark,’ ‘black,’ is often given to a mind strongly moved by passion (esp. anger): Il. 1. 103me/neos de\ me/ga fre/nes a)mfi\ me/lainai | pi/mplant): Theogn. 1199 kai/ moi kradi/hn e)pa/tace me/lainan (dark with resentment): Aesch. Cho. 414spla/gxna de/ mou kelainou=tai: Aesch. Pers. 114tau=ta/ moi melagxi/twn | frh\n a)mu/ssetai fo/bw|. Here, however, dark malignity is implied, as by kelaino/frwn ( Aesch. Eum. 459, of Clytaemnestra).

The form kelainw/phs occurs only here, though Pind. P. 1. 7 has the fem., kelainw=pin..nefe/lan. In Pind. P. 4. 212 he uses kelainw/y (kelainw/pessi *ko/lxois): and Blaydes here gives kelainw=p' a)n qumo\n: an ingenious conjecture. But the Sophoclean apocopè of a)na/ is elsewhere confined to compounds (see on Soph. Ant. 1275a)ntre/pwn).

Schneidewin strangely understands, ‘Odysseus mocks at the frenzy-darkened soul of Ajax.’ Hartung writes kelainw=p' e)/nqumon: ‘mocks at the brooding, passionate man’ (Ajax),—referring to Arist. Pol. 4.(7.) 7. 3 (where, however, e)/nqumos = ‘spirited,’ opp. to a)/qumos).
polu/tlas, much-enduring, ‘patient,’—the Homeric epithet, applied with bitter irony: he has known how to work and wait.—Not ‘unflinching,’ in the sense of ‘sticking at nothing’ (pantourgo/s, v. 445).

gela=| de\, the traditional reading, is slightly better here than gela=| te: de/, implying that the speaker turns to a new point, here serves to mark a climax: Odysseus exults in thought,—yes, and laughs aloud. For gela=|, cp. 382: Ph. 1125(kai/ pou..) e)ggela=|, xeri\ pa/llwn | ta\n e)ma\n mele/ou trofa/n.
toi=sde … a)/xesin, dat. of object with gela=|: cp. 1042: Nub. 560 o(/stis ou)=n tou/toisi gela=|, toi=s e)moi=s mh\ xaire/tw.

mainome/nois: as mai/nomai is said of fire, strife, etc., so here it denotes ‘frantic’ griefs, but with a further refer ence to their source in the mani/a of Ajax. Cp. I. A. 548 mainome/nwn oi)/strwn (so Reiske, for maino/men)).
cu/n te: for the adv. cu/n, cp. 1288, Ant. 85.
oi( d' ou)=n: 114 n.
kei) … mh\, where ei) kai\ mh/ would be normal (563 n.).

)po/qoun, ‘missed him,’ during the interval between the award of the arms and his death, when he remained in seclusion (193 f., n.). Il. 6. 361(Hector) o)/fr' e)pamu/nw | *trw/ess), oi(\ me/g' e)mei=o poqh\n a)peo/ntos e)/xousin. 1. 240 h)= pot' *)axillh=os poqh\ i(/cetai ui)=as *)axaiw=n. For the prodelision of the augment in the last foot of the v., cp. 557 )tra/fhs.
e)n xrei/a| doro/s, ‘in the need of the spear’=‘in the straits of war’: cp. 1275: Ant. 670doro\s..e)n xeimw=ni.—Not, ‘when they need his spear.’
kakoi\ gnw/maisi: cp. 1374 gnw/mh| sofo/n.
ta)gaqo\n xeroi=n is better attested than ta)ga/q' e)n xeroi=n: and in this context the singular ta)gaqo\n is preferable. For the dat., cp. El. 431w(=n e)/xeis xeroi=n, Tr. 265xeroi=n..e)/xwn be/lh.

pri/n tis e)kba/lh|=pri
 e)kba/lwsi: the collective tis, as in Thuc. 4. 85§ 6 oi(=s a)
 e)pi/w, h(=sso/n tis e)moi\ pro/seisi, dusxere\s poiou/menoi k.t.l. From the primary sense of ‘casting out,’ e)kba/llein derives that of ‘throwing away,’ ‘losing by one's own folly’: cp. Ar. Eccl. 750ou) ga to
 e)mo
 i(drw=ta kai\ feidwli/an | ou)de
 pro\s e)/pos ou(/tws a)noh/tws e)kbalw=. So a schol. here explains, pri
 a)/n tis au)tou= sterhqh=|. Sophocles has this use, with various shades of meaning, in Soph. Ant. 648(where see n.), Soph. O. T. 611, Soph. O. C. 631.[We could also render, ‘until one strike it out of their hands’; cp. Hom. Od. 2. 396pla/ze de\ pi/nontas, xeirw=n d' e)/kballe ku/pella. But a reason for preferring the other view is that it represents the loss as due solely to the folly of the possessors themselves; and thus suits the context better.]

For the sentiment, cp. Mimnermus fr. 1 (in Nauck's Frag. Trag. 2nd ed., p. 829) deinoi\ ga\r a)ndri\ pa/ntes e)sme\n eu)kleei= | zw=nti fqonh=sai, katqano/nta d' ai)ne/sai. Plaut. Capt. 1. 2. 39 Tum denique homines nostra intelligimus bona, | Quom quae in potestate habuimus ea amisimus. C. 3. 24. 31 Virtutem incolumem odimus, | Sublatam ex oculis quaerimus invidi.

Various theories of interpolation have been held with regard to this passage: see Appendix. Most of them are founded on the assumption that Tecmessa's former speech of ten lines (915—924) must be balanced by a speech of the same length here, and that therefore three of the thirteen verses (961— 973) must be struck out. (Nauck, who rejects 918 f., strikes out five verses here, 966—970.)
As several objections arise from the alleged incoherence of the speech, it is well to observe the train of thought in 961—973.

‘Let them mock, if they will, at the fate of Ajax; they will perhaps find out, in time of need, what they have lost; foolish men never know their own good fortune till they have thrown it away (961—965). No, his death is no gain for them—though it is anguish for me: for him, it is the release which he desired (966—968). Why should they mock at him, then? They cannot even claim that his death was their work; it is the affair of the gods (969 f.). So Odysseus may exult, if he pleases, but it is an empty triumph. He and his friends have merely suffered a loss; Ajax is gone, —and has left nothing behind him but the sorrow which is mine’ (971—973).

e)moi\ pikro\s k.t.l. Schol. in L: ma=llon e)moi\ pikro\s te/qnhken h)/per e)kei/nois gluku/s. This is the only tenable explanation of the words. For the omission of ma=llon, cp. Il. 1. 117bou/lom' e)gw\ lao\n so/on e)/mmenai h)\ a)pole/sqai: Her. 3. 40bou/lomai...ou(/tw diafe/re<*>n to\n ai)w=na e)nalla\c prh/sswn h)\ eu)tuxe/ein ta\ pa/nta. No proposed substitute for h)\ (h(=|, ei), w(s, kai\) really fits the sense. Her point throughout is that the death of Ajax is no triumph for the Greeks—only a loss. The sole positive result is her own wretchedness. gluku/s means, a cause of rejoicing for them—if they knew their own interest. Instead of ou) kei/nois gluku/s, a)ll' e)moi\ pikro/s, we have e)moi\ pikro\s (ma=llon) h)\ kei/nois gluku/s: cp. Thuc. 1. 34§ 2 pole/mw| ma=llon h)\ tw=| i)/sw| e)boulh/qhsan ta\ e)gklh/mata metelqei=n (= ou) tw=| i)/sw|, a)lla\ pole/mw|).
qa/naton is in appos. with the tau=ta implied (as antecedent) by w(=n: as we could say,—‘all that he desired he has found,—the death of his choice.’

e)peggelw=|en, as in 454, 989.— ka/ta, placed after its case, as in 302, and also separated from it, like e)n in 906. We find kata/ joined with a similar compound verb in El. 834 f. kat' e)mou=.. | ma=llon e)pemba/sei.—Conjectures which aim at e)ggelw=|en (toiou=d), tou=d' a)/n, tou=de/ g)) are needless: the stress on tou=d) mitigates the harshness of the verse.

qeoi=s k.t.l.: the dat. is one of relation: his death is a matter between the gods and himself,—one in which the Greek chiefs have no part. (‘His death concerns the gods,—not them, not them’: Whitelaw.) See on El. 1152te/qnhk' e)gw\ soi/. The implied meaning is that his death has been brought about by the gods; but qeoi=s should not be taken as a dat. of the agent (539), ‘by the gods’; indeed, that sense would be forced. Tecmessa's phrase is more expressive and more pathetic.
pro\s tau=t), with a command, as often; cp. 1066, 1115: Ant. 658pro\s tau=t' e)fumnei/tw *di/a | cu/naimon: O. T. 426: El. 820, etc.
e)n kenoi=s, in a case where his triumphs are kena/, empty, unreal: cp. Tr. 1118ou) ga\r a)\n gnoi/hs e)n oi(=s | xai/rein proqumei= (n.). El. 331qumw=|..xari/zesqai kena/.

972 f. There is no stress on au)toi=s as opposed to e)moi/. The emphasis is on ou)ke/t' e)sti/n, which is repeated in a negative form by a)lla\..dioi/xetai (cp. 167 n.). ‘It is all loss for them; nothing remains but the anguish which becomes my portion.’

div2.p: The fourth e)peiso/dion consists of two scenes. (1) 974—1039. Teucer's lament. (2) 1040—1184. Menelaüs forbids the burial of Ajax, and Teucer defies him.

div3.p: a)/ths … e)pi/skopon (from skopo/s as=‘mark’), aimed at it, having regard to it: schol. ou)x h(marthko\s th=s sumfora=s, a)ll' e)stoxasme/non. Another gloss, e)/foron, represents the view that e)pi/skopon is from skopo/s as=‘overseer’, and means ‘looking upon’ the a)/th: which yields virtually the same sense. But, in actual usage, this e)pi/skopos, when figurative, means ‘watching or presiding over.’ In Aesch. Ch. 125 f., tou\s gh=s e)/nerqe dai/monas klu/ein e)ma\s | eu)xa/s, patrw/|wn dwma/twn e)pisko/pous, the adj. is best taken with dai/monas, ‘looking upon.’ Hence it is better to suppose the notion of aiming at a mark both here and in Aesch. Eum. 903, o(poi=a ni/khs mh\ kakh=s e)pi/skopa. Herodotus has the literal sense, Aesch. Eum. 3. 35, ti/na ei)=des..ou(/tw e)pi/skopa toceu/onta;

me/los, said here of a loud lament, denotes the bellowing of oxen in fr. 637 me/lh bow=n a)/naula kai\ r(akth/ria (‘discordant’). Euripides applies the word to Nestor's winning eloquence, to\ *nesto/reion eu)/glwtton me/los (fr. 899).

cu/naimon o)/mm), the ‘face’ or ‘form’ of a kinsman: cp. 1004: El. 903su/nhqes o)/mma (n.): Ph. 171cu/ntrofon o)/mm): Aesch. Ch. 238w)= terpno\n o)/mma (where Herm. reads o)/noma). For cu/naimon, cp. <*> Soph. Ant.au)ta/delfon..ka/ra, Soph. O. C. 1387suggenei= xeri/.

h)mpo/lhkas=pe/pragas, ‘fared’: Hippocr. De morb. II. p. 353 (Kühn) ka/llion e)mpolh/sei o( a)/nqrwpos, ‘the patient's state will be better.’ In Aesch. Eum. 631h)mpolhko/ta | ta\ plei=st' a)/meinon (so Herm. , for a)mei/non)), the sense is similar.—Hermann, reading h)mpo/lhka/ s), explained, ‘Num te morando prodidi?’ This seems clearly less fitting.
w)/moi k.t.l. Cp. El. 1179oi)/moi talai/nhs a)=ra th=sde sumfora=s.

w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn: the same phrase in Aesch. Ag. 1393: so above, Aesch. Ag. 904w(s w(=de tou=d' e)/xontos ai)a/zein pa/ra, and 281 n. For the neut. plur. part., without subject, cp. El. 1344teloume/nwn ei)/poim' a)/n (n.).—The division of the verse between two speakers (a)ntilabh/) is again used, as in 591 ff., to mark strong emotion. The interruption after e)xo/ntwn has the effect of adding emphasis to the announcement: see on O. C. 645.

perisperxe\s, done in passionate haste,—fierce and sudden. spe/rxomai often refers to anger, as in Her. 5. 33e)spe/rxeto tw=| *)aristago/rh|: cp. id. 7. 207 perisperxeo/ntwn th=| gnw/mh| tau/th|, ‘being incensed’ at it: Oppian Cyn. 4. 218perisperxh\s o)du/nh|sin.
ti/ ga\r,..pou= … kurei=..; For the double question, cp. 101 f.
moi, ethic dat.: 733.
mo/nos: referring to te/knon: cp. Il. 22. 84fi/le te/knon: Eur. Andr. 570te/knou te tou=d), o(\n k.t.l. para\ skhnai=sin, where Tecmessa had left him at 809.

dh=t' au)to
 a)/ceis. There is no other example of dh=ta as first word of a verse. It is usually read as first word of a clause in Nub. 399 (kai\ pw=s) ei)/per ba/llei tou\s e)pio/rkous, dh=t' ou)xi\ *si/mwn' e)ne/prhsen..; where, however, Dindorf gives pw=s ou)xi (pw=s dh=t) being a variant for dh=t)). There is, however, no reason to doubt it here. With Sophocles the words sometimes run on from the end of one trimeter to the beginning of the next, as if there were no break between the verses. See e.g. 1089 o(/pws | mh/: Ant. 409pa=san ko/nin sh/rantes h(\ katei=xe to
 | ne/kun: Ph. 263o(
 oi( | dissoi\ strathgoi/: O. T. 332ti/ tau=t' | a)/llws e)le/gxeis; (Such elision at the end of the verse was remarked by the ancients as peculiar to Sophocles: see on O. T. 29.) The place of dh=ta here is only another example of the same tendency, and is illustrated by that of pote/ in O. T. 1084ou)k a)
 e)ce/lqoim' e)/ti | pot' a)/llos. This virtual synaphea of trimeters naturally occurs most often in passages where, as here, the speech is excited or rapid.

kenh=s, ‘robbed’ of her young: Bion Idyll. I. 59 xh/ra d' a( *kuqe/reia, kenoi\ d' a)na\ dw/mat' *)/erwtes. The adj. is ‘proleptic’: if the child is not quickly brought, the mother will seek him only to find that she is bereaved. Cp. Ant. 791dikai/wn a)di/kous fre/nas paraspa=|s: Aesch. Pers. 298a)/nandron ta/cin h)rh/mou qanw/n. Schol. oi( ga\r kunhgoi\ throu=si to\n kairo\n o(po/te e)/rhmoi tw=n mhte/rwn gi/gnontai oi( sku/mnoi. —Others take kenh=s as merely ‘separated’ (at this time) from her child: but this would be a strange sense for it.

e)gko/nei (811) and su/gkamne are said, like a)/ceis, to Tecmessa, who now hurries away. At v. 1168 she returns with her child, but only as a kwfo\n pro/swpon, whose part is taken by a supernumerary. The actor who has thus far played Tecmessa has to re-appear as Odysseus (or possibly as Agamemnon): see p. 7.

keime/nois is bitterly added after qanou=si, to mark the baseness of the action: ‘the dead—when they have fallen.’ Cp. Nub. 550 kou)k e)to/lmhs' au)=qis e)pemphdh=s' au)tw=| keime/nw|. Aesch. Ag. 884w(/ste su/ggonon | brotoi=si to\n peso/nta lakti/sai ple/on. There is no reason for changing qanou=si (cr. n.).
kai\ mh\n: 794.

tou=de, Eurysaces, the subject of vv. 983 ff. The absence of the child does not require us to make tou=de neuter (‘this matter’). me/lein might be personal (689), but, in view of me/lei, is prob. here the impersonal verb.
w(/sper ou)=n: Phaedr. p. 242 E ei) d' e)/stin, w(/sper ou)=n e)/sti, qeo\s h)/ ti qei=on o( *)/erws.
a(pa/ntwn dh\: cp. 858 panu/staton dh/.
qeama/twn … prosei=don o)fqalmoi=s: the redundant phrase denotes the vehemence of his feeling; cp. Ant. 763su/ t' ou)dama\ | tou)mo\n proso/yei kra=t' e)n o)fqalmoi=s o(rw=n.

o(do/s q' o(dw=n pasw=n. The fact that pasw=n has been corrected in L from a(pasw=n, the reading of some other MSS., has been regarded as confirming Brunck's conjecture, o(dw=n q' a(pasw=n o(do\s a)nia/sasa dh/. That reading is specious. In support of pasw=n, however, these points should be considered. (1) a(pasw=n could easily arise through the scribe's eye wandering to a(pa/ntwn in 992: and no MS. which has a(pasw=n alters the order of the words o(do/s q' o(dw=n. (2) After tw=n a(pa/ntwn..qeama/twn a)/lgiston, there is a rhetorical advantage in having o(do/s q' o(dw=n pasw=n rather than o(dw=n q' a(pasw=n o(do/s. It is a ‘chiasmus.’ (3) The absence of caesura in o(do/s q' o(dw=n pasw=n may have been intentional: see on 855.

a)nia/sasa dh/. Here dh/ emphasises the whole phrase pasw=n a)nia/sasa ma/lista (rather than pasw=n only). Cp. Creon's words in Ant. 1212a)=ra dustuxesta/thn | ke/leuqon e(/rpw tw=n parelqousw=n o(dw=n;
h(\n dh\: dh\ emphasises the pron., as in 1029, 1043, 1045, and often.

w(s e)ph|sqo/mhn. On learning that Ajax had left the tent, the Messenger and others had hastened to the camp, to inform Teucer (804). They knew nothing as to the hero's fate. Teucer, who had stayed near the council of chiefs in the hope of mediating (780), then set out to seek Ajax,—going, not, of course, to the tent itself, but to the coast near it. While engaged in the search, he heard the rumour that Ajax was dead.
diw/kwn expresses eager, rapid search; as the midd. diw/komai denotes speed ( El. 871).
ka)cixnoskopou/menos. The act. e)cixnoskopei=n occurs in Tr. 271: i)xnoskopei=n in Aesch. Ch. 228.
ba/cis, as Ajax had prayed Zeus to apprise Teucer (826).

sou is genitive of the object (221 n.): qeou=, of the subject (as in O. C. 447ge/nous e)pa/rkesin,=h(\n to\ ge/nos pare/xei). For the combination, cp. Thuc. 7. 34§ 6 dia\ th\n tou= a)ne/mou a)/pwsin au)tw=n (i.e. o(/ti o( a)/nemos a)pwqei= au)ta/, sc. ta\ naua/gia).

dih=lq' *)axaiou\s: Her. 9. 100(before the battle of Mycale) i)ou=si de/ sfi fh/mh.. e)se/ptato e)s to\ strato/pedon pa=n...h( de\ fh/mh dih=lqe/ sfi (ethic dat.) w(=de, w(s oi( *(/ellhnes th\n *mardoni/ou stratih\n nikw=|en e)n *boiwtoi=si maxo/menoi. As to fh/mh generally, see on El. 1066.
In sending this fh/mh to Teucer, Zeus illustrates his attribute of *panomfai=os ( Il. 8. 250).

du/sthnos, L's reading, is better attested than dei/laios: otherwise there is little to choose between them.— e)kpodw
 me
 w)
, merely, ‘while yet absent’ from this spot. It is grammatically possible to take it as=o(/ti e)kpodw
 h)=n, ‘I lamented that I had been absent’ (cp. fr. 667 a)ndro\s kakw=s pra/ssontos e)kpodw
 fi/loi). But this would be strained; and nu=n d' o(rw=n is decisive in favour of the simpler view.
u(peste/nazon: restraining the vehemence of his grief: cp. 322.
i)/q), e)kka/luyon. This is said to an attendant. Tecmessa left the scene at v. 989.

o)/mma, face, or form; 977 n.— to/lmhs pikra=s, a gen. of quality (cp. 616, e)/rga..a)reta=s). The corpse of the self-slain man shows the ‘cruel courage’ that animated him. For the combination of adj. (dusqe/aton) with gen., cp. 481 f.: Ph. 72 f. ou)/t' e)/norkos..ou)/te tou= prw/tou sto/lou.
Eustathius (p. 409, 46), whom some critics follow, takes the gen. as depending on w)= (‘O ghastly form! And alas for the cruel daring!’). But kai\ precludes this.
1006 f. For the dat. moi followed by the acc. (a)rh/canta) and inf., cp. Ant. 838 n.: Eur. Med. 814soi\ de\ suggnw/mh le/gein | ta/d' e)sti/, mh\ pa/sxousan, w(s e)gw/, kakw=s.

1008 The ironical h)= pou (‘methinks’) is reinforced by i)/sws, which goes more closely with the adjectives (‘radiant and benign, doubtless’). Hermann's change of i)/sws to i)dw\n weakens the passage.— e)mo/s q' a(/ma is clearly right: e)mo/s t' i)/sws was a mere error caused by the copyist's eye wandering to the next verse. The use of i)/sws in the sense of ‘equally’ ( Legg. p. 805 A) is rare.—Teucer's thought is, ‘Telamon is, indeed, my father no less than thine; but he will not welcome me as a son.’
pw=s ga\r ou)/x; sc. de/cetai.

o(/tw| pa/ra (pa/resti)..gela=n, ‘the man whose wont it is to wear no brighter smile (than usual), even when he is fortunate.’ mh/ is used, not ou), because o(/tw| here denotes a class or type. For this ‘generic’ mh/, see O. T. 397 n.—pa/ra. pa/resti, when thus used, is susceptible of two different shades of meaning. (1) More often it denotes one's situation at some given moment; as in 432, nu=n ga\r pa/resti kai\ di\s ai)a/zein e)moi/. (2) Sometimes, as here, it denotes a trait of character or disposition; cp. Eur. Med. 658a)xa/ristos o)/loiq' o(/tw| pa/resti | mh\ fi/lous tima=n (‘one who is capable of not respecting friendship’). In this sense pro/sesti is more frequent.

The v.l. i(/lewn for h(/dion is very inferior, and undoubtedly corrupt. It evidently arose from lews in 1009. The force of the comparative here is manifest: ‘If good fortune cannot lessen his gloom, what will his aspect be now?’
ti/ kru/yei; i.e. ‘what thought, however injurious to me, will he leave unspoken?’

poi=on ou)k e)rei= kako
 k.t.l. There should be no comma after kako/n: e)rei= here takes a double acc. At the same time the words to
 e)k doro\s k.t.l. express the substance of the taunts.— e)k doro\s gegw=ta polemi/ou, ‘begotten of the war-spear,’ i.e. e)k dorikth/tou gunaiko/s: cp. 1228 to
 e)k th=s ai)xmalwti/dos. Remark that do/ru pole/mion, which here means hasta bellica, would usu. mean hasta hostilis (as, e.g., in Aesch. Theb. 216, Aesch. Theb. 416): but it would be forced here to understand, ‘begotten from the ranks of the foe.’
kakandri/a|: a word not found elsewhere, except in Rhes. 814.— se/, fi/ltat' *ai)/as: the place of the pronoun is emphatic: ‘thee’—for whom I would gladly have died.
ta\ sa\ … qano/ntos: cp. Eur. Hec. 430qanou/shs o)/mma sugklei/sei to\ so/n.
kra/th, royal prerogatives, as in O. T. 237, Ant. 173.— do/mous: cp. El. 651do/mous *)atreidw=n skh=ptra/ t' a)mfe/pein ta/de.

du/sorgos, naturally prone to anger: e)n gh/ra| baru/s, choleric, irritable, in his old age. For this sense of baru/s, see on O. T. 673.—Ajax himself felt that, if he went home disgraced, he could not confront his father (462).
pro\s ou)de\n, ‘at nothing,’—without cause: cp. 40 pro\s ti/; 971 pro\s tau=ta.
ei)s e)/rin qumou/menos, lit. ‘growing wroth unto quarrelling,’ i.e., so as to provoke a quarrel.
1019 Join a)pwsto\s with gh=s: cp. O. T. 641gh=s a)pw=sai patri/dos, ib. 670 gh=s..a)pwsqh=nai.
a)porrifqh/somai, ‘cast off’ by his father: cp. O. C. 1383su\ d' e)/rr' a)po/ptusto/s te ka)pa/twr e)mou=. The fulness of phrase is like that in 830 r(ifqw= ..pro/blhtos.

In the Teucer of Pacuvius, fr. 19 (ed. Ribbeck), Telamon says to Teucer, Te repudio nec recipio: naturam abdico: facesse, i. Pacuvius probably used the lost *teu=kros of Sophocles, which dealt with the hero's expulsion from Salamis by Telamon. The reference to the subject here may be compared with that in the O. C.(1410) to the theme of the Antigone, and with the allusion in the Philoctetes (1437) to the theme of the poet's lost play, ‘Philoctetes at Troy.’

dou=los lo/goisin … fanei/s, ‘made out, represented, in his taunts, to be a slave.’ For fanei/s, cp. 1241 ei) pantaxou= fanou/meq' e)k *teu/krou kakoi/: Aesch. Ag. 593lo/gois toiou/tois plagkto\s ou)=s' e)faino/mhn. The vague lo/goisin could mean either (1) Telamon's words,—schol., tai=s tou= patro\s loidori/ais,—which is perhaps the best explanation: or (2) the common talk of men. lo/goisin further implies that he is e)/rgw| e)leu/qeros, and this is emphasised by a)nt' e)leuqe/rou: cp. Soph. O. T. 454tuflo\s..e)k dedorko/tos | kai\ ptwxo\s a)nti\ plousi/ou.
pau=ra need not be taken as= pau=roi (like ta\ xrhsta\ for ta\s xrhsta\s in El. 972, ta\..panou=rga in Ph. 448, etc.). The sense is simply, ‘few helpful things,’— few resources.
hu(ro/mhn, with irony, ‘gained’: Aesch. P. V. 267qnhtoi=s a)rh/gwn au)to\s hu(ro/mhn po/nous. In Helen. 94 Teucer says, *ai)/as m' a)delfo\s w)/les' e)n *troi/a| qanw/n.

tou=d' ai)o/lou knw/dontos, lit., ‘this gleaming spike,’—i.e., the end or point of the sword-blade, projecting through the body of Ajax. knw/dwn (kna/w, o)dou/s) meant any tooth-like prong or spike: see on Ant. 1233, where the ci/fous diploi= knw/dontes are the cross-pieces of the sword-hilt. Some suppose that here, too, knw/dontos denotes the handle of the sword, against which the corpse is resting. But there are at least two decisive objections to that view,—(1) the singular number, (2) the epithet ai)o/lou.

Lycophron borrows the word knw/dwn from this passage, in alluding to the suicide of Ajax (464): dusmenesta/tou ce/nwn | e)/tuye dw/rw| spla/gxnon, a)rneu/sas lugro\n | ph/dhma pro\s knw/dontos au)tourgou\s sfaga/s.—For the a)/ra after fone/ws, cp. 233 n.
ei)=des, ‘seest thou?’ (a rhetorical apostrophe to the corpse). The aor. is used as in Tr. 1221e)/gnws (‘thou art right’).

kai\ qanw\n a)pofqi/sein. As Heracles says of Nessus, zw=nta/ m' e)/kteinen qanw/n, Tr. 1163(n.). In Homer the fut. fqi/sw and the aor. e)/fqisa always have i_. The Attic poets use e)/fqisa with i^ ( Aesch. Eum. 173, Soph. O. T. 202, etc.); this is the only Attic example of the fut. fqi/sw. (The form a)pofqiei=n, which Dindorf once read here, has no authority, and is contrary to analogy.)

ske/yasqe … ka)gw\ ta/de. The grounds on which Morstadt and Nauck reject these twelve verses are considered in the Appendix. It is clear, I think, that the verses are genuine. If they were absent, Teucer's speech would end abruptly with v. 1027, and the Chorus could not well say, mh\ tei=ne makra/n (1040).

w(=| dh\ tou=d' e)dwrh/qh pa/ra, ‘the same with which he had been presented by Ajax.’ dwrou=mai/ tina/ tini, and dwrou=mai/ tini/ ti, are equally good constructions (the former being preferred when the notion of honour is prominent); but, when dwrou=mai is passive, the subject is usually the gift, not the person (see, e.g., Polit. 274 C, Tim. 47C). Here, however, the stress marked by w(=| dh\ is on the identity of the girdle, not of the man; and the subject of e)dwrh/qh is Hector.— As to the exchange of gifts between Ajax and Hector ( Il. 7. 303 ff.), see n. on 661.

prisqei\s … e)c a)ntu/gwn, firmly bound — gripped from the chariot-rail. The schol. explains prisqei/s by deqei/s: Suidas, by deqei/s, e)cafqei/s, desmeuqei/s. The senses of pri/w are:—1. To saw. 2. In pri/ein tou\s o)do/ntas, to grind or clench the teeth. Suidas quotes e)mpri/santes tou\s o)do/ntas (said of men under torture). 3. To bite: Soph. fr. 811 o)do/nti pri=e to\ sto/ma. 4. To clutch tightly (as with the teeth). Oppian Opp. Hal. 2. 138 describes a serpent winding its coils round an e)xi=nos (hedgehog): i)/sxei t' e)mpri/ei te, ‘he holds and compresses him’ (schol. pie/zei). So Hesychius: prismoi=s: tai=s biai/ois katoxai=s (‘grips’). Hence a)pri/c, a)/prigda, mordicus, ‘tightly’ (as between the teeth): see above, Opp. Hal. v. 310.

Thus prisqei/s is forcibly used here to describe the fatal grip of the girdle, from which Hector could not escape. I do not think that the word was meant also to suggest that the girdle cut into his flesh.—Paley is surely mistaken in explaining zwsth=ri prisqei/s as ‘lacerated by means of the girdle’: prisqei/s could not bear that sense, which is expressed in the next verse by e)kna/ptet).

a)ntu/gwn, the rail which protected the front and both sides of the chariot (hence the plur.): see on El. 746.i(ppikw=n, as in Homer i(/ppoi often=‘chariot’: so El. 730nauagi/wn..i(ppikw=n, ‘wreck of chariots.’

e)kna/ptet): cp. Aesch. Pers. 576knapto/menoi..di/na| (bodies mangled by the waves dashing them against rocks). kna/ptw, knafeu/s, knafei=on were the older Attic forms: gna/ptw, etc., with softening of k to g, came later. knafeu/s appears in an Attic inscr. of the 6th cent. B.C. (C. I. A. IV. 373 f.): the first trace of the g form seems to be gnafei=on, in an Attic inscr. of 358 B.C. (C. I. A. II. 817 A, 28): Meisterhans, Gramm. d. Att. Inschr. § 23.

e)/st' a)pe/yucen bi/on. The Homeric Achilles slays Hector in fight, and then drags the corpse ( Il. 22. 395 ff.). Hermann sought to reconcile this verse with Homer by writing, ai)w=n) eu)=t) a)pe/yucen bi/ou: quoting, for ai)w=na bi/ou, the author of a *melampodi/a ap. Tzetzes on Lycophron 682, *zeu= pa/ter, ei)/q' h(/ssw me\n e)moi\ ai)w=na bi/oio | w)/felles dou=nai. There, however, ai)w=na bi/ou means ‘term of life.’ Euripides could say, a)pe/pneusen ai)w=na (fr. 801); but a)pe/yucen ai)w=na bi/ou is surely impossible. It would have been better, for Hermann's purpose, to keep ai)e/n and bi/on, merely changing e)/st) to eu)=t).

As a matter of verbal criticism, it might be observed that ai)e/n and e)/st) confirm each other. But the defence of the text rests on broader ground. Evidently we must either reject the whole passage 1028 —1039, as Morstadt and Nauck do, or else leave this verse unaltered. For the parallel between the sword and the girdle, as fatal to their respective recipients, would fail altogether, if the girdle had not been an agent of death to Hector, but merely of insult to his corpse. It is not known whence Sophocles derived this version, which so strangely mars the very climax of the Iliad; possibly from one of the two Cyclic epics, the Aethiopis of Arctînus or the Little Iliad of Lesches, which related the o(/plwn kri/sis (see Introd. §§ 2, 3). One thing, at least, seems hardly doubtful. The original motive of this version must have been the same which prompts its use by Sophocles here, —viz., to point the fatal character of Hector's gift to Ajax by connecting a like result with the gift of Ajax to Hector. Two epigrams, attributed to Leontius Scholasticus (circ. 550 A.D. ), turn on the same legend (Anthol. 7. 151, 152): see Appendix.

dwrea\n e)/xwn. The form dwreia/ is quoted by Meisterhans from three Attic inscriptions belonging to the second half of the 5th century B.C.: dwrea/ appears first in 403 B.C., and does not become the predominant form till the early part of the 3rd century B.C. (Gramm. § 10. 4). The Hesychian by-form dwria/ is also significant. Curtius, who remarks that dwr-ea/ is properly a collective (like murmhk-ia/ etc.), meaning ‘a number of gifts,’ adds: ‘the original form was dwreia/, in which the e is of the same kind as that of i(/ppe-io-s, tau/re-io-s) (Etym. vol. II. p. 244, Eng. ed.). Wecklein may be right in giving dwreia\n here.

pro\s tou=d), i.e. tou= knw/dontos. This would be clearer if to/de..e)/xwn had preceded, but the pronoun (th/nde) has been assimilated to dwrea\n by the ordinary Greek idiom (see on O. C. 88, tau/thn e)/lece pau=lan).

*)erinu\s … e)xa/lkeuse: so Aesch. Cho. 646*di/kas d' e)rei/detai puqmh/n (anvil), | proxalkeu/ei d' *ai)=sa fasganourgo/s: Aesch. Ag. 1535di/khn d' e)p' a)/llo pra=gma qhga/nei bla/bhs | pro\s a)/llais qhga/naisi *moi=ra.

ka)kei=non, to\n zwsth=ra. From e)xa/lkeuse a verb of more general sense, such as ei)rga/sato, is to be supplied: cp. Her. 4. 106e)sqh=ta de\ fore/ousi th=| *skuqikh=| o(moi/hn, glw=ssan de\ i)di/hn: see also n. on El. 435pnoai=sin h)\..ko/nei | kru/yon nin. —Some critics think that e)xa/lkeuse might be said of the zwsth/r no less than of the ci/fos, because a girdle was often adorned with metal-work (see, e.g., Il. 11. 236). This seems a little forced.
dhmiourgo\s, a general term for any artificer ( Plat. Rep. 373B skeuw=n..pantodapw=n dhmiourgoi/).

e)gw\ me\n ou)=n, which has better authority than e)gw\ me\n a)/n, is also intrinsically better, since ou)=n serves to link this concluding sentiment with what precedes.—The active mhxana=n occurs nowhere else in classical Greek, except in Od. 18. 143mhxano/wntas (Apoll. Rhod. 3. 583 u(pe/rbia mhxano/wntes). Cp. 1129 a)ti/ma, a solitary instance in Attic of the Homeric verb a)tima=n. In the Thyestes (fr. 247) Sophocles used e)nte/llw as= e)nte/llomai.
e)n gnw/mh| fi/la, acceptable ‘in his judgment,’ i.e., when he ponders them. Distinguish the phrase in Her. 6. 37h)=n de\ o( *miltia/dhs *kroi/sw|..e)n gnw/mh| gegonw/s, ‘had won his esteem.’

kei=no/s t' e)kei=na k.t.l., an expression of settled conviction, serving to close the speech, as in O. C. 1665, ei) de\ mh\ dokw= fronw=n le/gein, | ou)k a)
 parei/mhn oi)=si mh\ dokw= fronei=n. Milton imitates this trait of Greek tragic style in Dalila's last words to Samson:—‘At this whoever envies or repines, | I leave him to his lot, and like my own’ (Sams. 995). For the sentiment cp. Suppl. 466 soi\ me
 dokei/tw tau=t), e)moi\ de\ ta)nti/a. Evenus fr. 1. 4 (Bergk) soi\ me
 tau=ta dokou=nt' e)/stw, e)moi\ de\ ta/de.
mh\ tei=ne makra/n: so Aesch. Ag. 1296makra\n e)/teinas: ib. 916 makra\n ga\r e)ce/teinas: Eur. Hec. 1177w(s de\ mh\ makrou\s tei/nw lo/gous.
kakoi=s gelw=n: the simple dat., as in 957 gela=|..a)/xesin (n.).
a(\ dh\, in the sense of oi(=a dh/, is very rare; Simonides Amorg. fr. 1. 3 e)fh/meroi | a(\ dh\ bo/t' ai)ei\ zw=men. So a(\ without dh\ in Nicander Alex. 215, boa/a|, a(/ tis e)mpela/dhn fw/s k.t.l.

ti/s d' e)sti\n o(/ntin' a)/ndra, instead of ti/s d' e)sti\n a)nh\r o(/ntin), the antecedent being attracted into the relative clause: cp. El. 1040ei)/rhkas o)rqw=s w(=| su\ pro/skeisai kakw=|: Tr. 1060 f. ou)/q' *(ella\s ou)/t' a)/glwssos ou)/q' o(/shn e)gw\ | gai=an kaqai/rwn i(ko/mhn. So in Latin, De Legg. 3. 5. 12 haec est enim, quam Scipio laudat in libris et quam maxime probat temperationem reipublicae.

w(=| dh\, dat. of interest (where we might rather have expected the stronger ou(= xa/rin), as in O. C. 1673w(=|tini to\n polu\n | ... po/non...ei)/xomen, and ib. 508 toi=s tekou=si ga\r | ou)d' ei) ponei= tis k.t.l.
plou=n e)stei/lamen, as Ph. 911to\n plou=n stelei=n.
maqei=n ou) duspeth/s. Menelaüs, king of Lacedaemon ( Od. 11. 460), is for Attic Tragedy a type of Spartan harshness and arrogance. In Eur. Andr. 458 he is called gorgo\s o(pli/ths.

ou(=tos, se\ fwnw=. In the older printed editions, from the Aldine onwards, a point of some kind is placed after fwnw=, to show that se\ fwnw= is parenthetic (cp. 73 *ai)/anta fwnw=),—sugkomi/zein being taken as an infinitive serving for an imperative. Lobeck, who adheres to this view, remarks that there is no other instance of fwnw= tina (=iubeo) with infin. This is true; nevertheless it seems probable that fwnw= here is used as a verb of ‘commanding’ with the inf., like le/gw ( Ph. 101), ei)=pon and e)nne/pw ( O. C. 932), au)dw= (ib. 1630), and fhmi/ (below, O. C. 1108).

nekro\n … sugkomi/zein, to aid in paying funeral rites to the corpse. For komi/zein, said with ref. to the dead, see El. 1114.In Plut. Sull. 38, e)/fqh to\ sw=ma sugkomisqe/n, the sense is, ‘the obsequies were already completed’ (sug-), i.e. the body had been consumed on the pyre.

a)nh/lwsas. Attic inscriptions, from the 5th cent. B.C. onwards, show that the aor. and perf. of a)nalo/w regularly took the temporal augment. No unaugmented form (such as a)na/lwsa) occurs in them. See Meisterhans, § 40. 6, who quotes Moeris, p. 23: a)nhlwme/non *)attikw=s, a)nalwme/non *(ellhnikw=s (i.e. in the koinh\ dia/lektos).
The slow movement of the verse (with only quasi-caesura after the 3rd foot) is intended to mark haughty surprise. Cp. Ant. 44h)= ga\r noei=s qa/ptein sf), a)po/rrhton po/lei;

dokou=nt' e)moi/: this is the acc. neut. plur. (not acc. sing. agreeing with lo/gon), and answers the question ti/nos xa/rin,...the partic. having a causal force: ‘I speak because these things seem good to me,’ etc. (Cp. Aesch. Theb. 1005dokou=nta kai\ do/cant' a)pagge/llein me xrh\ | dh=mou probou/lois k.t.l.)

dokou=nta d) (e)kei/nw|) o(\s krai/nei stratou=: for the omission of the antecedent in dative, cp. El. 1123do/q), h(/tis e)sti/, prosfe/rontes: Ant. 35o(\s a(\n tou/twn ti dra=|, | fo/non prokei=sqai.—The full expression would be, dokou=nta me\n e)moi/, dokou=nta d' e)kei/nw|: but in such ‘anaphora’ the me/n is often omitted: cp. O. C. 1342sth/sw s' a)/gwn, | sth/sw d' e)mauto/n: Ant. 906 f. (n.).
proqei/s, sc. keleu/eis, supplied from a)nh/lwsas lo/gon (1049). Cp. 800 tou= pot' a)nqrw/pwn maqw/n; (sc. e)lpi/zei).

e)lpi/santes … a)/gein, not a)/cein, because the sense is, ‘having formed the expectation that we were bringing him (to be) an ally,’ etc.; not, ‘that we should bring him.’ So 799 e)lpi/zei fe/rein, ‘forebodes that it tends.’ Ajax, as Teucer points out at v. 1097, was not ‘brought’ at all, but came of his free will.

zhtou=ntes seems to be rightly explained in the Triclinian scholium by e)ceta/zontes, ‘on trial’: but the use of the word is peculiar: its ordinary sense, when joined with eu(ri/skw, may be seen in Ar. Ran. 96go/nimon de\ poihth\n a)\n ou)x eu(/rois e)/ti | zhtw=n a)/n (if you searched for one). Here, it could doubtless mean, ‘on inquiry’ (into the slaughter of the cattle); but this sense is too narrow for the context.

*frugw=n=*trw/wn. In the Iliad, the Trojans and Phrygians are distinct, though allied, peoples: thus Priam helps the Phrygians against the Amazons ( Il. 3. 184—189). Post-homeric Greek poets came to use *fru/ges as a synonym for *trw=es, because, when Aeolian colonies were first founded in western Mysia, the country was subject to the Phrygians (cp. Kiepert, Anc. Geo. 66). Eur. Hec. 4*frugw=n po/lin=*troi/an: Eur. Or. 1480*(/ektwr o( *fru/gios.

stratw=| cu/mpanti, as in 726 he is called e)pibouleuth\s stratou=. His design had been against the chiefs (57 f.), the authors of his wrong; but that wrong had also embittered him against the whole Greek army (844).

dori/. Several editors write do/rei here, on account of the v.l. w(s e)loido/rei: which may, however, have been originally gr. w(s e(/loi do/rei, i.e., merely a marginal note of do/rei as an alternative form. Metre requires do/rei in O. C. 620, O. C. 1314, O. C. 1386: but there is no reason to doubt that Sophocles could also use the ordinary form dori/, as Aesch. ( IIIAesch. Ag.) and Eur. ( Eur. Hec. 5) certainly did.
qew=n tis: only Odysseus knows who it was.
e)/sbesen: cp. 1149: O. C. 422e)/rin katasbe/seian: Critias fr. 1. 40 th\n a)nomi/an te toi=s fo/bois kate/sbesen.

th/nd' … tu/xhn, best taken as a ‘cognate’ acc. with qano/ntes, like Il. 3. 417kako
 oi)=ton o)/lhai, Od. 1. 166a)po(lwle kako
 mo/ron. If the words h(
 o(/d' ei)/lhxen tu/xhn stood without th/nd), they could be taken as acc. in apposition with qano/ntes a)
 prou)k.: but, with th/nd), such a constr. would be awkward. The easy remedy, laxo/ntes for qano/ntes, should not be admitted; this is a case in which the harder reading is, as such, the more probable.
prou)kei/meq), prostrate in death, as Aesch. Theb. 965pro/keisai. Cp. above, Aesch. Theb. 427.

ai)sxi/stw|, most ignominious; as they would have been assassinated, not slain in fight. The epithet reflects, in fact, on Ajax; commentators who did not see this suggested the feebler e)xqi/stw| or a)qli/w|.
e)nh/llacen, changed its direction, schol. a)nte/streye.
mh=la kai\ poi/mnas, ‘sheep and cattle’: poi=mnai being used here (as in 42 and 300) in the wider sense, so as to include herds of oxen: see 53 n.

1062 f. The acc. au)to\n is resumed and more closely defined by sw=ma: cp. 1149 (boh/n after se/, etc.): O. T. 819kai\ ta/d' ou)/tis a)/llos h)=n | h)\ )gw\ )p' e)mautw=| ta/sd' a)ra\s o( prostiqei/s. Similarly Tr. 287 ff. nin after au)to/n.
tumbeu=sai ta/fw|: Lycophron 154 e)tu/mbeusen ta/fw|. Thesm. 885 pou= d' e)tumbeu/qh ta/fw|;

a)mfi\ … ya/maqon, ‘somewhere on the sand.’ The phrase implies scornful indifference as to the precise place, just as in Eur. Andr. 215ei) d' a)mfi\ *qrh/|khn.. | tu/rannon e)/sxes a)/ndra, ‘somewhere in Thrace.’ Cp. Il. 11. 706a)mfi/ te a)/stu | e)/rdomen i(ra\ qeoi=s, ‘about’ the city, i.e. here and there in it.

xlwra\n, ‘yellow.’ The epithet serves to call up more vividly a picture of the desolate sea-shore, where the corpse is to lie unburied. Cp. Verg. Aen. 5. 374fulva moribundum extendit arena. xlwro/s, primarily an epithet of young verdure (xlo/h), sometimes means ‘yellow’ or ‘yellowish’; a sense found in the kindred Sanskrit hAris and Lat. helvus (Curt. Etym. § 197). Il. 11. 631me/li xlwro/n. In Ant. 1132 the sense of xlwra\..a)kta\ (‘green’) is defined by the further epithet polusta/fulos.—The sense ‘moist’ is preferred here by Prof. Campbell (‘that part of the sands which the sea has moistened’).
leura\n, the conjecture of Burges ( Eur. Hec. 699e)n yama/qw| leura=|), did not deserve to be received by Wecklein.
o)/rnisi: cp. 830 r(ifqw= kusi\n pro/blhtos oi)wnoi=s q' e(/lwr.
pro\s tau=ta: 971 n.
e)ca/rh|s (a_): cp. O. T. 914u(you= ga\r ai)/rei qumo/n.

ei) … mh\ )dunh/qhmen, ‘granting that we were unable.’ Cp. Thuc. 3. 40§ 4 ei) ga\r ou(=toi o)rqw=s a)pe/sthsan, u(mei=s a)\n ou) xrew\n a)/rxoite, ‘assuming that they were right to revolt, your rule would be unwarrantable.’

xersi
 pareuqu/nontes, ‘guiding him with our hands’: cp. 542 xersi
 eu)qu/nwn, said of guiding a child's steps. ‘He will be docile enough now, and will go whither our hands guide him’ (i.e., the body shall be laid where we please). Then xersi
 suggests the bitter comment, (‘our hands, I say,) for our words were at all times lost upon him.’ For o(/pou, cp. O. T. 448ou) ga e)/sq' o(/pou m' o)lei=s.

kakou= pro\s a)ndro\s: for pro/s, cp. 319. These remarks on authority and obedience are suggested by the alleged insubordination of Ajax, who (in disregard of Homeric conditions) is styled a)nh\r dhmo/ths, in contrast to oi( e)festw=tes, —i.e. the Atreidae. (Cp. 945 e)festa=si.) The tone of Menelaüs here recalls that of Creon in Ant. 663—676.

a)/ndra, coming after a)ndro/s, is thought too inelegant by some critics, who replace it by Reiske's conjecture, o)/nta. But it may be doubted whether a Greek ear would have been offended; the words a)/ndra dhmo/thn closely cohere, and the emphasis falls, first on kakou=, and then on dhmo/thn. The phrase a)nh\r dhmo/ths occurs in Ant. 690 and Nub. 1219. Cp. 1093 a)/ndres, a)/ndra.
kalw=s fe/roint' a)/n, ‘have a prosperous course.’ Thuc. 5. 16§ I eu)= fero/menos e)n strathgi/ais: Xen. Oecon. 5. 17 eu)=..ferome/nhs th=s gewrgi/as.

e)/nqa mh\ with subjunct. (without a)/n), as in O. T. 316e)/nqa mh\ te/lh | lu/h|. kaqesth/kh|, which L supports, seems slightly better here than kaqesth/koi, which would make the statement more abstract or hypothetical. Similarly in 1081 we have o(/pou..parh=|. (On the other hand, in such a passage as Tr. 1235, ti/s tau=t' a)/n, o(/stis mh\ )c a)lasto/rwn nosoi=, | e(/loito; the optative is clearly better than nosh=|.)
fo/bou pro/blhma, a screen ( Ph. 1008 n.), a defence, afforded by fear,— the gen. defining that in which the defence consists; cp. El. 682pro/sxhm' a)gw=nos, ib. 857 e)lpi/dwn..a)rwgai/.

ai)dou=s. The schol. on 1074 quotes from Epicharmus, e)/nqa de/os, e)ntau=qa kai\ ai)dw/s: cp. Euthyphr. p. 12 B, where Socrates quotes from Stasînus, i(/na ga de/os, e)/nqa kai\ ai)dw/s,—remarking that we ought rather to say, i(/na me
 ai)dw/s, e)/nqa kai\ de/os: ou) me/ntoi, i(/na ge de/os, pantaxou= ai)dw/s. The sentiment of Menelaüs is genuinely Spartan. Plut. Cleom. 9 dwells on the place of fo/bos in Spartan government: timw=si de\ to
 fo/bon...th
 politei/an ma/lista sune/xesqai fo/bw| nomi/zontes. The Aeschylean Athena, too, counsels mh\ to\ deino
 pa=n po/lews e)/cw balei=n ( Plut. Eum. 698), but there the basis of the fear is to be ai)dw/s,—the se/bas (690) for the Areiopagus. As at Sparta there was a shrine of *fo/bos ( Plut. l.c.), so at Athens there was an altar of *ai)dw/s ( Paus. 1. 17. 1).

ka)\n sw=ma gennh/sh| me/ga: cp. the phrases fu=sai fre/nas ( O. C. 804), ptera/ ( Ar. Av. 785), etc.: Her. 5. 91to\n basile/a h(me/wn..e)ce/bale, do/can de\ fu/sas au)ca/netai. The words allude to the stature of the pelw/rios *ai)/as ( Il. 3. 229), but are meant also to be figurative; cp. Shakesp. Julius Caesar 1. 2. 135 Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world | Like a colossus, and we petty men | Walk under his huge legs.

ka)
 a)po\ sm. kakou=,=kai\ e)a
 (pe/sh|): cp. El. 1482a)lla/ moi pa/res | ka)
 smikro
 ei)pei=n, i.e., kai\ e)a
 smikro
 parh=|s: Dem. or. 2 § 14 kai\ o(/poi tis a)/n, oi)=mai, prosqh=| ka)
 mikra
 du/namin, pa/nt' w)felei=, i.e., kai\ e)a/n tis prosqh=|. We cannot here well take ka)
