 as=kai\ a(/n (the conditional particle), and suppose that it belongs to pesei=n understood. (See appendix on El. 1482.)—For a)po\ denoting result, cp. Ant. 695a)p' e)/rgwn eu)kleesta/twn fqi/nei.
pro/sestin, said of an attribute or quality: 521 n.
ai)sxu/nh, verecundia, here virtually an equivalent of ai)dw/s, as in Thuc. 1. 84§ 3 ai)dw\s swfrosu/nhs plei=ston mete/xei, ai)sxu/nhs de\ eu)yuxi/a.
o(/pou … parh=|, without a)/n: cp. 1074.

bou/letai, sc. tis: cp. Plat. Apol. 29B ou)k a)maqi/a e)sti\n au(/th h( e)ponei/distos, h( tou= oi)/esqai ei)de/nai a(\ ou)k oi)=den; Crito 49C ou)/te a)/ra a)ntadikei=n dei=...ou)de/na a)nqrw/pwn, ou)d' a)\n o(tiou=n pa/sxh| u(p' au)tw=n.

no/mize..xro/nw| pote\ … pesei=n. It seems best to take pesei=n as representing a gnomic aor., xro/nw| pote\ e)/pese. Cp. Plat. Rep. 490C (quoted by Goodwin, Moods and Tenses, § 159), h(goume/nhs dh\ a)lhqei/as ou)k a)/n pote..fai=men au)th=| xoro\n kakw=n a)kolouqh=sai, ‘when truth leads, we never could say that a chorus of evils accompanies her’ (h)kolou/qhsen). It may be observed that this view is slightly confirmed by the words e)c ou)ri/wn dramou=san, which clearly mean, ‘after running before favouring winds’ (the sense cannot be that the ship is to be sunk by a fatal ou)=ros): for, if pesei=n is an appeal to experience, then the mention of such a city's transient prosperity is fitting; but if pesei=n were a simple prediction, such a clause would be less natural. [I formerly took pesei=n as referring to the future; but now doubt whether no/mize, without more help from the context, could suffice to suggest such a sense. See Appendix on El. 442 f., where I read de/cesqai for de/casqai. Here we might, of course, write pot' a)\n, but the change seems needless.]

e)c ou)ri/wn: e)k denotes the condition; cp. O. C. 486e)c eu)menw=n | ste/rnwn de/xesqai. For the neut. plur. ou)ri/wn, cp. Ar. Lys. 550ou)/ria qei=te (adv.). Lobeck quotes e)c ou)ri/wn plei=n from Libanius 2. 421. e)c ou)ri/as plei=n occurs in Polyb. 1. 47. 2, etc.
e(sta/tw, be firmly set, as a principle, in the State; cp. 1074 kaqesth/kh|.
moi, ethic dat. (‘let me see it established.’) Cp. Plut. Cleom. 9dio\ kai\ para\ to\ tw=n e)fo/rwn sussi/tion to\n *fo/bon i(/druntai *lakedaimo/nioi.

kai\ de/os, ‘fear also’ —to temper natural u(/bris (1081). kai/rion, in due season and measure; as the Eumenides say, e)/sq' o(/pou to\ deino\n eu)= | kai\ frenw=n e)pi/skopon | dei= me/nein kaqh/menon ( Eum. 517).
a(\n h(dw/meqa: the cogn. acc. with h(/domai, lupei=sqai, etc., is frequent (cp. Ar. Ach. 2 f.).

ou)k a)ntitei/sein: for the spelling tei/sw, etc., see on O. T. 810.ou) with inf. is normal after a verb of saying or thinking (n. on O. T. 1455).— a(
 lupw/meqa: for the assonance (parechesis) at the end of two successive verses, cp. 807 f., Ph. 121 f. (parh/|nesa, sunh/|nesa), Tr. 1265 f. (suggnwmosu/nhn, a)gnwmosu/nhn). It is needless to read a(
 lupoi/meqa, though the optat. might be illustrated by Alcaeus fr. 82 (Bergk) ai)/ k' ei)/ph|s ta\ qe/leis, h)= ken a)kou/sais ta/ ken ou) qe/lois. Schneidewin quotes also Hes. Op. 721ei) de\ kako
 ei)/ph|s, ta/xa k' au)to\s mei=zon a)kou/sais: Libanius 2. 84 drw=ntes a(/tta e)qe/lousi pa/sxein du/naint' a)
 a(/tta a)
 ou)k e)qe/loien.
paralla\c, alternately; so in Her. 3. 40e)nalla\c prh/sswn=‘with alternations of fortune’ (good and evil).— ai)/qwn: see on ai)/qonos in 222.
o(/pws | mh\: with regard to the division of these words between two vv., see n. on the place of dh=ta in 986.

ei)s tafa\s pe/sh|s, come to need funeral rites: pe/sh|s is used, with grim irony, as in such phrases as ei)s a)na/gkas pi/ptein ( Thuc. 3. 82§ 2). tafa\s has its ordinary sense, ‘rites of sepulture,’ as it has also in v. 1109; it does not stand for ta/fous. Herodotus, indeed, uses tafai/ as=ta/foi, and employs the plural in that sense even with ref. to a single tomb ( Her. 5. 63).

u(posth/sas, after planting them like pillars (cp. u(posth=sai ki/onas, e)rei/smata, etc.); or, as we should say, after ‘laying them down’: the word is much more forcible than u(pobalw/n or u(poqei/s.
e)n qanou=sin: for e)n, cp. 43 n.

The dramatic function of a Chorus required that these Salaminian sailors, while loyal to Ajax, should recognise the sound elements in the speech which they have heard. Menelaüs has rightly condemned the u(/bris which defies human laws. But his own u(/bris menaces the laws of the gods.

a)/ndres. The burning anger of Teucer is marked in his first words by the fact that he addresses them to the Chorus: as Oedipus does after the speech of Polyneices ( O. C. 1348), and Clytaemnestra after that of Electra ( El. 612).

mhde
 w)
 gonai=sin: the phrase is exactly parallel with a)ge/nnhtos used in the sense of dusgenh/s ( Tr. 61). In 1231 ou)de
 w)
 has a like sense. Here mhde
 is ‘generic,’ denoting the class of person.

toiau=q' a(marta/nousin … e)/ph, make such erroneous statements; for the cogn. acc., cp. 1107 ta\ se/mn' e)/ph | ko/laz) e)kei/nous. e)n lo/gois, in their discourse. lo/goi and e)/ph are similarly combined in Thuc. 3. 67§ 6 lo/goi e)/pesi kosmhqe/ntes, ‘speeches adorned with fine sentiments.’
a)/gein=o(/ti h)=ges, as a)/gein in 1053=o(/ti h)/gomen: ‘that thou wast bringing him [when he came hither] as an ally found by thee (labw/n).’
au)to\s, sponte sua: cp. Il. 17. 252a)rgale/on de/ moi/ e)sti diaskopia=sqai e(/kaston | ...a)lla/ tis au)to\s i)/tw.
pou=, on what ground, in what respect? O. T. 390pou= su\ ma/ntis ei)= safh/s; ‘where hast thou proved thyself a seer?’
lew=n: the plur. of the Attic form is somewhat rare (except in the formula a)kou/ete lew/|); Ar. fr. 346 has pa/ntes lew/|.

h)/gag), the reading of one MS. (the Palatinus at Heidelberg, written in the 14th century), was doubtless no more than a conjectural emendation; but it appears probable. h(gei=t), the reading of the other MSS., has been defended by Erfurdt and others on the ground that the elision has the effect of running the two words h(gei=t' oi)/koqen together, so that they become virtually one. This is just possible; but in tragic iambics we find no certain examples of a precisely similar kind. (As to sh/main' ei)/t' e)/xei in Phil. 22, see n. there.) If h)/gag) was the original word, the change to h(gei=t) may have been caused by failure to perceive that the genitive w(=n (for ou(\s) was due to attraction. Porson (ap. Kidd, Tracts, p. 194) wished to read h)=gen, comparing Il. 2. 557, *ai)/as d' e)k *salami=nos a)/gen duokai/deka nh=as. The imperfect tense is, of course, free from objection (cp. also Aesch. Pers. 341*ce/rch|..xilia\s me\n h)=n | w(=n h)=ge plh=qos): but *h*g*e*n was less likely than *h*g*a*g to tempt the correction *h*g*e*i*t. Elmsley's h)/get) (n. on Eur. Heracl. 371) is still nearer to the letters of h(gei=t): but the middle voice would be at least very unusual, where the sense is simply that of ‘leading’; in Soph. O. C. 1460, indeed, a)/cetai is hardly more than a)/cei: but in Soph. Ph. 613a)/gointo suggests the notion, ‘bring with them, for their own ends.’

ou)d' e)/sq' o(/pou: cp. 1069.— to/nde kosmh=sai, to exercise authority over him. kosmei=n is properly said of a commander disposing his forces; Il. 2. 554kosmh=sai i(/ppous te kai\ a)ne/ras a)spidiw/tas: [Eur. ] Rhes. 662 kosmh/swn strato/n. The Atreidae are kosmh/tore law=n ( Il. 1. 16). For kosmei=n with ref. to civil government, cp. Ant. 677.

a)rxh=s … qesmo\s, an ordinance, an established right, of command. e)/keito, had been laid down (kei=mai serving as perf. pass. of ti/qhmi): cp. Thuc. 5. 105§ 2 ou)/te qe/ntes to\n no/mon, ou)/te keime/nw| prw=toi xrhsa/menoi.
h)\ kai\ tw=|de se/, ‘than for him, on his part, to rule thee’: for this kai/, cp. O. C. 53o(/s' oi)=da ka)gw/ (n.).

o(/lwn here can be only masc. This use of o(/loi as=su/mpantes elsewhere occurs only in later Greek; Lobeck cites Nonnus (5th cent. A.D. ) Dionysiaca 47. 482 o(/las oi)/strhse gunai=kas, and Anthol. Pal. 7. 679. 5 kth/masi me
 polu/olbos o(/lwn ple/on w(=n tre/fe *ku/pros (by Sophronius of Damascus, circ. 630 A.D. ). We are scarcely warranted, however, in assuming that a poet of the classical age could not have ventured on such a use. The view that o(/lwn is neuter (summae rerum) is decisively condemned (1) by the direct antithesis with the masc. a)/llwn, and (2) by the absence of the article, ta\ o(/la being the invariable phrase in this sense: see, e.g., Dem. or. 19 § 151 u(pe tw=n o(/lwn peisqei\s ei)rh/nhn a)/gein (‘for the general interests’): or. 22 § 16 th
 tw=n o(/lwn swthri/an: Xen. Cyr. 8. 7. 22th/nde th
 tw=n o(/lwn ta/cin (the universe): Lucian De Luctu c. 6 th
 tw=n o(/lwn despotei/an.
Apart from the difficulty as to o(/lwn, there is absolutely no ground for rejecting verses 1105 f., as Schneidewin and other critics have done.

w(=nper a)/rxeis arxe, as Agamemnon says to Achilles, *murmido/nessin a)/nasse ( Il. 1. 180), and Achilles to him, a)/lloisin dh\ tau=t' e)pite/lleo, mh\ ga\r e)moi/ ge. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 574a)/nac *)/apollon, w(=n e)/xeis au)to\s kra/tei.
ta\ se/mn' e)/ph ko/laz) e)kei/nous: e)/ph is a bold cognate acc.; cp. 1096: O. T. 339e)/ph | klu/wn, a(\ nu=n su\ th/nd' a)tima/zeis po/lin: Aesch. Eum. 230di/kas | me/teimi to/nde fw=ta.

ei)/te mh\ su\ fh/s, ei)/q' a(/teros str.= ei)/te su\ mh\ fh/s, ei)/t' *)agame/mnwn mh/ fhsin, whether the veto is thine or his. For fhmi/ as=‘to command’ (a rare use), see Pind. N. 3. 28*ai)akw=| se fami\ ge/nei te *moi=san fe/rein. Here the mh/, despite its place, belongs in sense to the inf. (qei=nai ei)s tafa\s) understood. (ou)/ fhmi qei=nai could mean only, nego te sepulturum: this might be referred to the assertion of Menelaüs in 1062 f.; but it would be forced.)
ei)s tafa\s qh/sw, I will give him due funeral rites: see on 1090.
sto/ma: cp. 1147: Ant. 997w(s e)gw\ to\ so\n fri/ssw sto/ma.

oi( po/nou pollou= ple/w|, the toiling laoi/, the born subjects of Menelaüs, who are bound to endure the labours of war in any field to which their lord calls them. Cp. Eur. Andr. 695ou) tw=n ponou/ntwn tou)/rgon h(gou=ntai to/de, | a)ll' o( strathgo\s th\n do/khsin a)/rnutai,—where oi( ponou=ntes are the rank and file. The strangeness which has been felt in the phrase, oi( po/nou pollou= ple/w|, will perhaps be lessened if we remember how habitually the Attic poets transfer the associations of their own time to the heroic age. In picturing the followers of the Spartan king, Sophocles may have had in mind the Perioeci who served as hoplites and the Helots who served as light-armed in the armies of their Spartan masters.

Assuredly oi( po/nou pollou= ple/w| does not mean ‘busybodies,’ oi( polupragmonou=ntes, as some have taken it,—supposing it to be said scornfully of basilei=s tributary to Menelaüs and eager to display their zeal.

o(/rkwn: the oaths sworn to Tyndareus by the suitors of his daughter Helen, o(/tou gunh\ ge/noito *tundari\s ko/rh, | tou/tw| sunamunei=n, ei)/ tis e)k do/mwn labw\n | oi)/xoito ( I. A. 61). Thuc. 1. 9§ 1 *)agame/mnwn te/ moi dokei= tw=n to/te duna/mei prou)/xwn kai\ ou) tosou=ton toi=s *tunda/rew o(/rkois kateilhmme/nous tou\s *(ele/nhs mnhsth=ras a)/gwn to\n sto/lon a)gei=rai. In Soph. Ph. 72Odysseus says that (unlike the other chiefs) Neoptolemus came to Troy, e)/norkos ou)deni/.
sou= d' ou)de\n: this third clause repeats the thought of the first, ou) ga/r ti th=s sh=s k.t.l.: on this trait of Sophoclean style see Ant. 465 ff. (n.).

tou\s mhde/nas, those who are as nought (mh/ having its generic force),—mere ciphers. Cp. Ant. 1322to\n ou)k o)/nta ma=llon h)\ mhde/na. So I. A. 371 tou\s ou)de/nas: Andr. 700o)/ntes ou)de/nes, Her. 9. 58ou)de/nes a)/ra e)o/ntes.

kh/rukas. Menelaüs is attended by two heralds, their presence marking the solemn character of his mission. So in the Iliad the chiefs deputed to intercede with Achilles are accompanied by two heralds (9. 170), whom Eustathius (780. 46) compares to the a)rga\ pro/swpa of the theatre.

yo/fou … strafei/hn: the gen. is properly causal, ‘turn for it,’ and is joined (here only) with the simple verb, as it is regularly joined with e)ntre/pomai (90), e)pistre/fomai ( Ph. 599), and in Eur. Hipp. 1224 ff. with the act. metastre/fein: (pw=loi) ou)/te nauklh/rou xero\s | ou)/q' i(ppode/smwn ou)/te kollhtw=n o)/xwn | metastre/fousai.

e(/ws: cp. Phaedr. 243 E e(/wsper a)
 h)=|s o(\s ei)=. This is a certain correction of the traditional reading w(s, as it is also in Ph. 1330e(/ws a)
 au(to\s h(/lios | tau/th| me
 ai)/rh| etc., and in O. C. 1361e)/wsper a)
 zw=. [Hermann explained w(s a)
 h)=|s as utcunque sis qualis es, ‘however much you may be what you are,’ i.e., quantumlibet ferocias. Prof. Campbell understands, ‘However you may be—just what you are,’ oi(=osper ei)= being said, para\ prosdoki/an, instead of basileu/s or the like.]
ou)d' au)=, ‘neither, again,’—referring to their reproof of Menelaüs in 1092. ou)d' au)= is similarly used in El. 1034.
e)n kakoi=s, because the friends of Ajax have the felling of the Greek chiefs and army against them. Cp. El. 335nu=n d' e)n kakoi=s moi plei=n u(feime/nh| dokei=.

o( toco/ths. The name of ‘bowman’ was a reproach only when it implied that the archer was not, like the hoplite, ready to meet his foe in close fight. It is in this sense that Diomedes upbraids Paris ( Il. 11. 385), toco/ta, lwbhth/r, ke/ra| a)glae/. In Il. 13. 313Teucer is said to be a)/ristos *)axaiw=n | tocosu/nh|: but the poet adds a)gaqo\s de\ kai\ e)n stadi/h| u(smi/nh|. At Athens, where the toco/tai or city police were slaves (*sku/qai, etc.), the word had acquired ignoble associations.

ba/nauson, sordid, unworthy of a freeborn man: Plato joins ba/nausos with a)neleu/qeros (Legg. 644 A). Cp. Arist. Pol. 8. 2§ 5 ta\s..toiau/tas te/xnas, o(/sai to\ sw=ma paraskeua/zousi xei=ron diakei=sqai, banau/sous kalou=men. Thus the notion at the root of the word was that of some mechanical (or sedentary) calling which interfered with efficiency in athletics or war. (Compare the taunts of Euryalus to the disguised Odysseus, Hom. Od. 8. 159.) Teucer might well say that his art was not ba/nausos: Heracles and Philoctetes were among its masters.
a)spi/d): the shield of a hoplite, who wore a helmet and breast-plate, and was armed with a pike (do/ru); while the bowman, ranking with the light-armed troops, had no defensive armour.

yilo\s … w(plisme/nw|. The contrast is illustrated by the case of the Locrians in the Iliad, who came to Troy armed only with bows, and are described as shrinking from the stadi/h u(smi/nh, because they were not armed as hoplites:— ou) ga\r e)/xon ko/ruqas xalkh/reas i(ppodasei/as, | ou)d' e)/xon a)spi/das eu)ku/klous kai\ mei/lina dou=ra. ( Il. 13. 714 f.)

tre/fei, has in it; i.e., his valour resides only in his words. Cp. Tr. 817o)/gkon..tre/fein: O. T. 356ta)lhqe\s ga\r i)sxu=on tre/fw. Dryden: Tongue-valiant hero, vaunter of thy might (l. 336 of his Trans. of the Iliad, bk. 1).

cu
 tw=| dikai/w|, with right on my side: Ph. 1251cu
 tw=| dikai/w| to
 so
 ou) tarbw= fo/bon. Shakesp. Henry VI. pt. II. 3. 2. 233 Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just.
di/kaia: for the plur., cp. 887 sxe/tlia (n.).

ktei/nanta: as Creüsa says to her living son ( Eur. Ion 1500) e)/kteina/ s' a)/kous), i.e., ‘doomed thee to perish.’ So Soph. O. C. 1008kle/yas to\n i(ke/thn, meaning that Creon had purposed to seize him.
deino/n g' ei)=pas: for ge in comment, cp. El. 341deino/n ge/ s' ou)=san patro\s ou(= su\ pai=s e)/fus | kei/nou lelh=sqai.

ei) kai\ zh=|s: here kai\ goes closely with zh=|s, ‘if thou indeed livest’: so O. T. 305ei) kai\ mh\ klu/eis (if indeed..): Tr. 71ei) kai\ tou=t' e)/tlh. Distinguish such instances from the ordinary uses of ei) kai/ (‘granting that..’), as in O. T. 408ei) kai\ turannei=s.

tw=|de d' oi)/xomai. The dat. of relation here means, ‘so far as concerns him,’—so far as his intention went; as in Ph. 1030te/qnhx' u(mi=n pa/lai. In 970 above the similar dat. (qeoi=s) has a different shade of meaning.

a)ti/ma. The verb a)tima=n is otherwise confined, in classical Greek, to the Homeric poems and hymns. The fut. and aor. occur both in Il.and Od.; the pres. once, in Od. 16. 307(a)tima=|); the imperf. twice ( Od. 21. 99a)ti/ma: 23. 28 a)ti/mwn, plur.). Nauck would here read a)ti/zei, with Elmsley (a)ti/zein occurs in O. C. 1153); but he would also banish a)tima=n altogether from the epic texts; see Appendix.

qeou\s, a monosyllable by synizesis, as qeo/s normally is with Sophocles, when it belongs to the third foot of the trimeter; see 489, O. C. 964, Ph. 1020, fr. 685. In El. 1264, to/t' ei)=des o(/te qeoi/ m' e)pw/trunan molei=n, we ought probably to read eu)=te.
qeoi=s seswsme/nos: for the dat. of the agent, cp. 539 n.

e)gw\ ga\r a)\n ye/caimi..; for ga\r in an indignant question, cp. Tr. 1124: Vesp. 1159 e)gw\ ga\r a)\n tlai/hn..;— daimo/nwn no/mous; Cp. 1343 (Odysseus to Agam.) ou) ga/r ti tou=ton, a)lla\ tou\s qew=n no/mous | fqei/rois a)/n.
ei) … ou)k e)a=|s. As ou)k e)w==veto, ou) can follow ei): cp. O. C. 935(n.) bi/a| te kou)x e(kw\n (=a)/kwn), after ei) mh/.
parw/n here has an indignant tone,— ‘You come and forbid’; cp. 338 n.

tou/s g' au)to\s au(tou=: the inserted au)to\s emphasises the reflexive pron.; O. C. 929ai)sxu/neis po/lin | th\n au)to\s au(tou= (n.).—For au)tou==e)mautou=, see O. T. 138(n.), O. C. 966, El. 285.— ou) ga\r kalo/n: sc. e)a=n qa/ptein au)tou/s. Ajax was pole/mios, a public enemy, ‘worse than any Trojan’ (1054), in view of his intended onslaught. Menelaüs, like Creon ( Ant. 284 ff.), conceives that refusal of burial to a pole/mios is warranted on religious grounds.

soi\ … prou)/sth, ‘stood forth to confront thee.’ For prosth=nai, see on El. 980.(In Her. 1. 129prossta\s, not prosta\s, should probably be read.)— Teucer parries the argument by asking how Ajax could have been the enemy of Menelaüs, a chief on his own side. He thus makes it a personal question between Ajax and Menelaüs whereas the latter had referred to the design of Ajax against the common weal.

misou=nt' e)mi/sei. Cp. Legg. 697 D misou=ntes misou=ntai. Menelaüs ought to have replied, ‘He was the public foe’; but, with the maladroitness which characterises him throughout this scene, he plays into Teucer's hands by saying, ‘If he was not pole/mios to me, at least he was e)xqro/s.’

yhfopoio\s, ‘making votes,’ in the sense of procuring them by a secret canvas among the chiefs. The word e)/pracan used by Ajax in 446 implies some such intrigue. Cp. Pindar's phrase, krufi/aisi...ya/fois, in N. 8. 26 (quoted on 447 ff.). Sophocles doubtless conceived the chiefs as voting by yh=foi placed in urns (cp. Aesch. Eum. 709), and this view appears in art (Introd. § 20). Eustathius remarks the anachronism (on Il. 2. 852): though, of course, neither e)yh/fisan in 449 nor yhfopoio/s here necessarily excludes the supposition that the votes were given, in Homeric fashion, by voice.—For other views of yhfopoio/s, see Appendix.
The gen. au)tou= depends on the phrase kle/pths yhfopoio/s, as it might depend on lwbhth/s or the like.
e)n toi=s dikastai=s, at their hands. e)n is said esp. of a tribunal: Ant. 459e)n qeoi=si th\n di/khn | dw/sein (n.).

kalw=s, ‘speciously.’ This is clearly a case in which L has preserved a true reading which the other MSS. have lost. Teucer means, ‘It might seem to be the judges' doing, while it was really yours.’ The common reading kakw=s misses this point. For kalw=s in a bad sense, cp. Ant. 1047(lo/gous) ai)sxrou\s kalw=s le/gwsi tou= ke/rdous xa/rin.
kle/yeias kaka/, commit furtive knaveries; see on 189 kle/ptousi mu/qous.

ei)s a)ni/an … e)/rxetai, tends to it, will issue in it (somewhat as in Her. 1. 120 it is said of dreams, e)s a)sqene\s e)/rxetai): tini/, i.e. soi/: for this menacing tis, see on Ant. 751qanou=s' o)lei= tina/.—The traditional accentuation, as seen in L and in the Aldine edition, is e)/rxetai tini/, the ground of it being that tini/ is here emphatic: so in Categ. 5 § 7 (p. 2 b 2) to\ xrw=ma e)n sw/mati: ou)kou=n kai\ e)n tini\ [not e)/n tini] sw/mati. (Cp. Chandler, Accent. § 942.) Some recent editors however write e)/rxetai/ tini.
ou) ma=llon, sc. ei)s a)ni/an e)moi\ e)/rxetai (i.e. luphqhso/meqa).
to/nd' e)sti\n ou)xi\ qapte/on: for the place of ou)xi/, cp. 1330 h)= ga\r ei)/hn ou)k a)\n eu)= fronw=n: for the neuter verbal with acc., 1250 ei)rkte/on ta/d' e)sti/n.

a)ll' a)ntakou/sei tou=ton w(s k.t.l.: cp. Phil. 549h)/kousa tou\s nau/tas o(/ti | ... ei(=en etc.: Xen. Mem. 4. 2. 33to\n *dai/dalon..ou)k a)kh/koas, o(/ti..h)nagka/zeto.. douleu/ein; Wecklein's conjecture, tou=q' e(/n for tou=ton, is very plausible, in view of 1040 e(/n soi fra/sw. We may observe, however, that tou=ton answers to to/nd) in 1040, and that the stress in Teucer's retort falls on the a)nt- in a)ntakou/sei, and on teqa/yetai. There is more of dignity in that retort, as it stands with tou=ton, than there would be with the mocking echo, tou=q' e(/n. If tou=q' e(/n were to be read, then su\ d) a)ntakou/sei (a v.l.) would be preferable to L's a)ll) a)ntakou/sei.
teqa/yetai: 577 n.

nau/tas e)formh/santa … to\ | plei=n: for the inf. with art., instead of a simple inf., cp. O. C. 442to\ dra=n | ou)k h)qe/lhsan (and ib. 47, n.): Thuc. 2. 87§ 1 ou)xi\ dikai/an e)/xei te/kmarsin to\ e)kfobh=sai (where Classen compares this verse). Liddell and Scott, s. v. e)forma/w, remark that the dat. vau/tais should be read here. It is, in fact, the reading of a few late MSS.,—having been introduced, perhaps, by Triclinius; but nau/tas is right. e)formw= takes a dat. of the person when it means to rouse or urge something against one; e.g. Hom. Od. 7. 272o(/s moi e)formh/sas a)ne/mous: Soph. fr. 619. 2 w(=| kai\ *z<*>u\s e)formh/sh| kaka/. But here, where e)formw= means to urge one to do something, the person is necessarily in the acc., as after e)pei/gw, protre/pw, etc. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 8. 1. 43tou/tous ou)/te meleta=n tw=n e)leuqeri/wn po/nwn ou)de/na parw/rma k.t.l.

w(=| fqe/gm' a)
 ou)k a)
 hu(=res. Against reading e)nhu=res, it should be noted that e)neuri/skw is post-classical, unless Dobree was right in conjecturing e)nhu/rhken (for a)nhu/rhken) in Ar. Ach. 1037.On the other hand, the sarcastic force of the doubled a)/n is in place here. The dat. w(=| is possessive: i.e. instead of the simple w(=| ou)k a)
 h)=n fqe/gma, we have w(=| ou)k a)
 hu(=res fqe/gma, in the sense, ‘you would have found that he had not a word at his command.’ The emendation w(=| fqe/gm' o)
 ou)k a)
 hu(=res would make this clearer, but seems needless: it is, indeed, slightly prosaic.
e)n kakw=| xeimw=nos: cp. O. C. 1358e)n po/nw| | ... kakw=n.
ei)/xet): Her. 9. 37e)n tou/tw| tw=| kakw=| e)xo/menos.
u(f' ei(/matos: Aesch. Ch. 81dakru/w d' u(f' ei(ma/twn: Eur. Hec. 346decia\n u(f' ei(/matos | kru/ptonta.
krufei/s. The form e)kru/fhn is not elsewhere found in classical Greek. At a later period e)kru/bhn was frequent (see Veitch, Gk. Verbs p. 393).

patei=n parei=xe, sc. e(auto/n: cp. Nub. 422 a)me/lei qarrw=n ou(/neka tou/twn e)pixalkeu/ein pare/xoim' a)/n. Plat. Theaet.p. 191 A e)a
 de\ pa/nth| a)porh/swmen, tapeinwqe/ntes, oi)=mai, tw=| lo/gw| pare/comen w(s nautiw=ntes patei=n te kai\ xrh=sqai o(/ ti a)
 bou/lhtai. Synesius IV. Plat. Ep. 163D meqh=ken o( kubernh/ths to\ phda/lion kai\ katabalw
 e(auto
 patei=n parei=xe tw=| qe/lonti nauti/lwn.—For the omission of the art. before nauti/lwn, cp. I. A. 340 tw=| qe/lonti dhmotw=n: Ion 1167to
 qe/lont' e)gxwri/wn.
kai\ de\ kai\ to\ so\n … sto/ma: cp. Ant. 573a)/gan ge lupei=s kai\ su\ kai\ to\ so\n le/xos.
la/bron sto/ma: Aesch. P. V. 327mhd' a)/gan labrosto/mei.

smikrou= ne/fous … e)kpneu/sas. Greeks gave the name of e)knefi/as to a wind caused by the meeting and breaking of clouds: De Mundo (p. 394 b 18) oi( de\ kata\ r(h=cin gino/menoi..e)knefi/ai kalou=ntai.

th
 … boh/n, a new acc. serving to resume se\ kai\ to\ so
..sto/ma: cp. 1062 f. (au)to
..sw=ma).
e)n kakoi=s u(/brize: Aesch. Ag. 1612*ai)/gisq), u(bri/zein e)n kakoi=sin ou) se/bw.

ka)=|t), introducing the consequence of such u(/bris: O. T. 1500toiau=t' o)neidiei=sqe: ka)=|ta ti/s gamei=; Ant. 1019ka)=|t) (‘and so,’ ‘and therefore’) ou) de/xontai qusta/das lita\s e)/pi | qeoi\ par' h(mw=n.
o)rgh/n=tro/pon. Aeschin. or. 2 § 179 a)na/ndrw| kai\ gunaikei/w| a)nqrw/pw| th\n o)rgh/n. Theognis 215 poulu/pou o)rgh\n i)/sxe poluplo/kou.
poh/seis: on the spelling, see Appendix to Ph. 120.
phmanou/menos. Other examples of the passive sense in futures of middle form, from stems ending in a liquid, are Ant. 93e)xqarei=: ib. 230 a)lgunei=: O. T. 272fqerei=sqai: Ph. 954au)anou=mai.

a)/nolbon, of folly, as in Ant. 1026(ou)k) a)/boulos ou)d' a)/nolbos: ib. 1265 w)/moi e)mw=n a)/nolba bouleuma/twn. Cp. 1290 du/sthne: O.T. 888 duspo/tmou xa/rin xlida=s (i.e., miserably perverse): Dem. or. 3 § 21 ou) ga\r ou(/tws a)/frwn ou)d' a)tuxh/s ei)mi e)gw/, w(/st' a)pexqa/nesqai bou/lesqai.
parw/n here serves merely to make the picture a little more vivid; he thus warned the man to his face. Cp. 338.

mw=n h)|nica/mhn; ‘I have not spoken too obscurely?’ (mw=n, num, as in 791.) Cp. Ant. 405a(=r' e)/ndhla kai\ safh= le/gw; Aesch. Ag. 269h)= torw=s le/gw; In Teucer's parody of his opponent's parable there is a rising tone of scorn, which the last words accentuate.

pa/ra (=pa/resti), the reading of A, is distinctly preferable here to parh=|, though the latter has the support of the first hand in L. With parh=| the sense would be: ‘It were shameful if people should hear that any one who may have the power to use force is chastising only by words.’ We must not be misled by the analogy of the Latin subjunctive: qui possit vi uti could be merely an allusive way of saying qui possim vi uti: but the Greek equivalent of qui possim would be (e)gw\) o(/tw| pa/resti, not w(=| parh=|. In 1081, o(/pou d' u(bri/zein dra=n q' a)\ bou/letai parh=| (wherever it may be allowed), the subjunctive is fitting: but not so here, where the reference is to a definite person who has a certain power. parh=| is not, indeed, impossible: it is, however, so unnatural in this context that it would require much stronger authority to support it as against pa/ra.

1163 The anapaests serve not only to mark the exit of Menelaüs, but also to afford a pause before the entrance of Tecmessa at 1168. For their bearing on the date of the play, see Introd. § 21.— e)/rido/s tis a)gw/n, a trial of strength in strife: cp. Tr. 20ei)s a)gw=na..sumpesw\n ma/xhs: Liv. 36. 19in ipso certamine pugnae. For the place of tis before its noun, cp. 29.

ka/peton, a grave dug in the earth, from ska/ptw (cp. kafw/rh, ‘fox,’ also skafw/rh): among kindred words G. Curtius gives the Lithuanian ka/p-a-s, ‘grave-mound’ (Etym. § 109). Il. 24. 797(Hector's burial) ai)=ya d' a)/r' e)s koi/lhn ka/peton qe/san.
i)dei=n, ‘look for’: Od. 8. 443au)to\s nu=n i)/de pw=ma: Theocr. 15. 2 o(/rh di/fron, *eu)no/a, au)th=|.

brotoi=s to
 a)ei/mnhston=to
 brotoi=s a)ei/mnhston: cp. O. C. 714i(/ppoisin to
 a)kesth=ra xalino/n: Tr. 872(dw=ron) *(hraklei= to\ po/mpimon: O. T. 139e)kei=non o( ktanw/n.

eu)rw/enta, from eu)rw/s, ‘mould’: an epithet applied in epic poetry to the nether world, where all things moulder in damp, cheerless gloom: Il. 20. 65(oi)ki/a, the home of Hades) smerdale/) eu)rw/enta, ta/ te stuge/ousi qeoi/ per. Od. 10. 512*)ai+/dew..do/mon eu)/rw/enta. Simonides illustrates this sense (fr. 4. 4), e)nta/fi)on de\ toiou=ton ou)/t' eu)rw\s | ou)/q' o( pandama/twr a)maurw/sei xro/nos: and Vergil reproduces it ( Aen. 6. 462) in his loca senta situ, the ‘rough and mouldering wilderness’ of the underworld. Quintus Smyrnaeus 14. 241 has tu/mbon e)p' eu)rw/enta. But in later antiquity a false etymology connected eu)rw/eis with eu)ru/s: thus Hesychius, s.v. eu)rw/enta, gives plate/a as one explanation of it. Oppian (circ. 180 A.D. ) actually uses the word in the sense of ‘wide,’ Opp. Hal. 5. 3ko/lpon a)n' eu)rw/enta qala/sshs: and so too Nonnus (5th cent. A.D. ) Dionys. 25. 476. [In Il. 20. 65Döderlein and others would change eu)rw/enta to au)ero/enta (au)h/r =a)h/r), or h)ero/enta, ‘murky’: while Nauck goes so far as to pronounce eu)rw/eis ‘a wholly apocryphal word.’]

The legendary tomb of Ajax was shown on the coast of the Troad near Cape Rhoeteum; Strabo 13. p. 595 tw=| *(poitei/w| sunexh\s h)|w\n a(litenh/s, e)f' h(=| mnh=ma kai\ i(ero\n *ai)/antos kai\ a)ndria/s. Alexander the Great, on landing in the Troad, offered e)nagi/smata at the tomb of Ajax as well as at that of Achilles ( Diod. 17. 17). There were legends of gigantic bones having been found in the tomb ( Paus. 1. 35. 5).
kai\ mh\n, marking the entrance of a person: 1223: O. C. 549(n.).

e)s au)to
 kairo
: so Ant. 386e)s de/on pera=|: Eur. Hipp. 899pai=s so\s e)s kairo
 pa/ra.— plhsi/oi, as in Eur. El. 640, parou/shs th=sde plhsi/as e)moi/, Soph. Tr. 896parou=sa plhsi/a. The v.l. plhsi/on is equally correct ( Soph. El. 927tou= plhsi/on paro/ntos, etc.).

Tecmessa had left the scene after v. 989, in order to bring the child Eurysaces from the tent, where he had been left when she set forth in search of Ajax (810). The part of Tecmessa is now taken by a mute person, as the deuteragonist has presently to resume the part of Odysseus (1318).

ta/fon peristelou=nte, here a general phrase for rendering funeral rites. Among these rites would be the washing and dressing of the corpse ( Ant. 901e)/lousa ka)ko/smhsa etc.), in which Tecmessa would naturally bear part, and the pouring of xoai/, in which Eurysaces also would share. The dual peristelou=nte is therefore right: Wakefield's conjecture peristelou=nti, which Nauck adopts, implies that the work was to be Teucer's alone. Cp. Od. 24. 292ou)de/ e( mh/thr | klau=se peristei/lasa: Ant. 902to\ so\n | de/mas periste/llousa.
i(ke/ths: an anapaest in the first foot, as in verse 1302. This licence occurs in every play except the Antigone: it is most frequent in the Philoctetes (Introd. Ph., p. xliv).

While the child knelt as a suppliant by the body, with his hand upon it, the corpse could not be forcibly removed without offence to Zeus *(ike/sios. Teucer is about to go and seek a place for the grave (1184), and he desires to secure that the body shall not be disturbed during his absence.
o(/s s' e)gei/nato: cp. 1296: El. 261mhtro\s h(/ m' e)gei/nato.

qa/kei de\ prostro/paios: cp. Aesch. Eum. 41e(/dran e)/xonta prostro/paion. Here qa/kei denotes a kneeling posture (prospesw/n 1181): cp. Soph. Ph. 293gonupetei=s e(/dras prospi/tnw s), O.T. 2 e(/dras..qoa/zete (n.). The offerings in the child's hands will show that he formally supplicates (prostre/petai, cp. 831) the xqo/nioi qeoi/ and the spirit of the dead man to avert outrage from the corpse.

ko/mas, offerings to the dead, as in Il. 23. 135, where the locks of hair are laid on the corpse (qrici\ de\ pa/nta ne/kun kataei/nusan, a(\s e)pe/ballon | keiro/menoi). So in El. 449 f. Chrysothemis is told to lay locks of her own hair and her sister's on Agamemnon's tomb,—the significance of the act being marked by the prayer which is to follow the gift: ai)tou= de\ prospi/tnousa gh=qen eu)menh= | h(mi=n a)rwgo\n au)to\n ei)s e)xqrou\s molei=n (453 f.). In its primitive symbolism the severed hair meant that the person from whose head it was cut devoted himself to the dead, and (as it were) escorted him to the shades; the gift of hair being a substitute for self-immolation at the grave.

tri/tou, marking the completion of the lucky number; O. C. 7 f. ai( pa/qai..xw( xro/nos.. | ..kai\ to\ gennai=on tri/ton: Aesch. Eum. 758 ff. *palla/dos kai\ *loci/ou | e(/kati kai\ tou= pa/nta krai/nontos tri/tou | *swth=ros.

i(kth/rion qhsauro/n, ‘the suppliant's store’; i.e., the efficacy of the supplication is stored up in, resides in, these gifts of hair, which symbolise the appeal of the i(ke/ths to the spirit of the dead.—G. Wolff takes the phrase as pathetic,—‘the suppliant's only wealth,’ ‘all that he has to offer,’—as Electra says of the gifts of hair, smikra\ me\n ta/d), a)ll' o(/mws | a(/xw ( El. 450). But it is rather the power than the poverty of the offering which is expressed by qhsauro/n.
kako\s kakw=s, as in 1391, O.T. 248, Ph. 1369.

a)/qaptos e)kpe/soi xqono/s, ‘may he be cast out of the land, unburied’: i.e., may he perish, and may his body then be cast beyond the boundaries of his country. Cp. Soph. Ph. 1629*polunei/kous ne/kun | e)kba/let' a)/qapton th=sd' o(/rwn e)/cw xqono/s. Under Athenian law a person put to death for treason (prodosi/a) or sacrilege was not to be buried in Attica ( H. 1. 7. 22): thus when Phocion was executed in 317 C.B. , e)/doce kai\ to\ sw=ma..e)cori/sai ( Plut. Phoc. 37). Teucer's curse is worded as if the supposed offender were at home in Greece, and not at Troy.
e)kpe/soi: cp. O.C. 766 o(/t' h)=n moi te/ryis e)kpesei=n xqono/s.
ge/nous a(/pantos: Dem. or. 19 § 71 (toi=s qeoi=s) eu)/xesq' e)cw/lh poiei=n au)to\n kai\ ge/nos kai\ oi)ki/an. Lys. or. 12 § 10 w)/mosen e)cw/leian e(autw=| kai\ toi=s paisi\n e)parw/menos.

r(i/zan e)chmhme/nos, with his race extirpated from the root,—i.e., may there be no survivor to continue it. Cp. El. 765pro/rrizon..e)/fqartai ge/nos: Lucian Tyr. 13panwleqri/a panto\s tou= ge/nous kai\ r(izo/qen to\ deino\n a(/pan e)kkekomme/non. So Antigone and her sister are the e)sxa/th r(i/za of their house ( Ant. 599 f.). For the constr. of the pass. verb with acc., cp. Tr. 157de/lton e)ggegramme/nhn | cunqh/maq) (n.): Xen. An. 2. 6. 1a)potmhqe/ntes ta\s kefala/s: Xen. Cyr. 5. 2. 32trau/mata e)pidedeme/nous. For the use of e)cama=n, cp. Paus. 8. 7. 7e)/melle de\ a)/ra o( dai/mwn kai\ to\ ge/nos to\ *kassa/ndrou kakw=s e)camh/sein.
au)/tws: as to the breathing, see on O. T. 931.

o(/pwsper to/nd' e)gw\ te/mnw plo/kon. The primary meaning of this act was self-dedication (1173 n.), but Teucer here gives it a further significance, suggested by the circumstances of the moment; exactly as in Il. 3. 300 the spondai/ at the truce are turned into a symbol of death for those who break the truce,—w(=de/ sf' e)gke/falos xama/dis r(e/oi w(s o(/de oi)=nos. Cp. Liv. 1. 24 si prior defexit...tu illo die, Iuppiter, populum Romanum sic ferito ut ego hunc porcum hic hodie feriam. Theocr. 2. 28
w(s tou=ton to
 karo
 e)gw\ su
 dai/moni ta/kw
w(\s ta/koiq' u(p' e)/rwtos o( *mu/ndios au)ti/ka *de/lfis.

kinhsa/tw: the 3rd pers. of the aor. imper. with mh/, though somewhat rare, occurs in good prose ( Plat. Apol. 17C mhdei\s...prosdokhsa/tw). Cp. 1334.— prospesw\n, kneeling beside the body, e)/xou (sc. au)tou=), cling to it. So Tr. 904bwmoi=si prospi/ptousa, Ph. 485prospi/tnw se go/nasi.

u(mei=s te, the Chorus. It has been proposed to read de\ instead of te, but needlessly. de/ would mark the change in the persons addressed; te marks the continuity of the precepts. Cp. El. 421(e)/k te tou=d' a)/nw), Tr. 462(h(/de t)), where the reason for retaining te is similar.
a)nt' a)ndrw=n: cp. 1020 dou=los.. a)nt' e)leuqe/rou.
e)/st)=e)/st' a)/n: cp. 555 e(/ws.. ma/qh|s.

ta/fou melhqei\s, after choosing and preparing a place of burial (1165). This aor. of the simple me/lomai does not elsewhere occur in a middle sense (in Anthol. 5. 201 melhqe/n in pass.), but e)pemelh/qhn as an aor. middle is frequent in
ka)\n mhdei\s e)a=|=ka)\n pa/ntes mh\-e)w=sin, though all men forbid (ou)k e)w= =veto). Cp. Ph. 443 f. o(/pou | mhdei\s e)w/|h.

div2.p: Third stasimon. 1st strophe, 1185—1191=1st antistr., 1192— 1198: 2nd str. 1199—1210=2nd ant. 1211—1222. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: ne/atos should be followed by a comma (as in some MSS.): the sense is, ti/s ne/atos e)te/wn a)riqmo\s (e)/stai), e)s po/te lh/cei e)te/wn a)riqmo/s; ‘what will be the last number (the completed total of the years),—when will the series of the years end?’—a)riqmo/s having a slightly different sense with ne/atos from that which it bears with e)s po/te. This difference is the reason against taking the sentence as two questions combined in one (like ti/s po/qen ei)=s a)ndrw=n;). The scholiast in L understood the construction aright:—ti/s a)/ra h(mi=n o( e)/sxatos tw=n e)tw=n a)riqmo\s tw=n polupla/gktwn; [Remark that he does not supply e)/stai—thus indicating that it is to be understood in the text also.] e)s po/te lh/cei o( a)riqmo\s tw=n e)tw=n e)moi\ po/nous paraskeua/zwn; For ne/atos in this sense, cp. Ant. 807 f.
polupla/gktwn, ‘muchwandering,’ ‘restless,’ refers to the toils of the campaign beyond sea; the epithet of the men is transferred to the years; cp. Od. 17. 425lh|sth=rsi polupla/gktoisin.
ta\n a)/pauston: for the art. (‘that ceaseless misery’), cp. El. 166to\n a)nh/nuton | oi)=ton e)/xousa kakw=n (n.).

dorussoh/twn, ‘spear-hurling,’ here=‘martial.’ dorusso/hs occurs nowhere else, but is related to dorusso/os as gumnh/s to gumno/s, kourh=tes to kou=roi, and it would certainly be rash to deny that metrical convenience could have suggested such a by-form. Blaydes and Wecklein change it to dorusso/wn, reading e)/deic) (instead of e)/deicen) in 1195. Nauck gives dorussw=n (further changing a)/pauston to a)pau/stan), and in 1196 omits the word koino/n. (Cp. O.C. 1313 dorussou=s *)amfia/rews.)

a)n ta\n eu)rw/dea *trwi+/an. This, the emendation of Ahrens, is very close to the MS. text, a)na\ ta\n eu)rw/dh *troi/an. There is no reason to doubt the metrical soundness of the antistrophic verse, 1197 i)w\ po/noi pro/gonoi po/nwn. Hence the correction of *troi/an to *trwi+/an has strong probability. Lobeck compares eu)rw/dhs (from eu)ru/s) with the late forms braxw/dhs, traxw/dhs. With regard to a)n (=a)na/), it should be noted that Sophocles uses this apocopè elsewhere only in compounds (cp. 416: Ant. 1275, n. on a)ntre/pwn).—For other emendations, see Appendix.
du/stanon o)/neidos *(ella/nwn, acc. in appos. with the sentence: cp. 559 xarmonh/n (n.), 1210 mnh/mata.
o)/fele: the unaugmented form is frequent in Homer: e.g. Od. 5. 308w(s dh\ e)gw/ g' o)/felon qane/ein.
ai)qe/ra du=nai me/gan, i.e., vanish into the depths of the sky, as if caught up by a(/rpuiai: cp. Eur. Or. 1375pa=| fu/gw, ce/nai, | polio\n ai)qe/r' a)mpta/menos h)\ po/nton;
polu/koinon *(/aidan: El. 137*)ai+/da | pagkoi/nou li/mnas (n.).

kei=nos a(nh\r, not Paris, but an indefinite person, the supposed inventor of war: cp. Tibull. 1. 10. 1 Quis fuit, horrendos primus qui protulit enses? | Quam ferus et vere ferreus ille fuit! C. 1. 3. 9 Illi robur et aes triplex | Circa pectus erat qui fragilem truci | Commisit pelago ratem | Primus.
e)/deicen, taught: Aesch. P. V. 457e)/ste dh/ sfin a)ntola\s e)gw\ | a)/strwn e)/deica.

koino\n *)/arh, ‘public’ warfare, in which all the Greeks make common cause (as against the Trojans): Thuc. 1. 3§ 1 pro\ ga\r tw=n *trwi+kw=n ou)de\n fai/netai pro/teron koinh=| e)rgasame/nh h( *(ella/s.

i)w\ po/noi pro/gonoi po/nwn. This is a parenthetic exclamation (cp. 173 f.): ‘Alas, those warlike toils (of the man who invented war), from which so many toils have sprung.’ Cp. the phrase in Legg. 928 E cumforai\..e)/xqras e)/kgonoi.—Dindorf writes i)w\ po/noi pro/ponoi (omitting po/nwn, as in 1190 he reads a)n' eu)rw/dh *troi+/an), ‘toils pre-eminent among toils’: cp. Aesch. Pers. 987kaka\ pro/kaka.

ou)/te stefa/nwn. ou)/te, the reading of the MSS., is sound; the fault is in the antistrophe (1211), where they give kai\ pri\n me\n e)nnuxi/ou, but this is satisfactorily cured by G. Wolff's correction; see n. on 1211.

stefa/nwn, the wreaths, usually of myrtle (murri/nai), with which the guests at a banquet crowned their heads before the spondai/ were poured and the po/tos began: Athen. p. 685 C h( de\ tw=n stefa/nwn kai\ mu/rwn pro/teron ei)/sodos ei)s ta\ sumpo/sia h(gei=to th=s deute/ras trape/zas. Ar. Ach. 1145pi/nein stefanwsame/nw|. Eur. Bacch. 376para\ kallistefa/nois | eu)frosu/nais.
baqeia=n, ‘copious’: see on ba/qei in 130.

kuli/kwn. The ku/lic was the commonest form of drinking-cup at Athens (cp. Plat. Symp. 214B e)pi\ th=| ku/liki le/gein). It was usually of earthenware (ku/lika kerame/an, Lys. 219 E), with a broad and relatively shallow bow] (hence compared to an a)spi/s, Athen. p. 472 C), a stem, and handles (w)=ta) projecting horizontally from the sides. The average ku/lic seems to have held about three kotu/lai, or between 1 1/3 and 1 1/2 pint.

nei=men governs te/ryin, to which o(milei=n is added as epexegetic inf., ‘for me to consort with’ (o(milei=n au)th=|): cp. Pind. N. 10. 72xalepa\ d' e)/ris a)nqrw/pois o(milei=n kresso/nwn (a strife with more than mortal foe is hard for men to encounter): id. Pind. I. 2. 37ai)doi=os me\n h)=n a)stoi=s o(milei=n.— Others take o(milei=n as depending on nei=men, and te/ryin as cogn. acc. (or ‘acc. of the inner object’): ‘gave me companionship in the joy of the wine-cup.’ But this somewhat forces the word o(milei=n.
au)lw=n, the flutes played at banquets by au)lhtri/des.
o)/tobon: cp. Aesch. P. V. 574khro/plastos o)tobei= do/nac. The word usu. denotes a loud noise, as the rattling of chariots ( Aesch. Theb. 151), or the crash of thunder (O.C. 1479).
du/smoros, ‘that wretch’: cp. 1290 du/sthne.

e)nnuxi/an te/ryin i)au/ein, ‘to pass the night in sweet repose.’ The inf. depends on nei=men, with te/ryin as cogn. acc.—The Homeric i)au/w means, not ‘to sleep,’ but ‘to pass the night’ or ‘bivouac’: see, e.g. Il. 9. 325a)u-/pnous nu/ktas i)/auon. It used to be connected with the rt. a)v (a)/w), ‘breathe’: but Leo Meyer, who converted G. Curtius on this point, has shown that i)au/w should be referred to a rt. a)ves, equivalent to the Sanskrit rt. vas (‘dwell’), whence the aorist a)/esa, Od. 3. 151nu/kta me
 a)e/samen (‘we abode’) xalepa\ fresi
 o(rmai/nontes. In the present i)au/w i is the reduplication. Curtius compares i)-a/-skein, an inchoative present from a)g, which Hesychius explains by a)/gein. (See Curtius Gk. Verb pp. 197, 520, 543.)—i)au/w occurs in postHomeric Greek of the classical age only here and in Soph. Ph. 1537 f. demni/ois | ... i)au/wn. [Eur. ] Rhes. 740 to
 u(paspi/dion koi=ton i)au/ei.
Remark the repetition of te/ryin (after 1201): it recurs in 1216. See n. on O.C. 554.
e)rw/twn d), e)rw/twn: for the iteration, cp. 621 (n.).

a)me/rimnos, ‘uncared for’: the pass. sense occurs only here, but may be illustrated by the use of a)khdh/s, which can be either passive or active; and by the passive sense of a)melh/s in H. 6. 5. 41, where it means, ‘neglected.’ Those who make a)me/rimnos active here explain it as=‘without occupation,’ ‘without any interest in life’; but this is clearly untenable.

ou(/tws strengthens the adj. (‘thus utterly uncared for’); cp. Aesch. Theb. 1056ge/nos w)le/sate pre/mnoqen ou(/tws. This is better than to take it as=‘simply,’ as in Plat. Gorg. 506D ou(/tws ei)kh=| [v.l. ou) tw=| ei)kh=|], like iacentes sic temere in C. 2. 11. 14.
dro/sois: the leimw/niai dro/soi of Aesch. Ag. 560(quoted above on 601 ff.).
mnh/mata, acc. in appos. with the sentence: cp. 1191 n. The miseries of the nightly bivouac never allow them to forget that they are in the dreary Troad.

ai)e\n nuxi/ou, G. Wolff's excellent emendation of e)nnuxi/ou, brings the verse into metrical agreement with 1199 e)kei=nos ou)/te stefa/nwn (n.). The corruption could easily arise from e)nnuxi/an above (1203). Keeping e)nnuxi/ou, Dindorf inserts e)c before it; but this remedy (though better than the Triclinian ou)=n) gives an unusual constr. to probola\, which regularly takes a simple genitive,—either of the thing defended (as xw/ras, M. 3. 5. 27), or of the thing which is warded off, as Eur. Or. 1488qana/tou probola/n: Plat. Tim. 74B probolh\..kauma/twn.— qou/rios, as in 212.

a)nei=tai stugerw=| dai/moni, has been consecrated, devoted, to it; i.e., has become its victim. Cp. Soph. Ph. 947ou(=tos de\ pw=los (Menoeceus), th=|d' a)neime/nos po/lei, | qanw\n patrw/|an gai=an e)ksw/seien a)/n. The word a)neime/nos was properly said of animals which, having been consecrated to a god, were allowed to roam at liberty in the pastures; Her. 2. 65tw=n de\ ei(/neken a)nei=tai ta\ i(ra\ (qhri/a) ei) le/goimi, katabai/hn a)\n tw=| lo/gw| ei)s ta\ qei=a prh/gmata: then the term was extended to inanimate things; Legg. 761 C ei)/ ti/ pou a)/lsos h)\ te/menos peri\ tau=ta a)neime/non h)=|. The young Ionin the Delphic temple is said to be a)/fetos, ‘consecrated’ to the god ( Eur. Ion 822: cp. Critias 119 D a)fe/twn o)/ntwn tau/rwn e)n tw=| tou= *poseidw=nos i(erw=|). Similarly the sacred horses of the German tribes publice aluntur..nullo mortali opere contacti (Tac. Germ. 10).
e)pe/stai, will ‘attend upon’ me; cp. El. 1467ei) d' e)/pesti ne/mesis (n.).
genoi/man: cp. Eur. Hipp. 732a)liba/tois u(po\ keuqmw=si genoi/man.

u(la=en. Colonel William Mure (the author of the well-known History of Greek Literature) remarks:—‘Sophocles calls Sunium a woody promontory, a description no longer applicable. But a few stunted fir bushes, straggling over the declivity below the temple, would seem still to vouch for its propriety in his own age.’ (Tour in Greece, vol. II. p. 123: 1842.)

e)/pesti po/ntou | pro/blhm): the genitive goes with pro/blhma: cp. Ph. 1455po/ntou probolh=s: Quintus Smyrn. 9. 378 e)pi\ probolh=|si qala/sshs. The scholiast confirms the reading of the MSS.: e)/nqa u(lw/dhs e)coxh\ th=s qala/tths e)sti/. With e)/pesti we understand po/ntw| from po/ntou. For e)/pesti after e)pe/stai in 1216, cp. Ant. 73, Ant. 76(kei/somai), Ant. 613, Ant. 618(e(/rpei).

u(po\ pla/ka *souni/ou: for the o_ of u(po\ before pl, cp. Ant. 612to\ pri/n.—Sunium, the S. E. promontory of Attica, is, in Leake's words, ‘lofty, steep, and rugged on every side, except the south-west, where there is a beach and a small bay, with an island at the entrance’ (Demi of Attica, vol. II. p. 63). On the highest point stood the Doric temple of Athena, built probably about the middle of the 5th century B.C. The modern name of the cape, Colonna (*kolo/nnais), is derived from the remaining columns of the temple, which are of a brilliant whiteness, the marble of which they are made being of a much lighter colour than the Pentelic. ‘As seen from a distance, glittering in the sun across the blue sea, they look like pillars of snow or salt, rather than stone’ (Mure, Tour II. p. 123). Cp. Eur. Cycl. 293h(/ te *souni/ou | di/as *)aqa/nas sw=s u(pa/rguros pe/tra (where the epithet alludes to the silver-mines of Laurium). Poseidon also was worshipped at Sunium (*sounia/rate, Ar. Eq. 560): but Leake was disposed to think that he can have had an altar only, as the sole buildings traceable were the temple of Athena and the fortress erected on Sunium circ. 413 B.C. (Demi II. p. 64). Wordsworth, however, saw remains which, he thought, might be those of a Poseidonion (Athens and Attica, p. 177).
ta\s i(era\s: so Pind. fr. 75. 4 e)n tai=s i(erai=s *)aqa/nais. Ar. Eq. 1319w)= tai=s i(erai=s fe/ggos *)aqh/nais: Timocreon fr. I. 3 i(era=n a)p' *)aqhna=n. Cp. El. 707*)aqhnw=n tw=n qeodmh/twn.

o(/pws … prosei/poimen, after the optative genoi/man (1217): Ph. 324qumo\n ge/noito xeiri\ plhrw=sai/ pote, | i(/n' ai( *mukh=nai gnoi=en k.t.l.: Aesch. Eum. 297e)lqoi... | o(/pws ge/noito k.t.l. (Sometimes, however, we find the subjunct. after such an optative: Eur. Or. 982mo/loimi...i(/n' e)n qrh/noisin a)mboa/sw.) For the custom of greeting the land to which one comes, cp. Aesch. Ag. 503: Verg. Aen. 3. 524Italiam laeto socii clamore salutant.

Pausanias says (1. 28. 2), referring to the colossal Athena Promachos on the Acropolis, h( tou= do/ratos ai)xmh\ kai\ o( lo/fos tou= kra/nous a)po\ *souni/ou prosple/ousi/n e)stin h)/dh su/nopta. As Leake observed (Demi I. p. 631), Cape Zoster, some miles N.W. of Sunium, is the first point on the Attic coast from which a voyager could possibly have caught a glimpse of the spear-point and crest.

div2.p: The exodos falls into three parts. 1. The scene between Teucer and Agamemnon: 1223—1315. 2. The mediation of Odysseus: 1316— 1401. 3. Preparations for the burial of Ajax: 1402—end.

div3.p: kai\ mh\n: 1168 n.
h(mi=n, a ‘dativus incommodi,’—‘to trouble us.’— dh=los, in the personal constr. with partic., as O.T. 673, Ph. 1011.(With w(s added, above, Ph. 326 n.)
mou)sti\: for the crasis, cp. Ph. 812w(s ou) qe/mis g' e)mou)/sti sou= molei=n a)/ter.

skaio\n … sto/ma. The notion of skaio/s here is that of headstrong perversity, unrestrained by good sense or good feeling; cp. Eur. fr. 290 a)ei\ ga\r a)/ndra skaio/n, i)sxuro\n fu/sei, | h(=sson de/doika ta)sqenou=s te kai\ sofou=. Dem. or. 18 § 120 skaio\s..kai\ a)nai/sqhtos.
e)klu/swn: Isocr. or. 12 § 96 e)pelh/luqe/ moi to\ parrhsia/zesqai kai\ le/luka to\ sto/ma. Eur. Hipp. 1060ti/ dh=ta tou)mo\n ou) lu/w sto/ma; Cp. Eur. Bacch. 385a)xali/nwn stoma/twn.

se\ dh\: the abrupt acc., roughly calling the attention of the person addressed, is sometimes used even without a governing verb, as in Ant. 441se\ dh/, se\ th\n neu/ousan e)s pe/don ka/ra, | fh/s, k.t.l.
ta\ deina\ r(h/mat', ‘those terrible words’: 312 n.

a)noimwkti\, impune, like a)klau/stw| in El. 912.Cp. Ar. Ran. 178ou)k oi)mw/cetai; The adverb ends in i, not ei, as presupposing an adj. in -os: for these adverbial forms, see n. on O.C. 1251 a)stakti/.
xanei=n r(h/mata, like Aesch. Ag. 920bo/ama prosxa/nh|s: Vesp. 341 tou=t' e)to/lmhs' o( miaro\s xanei=n; Attius Armorum Iudicium fr. 11 Hem, vereor plus quam fas est captivum hiscere.
se/ toi: cp. El. 1445se/ toi, se\ kri/nw: Ar. Av. 274ou(=tos, w)= se/ toi.
to\n e)k th=s is better than the v.l. se\ to\n th=s, since e)k lays an intentionally scornful emphasis on Teucer's origin.
trafei\s = ei) e)tra/fhs.— mhtro\s … a)/po: e)k is usu. said of parents, a)po/ (as in 202) of ancestors; but cp. O.C. 571 ka)f' o(/tou patro\s gegw/s. ( Ant. 192 f., n.)
u(yh/l' e)fw/neis is a choicer phrase, and marks the irony better, than the v.l. u(yh/l' e)ko/mpeis.

ka)p' a)/krwn w(doipo/reis: schol. e)p' a)/krwn daktu/lwn e)/baines gauriw=n. Eur. Ion 1166 f. e)n d' a)/kroisi ba\s posi\n | kh=ruc a)nei=pe (describing the proud gait of the herald). Lobeck compares Libanius 4. 162 e)p' a)/krwn poreu/esqai, and a)krobatei=n ‘to strut’ in Philo De Somn. 1. 60.
o(/te in its causal sense,=e)peidh/ (O.T. 918 n.).

ou)de
 w)
, ‘being naught’ (a simple statement): tou= mhde
 … u(/per, ‘for him who is as naught.’ The only difference between the two expressions is that the phrase with mhde/n is, in effect, somewhat more emphatic, and (here) more bitter, since it implies a mental act of comparison, with the result of deciding that this particular person is no more than a nonentity. The angry king scorns Teucer, but his bitterness is against the dead Ajax. The phrase with ou)de
 is, of course, equally applicable to the dead ( El. 244, El. 1129), and that with mhde
 to the living (above, El. 767, cp. 1275). Cp. 1114 tou\s mhde/nas (n.).

kou)/te strathgou\s k.t.l. Agamemnon speaks throughout of ‘us,’ meaning Menelaüs and himself. Teucer had implicitly acknowledged that Agamemnon was commander-in-chief (1105). But he denied that Menelaüs had any authority over Ajax (1100), and also that either of the two Atreidae had a right to forbid the burial (1109).
ou)/te naua/rxous: alluding to Teucer's denial that Ajax had sailed from Salamis at the summons, or under the command, of Menelaüs (1097, 1111 f.).

*)axaiw=n ou)/te sou=: another ou)/te is understood before *)axaiw=n: cp. Ant. 266to\ mh/te dra=sai mh/te tw| cuneide/nai | to\ pra=gma bouleu/santi mh/t' ei)rgasme/nw|, i.e. (mh/te) bouleu/santi etc. (cp. O.T. 239 n.): Aesch. Ag. 532*pa/ris ga\r ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis. It is needless to read ou)de\ sou=.
diwmo/sw; the prep. gives emphasis, as in Tr. 378diw/mnuto.

au)to\s a)/rxwn … e)/plei: the imperf. serves to mark the position which Ajax was holding at the time when he was setting forth. Similarly in Ph. 572pro\s poi=on au)= to/nd' au)to\s ou(dusseu\s e)/plei; the imperf. refers to the motive which was actuating him. (Cp. ka)pempo/mhn in El. 680, and n. in append. there, p. 213.)
dou/lwn, i.e., Teucer as the son of an ai)xmalwti/s: cp. 1020 dou=los.. fanei/s.
poi/ou ke/kragas a)ndro\s: for the gen., cp. El. 317tou= kasignh/tou ti/ fh/s; (n.).

poi= ba/ntos. pou= ba/ntos has the better MS. authority; in a question, however, between i and u, little weight can be claimed for our MSS. If ba/ntos meant, ‘having taken his stand,’ then pou= ba/ntos would be as correct as pou= bebhko/tos. But when, as here, ba/ntos is opposed to sta/ntos, it is very improbable that a writer of the classical age would have used pou= rather than poi=. Cp. Ph. 833pou= sta/sei, | poi= de/ moi...ba/sei. It cannot be argued from such an example as Eur. Hec. 1057, pa=| bw=, pa=| stw=, that there was a tendency to repeat the same word, since pa=| (unlike pou= or poi=) suits both verbs alike.
a)/ndres, emphatic, like a)nh\r in 77.
pikrou\s, to our cost: El. 470pikra\n | dokw= me pei=ran th/nde tolmh/sein e)/ti (n.).

e)/oigmen, for e)oi/kamen, occurs also in Eur. Heracl. 681, Eur. Cycl. 99. Eur. Itis not found in the Homeric poems, but may be compared with e)pe/piqmen ( Il. 2. 341), ei)lh/louqmen ( Il. 9. 49), and a)/nwgmen (Hom. hymn. Apoll. Pyth. 350).
o(/plwn a)gw=nas: the objective gen. here denotes the prize: cp. 936 o(/plwn e)/keit' a)gw\n pe/ri.— khru=cai, instead of the usual qei=nai: cp. El. 690o(/swn ga\r ei)sekh/rucan brabh=s k.t.l.
to/te: 650 n.
pantaxou=, ‘in every case,’— i.e., whenever the result of the contest is disappointing to Teucer. Cp. Ph. 1052nika=n ge me/ntoi pantaxou= xrh/|zwn e)/fun.— fanou/meq): 1020 n.
e)k *teu/krou, on his part: cp. O.C. 51 kou)k a)/timos e)/k g' e)mou= fanei=.

kou)k a)rke/sei, not mhd), though ei) precedes, for ou)k a)rke/sei is felt rather as a statement of that which is sure to happen, than as a hypothesis. Similarly ou) often stands in the second of two clauses after deino
 ei) or the like: Thuc. 1. 121§ 5 deino
 a)
 ei)/h ei)...ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen: Lys. or. 10 § 13 ou)k ou)=n deino/n, ei)...ou)k a)cioi=s.

ei)/kein a(\ … h)/resken. The antecedent to a(/ is tau=ta, a cognate acc.,—‘to yield in regard to’ what the judges decided: cp. O. C. 1178ta/d' ei)kaqei=n: ib. 172 ei)/kontas a(\ dei=.—Others suppose the antecedent to be tou/tois (cp. 1050). But, for Greek idiom, such a dat. ought to denote the judges, not the judgment.
kakoi=s balei=te: cp. 724 o)nei/desin | h)/rasson (n.): Tr. 940w(/s nin matai/ws ai)ti/a| ba/loi kakh=|.

su
 do/lw|: cp. El. 641su
 fqo/nw|: Ph. 842su
 yeu/desin.
kenth/seq). In Ant. 1030, too, ke/ntei is figurative,—meaning to inflict a base wrong (on the dead).

oi( leleimme/noi, ye who have been left behind in the race. Cp. Tr. 266tw=n w(=n te/knwn lei/poito pro\s to/cou kri/sin: Aesch. Pers. 339th=|de leifqh=nai ma/xh|. Polyb. 1. 62 § 6 ble/pein to/n te tou= nika=n o(moi/ws de\ kai\ to\n tou= lei/pesqai kairo/n.
e)k tw=nde … tw=n tro/pwn, as a result of them.
kata/stasis: there may be nomoqesi/a, but no firm establishment of a law can come to pass. Cp. 1074: Ant. 1113tou\s kaqestw=tas no/mous.
tou\s … nikw=ntas: for the pres. partic., cp. Xen. Cyr. 8. 2. 27o( de\ mh\ nikw=n toi=s me\n nikw=sin e)fqo/nei.

e)cwqh/somen, thrust him out of the honourable place which he has fairly wo<*> The fut. w)qh/sw occurs also in Eur. Cycl. 592, Ar. Eccl. 300, but the ordinary future of w)qe/w is w)/sw (as if from w)/qw).

tou\s o)/pisqen: a metaphor from rear and front rank suits the speaker. Cp. Her. 8. 89(describing the confusion in the Persian fleet at Salamis), oi( o)/pisqe tetagme/noi e)s to\ pro/sqe th=|si nhusi\ parie/nai peirw/menoi.
ei)rkte/on ta/d): cp. 1140.— platei=s, ‘burly,’ ‘big’; eu)ru/nwtoi ‘broadshouldered.’ Ajax was e)/coxos *)argei/wn kefalh/n te kai\ eu)re/as w)/mous ( Il. 3. 227).
oi( fronou=ntes eu)=: for the place of eu)=, cp. Ant. 723kai\ tw=n lego/ntwn eu)= kalo\n to\ manqa/nein.—As to the verse which the paroemiographer Apostolius subjoins to this, see Appendix.
u(po\ … poreu/etai: so Tr. 391ou)k e)mw=n u(p' a)gge/lwn | a)ll' au)to/klhtos e)k do/mwn poreu/etai.
smikra=s, in contrast with the ‘large ribs.’ Cp. Ant. 477smikrw=| xalinw=| d' oi)=da tou\s qumoume/nous | i(/ppous katartuqe/ntas.

o)rqo\s, ‘it is brought straight into the road’ (from which it has strayed): cp. Helen. 1555 tau/reios de\ pou\s | ou)k h)/qel' o)rqo\s sani/da prosbh=nai ka/ta, ‘to advance straight across the plank’ (into the ship).

fa/rmakon, ‘corrective,’ th\n ma/stiga. Cp. O.C. 714 i(/ppoisin to\n a)kesth=ra xalino/n. So the bit for Pegasus, given by Athena to Bellerophon, is fi/ltron to/d' i(/ppeion ( Pind. O. 13. 68), fa/rmakon prau_/ (ib. 85).
nou=n katakth/sei: cp. Plat. Rep. 591B (h( yuxh\) swfrosu/nhn.. ktwme/nh. So kth=ma is said of moral or mental attributes (O.T. 549, Ant. 1050). tina/, ironical, some small measure of it.

a)ndro\s ou)ke/t' o)/ntos, genitive absolute. The genitive could not depend on u(bri/zeis, in the sense of ‘uttering insults about him’ (like poi/ou ke/kragas a)ndro\s in 1236). The constr. with gen. absolute (‘when he is dead’) is also more forcible. Reiske's conjecture (a)/ndras..o)/ntas..skia/s) is ingenious; but here the plural is evidently less fitting than in a general allusion like e)n qanou=sin u(bristh/s (1092).
skia=s: cp. El. 1158a)nti\ filta/ths | morfh=s spodo/n te kai\ skia\n a)nwfelh=.
ou) swfronh/seis; Cp. Ph. 1259e)swfro/nhsas (‘thou hast come to thy senses’).

maqw
 o(\s ei)= fu/sin, i.e. dou=los. In O.T. 1068 mh/pote gnoi/hs o(\s ei)=, and O.C. 1171 e)/coid' a)kou/wn tw=nd' o(/s e)sq' o( prosta/ths, where o(/s stands, as here, for o(/stis, the reference is to the person's identity; here it is to his quality (=oi(=os ei)=), as in Eur. Alc. 640e)/deicas ei)s e)/legxon e)celqw
 o(\s ei)=: Plat. Euthyd. 283D bou/lesqe gene/sqai au)to
 sofo/n, a)maqh= de\ mh\ ei)=nai;...ou)kou=n o(\s me
 ou)k e)/sti, bou/lesqe au)to
 gene/sqai, o(\s d' e)/sti nu=n, mhke/ti ei)=nai.

a)/llon tin' … e)leu/qeron, some one else, who (unlike thee) is a free man. Cp. Od. 6. 84a(/ma th=| ge (with their mistress) kai\ a)mfi/poloi ki/on a)/llai. Plat. Gorg. 473C tw=n politw=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn ce/nwn.

a)nti\ sou= le/cei ta\ sa/. At Athens, as elsewhere, a slave had no locus standi in a law-court, and could plead to a charge only through his master. Cp. frag. adesp. 304 (Nauck p. 897) dou=los pe/fukas, ou) me/testi/ soi lo/gou. In Plat. Gorg. 483B incapacity for self-defence generally (au)to\s au(tw=| bohqei=n) is noted as characteristic of the servile condition. Cp. O.T. 410 f. (n.), where Teiresias says that he is not the dou=los of Oedipus, and therefore has the right i)/s' a)ntile/cai, instead of pleading only by Creon's mouth.

sou= … le/gontos could depend on ma/qoim) as=‘understand’ ( Plat. Gorg. 463D a)=r' ou)=n a)\n ma/qois a)pokriname/nou;), but is better taken as gen. abs., since thus we obtain a clearer sense for ou)ke/t): ‘when thou beginnest to speak, my power of comprehension ceases.’
ba/rbaron, because Teucer's mother Hesionè was Trojan.

e)pai+/w, a current word in Attic ( Nub. 650 etc.), is used in this sense by Plato both with acc. and with gen. The simple a)i+/w, which is poetical only, has a like sense in O.C. 181, su\ ga\r a)i+/eis (‘for thou understandest’).
fra/sai, monstrare, or suadere; cp. Tr. 53fra/sai to\ so/n, to indicate thy duty. So of a teacher's directions, Antiphon or. 6 § 13 ei)/ ti fra/zoi o( dida/skalos.
w(s taxei=a/ tis, ‘in what quick fashion’ (with what strange quickness): cp. O.T. 618 o(/tan taxu/s tis ou(pibouleu/wn la/qra| | xwrh=|, ‘when the stealthy plotter is advancing in quick fashion.’
brotoi=s, ethic dat., ‘in the minds of men.’
diarrei=: said in fr. 787. 9 of the waning moon; diarrei= ka)pi\ mhde\n e)/rxetai. Cp. 523 a)porrei= mnh=stis.

prodou=s' a(li/sketai. Here xa/ris tou= qano/ntos is that grateful memory of the dead which ought to abide in men's minds. When this memory deserts them, it is a traitor to the dead. Cp. Ant. 46ou) ga\r dh\ prodou=s' a(lw/somai.

ou)d' e)pi\ smikrw=n lo/gwn. In El. 415smikroi\ lo/goi mean ‘few’ or ‘brief’ words. Probably the sense here is, ‘not even in brief words.’ This use of e)pi/ with the genitive is illustrated by two passages which Wolff has quoted; Plat. Symp. 192C e(/teros e(te/rw| xai/rei cunw
 ou(/tws e)pi\ mega/lhs spoudh=s (‘with such great eagerness’): Dem. or. 18 § 17 ou)/te dikai/ws ou)/t' e)p' a)lhqei/as ou)demia=s ei)rhme/na (‘nor with any truth’). Julian or. 3. 128 A (quoted by Lobeck) has tou/twn e)pi\ smikrw=n mnhmoneu/ei, meaning by e)pi\ smikrw=n ‘in brief words only.’ (In El. 414e)pi\ smikro
=‘to a small extent only’: the v.l. e)pi\ smikrw=n is there an error.) I formerly took e)pi\ smikrw=n lo/gwn as=‘not even in slight respects,’ ‘on slight accounts,’ but now doubt whether this sense can be given to the plural of lo/gos.—The best emendation, if any were needed, would be ou)d' e)pi\ smikro
 lo/gon, ‘not even to the extent of a brief mention’; but, though e)pi\ smikro
 can bear this sense ( El. 414), the phrase is hardly satisfactory when lo/gon is added.

ou(= depends on prou)/kames: dori/ should be taken with protei/nwn. Cp. [Eur. ] Rhes. 183 yuxh
 proba/llont' e)n ku/boisi dai/monos. There is a reminiscence of the words of Achilles, ai)e
 e)mh
 yuxh
 paraballo/menos polemi/zein ( Il. 9. 322).
e)rrimme/na, contemptuously flung aside: cp. Aesch. Eum. 215*ku/pris d' a)/timos tw=|d' a)pe/rriptai lo/gw|.

ka)no/ht) seems fitter here than ka)no/nht): though its superiority is not so clear as that of ka)no/nhta over ka)no/hta in 758. The balance of manuscript authority, too, is here on the side of ka)no/ht), though there is no such unanimity as supports ka)no/nhta in 758,—a difference which the nature of the two passages sufficiently explains.

ou) mnhmoneu/eis … ou)de/n (adv.), h(ni/ka, as we say, ‘remember when...’: so Thuc. 2. 21§ 1 memnhme/noi kai\ *pleistoa/nakta..o(/te e)sbalw\n..a)nexw/rhse pa/lin: Eur. Tro. 70oi)=d' h(ni/k' *ai)/as ei(=lke *kassa/ndran bi/a.

e(rke/wn … e)gkeklh|me/nous, ‘shut within your lines.’ Cp. Soph. Ph. 451to/nd' ei)sede/cw teixe/wn=ei)/sw teixe/wn e)de/cw. There, as here, the genitive would probably be felt in the first instance as a genitive of place (‘at the walls,’ like e)sxa/ths.. pura=s in Soph. El. 900 f.); and the special sense required by the context (‘within’) would be suggested by the compound verb ei)sede/cw.

e(rke/wn: the wall, surrounded by a fosse, which the Greeks at Troy built to protect their ships, drawn up on the shore of the Hellespont. Il. 12. 4tei=xos u(/perqen | eu)ru/, to\ poih/santo new=n u(/per, a)mfi\ de\ ta/fron | h)/lasan.

to\ mhde
 o)/ntas: so Tr. 1107ka)

 w)=, ‘though I am as naught.’ Cp. 1281 n.
e)n troph=| doro/s, at the moment when your battle had been turned back,—when you had been routed. Cp. Ant. 674(a)narxi/a) summa/xou doro\s | tropa\s katarrh/gnusi. Aesch. Ag. 1237e)n ma/xhs troph=|.
a)mfi\ me\n new=n … e(dwli/ois: ‘when fire was now blazing around the quarter-decks of the ships at their sterns (a)/kroisin).’ Three points should be noted.

(1) There is strong evidence that the term e(dw/lia was used in the 5th cent. B.C. to denote a raised deck, a quarter-deck, at the stern of the ship. This is clear in Her. 1. 24: Arion asks leave, sta/nta e)n toi=si e(dwli/oisi a)ei=sai: the officers of the ship consent, and are then said a)naxwrh=sai e)k th=s pru/mnhs e)s me/shn ne/a,— leaving Arion alone on the e(dw/lia. In Helen. 1571, *(ele/nh kaqe/zet' e)n me/sois e(dwli/ois: which is clearly a place distinct from that where the rowers sat; of them it is said, toi/xous deciou\s laiou/s t' i)/soi | a)nh\r par' a)/ndr' e(/zonto. (For further evidence on this point, see Appendix.)

(2) a)/kroisin denotes the position of the e(dw/lia at the extremities, or sterns, of the ships. Though the Iliad is not closely followed here, Sophocles may probably have had in mind how the Trojans fired the ship of Protesilaüs at the stern: Il. 16. 124w(\s th\n me\n pru/mnhn pu=r a)/mfepen. In Il. 9. 241 it is said of Hector, steu=tai ga\r nhw=n a)poko/yein a)/kra ko/rumba,—the ‘crowning ensigns’ (a)/flasta, aplustria) at the sterns. a)/kroisin might also mean ‘topmost,’—the e(dw/lia being a raised deck. This, however, would suggest rather flames shooting up to a great height; but in Il. 15. 716 f., where Hector grasps the a)/flaston, it appears that even this can have been only some 7 to 9 feet from the ground, and that the i)/kria at the stern (the Homeric equivalent of e(dw/lia here) can have stood only about 5 feet from the ground. (See Dr Warre E. in Smith's Dict. of Ant., 3rd ed., vol. II. p. 211 b, art. Navis.)

(3) nautikoi=s, after new=n, is pleonastic, if e(dw/lia be explained as above; whereas, if e(dw/lia meant the rowers' seats, nautikoi=s could mean, belonging to the nau=tai. This is a fair objection to the interpretation given above. But in reply to it we may observe:—(1) the word e(dw/lia means ‘dwellings,’ ‘abodes’ in El. 1393, Aesch. Ch. 71, Aesch. Theb. 455.The nautical sense occurs (apart from Her. 1. 24) only here, and in Helen. 1571, Cycl. 238.Hence the distinctive epithet is intelligible. (2) Further, as the purport of the passage is to mark the urgency of the danger to the ships, on which the ultimate safety of the Greeks depended, there is excuse for the emphatic iteration, new=n —nautikoi=s—nautika/.
Other views of the passage, and some emendations which have been proposed, will be found in the Appendix.

ei)s de\ nautika\ ska/fh … ta/frwn u(/per. The situation described here does not exactly correspond with anything in the Iliad. Ajax, indeed, distinguishes himself in repulsing the Trojans after they have come over the wall, and on one occasion wounds their leader Hector ( Il. 14. 409 ff.); but this happens before any ship has been set on fire. The supreme crisis in this part of the Iliad is the moment when the Trojans set fire to the ship of Protesilaüs (16. 122); but just then Ajax is driven back (xa/zeto d' e)k bele/wn ib.); it is Patroclus who, urged by Achilles, then comes to the front, and finally beats back the foe. Nor has the Iliad directly furnished the picture of Hector ‘leaping high’ over the trench.

Sophocles may have had some other source, epic or lyric. But it seems equally possible that he wrote from a general recollection of the Iliad, without caring whether he reproduced its details. Indeed, two verses of the Iliad might alone have sufficed to suggest the picture which he has drawn,—that which says of Ajax, *trw=as a)/mune new=n, o(/stis fe/roi a)ka/maton pu=r (15. 731),—and the verse which describes Hector leading the Trojans from the Greek wall towards the ships,—h(=| r() o(/ g' o( lussw/dhs flogi\ ei)/kelos h(gemoneu/ei (13. 53).

ou(= su\ mh/, bh=nai podi/. This excellent emendation (by Madvig) of the obscure ou)de\ sumbh=nai podi/ is irresistibly commended by those very words of Agamemnon to which Teucer refers (1237), poi= ba/ntos h)\ pou= sta/ntos, ou(=per ou)k e)gw/; The origin of the corruption may have been the effacement of the H in MH, giving rise to *s*u*m*b*h*n*a*i, when *o*u would be altered into *o*u*d*e to satisfy the metre. sumbh=nai podi/ has been explained: (1) ‘to come and join thee’ on the field of danger. But, even if sumbh=nai podi/ could bear this sense, Agam. could not say that Ajax had never fought on his side at Troy. (2) ‘To meet’ the foe, sc. toi=s polemi/ois: which is plainly untenable. Agamemnon had asked merely, ‘what has Ajax done that I have not done?’ Teucer has replied by referring to the crisis at the ships; and now drives his point home.
u(mi\n … e)/ndika, just in your eyes (ethic dat.): cp. O.C. 1446 a)na/ciai ga\r pa=si/n e)ste dustuxei=n: Soph. Ph. 495sofoi=s | kai\ toi=si fau/lois e)/ndix), w(s e)moi\ dokei=.

au)to\s, ‘by himself,’ ‘alone’: cp. Ar. Ach. 504au)toi\ ga/r e)smen.— mo/nos mo/nou: though au)to/s has preceded, mo/nos is added to emphasise the idea of single combat. Cp. 467 mo/nos mo/nois: Dem. or. 18 § 137 tw=| u(po\ tw=n polemi/wn pemfqe/nti mo/nos mo/nw| sunh/|ei.

laxw/n te ka)ke/leustos: i.e., simply because, among the Greek warriors who had offered to meet Hector, he was the one who drew the lot; not because he had been urged to undertake the task. laxw/n implies e(kw/n, since lots were drawn only for those who had volunteered.

This combat between Hector and Ajax is told in Iliad 7. 38—312. Hector having challenged a Greek champion, nine Greek chiefs offered themselves; lots were cast, and the honour fell to Ajax. Hector and Ajax fought till nightfall, when they were parted by heralds, and exchanged gifts (1029 n.).

ou) drape/thn k.t.l. The ordinary klh=ros was a stone or a potsherd, which its owner marked ( Il. 7. 175klh=ron e)shmh/nanto e(/kastos). Ajax did not seek to avoid being drawn by putting in, as his klh=ros, a piece of damp earth, which would stick to the bottom of the helmet or fall to pieces. Such a klh=ros is called drape/ths, ‘a runaway,’ because it eludes the ordeal. The allusion is to the story of Cresphontes. After the Dorian conquest of the Peloponnesus, he, Temenus, and the heirs of Aristodemus agreed to cast lots. The first was to have Argos; the second, Lacedaemon; the third, Messenia. Cresphontes wished to have Messenia. He therefore put a lump of earth, as his klh=ros, into the voting urn. It broke to pieces, so that only the two other klh=roi came out. ( Apollod. 2. 8. 4gh=s e)ne/bale bw=lon, tau/ths de\ dialuqei/shs e)/dei tou\s du/o klh/rous a)nafanh=nai.) The scholiast remarks on the anachronism (a)nh=ktai toi=s xro/nois h( i(stori/a h( peri\ *kresfo/ntou): so, too, does Eustathius (p. 361. 26).

e)s me/son kaqei/s. me/son has been suspected; Nauck writes krwsso\n (‘urn’). But the literal sense is simply, ‘having cast down into the midst’—the competitors being imagined as standing round the kunh=. Cp. the phrases ei)s me/son tiqe/nai, ei)s to\ me/son fe/rein, etc.
kunh=s: Il. 7. 182e)k d' e)/qoren klh=ros kune/hs, o(\n a)/r' h)/qelon au)toi/, | *ai)/antos.— a(/lma koufiei=n=a(/lma kou=fon a(lei=sqai. Cp. Eur. El. 860ou)ra/nion | ph/dhma koufi/zousa.

su\n d' e)gw\ parw/n. tau=ta includes the combat with Hector, in which Teucer, of course, had no part; but he was the comrade of Ajax in the teixomaxi/a ( Il. 15. 436 ff.), as often on other occasions (e.g., Il. 7. 266 ff.). For su\n as adv., cp. 959.
o( dou=los: cp. 1260.

du/sthne: cp. 1203 du/smoros.— poi= ble/pwn, ‘whither canst thou be looking?’ i.e., ‘how canst thou be so blind?’ [Not: ‘in reliance on what?’—like ei)s o(/ ti ble/pw in 514.] We should distinguish this poi= ble/pwn from pw=s ble/pwn, ‘with what face?’ ( Ph. 110: O.T. 1371 o)/mmasin poi/ois ble/pwn).
kai\ qroei=s: kai/ emphasizes the verb: ‘how canst thou utter the words?’ Cp. O.T. 1129 poi=on a)/ndra kai\ le/geis; Lys. or. 12 § 29 para\ tou= pote kai\ lh/yesqe di/khn;

Construe: ou)k oi)=sqa a)rxai=on *pe/lopa, o(\s sou= patro\s path\r prou)/fu, o)/nta ba/rbaron, *fru/ga; The phrase a)rxai=on *pe/lopa, ‘Pelops of old,’ indicates him as the founder of Agamemnon's royal house. Others take a)rxai=on adverbially with o)/nta ba/rbaron, ‘a barbarian by origin.’ But such a use of a)rxai=os is strange, and seems to be without parallel.

*fru/ga: the term is used invidiously, but is not incorrect. Sipylus, the legendary seat of Tantalus, father of Pelops, was in Maeonia, afterwards called Lydia; but Phrygia, in the older and larger sense, included that region. (Cp. Ant. 824 where Niobe, daughter of Tantalus, is ta\n *frugi/an.) In Her. 7. 11Xerxes speaks of *pe/loy o( *fru/c.
dussebe/staton could go with (1) *)atre/a, (2) se, or (3) dei=pnon. As the guilt of Atreus is the point, (2) is less relevant, and (3) is perhaps best.

a)delfw=| Thyestes. Atreus, seeking revenge for certain grievous wrongs, feigned to have forgiven him, and bade him to a feast at Mycenae. There the flesh of three of his sons was set before Thyestes. In Aesch. Ag. 1591Aegisthus (a son of Thyestes) says: *)atreu\s proqu/mws ma=llon h)\ fi/lws patri\ | tw)mw=|, kreourgo\n h)=mar eu)qu/mws a)/gein | dokw=n, pare/sxe dai=ta paidei/wn krew=n. Schol. Eur. Or. 812(alluding to the *)atreu\s h)\ *mukhnai=ai of Sophocles), tou\s trei=s ui(ou\s tou= *que/stou, *)aglao\n *)orxo/menon kai\ *ka/leon, a)poktei/nas pare/qhken ei)s tra/pezan tw=| patri/.

*krh/sshs: Aëropè, daughter of Catreus, king of Crete, a descendant of Minos. According to the legend which Sophocles follows here, Catreus found Aëropè with a paramour (a slave), and sent her to Nauplius, king of Euboea, charging him to drown her. Nauplius, however, spared her life, and she afterwards married Atreus. The scholiast on 1297 says that this was the story treated by Euripides in the *krh=ssai (Nauck Trag. Frag. p. 501); with the difference, however, that Aëropè married Pleisthenes, not Atreus. The *krh=ssai was produced in 438 B.C. (Argum. Eur. Alc.)

e)pakto
, ‘imported,’ ‘alien’; Tr. 259strato
..e)pakto/n, cp. O. C. 1525 n.: Eur. Ion 592patro/s t' e)paktou= kau)to\s w)
 noqagenh/s (bastard son of the alien Xuthus): here, a paramour, as opposed to a lawful husband.

o( fitu/sas path/r can mean only the father of Aëropè, Catreus. Now, according to the schol. on Eur. Or. 812, Sophocles (in a play not named there, but which was probably the *)atreu\s h)\ *mukhnai=ai) somewhere described Atreus himself as drowning his false wife for a twofold crime,—adultery with Thyestes, and the theft of the golden lamb: th
 gunai=ka *)aero/phn timwrei=tai kat' a)/mfw...r(i/yas au)th
 ei)s th
 qa/lassan, w(s fhsi\ *sofoklh=s. Hence it has been proposed to change path into s' *)atreu\s (Hermann), or s' a)nh (Wolff). A simpler correction would be, o( s' e)kfu/sas path/r. But it cannot be assumed that Sophocles must have followed here the same version which he used elsewhere. In his *)alh/ths, for example, he appears to have modified the version of the *)orestei/a which he adopts in his Electra (see El., Introd., p. xliii, n. 4). The story of Aëropè's detection by Catreus is effective for the purpose here, which is to represent Agamemnon as born of a mother who had sinned before his birth. Nor is that story necessarily inconsistent with the other, that she was false to Atreus, and was drowned by him.

e)fh=ken … diafqora/n, ‘consigned her as a prey,’ since he charged Nauplius to drown her,—though the charge was not executed. Schol.: o( path\r *naupli/w| pare/dwken, e)nteila/menos a)popontw=sai: o( de\ ou)k e)poi/hsen.—Cp. Eur. H. F. 458e)te/k- omen u(ma=s: polemi/ois d' e)qreya/mhn | u(/brisma ka)pi/xarma kai\ diafqora/n.

e)lloi=s, traditionally explained as ‘mute,’ is a word of unknown origin. In Athen. 277 C this verse is quoted, and the question is raised whether any one before Sophocles had used the word: the answer is a quotation from a *titanomaxi/a (variously ascribed to Eumêlus or Arctînus), e)n d' au)th=| plwtoi\ xrusw/pides i)xqu/es e)lloi/: with the comment, e)/xaire de\ *sofoklh=s tw=| *)epikw=| ku/klw|. The form e)/lloy occurs in Scut. 212 (e)/llopas i)xqu=s), and as a subst. (‘fish’) in the Alexandrian poets (Lycophron 598, 1375: Nicander Alex. 481). A third form, e)/llopos, is the epithet of i)xqu/s in Empedocles, v. 12. A desperate etymology is suggested in Athen. 307 C, from i)/llesqai (as=ei)/rgesqai) and o)/y, ‘debarred from utterance.’ Cp. Aesch. Pers. 578sku/llontai pro\s a)nau/dwn, e)h/, | pai/dwn ta=s a)mia/ntou.
e)k patro\s me\n, as if e)k de\ mhtro\s were to follow, but the constr. changes; cp. Tr. 6h(/tis patro\s me\n k.t.l. (where no de/ follows).
o(/stis with causal force, ‘one who..’
ta\ prw=t), an adverbial cognate acc., like pa/nt' a)risteu/sas ( Ant. 195).
i)/sxei, historic pres., referring to a well-known fact (cp. O. T. 560e)/rrei: Ph. 727qeoi=s pla/qei).
fu/sei me\n: the antithesis is with e)/kkriton de/: as her birth was royal, so her beauty marked her out to be his prize.
basi/leia: for the initial anapaest, cp. 1172.

*laome/dontos, his daughter; cp. 172 *dio\s *)/artemis (n.). For the anapaest in the proper name, cp. Ant. 11, O. C. 507.—Apollo and Poseidon having been defrauded by Laomedon of their recompense for building the walls of Troy, the sea-god sent a dragon into the Troad. Hesionè, the false king's daughter, was doomed to be sacrificed to the monster, when Heracles slew it, and saved her. He, too, was cheated by Laomedon of his promised reward (the horses given to Tros by Zeus); he sacked Troy, and gave Hesionè to Telamon. ( Il. 5. 638 ff.: Pind. I. 5. 27 ff.)

e)/kkriton, chosen out of the spoil, and reserved as a special meed of honour: cp. Aesch. Ag. 954(of Cassandra) au(/th de/, pollw=n xrhma/twn e)cai/reton | a)/nqos, stratou= dw/rhm), e)moi\ cune/speto. So in Latin exsors, Verg. Aen. 8. 552Ducunt exsortem Aeneae (equum).

a)/ristos combines the ideas of to\ gennai=on and to\ eu)gene/s: cp. 636 e)k patrw/|as h(/kwn genea=s a)/ristos. The conjecture a)risteu\s is needless, and is also less suitable, since it would imply a recognised rank which Teucer did not actually hold.
a)riste/oin is probably right; but a)riste/wn (see cr. n.) would be tenable (cp. 237 du/o..kriou/s, El. 701du/o | *li/bues).

tou\s pro\s ai(/matos: cp. El. 1125h)\ fi/lwn tis h)\ pro\s ai(/matos (n.). Agamemnon had told Teucer to bring some free man to plead the cause of Ajax (1260 f.). Teucer asks, ‘Why should it dishonour Ajax to have his cause pleaded by the son of Telamon and Hesionè?’ For the allusive plur., cp. 734, 1092.
toioi=sd' e)n po/noisi keime/nous, ‘laid low (dead), amidst such troubles,’—i.e., self-slain, under circumstances of such horror. For keime/nous cp. Ant. 1174kai\ ti/s foneu/ei; ti/s d' o( kei/menos;
w)qei=s: cp. 1064 a)mfi\ xlwra\n ya/maqon e)kbeblhme/nos.

ou)d' e)paisxu/nei le/gwn, sc. o(/ti w)qei=s. Agamemnon had not expressly repeated the prohibition of burial, but the whole drift of his speech was to confirm the doom pronounced by Menelaüs. It seems strange, then, that le/gwn should have been so much suspected (cr. n.).—Cp. Ph. 929ou)d' e)paisxu/nei m' o(rw=n.
balei=te/ pou. Though poi would better bring out the notion of ‘casting forth,’ pou is also correct; cp. Ph. 481e)mbalou= m' o(/ph| qe/leis (not o(/poi, though ei)s a)ntli/an etc. follows).

xh(ma=s trei=s, Tecmessa, Eurysaces, and himself; all three are ready to perish in defence of the corpse. The child is still kneeling as a suppliant beside the body, and clinging to it (1180); his mother is near him. A scholiast in L understands the ‘three’ to be Agamemnon, Menelaüs, and Teucer— a theory which the word h(ma=s itself refutes. One of the later scholia, however, gives the right explanation.
sugkeime/nous, i.e. prostrate in death at his side (cp. 1306).

kalo/n moi, as in Ant. 72qa/yw: kalo/n moi tou=to poiou/sh| qanei=n.— u(perponoume/nw|: the only instance of this compound in the middle (as proponoume/nas in O. T. 685 is also unique). The active u(perponei=n occurs in O. C. 345.— prodh/lws: cp. 229 peri/fantos..qanei=tai. It is better to die in making a public protest against the wrong to Ajax, than to fall in battle for Helen's sake.

th=s sh=s … h)\ tou= sou= g' o(mai/monos le/gw; ‘thy wife—or should I rather (ge) say, thy brother's?’ Teucer speaks, with bitter scorn, as if he did not know or care to which of the brothers Helen belonged: at any rate, it is their war, and she is the pretext of it. Eustathius (p. 754. 21) thinks that this touch was suggested to Sophocles by the scornful phrases in which Achilles refers to the Atreidae, when he speaks of himself as a)ndra/si marna/menos o)a/rwn e(/neka sfetera/wn, ‘for their lady-loves' sakes,’—and asks, h)\ mou=noi file/ous' a)lo/xous mero/pwn a)nqrw/pwn | *)atrei=dai; Teucer speaks, at any rate, in the same vein. The words of Eustathius prove that he read th=s sh=s, and that he understood the text in the manner explained above: o( *sofoklh=s... poiei= to
 *teu=kron le/gonta tw=| *)agame/mnoni o(/ti o( *ai)/as dia\ th
