For h)\ … le/gw (subjunct.), cp. Aesch. Cho. 1073nu=n d' au)= tri/tos h)=lqe/ poqen swth/r, | h)\ mo/ron ei)/pw;
tou)mo/n, ‘my interest’: cp. El. 251to\ so\n speu/dous' a(/ma | kai\ tou)mo/n.
e)n e)moi/: cp. 1092 e)n qanou=sin u(bristh/s.

kairo\n, adv.: 34 f.—The sense of cuna/ywn here is shown by that of sullu/swn: i.e., the one means ‘to help in tying a knot’; the other, ‘to help in loosing it.’ ‘If thou hast come, not to make the tangle worse—not to embroil the feud—but to aid in solving it.’ suna/ptein is also said of bringing opponents into conflict; Suppl. 479 e)lpi\s brotoi=s ka/kiston, h(\ polla\s po/leis | cunh=ye: but here the metaphor is from a knot. Our word ‘embroil’ exactly fits suna/ptein here, since its primary sense is ‘to entangle’ or ‘perplex’ (embrouiller, imbrogliare). (The phrase in Ant. 40lu/ous' ..h)\ )fa/ptousa cannot properly be compared: see n. there.)
1318 f. The conciliatory temper of Odysseus is marked at once by the courteous form of address, a)/ndres,—by the honourable patronymic *)atreidw=n,—and by the designation of Ajax as a)/lkimos.
boh\n *)atreidw=n: he had first heard the voice of Menelaüs (who made his exit at v. 1160), and then, after an interval, that of Agamemnon.
ou) ga\r often introduces an indignant retort: Ant. 20*i*s. ti/ d' e)/sti; ... | *a*n. ou) ga\r ta/fou nw=|n, k.t.l. Cp. Ar. Ach. 576, Ar. Pl. 856, Vesp. 836.
klu/onte/s e)smen=klu/omen: cp. 1062 e)sti\.. sqe/nwn: 1324 drw=n..h)=n: 1330 ei)/hn..fronw=n.
a)rti/ws is joined with the present tense as in El. 347le/geis..a)rti/ws (‘you have just been saying’).

flau=ra. In phrases denoting censure or disparagement, writers of the classical age regularly use the form flau=ros, not fau=los: e.g., Her. 7. 10§ 7 flau/rws a)kou/ein: Nub. 834 kai\ mhde

sumbalei=n e)/ph kaka/, to pit taunts against taunts, like sumba/llein ma/xhn, e)/rin ( Eur. Med. 522), etc. Cp. Eur. I.A. 830ai)sxro\n de/ moi gunaici\ sumba/llein lo/gous.
kaka/, instead of repeating flau=ra: cp. 22 n.: O.C. 1501 safh\s me\n a)stw=n, e)mfanh\s de\ tou= ce/nou.

h)/kousen ai)sxra/: so Ph. 607o( pa/nt' a)kou/wn ai)sxra\ kai\ lwbh/t' e)/ph.— drw=n ga\r h)=n toiau=ta/ me: i.e., ai)sxra\ e)/lege/ me, since h)/kousen ai)sxra/ implies e)gw\ ai)sxra\ e)/legon au)to/n.

w(/ste kai\ bla/bhn e)/xein (se), so that you have actually been injured: cp. Aesch. Eum. 799w(s tau=t' *)ore/sthn drw=nta mh\ bla/bas e)/xein.—Not: ‘What has he done so bad that it is fraught with harm?’ (like Eur. Ion 1350e)/xei de/ moi ti/ ke/rdos h)\ ti/na bla/bhn;)
ou) fh/s' e)a/sein..a)lla\ … qa/yein: cp. Her. 7. 104ou)k e)w=n feu/gein.. a)lla\ me/nontas..e)pikrate/ein. So in O.T. 241 w)qei=n depends on au)dw= supplied from a)paudw= (veto) in 236.
tafh=s a)/moiron, without its due moi=ra of funeral rites. In Ant. 1071a)/moiros (without tafh=s) has this sense, the context sufficing to define it,— a)/moiron, a)kte/riston, a)no/sion ne/kun.

cunhretei=n is Lobeck's certain correction of the MS. reading, cunhretmei=n. The latter would be formed from an adj. cunh/retmos, which does not occur, but which would be like eu)h/retmos, etc. (e)retmo/n, oar). cunhretei=n is formed from cunhre/ths (e)re/ths, oarsman), a word recorded by Photius, who explains it by su/mfwnos, and compares a)nthre/ths ( Aesch. Theb. 283a)nthre/tas e)xqroi=si). In Eur. fr. 776. 3 (from Stobaeus Flor. 93. 2), a)=r' o)/lbos au)toi=s o(/ti tuflo\s sunhrefei=, Meineke restored sunhretei=. In Eur. fr. 282. 7 the best texts of Athenaeus (413 D) have ou)d' au)= pe/nesqai kai\ cunhretei=n tu/xais, though Schweighäuser, following Valckenär, gave cunhretmei=n: the true reading there, however, is found in Galen's quotation of the verse (vol. 1. p. 23), viz., ka)cuphretei=n. [Hesychius gives cunhreti/seis: sunh/seis. suzugh/seis. Lobeck proposed to read cunhreth/seis: but the interpretation by suzugh/seis seems rather to favour a conjecture (Ruhnken's?) mentioned in Alberti's ed. of Hesychius, vol. II. p. 707, cunarti/seis.]
For the metaphor, cp. Ant. 541cu/mploun (n.). In Aesch. Ag. 842 the king says of Odysseus, zeuxqei\s e(/toimos h)=n e)moi\ seirafo/ros.

h)= ga\r ei)/hn ou)k a)\n eu)= fronw=n, sc. ei) mh\ e)cei/h soi ei)pei=n. For the elliptical use of ou) ga/r, cp. O. T. 82, O. T. 318(and Append. to O. T., p. 221): I. Thuc. 11.§ 4 dh=lon de/ (sc. o(/ti ma/xh| e)kra/thsan): to\ ga\r e)/ruma..ou)k a)\n e)teixi/santo.—For the place of ou)k after ei)/hn, cp. 1140.
fi/lon … me/giston, as in Ph. 585ou(=tos de/ moi | fi/los me/gistos: El. 46me/gistos..doruce/nwn.
tlh=|s: cp. 411 e)/tlh, and 1384.
balei=n=probalei=n, as in 1308.

h( bi/a. The definite article indicates that bi/a is a half-personified agency, as nikhsa/tw also implies: ‘violence’ is here the impulse which may tempt a strong man to abuse his strength. A parallel to this use of h( bi/a occurs in a fragment of the tragic poet Moschion (fr. 6. v. 15 in Nauck Trag. Frag. p. 814), where he is describing the primitive life of mankind;—h)=n d' o( me\n no/mos | tapeino/s, h( bi/a de\ su/nqronos *dii+/.
patei=n: cp. Ant. 745tima/s ge ta\s qew=n patw=n.
e)/xqistos, ‘my worst foe,’— the active and passive senses being blended.
)kra/thsa: cp. 308 )qw/u+cen.
e)/mpas=o(/mws, as in 122, where kai/per is added to the participle.

a)ntatima/saim). The choice lies between this correction by Bothe of L's ou)k a)\n a)tima/saim), and Elmsley's ou)/ ta)\n a)tima/saim). The best reason for preferring a)ntatima/saim) is a palaeographical one, viz., that a change of *o*u*t*a*n into *o*u*k*a*n (T into K) is rather less probable than a loss of T in *o*u*k*a*n(*t)*a*t*i*m*a*s*a*i*m, seeing that a)tima/zw was a familiar word, while a)ntatima/zw was unfamiliar. There is no force in the objection that a)nt- in the compound is unfitting (since Ajax had not ‘dishonoured’ Odysseus); the reciprocity marked by a)nt- is simply that of overt hostility. As to the ou)/koun (or ou)k ou)=n) of the later MSS., it was evidently a makeshift, only less feeble than the Triclinian ou)k a)/n g).— a)ntatima/zw occurs nowhere else, but is formed like a)ntadikei=n.
e(/n' a)/ndr' … a)/riston: cp. Ph. 1344*(ellh/nwn e(/na | kriqe/nt' a)/riston. See also O. T. 1380(n.), O.C. 563 (n.).

plh\n *)axille/ws. The rank of heros ab Achille secundus (Hor. Sat. 2. 3. 193) is ascribed to Ajax in the Iliad (2. 768 f., 17. 279 f.), and by later poets; Alcaeus fr. 48 *ai)/an, to\n a)/riston pe/d' *)axi/llea: Pind. N. 7. 27kra/tiston *)axille/os a)/ter.

tou\s qew=n no/mous. The injury done will not be to the senseless clay, but rather to the ne/rteroi qeoi/, to whom the dead belong ( Ant. 1070), and to their unwritten laws, ‘which live for ever’ (ib. 456). Cp. 1129 f.

to
 e)sqlo
 a)/ndra is object to bla/ptein. Some take to
 e)sqlo
 as subject, and a)/ndra alone as object. But (a) the merit of the dead man comes into account here; cp. 1355: and (b) ou) di/kaion puts the precept on the broadest ground; it is not merely a point of honour for the e)sqlo/s.
ei) qa/noi: for the opt. in general statement, cp. 521 ei)..pa/qoi (n.).

tau=t), adverbial cognate acc. with u(permaxei=s: so O. T. 264a)nq' w(=n e)gw\ ta/d), w(sperei\ tou)mou= patro/s, | u(permaxou=mai (where ta/d) is the reading of the MSS., and tou=d) only a conjecture).
e)/gwg): cp. 104.
h(ni/k' h)=n misei=n kalo/n: i.e., while he was a living and a sane foe. Even before his death, the demented Ajax had won the pity of Odysseus (121).
ou) ga\r: cp. 1320.

prosembh=nai: pros- refers to e)mi/soun: ‘in addition to’—in continuation of—that former enmity. Cp. El. 456e)xqroi=sin au)tou= zw=nt' e)pembh=nai podi/. Aesch. Ag. 884w(/ste su/ggonon | brotoi=si to\n peso/nta lakti/sai ple/on. Sopater (in Walz Rhet. Graec. IV. 550) remarks that it is characteristic of Athenians, toi=s pro/teron h)dikhko/si keime/nois u(/steron mh\ e)pembai/nein: as Aristophanes says of himself (alluding to Cleon), kou)k' e)to/lmhs' au)=qis e)pemphdh=s' au)tw=| keime/nw|. So Plut. Flam. 21(speaking of Scipio's conduct towards Hannibal after Zama) ou)de\n e)peto/lmhsen, ou)d' e)pene/bh th=| tu/xh| tou= a)ndro/s.
*)atrei/dh is propitiatory (cp. 1319).

ke/rdesin toi=s mh\ kaloi=s. The ke/rdh meant are unworthy personal triumphs,—assertions of power which violate some higher law. It is in the same sense that Teiresias replies to Creon's taunt against the mantiko\n ge/nos,—to\ d' e)k tura/nnwn ai)sxroke/rdeian filei= ( Ant. 1056). Cp. Moschion fr. 7. 1 ti/ ke/rdos ou)ke/t' o)/ntas u(bri/zein nekrou/s;

to/n toi tu/rannon eu)sebei=n ou) r(a/|dion. This is the first symptom that Agamemnon's resolve has been shaken: he feels dimly that there is a conflict of duties. As a king, he must uphold the common weal, and punish treason (such as Ajax seemed guilty of). It is eu)sebe/s to do that. But what if, in doing so, he violates eu)se/beia on another side,—that represented by the qew=n no/moi of which Odysseus spoke (1343)? A somewhat similar utterance of Agamemnon, when perplexed by the demands upon him, occurs in fr. 481: ou) ga/r tis a)\n du/naito prw|ra/ths stratou= | toi=s pa=sin ei)=cai kai\ prosarke/sai xa/rin.

a)ll' eu)= le/gousi. If it is not easy for a king to see his course of duty clearly, he can at least pay regard to his friends, when they offer good advice; as Haemon says to Creon, kai\ tw=n lego/ntwn eu)= kalo\n to\ manqa/nein ( Ant. 723).
tima\s ne/mein: for the plur., cp. El. 355tw=| teqnhko/ti | tima\s prosa/ptein (where the sense is simply ‘to honour,’ not, ‘to render rites’).

klu/ein to
 e)sqlo
 a)/ndra: i.e. ‘An e)sqlo\s a)nh/r, such as thou art, ought to defer to his king, instead of seeking to overrule him.’ The words seem also to glance at the alleged disloyalty of Ajax. Cp. Ant. 666a)ll' o(
 po/lis sth/seie, tou=de xrh\ klu/ein. Ph. 925tw=n ga e)n te/lei klu/ein | to/ t' e)/ndiko/n me kai\ to\ sumfe/ron poei=.—For tw=n e)n te/lei, see Ant. 67 n.

pau=sai is said in a gentle and kindly tone; ‘Be content; you have the best of it,—it is your own true interest that prevails,—when you allow yourself to be overruled by a prudent friend.’ Cp. 330, 484: Aesch. Ag. 941*k*l. toi=s d' o)lbi/ois ge kai\ to\ nika=sqai pre/pei. | *a*g. h)= kai\ su\ ni/khn th/nde dh/rios ti/eis; | *k*l. piqou=: kratei=s me/ntoi parei\s e(kw
 e)moi/ [vulg. kra/tos..pa/res g)]. Isocr. or. 9 § 44 polla\ me
 tw=n xrwme/nwn h(ttw/menos (often yielding to his familiar friends), pa/nta de\ tw=n e)xqrw=n perigigno/menos.— tw=n fi/lwn: for the gen., cp. Eur. Med. 315kreisso/nwn nikw/menoi: Nub. 1087 h)
 tou=to nikhqh=|s e)mou=.
pote/ refers to e)xqro\s as well as gennai=os. The feud dated, indeed, only from the o(/plwn kri/sis (1337): but pote/ means merely, ‘in his lifetime.’
e)xqro\n w(=d' ai)dei= ne/kun; Agamemnon's case is now hopeless; he has allowed Odysseus to narrow the argument down to a personal question,—just as Teucer did with Menelaüs (1134 n.).

nika=| ga\r: ‘Yes, for with me his worth is far more potent—weighs far more—than his enmity.’ th=s e)/xqras is a genitive of comparison, depending on the notion of superiority contained in nika=|: =h( a)reth\ polu\ krei/sswn e)sti/ moi th=s e)/xqras. There is no parallel for such a genitive after nika=|: but it is quite intelligible, and seems not too bold for the poet's style. (Eustathius p. 842. 10 takes th=s e)/xqras as depending on polu/:—kainw=s to\ polu\ a)nti\ tou= ple/on lhfqe/n.)

It is very improbable that the text is corrupt. The context in verses 1355 f. at once proves that the words a(reth/ and e)/xqras are genuine; and the article before a)reth/ confirms th=s. As nika=| also is presumably sound, the fault, if any, would have to be sought in polu/, for which neither ple/on nor pa/ros is a tolerable substitute; or else in me. Now in a reply to the question, e)xqro\n w(=d' ai)dei= ne/kun; we should expect some reference by Odysseus to his own feeling; and v. 1358 (toioi/de me/ntoi fw=tes k.t.l.) further indicates that in the preceding verse he actually did refer to himself. Hence the only correction of me which would solve the difficulty of the genitive, viz. ta\, is unsatisfactory.

toioi/de..fw=tes … brotw=n: ‘such men, however, are the unstable of mankind’;—such, namely, as relent like Odysseus. brotw=n, L's reading, is strongly confirmed by the exactly similar pleonasm in O. C. 280 f., fugh\n de/ tou | mh/pw gene/sqai fwto\s a)nosi/ou brotw=n. Cp. also Od. 17. 587ou) ga/r pw/ tines w(=de kataqnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn | a)ne/res k.t.l.: 23. 187 a)ndrw=n d' ou)/ ke/n tis zwo\s broto/s. The v.l. brotoi=s would be an ethic dat., ‘in men's judgment’ (cp. 1363). It has more point than its rival: but this seems a case in which a tenable reading, with the stronger evidence on its side, should be preferred to a more attractive variant.

e)/mplhktoi (from e)mplh/ssw, to ‘rush’ or ‘dash’ in), ‘impulsive,’ with the notion of ‘inconstant’: Eur. Tro. 1205(ai( tu/xai) e)/mplhktos w(s a)/nqrwpos, a)/llot' a)/llose | phdw=si. Lys. 214 C mhde/pote o(moi/ous mhd' au)tou\s au(toi=s ei)=nai, a)ll' e)mplh/ktous te kai\ a)staqmh/tous. Eumenes 3 e)/mplhkton o)/nta kai\ fora=s mesto\n a)bebai/ou kai\ o)cei/as.
kau)=qis: au)=qis=‘afterwards,’ as in Tr. 270, Ant. 1204.
pikroi/, infensi: Aesch. Cho. 234tou\s filta/tous ga\r oi)=da nw=|n o)/ntas pikrou/s. Cp. O.C. 615 ta\ terpna\ pikra\ gi/gnetai kau)=qis fi/la: and above, 679 ff.

Odysseus is here replying to the taunt that he is e)/mplhktos, inconstant. ‘It is common enough for friendship to turn into bitterness. When, therefore, I forget the later enmity of Ajax, and remember only his good service, I am merely condoning a very ordinary change.’ There is also a gentle hint that Agamemnon, who had professed so much fili/a (1331), is becoming a little pikro/s.
toiou/sd). Agamemnon retorts: ‘Do you recommend, then, friends who change as Ajax did?’—e)painw= with inf., as in El. 1322, O. C. 664 f.
e)painei=n: Odysseus borrows the other's word only in order to parry his question.
sklhra\n … yuxh\n: this phrase denotes the stubborn fortitude of Heracles in Tr. 1260(n.).
deilou\s … fanei=s, make us appear so to men. Cp. 1020 fanei/s (n.).
th=|de qh(me/ra|: 756 n. He is now ready to yield, and hesitates only from fear of public opinion.
me\n ou)=n, immo: O. T. 705.
*(ellhsi, ethic dat.: 1282 (n.).

e)nqa/d) i(/comai, sc. to\ qa/ptesqai. Cp. O. T. 1158a)ll' ei)s to/d' h(/ceis, sc. ei)s to\ o)le/sqai. Eur. H. F. 1356e)s tou=q' i(ke/sqai, da/kru) a)p' o)mma/twn balei=n. Here e)nqa/de=e)kei=se: cp. Soph. Ph. 304ou)k e)nqa/d' oi( ploi= (=deu=ro).

h)= pa/nq' o(/moia. Many editors place a colon after o(/moia, explaining the phrase as a proverb: ‘It is always so: every man works for himself.’ One of the later scholia gives this view: o)/ntws pa/nta ta\ a)nqrw/pina o(/moia: pa=s ga\r a)/nqrwpos th\n e(autou= pragmateu/etai swthri/an. (Cp. Terence Phormio 264 ecce autem similia omnia: omnes congruont etc.) This may be right; but the somewhat homely proverb seems rather too abrupt here for Sophocles. I still prefer the simpler view that o(/moia is adverbial: ‘in all things alike every man works for himself.’ Even in the matter of giving burial to another man a selfish motive enters. For au(tw=| as dat. of interest with ponei=, cp. H.F. 388 *mukhnai/w| ponw=n tura/nnw|.—Some understand, ‘every man does deeds like himself,’—works in his characteristic way,—meaning that Odysseus is, as usual, fi/lautos. This seems too artificial.

tw=| ga/r me ma=llon k.t.l. Odysseus frankly accepts the imputation of selfishness, which helps his cause by making the favour seem done to him. Cp. Ant. 736a)/llw| ga\r h)\ )moi\ xrh/ me th=sd' a)/rxein xqono/s;
so\n appears better than so/n g) here: the so\n ga\r a)/ra in a few of the inferior MSS. was probably a conjectural attempt to restore the metre, when a)=ra had become a)/ra.

w(s a)
 poh/sh|s, i.e., whether you make the deed your own, or merely consent to others doing it. For w(s a)
, ‘in whatever way,’ cp. Legg. 881 D kolazo/ntwn au)to
..w(s a)
 e)qe/lwsi: Symp. 181A e)n th=| pra/cei, w(s a)
 praxqh=|, toiou=to a)pe/bh: Crat. 424E w(s a)/n, oi)=mai, dokh=| e(ka/sth h( ei)kw
 dei=sqai e(ka/stou farma/kou. Apoll. Rhod. 2. 345 kai\ ta\ me
 w(/s ke pe/lh|, tw\s e)/ssetai. Elsewhere in Sophocles w(s a)/n=‘in order that’: 655; O. T. 329; O.C. 72; Ant. 215; Ph. 129, Ph. 826; fr. 816; fr. 1019. 11.
pantaxh=|, ‘in every case’: cp. 1241; Ant. 634pantaxh=| drw=ntes, ‘however we act’ (n.).
xrhsto/s g), good and kind, at least,—even if only passive in the matter.

a)ll' eu)= ge me/ntoi. Here a)lla/ =‘well,’ me/ntoi=‘however,’ and ge emphasises eu)=. Cp. Tr. 1107a)ll' eu)= ge/ toi to/d' i)/ste. We find a)lla\..me/ntoi in Ph. 524.The combination ge me/ntoi is frequent ( O. T. 442 n.).

ka)kei= ka)nqa/d' w)
, in the shades, as upon earth: for e)kei=, cp. 855 (n.). Ant. 75(plei/wn xro/nos) o(
 dei= m' a)re/skein toi=s ka/tw tw=n e)nqa/de. For the parataxis (= ‘there, as he was here’), cp. Ar. Ran. 82o( d' eu)/kolos me
 e)nqa/d' eu)/kolos d' e)kei=.

xrh=|s. For xrh=|, xrh=|s, see on Ant. 887ei)/te xrh=| qanei=n | ei)/t' e)n toiau/th| zw=sa tumbeu/ein ste/gh| (where zw=sa excludes xrh/). Here, as in El. 606kh/russe/ m' ei)s a(/pantas, ei)/te xrh=|s kakh/n, xrh/ is not impossible, but is so much less suitable than xrh=|s that the latter may be considered certain.

ta)po\ tou=d)=to\ a)po\ tou=de: so Thuc. 2. 15§ 2 to\..pro\ tou/tou (‘formerly’): Plat. Gorg. 512 E to\ e)pi\ tou/tw| (‘next’).— a)gge/llomai (midd.)...ei)=nai fi/los, announce that I am ready to be a friend. This use of the simple verb does not occur elsewhere; but cp. Eur. Heracl. 531 ka)cagge/llomai | qnh/|skein, ‘offer to die.’ In O. T. 148 e)cagge/lletai (with acc.)=to offer a thing spontaneously. The ordinary word in this sense was e)pagge/llomai.— to/t), olim: 650 n.
h)=, the older Attic form (for e)/a): O. T. 1123.
cumponei=n, in preparing and conducting the obsequies.

mhde
 e)llei/pein o(/swn=mhde
 tou/twn, o(/sa: for e)llei/pw with acc., cp. Plat. Politicus 269 C le/ge mhde
 e)llei/pwn: Xen. Cyr. I. 2. 14 h)/n tis..e)lli/ph| ti tw=n nomi/mwn. (mhde
 could also be adv., ‘in nothing,’ as in 115 fei/dou mhde
 w(=nper e)nnoei=s, since e)llei/pein with gen. could mean, ‘to fall short in’; but that constr. is less fitting in this context.)—The reading of the MSS., o(/son, is clearly an error; the plural number is needed here. Cp. Ant. 196 ta\ pa/nt' e)fagni/sai | a(\ toi=s a)ri/stois e)/rxetai ka/tw nekroi=s.
a)/rist): the first word marks his gratitude. (Nauck, however, would change it to a)/nac.)

lo/goisi, causal dat., ‘for thy words.’ Cp. Tr. 1127 ou) dh=ta (sc. siga=n pre/pei) toi=s ge pro/sqen h(marthme/nois, ‘in view of her past crimes.’ Thuc. 3. 98 § 5 toi=s pepragme/nois fobou/menos tou\s *)aqhnai/ous (on account of what had occurred).—The objection to taking lo/goisi as =‘in my words’ is that the implied reservation (e)/rgois de/ se tima=n ou)k e)/xw) would be premature and ungraceful here. It would foreshadow the exclusion of Odysseus from an active part in the funeral rites (1394).

e)/yeusas e)lpi/dos, cheated me of (agreeably disappointed me in) my foreboding: cp. O. T. 1432 e)lpi/dos m' a)pe/spasas (n.), where, as here, e)lpi\s is a dark presentiment. Xen. H. 7. 5. 24 ou)k e)yeu/sqh th=s e)lpi/dos.

pare/sths xersi/n: schol. sunema/xhsas e)/rgw|, ou) lo/gw|. He has given active help by coming to the spot, and withstanding the resolve of the Atreidae. The peculiarity consists in the figurative sense of xersi/n (=‘effectually’): but to a Greek the word would at once suggest e)/rgois, as opp. to lo/gois.
parw\n, in the presence of the dead: cp. 1156 n.
qano/nti … e)fubri/sai: the dat. as with e)peggela=n: Soph. Ph. 180pou= d' o(\s ta\ deina\ th=|d' e)fubri/zei po/lei.
zw=n: for the antithesis with qano/nti, cp. Tr. 1163zw=nta/ m' e)/kteinen qanw/n.

w(s … h)qelhsa/thn, instead of w(s..e)/tlhsan, e)qe/lontes. Such compression is frequent, esp. after ou)x w(/sper: e.g. Plat. Gorg. 522A peinh=n kai\ diyh=n a)nagka/zwn, ou)x w(/sper e)gw\ polla\ kai\ h(de/a kai\ pantodapa\ eu)w/xoun u(ma=s: Plat. Symp. 179E e)poi/hsan to
 qa/naton au)tou= u(po\ gunaikw=n gene/sqai, ou)x w(/sper *)axille/a to
 th=s *qe/tidos ui(o
 e)ti/mhsan.

ou(pibro/nthtos, crazy with arrogance (cp. 1225 skaio\n). Dem. or. 19 § 231 (h(gou=nto) e)mbebronth=sqai, they thought him crazed: id. or. 18 § 243 e)mbro/nthte, e<*>=ta nu=n le/geis; Ar. Eccl. 793w)mbro/nthte su/. Xen. An. 3. 4. 12(of a besieged city) *zeu\s de\ e)mbronth/tous poiei= tou\s e)noikou=ntas, kai\ ou(/tws e(a/lw. P.V. 361 (of Typhon) fre/nas ga\r ei)s au)ta\s tupei\s | e)feyalw/qh ka)cebronth/qh sqe/nos. (The form e)pibro/nthtos occurs only here.)

molw\n, though a dual verb follows: cp. Eur. Alc. 734e)/rrwn (so schol., e)/rrois vulg.) nun au)to\s xh( sunoikh/sasa/ soi | ... ghra/skete: Xen. An. 7. 1. 40proselqw\n de\ *timasi/wn..kai\ *ne/wn..e)/legon.
au)to/s te xw( cu/naimos: this redundant au)to/s te often occurs when the mention of the other person or persons is an afterthought: O.C. 462 au)to/s te pai=de/s q' ai(/de (n.).
*)olu/mpou tou=d): cp. O.C. 1654 gh=n te proskunou=nq' a(/ma | kai\ to\n qew=n *)/olumpon: Ant. 758to/nd' *)/olumpon (‘by the heaven above us’).
presbeu/wn: cp. fr. 248 (*)/inaxe) me/ga presbeu/wn | *)/argous te gu/ais *(/hras te pa/gois.
mnh/mwn: so P.V. 516 mnh/mone/s t' *)erinu/es: Eum. 381eu)mh/xanoi/ te kai\ te/leioi kakw=n | te mnh/mones *semnai/.
*di/kh the avenger is here associated with the Erinys, as in Tr. 808w(=n se poi/nimos *di/kh | tei/sait' *)erinu/s t), and Aesch. Ag. 1432 f.
telesfo/ros, the epithet of *moi=ra in P.V. 511.
kakou\s kakw=s: 1177 n.— to\n a)/ndra. It seems needless to write to/nd), since a reference to Ajax has just preceded (v. 1388 au)to/n).
lw/bais, a modal dat. like fonai=s in Ant. 1003.
*lae/rtou: cp. 1 *larti/ou (n.). The mode of address is honorific, like *)atrei/dh in 1349.

ta/fou … e)piyau/ein. Odysseus cannot be allowed to touch the body, or to assist in carrying it to the grave, or to join in pouring the xoai/ at the time of interment. It is this intimate participation which is poetically expressed by the phrase ta/fou e)piyau/ein. (Morstadt wished to read nekrou= instead of ta/fou, but this would unduly narrow the sense.)

On the other hand, Odysseus is at liberty to assist in protecting the funeral from interruption by the Greek army. He may be a spectator of the rites, though not a participator; and he may bring with him (komi/zein) any one he pleases. This is what seems to be meant by ta\ d' a)/lla kai\ cu/mprasse: where it should be noted that kai\ is not ‘both’ (as if answering to the kai\ in kei)/ tina stratou=), but emphasises the verb,—‘in all else do cooperate’—as you wish to do. That is, cu/mprasse alludes to the request of Odysseus in 1378 f., sunqa/ptein..kai\ cumponei=n, and must therefore refer, in part at least, to something connected with the obsequies —not solely to friendly offices of a different kind, such as care for Tecmessa and Eurysaces; though it may include these.

mh\ tw=| qano/nti k.t.l. It might be unpleasing to the spirit of the dead if Odysseus were allowed to touch the body, or to have any active part in the rites. So in El. 442 ff. the spirit of Agamemnon is conceived as refusing Clytaemnestra's xoai/ at his grave; and in the same play, when (1123) Electra is allowed to handle the funeral urn, the pretended Phocian justifies the boon by saying that she is evidently not dusmenh\s to the dead. The wrath of Ajax against Odysseus was conceived as enduring in the world below: oi)/h d' *ai)/antos yuxh\ *telamwnia/dao | no/sfin a)festh/kei ( Od. 11. 543)—when Odysseus approached.
ta)/lla pa/nta: all that pertains to the funeral rites (including the preparations described in vv. 1402 ff.). The phrase is purposely brief and vague, to avoid a second mention of the ta/fos.
kaq' h(ma=s, in regard to us; Her. 7. 158to/ te kat' u(me/as (‘as far as you are concerned’): Eur. Andr. 740ka)\n..to\ loipo\n h)=| | sw/frwn kaq' h(ma=s, sw/fron' a)ntilh/yetai.

a)ll' h)/qelon me/n: sc. e)cei=nai/ moi sunqa/ptein. This impf. (without a)/n) states a wish which has not been fulfilled; i.e., a wish that something were now true which is not true. It is usually joined with me/n (implying the contrast with the actual fact): so Ar. Ran. 866e)boulo/mhn me
 ou)k e)ri/zein e)nqa/de (‘I would that I were not contending here—as I am’): Andoc. or. 5 § 1 e)boulo/mhn me/n, w)= a)/ndres, th
 du/namin tou= le/gein..e)ci)/sou moi kaqesta/nai th=|..sumfora=|: Isae. or. 10 § 1 e)boulo/mhn me/n, w)= a)/ndres,..ta)lhqh= pro\s u(ma=s..ei)pei=n dunhqh=nai: Aeschin. or. 3 § 2 e)boulo/mhn me
 ou)=n, w)= *)aqhnai=oi, kai\ th
 boulh
..o)rqw=s dioikei=sqai. So ma/lista me
 e)boulo/mhn, Isae. fr. 4 (Scheibe). This usage is analogous to that of the impers. e)/dei, xrh=n, etc., with inf. ( O. T. 256 n.). On the other hand, h)/qelon a)/n (88 n.), e)boulo/mhn a)/n, with inf., means that the wish would have been (or would now be) formed, if it had not been (or were not now) vain to form it.

e)paine/sas: cp. Ar. Av. 1616e)painei= xou(=tos (‘assents’): Thuc. 4. 65§ 2 e)painesa/ntwn de\ au)tw=n e)poiou=nto th\n o(mologi/an. So ai)nei=n in poetry, as Aesch. Eum. 469pra/cas ga\r e)n soi\ pantaxh=| ta/d' ai)ne/sw.
to\ so/n: cp. 99 w(s to\ so\n cunh=k e)gw/ (‘thy saying’).

a(/lis: h)/dh ga\r k.t.l. During his brief absence from the scene (vv. 1185—1222), Teucer has fulfilled the charge given by the Chorus (1165), and has chosen the spot where Ajax is to be buried. He now directs some of the Salaminian sailors to go and dig the grave; others are to place the tripod near it; a third detachment is to bring thither the hero's armour from the tent. Tecmessa and Eurysaces are still kneeling beside the corpse (1171 ff.). Verses 1409 ff. mark the moment when the body is lifted from the ground. Then it is borne forth (probably by Teucer and one or more pro/spoloi), the Chorus following, before they separate to their several tasks.

polu\s e)kte/tatai xro/nos, the delay caused by the Atreidae. Cp. Suppl. 1109 e)ktei/nein bi/on: Ion 625ai)w=na tei/nei. ( Itis difficult to comprehend why the phrase xro/nos e)kte/tatai should be thought suspicious, as by Morstadt and Nauck: the former proposed lo/gos.)

a)ll' oi( me\n k.t.l. The threefold command (oi( me\n—toi\ d)—mi/a d)..a)ndrw=n i)/lh) may have been the signal for some corresponding movement on the part of the Chorus; perhaps for the usual change from the formation in three ranks (kata\ zuga/), facing the actors, to that in three files (kata\ stoi/xous), preparatory to the final exit. Wecklein thinks that the three divisions of the Chorus made separate exits (right, left, and in front of the spectators). This seems less probable, as the closing scene would be more effective if the whole Chorus went out in procession after the body of Ajax.
ka/peton: 1165 n.

taxu/nete has better MS. authority than taxu/nate. The latter may, indeed, have been read by the scholiast (meta\ spoudh=s o)ru/cate); but it can derive no support from qe/sqe (1406), since the process of digging is fitly expressed by the pres. imper., while the aor. imper. better suits the act of placing. taxu/nw is not elsewhere transitive.

toi\ d). The Doric (and Homeric) toi\ occurs in tragic lyrics ( Aesch. Pers. 584 etc.), and once in a trimeter, Aesch. Pers. 424toi\ d' w(/ste qu/nnous k.t.l., where it is a trait of epic style in the narrative. Sophocles uses it only here. The v.l. to\n d) is not only weaker, but untenable, since a pronoun is needed which shall answer to oi( me/n: the loutra/ are to be prepared while the grave is being dug.

u(yi/baton tri/pod), the caldron, supported on a high three-legged stand. (Cp. Pind. N. 10. 47*)axaiw=n u(yi/batoi po/lies, built on lofty sites.) The stand was the tri/pous proper, while the caldron was le/bhs, but the former term is often used so as to include the latter: Aesch. fr. 1 to
 me
 tri/pous e)de/cat), oi)kei=os le/bhs, | ai)ei\ fula/sswn th
 u(pe puro\s sta/sin. The fire was kindled in a brazier under the le/bhs, as may be seen on a vase in the British Museum, which represents Medea boiling a ram in a lebes or xu/tra (Smith's Dict. Ant., new ed., vol. I. p. 426).

a)mfi/puron … qe/sqe, place it so that the fire shall rise all round it from beneath: cp. Il. 18. 344a)mfi\ puri\ sth=sai tri/poda me/gan, and ib. 348 ga/strhn me\n tri/podos pu=r a)/mfepe. Il. 23. 702tri/pod' e)mpuribh/thn.
loutrw=n … e)pi/kairon: a genitive of relation; cp. Xen. Cyr. 4. 6. 9ga/mou h)/dh w(rai/a. So oi)kei=os or a)llo/trio/s tinos.

o(si/wn, i.e., prescribed by piety ( El. 433 n.). Cp. Ant. 1201lou/santes a(gno\n loutro/n: and ib. 901 (n.). The caldron used for this purpose is called loetroxo/os tri/pous in Il. 18. 346.After the washing of the dead, unguents were usually applied (as in the case of Patroclus, Il. 18. 350). Verg. Aen. 6. 218Pars calidos latices et aëna undantia flammis | Expediunt, corpusque lavant frigentis et ungunt.

i)/lh, band, troop, from rt. vel, ei)/lw, to press: cp. o(/m-ilo-s (Curt. Etym. § 660). The Ionic form is ei)/lh ( Her. 1. 73 etc.). Its poetical use is as free as that of Lat. manus (e.g., Pind. N. 5. 38eu)/frones i)=lai): but it had also a technical military sense, Xen. An. 1. 2. 16kat' i)/las kai\ kata\ ta/ceis (‘troops’ of cavalry and ‘companies’ of infantry).— to\n u(paspi/dion ko/smon, the armour ‘under the shield,’ i.e. the body-armour, as the qw/rac and the knhmi=des. Ajax had directed that all his armour except his shield should be buried with him (577). u(paspi/dios occurs only here and in [Eur. ] Rhes. 740 to\n u(paspi/dion koi=ton.

pai=, su\ de\ patro/s g): for su\ de/ after the vocative, cp. O. T. 1097, El. 150: for the combination de/..ge, O. T. 1030(n.). The emphasis of ge belongs here to the whole clause (‘do thou, too, raise’), and not to the word patro/s. For other instances, in which the stress of ge does not fall on the word next before it, but on a whole phrase or clause, see Ant. 213, Ant. 648, Ant. 747; O. C. 1278; El. 1506.— pleura\s: Elmsley (on Eur. Heracl. 824) held that the fem. plur. pleurai\ was not used in tragedy: here he wished to read pleura\ (dual), or pleura/n. But, as Hermann observed, this view would involve some very improbable changes; e.g., in I. T. 298 pai/ei sidh/rw| lago/nas, ei)s pleura\s i(ei/s (where Elmsley suggested lago/nas ei)s me/sas).

e)/ti ga\r qermai\ k.t.l. In vv. 918 f. blood was said to be issuing from his nostrils, and from the wound. There, in the phrase fusw=nt' a)/nw pro\s r(i=nas, the context shows that a)/nw means ‘upward (from the lower part of the body) to the nostrils.’ Here, however, a)/nw seems to have a more general sense,—‘upward to the surface’ (whether through the nostrils, or from the mouth of the wound). As Ajax must now have been dead for about an hour, the thing described seems impossible.

su/rigges, a vague term (=‘channels’), seems to mean fle/bes, a word which down to the time of Aristotle (and later) denoted arteries as well as veins;—a)rthri/ai meaning the bronchial tubes. (See Append. on Tr. 1054.) Now in Empedocles 344 su/rigges certainly mean air-passages; w(=de d' a)napnei= pa/nta kai\ e)kpnei=: pa=si li/faimoi | sarkw=n su/rigges pu/maton kata\ sw=ma te/tantai,—where the epithet ‘bloodless’ points to the reason why the ancients took the arteries for air-passages,—viz. because, after death, they were found empty, while the veins were filled with blood returning from the heart. But here Sophocles cannot have meant by su/rigges the bronchial tubes; the epithet qermai/ clearly points to fle/bes. In Apoll. Rhod. 4. 1647 su=rigc ai(mato/essa kata\ sfuro/n means ‘a vein.’ Another explanation of su/rigges, viz. the ‘nostrils,’ may be rejected. Aristotle uses su/rigges for the pores of the lungs: ai)/tion tou= a)napnei=n o( pneu/mwn somfo\s w)\n (‘porous’) kai\ suri/ggwn plh/rhs, De respir. 15 (p. 478 a 13).
me/lan me/nos: cp. Aesch. Ag. 1067pri\n ai(mathro\n e)cafri/zesqai me/nos.
fhsi\: i.e., if he says that he is a friend, let him now prove it.
sou/sqw: for the form, see on Tr. 645sou=tai.— ba/tw: of this 2nd aor. imperat. we find also e)/mba_ ( Eur. El. 113), kata/ba_ ( Vesp. 979), ba=qi ( Soph. Ph. 1196), ba=te ( Soph. O. C. 1547).
pa/nt' a)gaqw=|: cp. 910 o( pa/nta kwfo/s.

kou)deni/ pw lw/|oni qnhtw=n. If the text is sound, we must supply ponh/sas, as pw indicates: lit., ‘toiling for this heroic man, and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier.’ This is a harsh kind of compression; but, as the general sense is so clear, it might be tolerated. The phrase cannot be explained by ‘attraction,’ as if pa/nt' a)gaqw=|, kou)deni/ pw lw/|oni qnhtw=n, could mean, pa/nt' a)gaqw=|, kai\ ou(= ou)dei/s pw lw/|wn h)=n qnhtw=n. Blaydes writes, kou)deno\s ou) lw/|oni qnhtw=n. As to metre, the verse is a correct paroemiac, i.e., an anapaestic dimeter short of one syllable (‘catalectic’); the only peculiarity is the dactyl in the first foot, which in that place of a paroemiac is less usual than a spondee or an anapaest.

[*ai)/antos, o(/t' h)=n, to/te fwnw=.] Either this verse is spurious (as is now generally thought), or else both it and verse 1416 are corrupt. If v. 1416 is a paroemiac, it cannot be followed by a paroemiac. If, then, v. 1417 is to be retained, v. 1416 must be made into an anapaestic dimeter. Further, v. 1417, as it stands, yields no satisfactory sense. It must be taken in one of two ways: (1) by itself, a colon or stop being placed after qnhtw=n:—‘I speak of Ajax, in the days when he lived’: for the genitive, cp. 1236. Or (2) in connexion with v. 1416, a colon being placed after *ai)/antos, but no point after qnhtw=n:—‘and never yet (having toiled) for a worthier man than Ajax;—I speak of the time when he lived.’ (Cp. Meleager epigr. 22 h)=n kalo\s *(hra/kleitos, o(/t' h)=n pote.) The interpolation of v. 1417 may have been prompted by the comparative lw/|oni, and by a wish to find the name of the hero at the close of the play. No emendation yet proposed is probable: see Appendix.
i)dou=sin, by experience: cp. El. 205tou\s e)mo\s i)/de path\r | qana/tous.
ma/ntis: Ant. 1160kai\ ma/ntis ou)dei\s tw=n kaqestw/twn brotoi=s.

o(/ ti pra/cei, how he (himself) will fare: fr. 531
tou=to kateido/tas w(s ou)k e)/stin
plh\n *dio\s ou)dei\s tw=n mello/ntwn
tami/as o(/ ti xrh\ tetele/sqai (verses which probably closed the poet's Tereus).
